HEADLINE: Eastern Airlines Is Shutting Down And Plans to Liquidate Its Assets

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Eastern Airlines, a fixture in United States aviation since 1928 and the nation's eighth-largest airline, announced that it had stopped flying last night and would begin to sell off its planes and other assets.
The airline, which had been struggling for almost two years to rebuild under the protection of the bankruptcy court, is by far the largest casualty of the pressures brought by the deregulation of the industry 13 years ago. 
 About 5,000 of Eastern's 18,000 workers are expected to be dismissed immediately. The others will work a while longer to run ground operations, including the maintenance of Eastern's 190 planes while buyers are sought. Many of Eastern's workers live in the New York, Atlanta and Miami areas, where the carrier has its biggest operations.
 
Employees Told to Stay Home
 The airline said in a statement announcing the midnight shutdown that Eastern employees should not report to work unless otherwise notified by their supervisor. An exception, Eastern said, were reservation agents, who should come in at their usual time.
The carrier said all passengers holding tickets purchased for flights scheduled after it stopped flying would be given a full refund. Eastern said it was also working to set up ways for other carriers to honor its tickets.
Before the airline's announcement, most big airlines declined to comment on whether they would accept Eastern tickets, but American Airlines, referring to rumors, said it would honor all Eastern tickets subject to seat availability.
Ticket holders are to be reimbursed from a $50 million fund set up as part of Eastern's bankruptcy proceedings under Burton R. Lifland, the bankruptcy court judge who has overseen the airline's attempt to reorganize.
The airline's agents kept taking reservations into the early evening without telling callers that the airline would shut down. At about 7 P.M. six ticket agents behind the desk in Miami reassured passengers that the airline would continue to fly and that there was no reason to switch to another carrier.
A familiar face to residents of the East Coast, where most of the carrier's routes lie, Eastern was a ticket to the Florida and Caribbean sun in winter. Built by the World War I ace Eddie Rickenbacker, it was the first large airline to ply the north-south routes along the Eastern seaboard. Its innovations included shuttle flights between New York and Washington, begun in the early 1960's, and later the added run between Boston and New York. The shuttle operation was sold to the developer and casino owner Donald J. Trump.
 
 Response to Deregulation
 Many industry analysts attributed the airline's initial problems to a poor response by management to the competitive pressures brought by deregulation after 1978, and to bad luck, with low-fare carriers like People Express expanding over much of its route system.
Eastern filed for protection from its creditors on March 9, 1989, after a strike by the machinists' union five days earlier crippled its operations. The feeling of the strikers remains so strong that several members of the union, which is still on strike, hailed the shutdown as a victory while they picketed at La Guardia Airport in New York last night .
The airline's attempt to rebuild was marred by the weakening economy and since the invasion of Kuwait last summer, by the steep rise in jet-fuel prices. All carriers have been hurt by these factors; indeed, Pan American World Airways filed for bankruptcy-court protection earlier this month, and Continental Airlines did so last month.
Eastern's decision to shut down was made at headquarters in Miami. Martin R. Shugrue, the trustee appointed to run the airline by the court, presided over the meeting, said someone who talked with Eastern's management. Only two months ago, Mr. Shugrue had argued that the airline could be turned around by March and persuaded Judge Lifland to release another $120 million from an escrow fund meant for the unsecured creditors. But yesterday, he had run out of cash.
 
 Unsecured Creditors
 The airline's unsecured creditors had argued that despite an energetic attempt to revive the airline after Mr. Shugrue took over in April, it was evident by November that its losses could not be stemmed. They urged Judge Lifland to shut down the carrier then and begin liquidating the assets while the airline still had cash to help repay them. The unsecured creditors include the aircraft makers Airbus Industrie and Boeing, the engine makers General Electric and Pratt & Whitney, banks, and the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, which has claims because Eastern's pension are not adequately financed. The unsecured creditors are owed about $1.4 billion.
Early in the bankruptcy, when Frank Lorenzo, who was chairman of the Texas Air Corporation at the time, was still in control of Eastern, he was fond of reciting the value of Eastern's assets and saying that creditors could expect to be repaid in full. Now, after losses that totaled more than $1.5 billion since the strike began, it is uncertain whether the unsecured creditors will get anything at all.
 
 Valuable Assets
 One person involved in the bankruptcy said there is definite interest by Delta Air Lines and United Airlines. American Airlines already moved to obtain emergency permission to operate from Miami to Toronto and from New York to Montreal.
The person, who insisted on remaining anonymous, said that only after the carrier was liquidated would it be known whether the unsecured creditors would get any money.
The unsecured creditors in the last year have become increasingly disillusioned by attempts to revive the airline as money meant for them was turned over by the court to offset huge losses.
Even the secured creditors, mostly bondholders that hold assets like planes as collateral, are worried that they can not be sold for enough to pay them off in full.
 
 
Planes Are Less Valuable
 At one point, even Eastern's older planes, like its Boeing 727-200's, were considered valuable for resale. But the huge increase in the cost of fuel and a weakening economy that has reduced demand for such planes have brought down their value.
A liquidation will also have effects on the economies of New York, Atlanta and Miami, where thousands of employees work for Eastern.
Eastern still maintains a large operation at La Guardia; its flights at Newark International Airport have been cut back substantially.
E. J. Breen, an Eastern Airlines co-pilot who was chairman of the strike committee of the pilots's union, expressed sorrow at news of a shutdown. "The first reaction is, it's something we understood would happen," he said. "But now that it has, it's like the loss of a loved one."
The pilots and the flight attendants joined the machinists' walkout in March but both unions gave up in November 1989.
Barely several hundred of the 2,000 pilots who refused to cross the picket lines were rehired by Eastern, Mr. Breen said. "Inevitably, most of the guys went to other airlines or retired early," he said.
 
 Unions Saw No Choice
 Charles Bryan, the union leader who led Eastern's 9,500 mechanics and ground service workers out on strike, said the airline's failure was a tragedy. But he added that if he were given a chance to run the strike all over again, he would do nothing differently.
"I regret that the strike had to happen, but there was absolutely no choice, and I have yet to meet a striking machinist who didn't think so," he said.
Mr. Bryan said the mechanics could draw some comfort from the fact that they had driven out Mr. Lorenzo as the chairman of Eastern's parent, the Texas Air Corporation, which is now called Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. "It's a terrible price to pay, but at least he's out of the industry," he said.
The machinists who at one time numbered about 12,000 at Eastern have not called off their strike. A few still maintained the picket lines at big airports.
 
 Machinists Paid High Cost
 Most of the machinists have been forced to find other jobs, often at lower wages, while some have had a hard time finding employment and have paid severely for supporting the walkout. Families have broken up and there have been suicides.
The strike was an odd turn of events, as it had been Mr. Bryan who helped Mr. Lorenzo gain control of Eastern on Feb. 23, 1988, hoping that the two could work together to revive the carrier.
The two men soon became locked in a bitter conflict. Among other things, Eastern's machinists' and pilots' unions accused the airline of doctoring maintenance records and not making repairs properly in an effort to cut costs.
The charges drove away fliers, particularly business travelers. Even now the carrier is fighting such charges after some Eastern workers were indicted for falsfying maintenance records.
The conflict intensified when Mr. Bryan led his members out on strike. It was not a bread-and-butter strike over wages and benefits. The unions including the pilots and the flight attendants who walked out in sympathy wanted to force Mr. Lorenzo to sell the airline with the unions getting a large stake in Eastern in return for concessions.
For a time the unions seemed near victory when Peter Ueberroth, who had resigned as Commissioner of Baseball, had put together a group which in cooperation with the unions would buy out Mr. Lorenzo.
 
 Issue of Lorenzo's Control
 The unions, however, insisted that Mr. Lorenzo give up control before the deal was closed and that a trustee be appointed.
The effort failed and then other attempts also foundered. Meanwhile Eastern's flights had been crippled by the strike. Mr. Lorenzo, however, began to rebuild by hiring new pilots, machinists and flight attendants.
By the summer a large part of the airline was flying again and some strikers, particularly pilots, were worried that there would not be any jobs left for them to go back to. About 500 broke from the strike and returned that August. Mr. Lorenzo's strategy of breaking the strike by replacing strikers with new employees began to work.
By November the pilots and flight attendants broke off their strike. Even though Mr. Lorenzo had rebuilt the airline with largely new, lower- paid workers the legacy of the labor conflict drove away many travelers and left many travel agents uneasy about booking Eastern.
Another attempt to remake Eastern's battered image was made last April when Judge Lifland finally accepted the union's demand that Mr. Lorenzo give up control and that a trustee be appointed.

HEADLINE: View in Poll: a Recession

 BODY:
An overwhelming majority of Americans say the country is in a recession, according to a recent New York Times/CBS News Poll.
That perception is now almost universally accepted, although the downturn has not lasted long enough to be officially declared a recession. The Bush Administration and the Federal Reserve have acknowledged for months that the economy was growing ever more slowly, but only in recent weeks have they begun to use the word "recession." 
 Seventy-eight percent of the Americans polled on Thursday said the nation was in a recession, up nine points from October. This is the highest reading since The New York Times/ CBS News Poll began asking the question in August, when 52 percent of Americans said the nation was in a recession.
A committee of economists, known as the Business Cycle Dating Committee, is the official arbiter of when recessions begin and end. The group declared in December that a recession probably began between June and September. But the committee postponed a final, official ruling until later.
Normally, it does not declare turns in the economy until six months or longer after they occur. The committee is sponsored by the National Bureau of Economic Research, a privately financed research organization in Cambridge, Mass.
The new poll was conducted by telephone with 544 adults and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Jordan;
In Jordan, the Iraqis Regain Respect by Striking at Israel

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Saturday, Jan. 19

 BODY:
In his photo store in central Amman, Naser Jafr had not known about the Iraqi missiles that crashed into Israel early Friday, until a friend called with the news at 4 A.M. And then, he said, he was filled with delight.
"The world said Saddam Hussein was weak," the 27-year-old Palestinian said. "Today he proved he is not." 
 The friend, Zeki Hamdan, 35, seemed inspired, too. "Now there is a leader for the Arabs and he is Saddam Hussein," he said, gesturing excitedly at television images of the missiles' impact on Tel Aviv.
This morning, Iraq launched a second missile attack against Tel Aviv.
The euphoria after the first missile offensive, ignoring Western accounts of the progressive destruction of Iraq's power, reflected a profound and precipitate swing in mood in this capital on Friday., Initial accounts of American successes in the gulf war on Thursday had filled many with anger, disbelief and a nascent sense of betrayal by Iraq.
That feeling was expressed by a banker quoted Friday in The Jordan Times. "If Saddam has no gear to retaliate, then it is all over," he said. "We have been mocked at again."
 The missile strikes "really built back Iraqi credibility," said Assad Abdu Rahman, a leading analyst of Palestinian affairs. Khaled Nasser, a prominent Palestinian academic, said, "This attack only indicates one thing: that Iraq is powerful and is the only Arab country capable of doing something to the Israelis."
Israel said Friday that eight Iraqi missiles had struck in the Haifa and Tel Aviv areas, slightly injuring 15 people. The weapons were identified as Soviet-made Scud missiles carrying conventional warheads.
The strikes on Tel Aviv and Haifa, and the prospect of Israeli reprisals, sharpened and brought closer a decision that King Hussein of Jordan has sought to avert since the gulf crisis began in August.
While many of the people he rules -- more than half of them Palestinian -- draw hope and faith from the belief that President Hussein will somehow lead the Arabs to redeeming victory, the King and his advisers seem filled more with foreboding that the conflict will spread into a ruinous, regional war that will engulf Jordan.
"This is what we were afraid of," said a senior military officer, referring to the Iraqi missile strikes. "We don't know how events will unfold."
 
Jordan Reopens Border
 Fearful of offending Palestinian and Iraqi sentiment, King Hussein's Government on Thursday condemned the Western allied assault on Iraq as a "brutal attack against an Arab and Muslim country and people." It withheld all comment on the Iraqi missile strikes on Israel, seeming to indicate that King Hussein saw no option but to support Saddam Hussein.
Jordan announced Friday that it had reopened its border to refugees from Iraq, following United Nations agreement to underwrite the costs of coping with a new exodus.
When the gulf crisis first erupted in August, around 860,000 people, many of them Asians working in Kuwait, fled through Jordan in a relief operation that, according Jordanian officials, left this cash-strapped country between Iraq and Israel with a $40 million debt.
As war approached this week, Jordan closed the border with Iraq to all non-Jordanian travelers except those who could pay for their stay in and passage out of the country.
The move seemed intended to press relief organizations into advance agreement to finance a new influx following the outbreak of hostilities, diplomats said.
 
A 'Tragic Situation'
 The effort seemed to have been successful. But by siding with Iraq, the King has jeopardized the long-term Gulf Arab and Western financial support he needs to rescue his country from a deep economic crisis. With the missile strikes on Israel, he now also faces the possibility of embroilment in a war and critical military decisions.
In an interview with American television, his brother, Crown Prince Hassan, spoke of the region's "tragic situation" and said that, if Israeli warplanes overflew Jordan on reprisal raids to Iraq, "we will have to try to defend our airspace within our capabilities."
"Jordan is not going to stand still if its territory and airspace are violated," a senior Government official said. "And it seems that the war could be lengthy."
Jordan is equipped with American- and Soviet-supplied air-defense systems. But deploying them against Israel's vastly superior air power would invite Israeli reprisals. Jordanian airspace offers the shortest route between Israel and Iraq.
 "Jordan might be able to pretend it has not seen the Israelis on their way out, but it would be difficult to argue that they had not spotted them on the way back," said a Western official, requesting anonymity. "It would have to choose between offending the Iraqis by not attacking Israels, and offending the Israelis by taking action."
Such imponderables do not play well in a city seized by passions that draw on well-springs of pride and lost dignity.
"Now the war will spread," said a 33-year-old vegetable seller who identified himself only as Samir. "If Israel retaliates, all the Arab people will be with Iraq against Israel. People were sad when it looked like Iraq had been hit by the first strike. Now they believe Saddam has more powerful weapons."
"I am happy and sad together," said Jiryis Qusous, who owns a restaurant. "I'm sad because this situation has arisen, and happy because it is the first time the Arabs struck inside Israel."
Many people interviewed Friday suggested that President Hussein had somehow duped the West and was waiting to unveil a greater, hidden arsenal of chemical and other weapons.
 As much as anything, the comments evoked the desperation of people who have known nothing but defeat for decades and are thus ready to clutch at any intimation of even the most token victory.
But more troublesome to Arab and Western diplomats pondering President Hussein's intentions is the worry that he now believes he has only one strategic option: to draw in Israel and split the Arab coalition supporting the American and Western deployment.
"If that is his thinking," a Western envoy said, "his only option is to try something horrific that will leave the Israelis no choice but to get involved."

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Israel;
Iraq Fires New Missle Attack at Israel; Allies Continue Bombing; Seek Launchers

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Saturday, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Iraq launched a second missile attack against Tel Aviv this morning, military officials said. The Israeli authorities said the missiles carried conventional explosives, like the missiles that hit Tel Aviv and Haifa early Friday.
The Mayor of Tel Aviv was reported on radio and television to have said that two missiles landed in the city in the latest attack and that a few people were slightly wounded. 
 On Friday, Israeli officials had warned that the earlier attack could not stand without retaliation, even though President Bush has urged Israel not to respond, out of fear that this would shatter the coalition against Iraq and bring a larger Middle East war.
 
Warning of Retaliation
 But an Israeli Cabinet member, Health Minister Ehud Olmert, told ABC News today that retaliation was now "almost inevitable" because of the second attack, which came a bare 30 hours after the first assault.
In Washington, the Pentagon confirmed that at least three missiles were launched from western Iraq. Baghdad radio said later that Iraq had launched 11 missiles "at the enemy."
Aid raid sirens sounded nationwide shortly after 7 A.M., and for the fourth time since early Friday, Israelis took refuge in rooms sealed against chemical attack. An hour later, the army radio confirmed that there had been a missile attack, but said that citizens could now safely leave the safe rooms and take off their gas masks.
Israeli officials had warned Friday that they intended to respond to the first attack, in which houses and cars were severely damaged and 15 people suffered slight injuries.
"After the dreaded attack in the middle of the night, with children in their beds asleep," Foreign Minister David Levy said Friday of the first missile offensive, "we say to our friends, how could anyone restrain himself and refrain from reacting? If we do, will Saddam Hussein refrain from firing more missiles?"
He and others said they believed that Iraq has more mobile launchers for its Scud surface-to-surface missiles that it has hidden from American bombers.
Bush Administration officials had said Friday they were hoping Israel would not retaliate, or that if it did, the damage would be not be so severe that Arabs would bolt from the coalition against Iraq.
Israelis had been told to stay home for another day on Friday, close to their gas masks and gas-resistant safe rooms. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir warned that "the danger still hasn't passed."
Just before 9 P.M., air raid sirens warning of a chemical-weapons attack sounded nationwide.
The army said that alert, which proved to be a false alarm, was based on satellite information passed on by the United States suggesting that the Iraqis were about to launch more missiles. Similar alarms were sounded in Saudi Arabia.
Another air raid alert, also a false alarm, sounded briefly in the Tel Aviv area early today. The army issued another alert in Jerusalem five hours later after hearing an explosion north of the city, but said later there had been no attack and told residents to return to bed.
Even before the second missile attack, the renewal of the air raid alerts seemed to harden the Israeli view. Deputy Foreign Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was being interviewed in the Cable News Network studio here when the first false alarm went off. Immediately after the all-clear signal sounded, he declared: "We're not going to allow Israel to be in a position where every night or every day its citizens are threatened with gas attacks by this savage, brutal dictator. You should know that."
If Israel responds, he said, "it's not retaliation. It's self-defense."
Lieut. Gen. Dan Shomron, the Army Chief of Staff, told Israel television earlier Friday that n the initial missile attack "requires a response." And Defense Minister Moshe Arens said: "We'll respond. But you don't expect me to announce the date today."
Despite such comments, Mr. Levy had said after an emergency Cabinet meeting on Friday morning that the Government had not decided what it would do. This appeared to be the line the Government was taking with the United States, and it convinced some officials in Washington that Jerusalem had decided not to act immediately.
But several military officials and analysts said they believed that Israel was likely to retaliate with attacks on missile launcher sites -- if not immediately, then certainly after another Iraqi attack.
American officials worked throughout the day to persuade Israel to hold off, saying that the allied forces were tracking down the remaining Iraqi missiles and their launchers.
The White House press secretary said Friday night that President Bush had told Mr. Shamir in a telephone conversation that "he basically appreciated their restraint and asked for their understanding."
 
Hard to Certify Hits
 Allied forces reported that they had destroyed six Iraqi missile launchers on Friday. Still, President Bush acknowledged at a news conference that "when you hide a mobile missile, as they have done, it's very hard to certify that they have been hit."
Mr. Netanyahu noted that the missiles fired on Friday morning had been "targeted at Israel's heartland," the coastal plain where 80 percent of the country's people live.
Though Iraq declared on Friday that its missiles had hit "important political and economic targets," the missiles fired in the first attack in fact hit low-income residential areas and open fields.
Those eight Iraqi missiles, armed with conventional warheads, struck Israel just after 2 A.M. Friday. Two fell in Tel Aviv, three in or near Haifa and three in open fields.
 Military censors forbid publication of the precise locations or detailed descriptions of the areas hit. The army fears that the Iraqis could use such information to help them aim missiles in future attacks.
Several homes were heavily damaged or destroyed in that attack. The 15 people who were reported injured mostly received glass cuts or suffered from shock. But the authorities said four other people died Friday as a result of the civil-defense alert that was declared while the missiles were falling.
Three elderly women were found dead in the safe rooms of their apartments on Friday. All had failed to take the seals off their gas-mask filters before putting them on, and had suffocated. A 3-year-old girl died from suffocation as her parents struggled with her to put on her mask.
Dozens of people appear to have panicked and injected themselves with atropine provided in their state-issue chemical warfare kits. Atropine is a powerful antidote to gas poisoning that can be harmful if gas is not actually ingested. People who had such injections were treated and released.
 
False Claim by Iraq
 As Israel debated what it should do on Friday, Iraq moved to capitalize on its first attack by asserting that Israel had been drawn into the war. Baghdad radio reported falsely in a morning broadcast that Israeli warplanes had flown to Saudi Arabia and were participating in the bombing raids.
Analysts here and elsewhere have said they believe Iraq's goal in attacking Israel was to draw the country into the conflict, and prompt Arab countries to abandon the anti-Iraqi coalition rather than fight on the same side as Israel.
Syria, a member of the alliance against Baghdad, has said it would switch sides and help defend any country, even Iraq, if that country is attacked by Israel.
Israeli retaliation could also draw Jordan into active military support of Iraq. Jordan has tilted toward Iraq politically but is militarily neutral.
Yet the Amman Government has said repeatedly that it would seek to attack any Israeli warplanes sent over its territory. Jordan's military is already at its highest level of alert since the 1967 Middle East war. Members of the Jordanian Popular Army, a civilian militia, were given firearms on Wednesday in preparation for combat.
On Tuesday, Brig. Gen. Avihu Bin-Nun, commander of the Israeli Air Force, said his planes would fly over Jordan if ordered to attack Iraq. If Jordan tried to attack his planes, General Bin-Nun said, he would order his pilots to destroy the far smaller Jordanian Air Force.

HEADLINE: What Prompted Investigations Into Pricing of Baby Formula

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
The infant-formula industry, which likes to project a warm and comforting image, now finds itself at the center of Federal and state price-fixing investigations.
The antitrust inquiries promise to shed light on how the $1.9 billion industry works and to answer such questions as whether producers illegally collaborated to drive prices up. 
 But the story of how those investigations came about also provides insights into the formula industry's lobbying tactics and shows how a major antitrust inquiry develops.
The investigations largely focus on contracts awarded to the major formula producers under the Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children, or WIC. The program, which is federally financed but run by the states for the benefit of low-income families, accounts for about one of every three cans of formula sold.
The Federal Trade Commission and state Attorneys General in New York, Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and Texas are looking into whether the producers rigged bids on the contracts or overcharged consumers by creating anticompetitive conditions. In Florida, Attorney General Robert Butterworth recently sued the three largest formula producers -- Abbott Laboratories , Bristol-Myers Squibb and the American Home Products Corporation -- over pricing issues.
All three companies have denied any wrongdoing. Citing pending litigation, company officials declined to be interviewed.
Together, Abbott, which markets Similac through its Ross Laboratories unit, and Bristol-Myers Squibb, which markets Enfamil through its Mead Johnson Nutritional Group, account for almost 9 of every 10 cans of formula sold. American Home Products, which accounts for about 9 percent of sales, markets SMA brand formula through its Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories.
Since 1980, the average wholesale price of formula has doubled; a 13-ounce can of concentrated formula is now $1.80 to $2.30. The three major producers have often charged virtually the same wholesale price for their products. Federal investigators want to determine the business reasons for the pricing patterns.
 
Giveaway Programs
 The major producers market their formula through giveaway programs in hospitals and doctors' offices. Because Federal law requires all formulas to have the same nutrients, many doctors consider the products so generic that hospitals often rotate them.
Companies that sell formula do not release figures on its contribution to overall earnings, but some analysts believe it is substantial.
"The major formula companies are tremendous cash cows," said James E. Post, a professor of management at Boston University who has studied the formula industry.
The roots of the current investigations stretch to the mid-1980's, when virtually all state WIC programs were paying full retail prices for formula because there was no competitive bidding. As formula prices rose, state WIC directors saw their budgets erode, said Debra Stabeno, the director of the program in Texas. In 1986, the WIC program there lacked the money to serve needy families in 40 counties, Ms. Stabeno said.
The WIC program's plight was noticed by researchers at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a nonprofit group in Washington concerned with Federal economic policies.
"Most WIC directors hadn't really thought about competitive bidding as a way to control costs," said Stefan Harvey, the director of the center's project that monitors WIC.
Ms. Harvey and her colleagues urged state officials to start competitive procedures. In 1987, Texas followed Oregon and Tennessee in announcing it would give the WIC contract to the formula company that provided the biggest rebate in competitive bidding.
The major formula companies tried to counter the move. "In a nutshell, both Ross and Mead Johnson opposed us and heavily lobbied the Texas Legislature and medical community," Ms. Stabeno said.
More than 100 Texas pediatricians protested to state health officials that competitive bidding might endanger children's health by preventing doctors from prescribing certain brands of formula. Ms. Stabeno said that fear was unfounded.
A Mead Johnson sales manager, James A. Poloni, wrote to Texas officials in 1987 to warn that the company might end its longstanding policy of supplying free formula to state hospitals if the bidding plan went forward. "The high probability exists that formula companies would begin charging hospitals," he wrote.
 
Investigation in Texas
 Both Ross and Mead Johnson said they would give rebates but wanted to keep the so-called open-market system. In that system, a WIC voucher is exchanged in stores for any brand of formula; under competitive bidding, the voucher is good only for a specific brand. Under an open-market system the market share of each of the companies tends to remain the same because consumers usually buy the brand that doctors recommend.
The lobbying by Ross and Mead Johnson against competitive bidding became so intense that in 1988 the Texas Attorney General's office opened an investigation. It was dropped shortly afterward when the bidding system was adopted. Mead Johnson submitted the winning rebate bid of about $1 a can, nearly twice the rebate it said it would give under the open-market system.
As a result, Texas has saved about $35 million a year on formula and expanded its WIC program to serve an additional 110,000 residents, Ms. Stabeno said.
As more states turned to competitive bidding, formula companies competed furiously to win WIC contracts, particularly in larger states. Rebates rose steadily, reaching a high of $1.51 a can in Michigan.
Some of the pressure for higher rebates came from Wyeth-Ayerst, which had the smallest market share of the three major producers and thus the most to gain.
"Whoever wins the WIC bid gets more shelf space in supermarkets, so there is a spillover into regular retail sales," Ms. Harvey said.
With WIC rebates rising, Ms. Harvey said she and her colleagues believed that their strategy had triumphed. But a complete victory may have been short-lived.
Beginning in early 1990, rebates offered by producers began to drop. Some financial analysts said the rebates fell simply because they had become so high they cut deeply into profits. But for Ms. Harvey and her colleagues, the turnabout raised the question of possible collusion. As a result of their telephone calls, officials of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities met with the staff of the Senate Subcommittee on Antitrust, Monopolies and Business Rights, headed by Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio.
In Senate hearings in May, a Federal Trade Commission official said the agency would investigate the formula industry for possible antitrust violations.
One clue being followed by Federal investigators is a March 1990 letter by Donald G. Harris, Mead Johnson's president, to WIC directors in Arizona, Montana, Oklahoma and West Virginia. The letter is unusual because in it Mr. Harris announced the rebate Mead Johnson planned to offer in sealed competitive bidding, 75 cents a can.
"We're looking at questions concerning why a company might want to announce prices in advance," said Kevin Arquit, director of the F.T.C.'s Bureau of Competition. Mr. Arquit said the commission expects to finish its inquiry in several months.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Players and Clubs Show Figures for Arbitration

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Additional evidence of baseball's new world of economics erupted yesterday when 138 players and their clubs exchanged figures for salary arbitration. The salaries sought and offered reflected the contracts other players have signed this winter:
*Eleven players sought salaries of $3 million or more. 
 *Those 11 and 3 other players were guaranteed 1991 salaries of $2 million or more because of the figures their clubs submitted. In the previous 15 years of salary arbitration, clubs went in at $2 million or more a total of five times.
*In all, clubs offered 41 players, or 30 percent of the group, salaries of $1 million or more. Clubs offered $1 million or more a total of 57 times in prior years.
*Sixty-one of the players, or 44 percent, asked for $1 million or more. Players in the first 15 years did that a total of 108 times.
*The numbers were so large that in nine instances player and club were $1 million or more apart in their submitted figures.
 
Thigpen Reaches Terms
 Fourteen players who had filed for arbitration reached agreements with their clubs yesterday and did not exchange figures.
Leading the list was Bobby Thigpen, the relief pitcher for the Chicago White Sox. Thigpen, who had 57 saves last season, will receive $9 million over three years, making him the 30th player to average $3 million or more a year. The White Sox have two option years at salaries of $3.25 million and $3.35 million.
In the arbitration process, to begin the first three weeks of next month, an arbitrator awards either the club's figure or the player's figure, not anything in between. For all of the stratospheric salary figures submitted yesterday, perhaps the most intriguing one was $225,000. The Montreal Expos and Scott Boras, the agent, both filed that number for Drew Hall, an Expos pitcher.
That was only the second time club and player have had the same salary in mind. In 1987, David Palmer and the Atlanta Braves each submitted $725,000. In two instances, with Mike Edwards of Oakland in 1980 and Mike Flanagan of Baltimore in 1982, the agent submitted a lower number than the club.
 
Davis Seeks the Most
 Glenn Davis, recently traded by Houston to Baltimore, filed the highest number, a record-setting $3.65 million. The previous high was Robin Yount's $3.4 million a year ago.
The Orioles' $2.9 million figure for Davis was the highest offer from a club this year, but it fell short of the Brewers' $3.2 million for Yount.
Also guaranteed $2 million or more were three members of the Pittsburgh Pirates, Bobby Bonilla, Doug Drabek and Barry Bonds; Mike Greenwell and Tom Brunansky of Boston; Jack Morris of Detroit, Kelly Gruber of Toronto, Fred McGriff of San Diego, Mark McGwire of Oakland, Gary Gaetti of Minnesota, Ruben Sierra of Texas, Tom Candiotti of Cleveland and Fernando Valenzuela of Los Angeles.
 
$1 Million Gaps
 McGwire and Jose Rijo of Cincinnati, the Reds' World Series hero, have the largest gaps -- $1.3 million -- with their clubs. McGwire wants $3.3 million to Oakland's $2 million, and Rijo wants $2.9 million to the Reds' $1.6 million. Also $1 million or more apart are Morris, Sierra, Bonilla, McGriff, Drabek, Gruber and Jim Gantner of Milwaukee.
Lee Guetterman was one of the players who negotiated a contract, agreeing yesterday to a $1.05 million salary with the Yankees. The relief pitcher earned $500,000 last year.
In other agreements, Randy Myers raised his salary from $875,000 to $2 million with the Reds, Joe Orsulak accepted a two-year, $2.4 million deal from Baltimore and Mitch Williams approved a raise from $1,125,000 to $1.5 million with the Cubs.

HEADLINE: Accountants as Financial Planners

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.

 BODY:
The nation's certified public accountants are beginning a major effort to convince the public that they are the best sources of advice on financial planning. Other financial planners who are not accountants say that is not necessarily so.
At this desert resort near Palm Springs recently, accountants attending a meeting of the personal financial planning division of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, their profession's largest group, outlined their effort. 
 It will include, among other things, a toll-free number, (800) 969-7371, that prospective clients can call for the names of qualified accountant-planners and brochures about the accountant's role in financial planning -- a subject emcompassing all elements of personal finance, including insurance, investments, taxes and estates.
Even in this period of recession, many people are turning to professional financial planners for counsel on such objectives as paying for their children's education or preparing for retirement. But many consumers have long been confused about where to go for financial planning.
There are no Federal or state licensing requirements; anyone can call himself or herself a financial planner. And although the designations "certified financial planner" and "chartered financial consultant" indicate competence, they are conferred by private organizations and have no government sanction.
"Of all the people who are 'players,' we are the only ones licensed by the states," said Howard Safer, a partner in Kraft Brothers , Nashville accountants, and co-chairman of last week's conference. "We paid our dues as a profession."
Stuart Kessler, a partner in the New York accounting firm Goldstein Golub & Kessler and the chairman of the accountants' financial planning division, said: "We are bound by enforceable standards of conduct. The C.P.A. is thought of in the public mind as being independent and objective."
However, some consumers may be more inclined to choose a different type of adviser when it involves putting a financial program into effect.
 
The Issue of Liability
 Accountants in all but seven states -- Delaware, Indiana, Maryland, New Hampshire, Oklahoma, South Dakota and Texas -- are barred from accepting commissions for selling investments and insurance policies. And most accountants are not registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission as investment advisers, nor do they want to be.
Thus, their advice about stocks and bonds is usually generic rather than specific. Clients often have to select someone else to put the plan into effect.
"Accountants feel they can be involved without having to take on some liability and risk for the client," said Mary Malgoire, the regulatory representative of the National Association of Personal Financial Advisers, a group of planners who do not accept commissions but are paid a set fee, just as most accountants are.
And while accountants emphasize that their expertise on tax matters and in managing budgets makes them especially capable as financial advisers, others whose education and experience are in fields like securities and insurance argue that they are at least as qualified as accountants are.
"I'm not convinced that any one particular background prepares a person any better to provide competent financial planning advice," said Robert A. Hewitt, the chairman of the International Association for Financial Planning, one of the largest groups in the field. Its members receive fees, commissions or a combination of both.
"Any background you come from is a pretty narrow background," Mr. Hewitt added, "and it's up to the planners to pick up the other skills that they need."
Even some accountants who are financial planners are aware that some of their number may not always be right for the job.
"Some C.P.A.'s may offer complicated and exotic solutions to problems that generate high professional fees when there may be simpler approaches," said Larry Fowler, a Bellevue, Wash., accountant who is an official of the accountants' financial planning division.
Finally, there is the matter of expense: The fees charged by most accountant-planners are at the high end of the range for financial planners, generally between $100 and $350 an hour, and many people cannot afford them.
Nevertheless, accountants charging that kind of money have shown that they can offer tax services to a broad segment of the population, especially in personal income tax matters. Accountants who specialize in financial planning hope to attract many kinds of customers.
"Being an accountant gives you more credibility to start," said Joel S. Isaacson, a partner in Weber Lipshie & Company in New York, who is active in the professional education programs of the accountants' planning division, "but with financial planning services, you have to know what you're doing."

HEADLINE: Guidepost;
Pick a Card. Any Card?

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:

Most interest rates are declining, but three-quarters of all credit-card holders will not reap the benefit. The reason: their interest rates are fixed and rarely change. To find lower rates, they must shop around. The remaining quarter of all credit cards offer variable interest rates, usually tied to the prime rate. Last year the average cost of financing purchases on a standard fixed-rate Visa card or Mastercard was 18.86 percent. The Bank Rate Monitor, an industry weekly, says these three banks offer the best deals on credit cards in the country, taking into account interest rates, annual fees and grace periods before interest charges are added.

HEADLINE: Economics by the Cup

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While serving time recently as a clear-liquids patient at New York Hospital, I began to understand the impact of what you aptly condemn in "The Europeans Sabotage Trade" (editorial, Dec. 8). You point out that the European Community protects its 10 million farmers by keeping prices high and shutting out foreign imports. The high prices generate huge surpluses that are dumped on world markets at artificially low prices, amounting to what you term "economic warfare" against American, Canadian and third world farmers.
At the hospital I was served prune juice made from concentrate produced in France and West Germany; apple juice from West Germany; pineapple juice from Thailand and the Philippines (has Hawaii run out of pineapples?); and grape juice from Argentina and Brazil (another grape juice container identified the contents as coming from Argentina and Chile). The only fruit juice with anything made in the United States was cranberry -- and even it had to share billing with concentrate from West Germany.
 
RICHARD COHEN
New York, Jan. 7, 1991

HEADLINE: A Quick Victory? It Better Be

BYLINE: By John Mueller; John Mueller, professor of political science at the University of Rochester, is author of "War, Presidents and Public Opinion."

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, N.Y.

 BODY:
President Bush has vowed that the war with Iraq "will not be another Vietnam." In its essential shape, however, the war will be quite similar, except that everything will be compressed in time. And, as in Vietnam, the key to the outcome is not the unquestionable American ability to impose damage but the enemy's ability to maintain a fighting force that can inflict casualties on Americans.
In a Gallup Poll taken last Wednesday, 79 percent of Americans supported the U.S. decision to go to war. Of those interviewed, 17 percent said they thought it would last a few of days, 39 percent saw it ending in a matter of weeks and 23 percent feared a war of some months' duration. Only 5 percent could imagine the war lasting a year or more. 
 By contrast, when the Vietnam War began in 1965, a "can do" military generally anticipated, or hoped, that the enemy would break after suffering punishment for some two or three years -- about the duration of the Korean War. The public and Congress seemed to accept that estimate, and they generally supported the war for that long.
While President Bush has said that no cost would be too high to liberate Kuwait, the public obviously envisions -- and, in all likelihood, will only tolerate -- a walkover war attended by casualty rates more like those suffered in Panama than in Vietnam.
In several recent polls, for example, support for war falls off quickly when casualty numbers are added to the query. In one, taken shortly before the war broke out, approval dropped by 19 percentage points -- from 63 to 44 percent -- when the question suggested that 1,000 U.S. troops might die. This attitude may have been reinforced in the war's early stages by reports of widespread destruction of Iraqi military and industrial installations and remarkably light allied casualties.
Tolerance for losses is far lower in the gulf than in Vietnam for at least two reasons. First, in Vietnam (as in Korea) the enemy was seen by the Administration, Congress and public to be part of the international Communist threat that had as its ultimate goal the destruction of the United States itself. Accordingly, the war inspired high levels of support, at least at first. Saddam Hussein may threaten American interests, but no one sees him as that sort of menace.
Curiously, the military often claims that a central lesson from the Vietnam experience is that forces should not be committed to war unless there is solid public backing. That was not a problem when the Vietnam War began. It is now.
Second, in Vietnam (and also in Korea) there were seen to be no alternatives when American troops were sent into action: Either the troops went in or the enemy would succeed. In Kuwait, by contrast, there was the option of continuing with the economic sanctions.
To inspire a decline in support for the war in the U.S., the Iraqis need not win a single battle. They need only maintain a dedicated fighting force that is able to push American casualties beyond tolerable levels -- and those levels are far lower than they were in Vietnam or Korea.
Of course, the Iraqis may very well collapse on cue. The Communists in Vietnam accepted losses that, as a percentage of population, were all but unprecedented in modern warfare -- about twice the rate of the Japanese in World War II, for example.
But, as Clausewitz observed, war is the least predictable of human activities. The Iraqis -- or significant numbers of them -- might refuse to break, and develop instead a Masada or Alamo complex. Massive bombing, in fact, does not usually break the targeted people's will, particularly in the short run. It often generates rage and cohesion, creates martyrs, stiffens resistance and inspires the perception that there is nothing more to lose.
The Iraqis might, for example, be able to sustain a Tet-like house-to-house battle in Kuwait City. Or they might retreat from Kuwait and launch persistent counter-attacks from Iraq, requiring a quagmire-like invasion of that country.
If something like that comes about, American losses will become intolerable and public support for the war -- Bush's war, it will surely be called -- will swiftly erode. As in Vietnam, the battle will be over American public opinion, and the Iraqis seem to understand this. There is still a danger they may conquer us even while being devastated on the battlefield.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: The West Side Viaduct;
Conrail Looking to a Revival of Its Freight Traffic

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
WITH demolition under way on the southern end of New York Central's unused elevated freight railroad through the industrial West Side of Manhattan, the Federal Government last week rebuffed an effort by local property owners to force an abandonment of the entire line.
On Jan. 7, a Manhattan developer began razing five blocks of the viaduct, known as the High Line, from Gansevoort to Bank Streets. Further demolition would have opened the prospect of development from the West Village to the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. New construction in the area has been inhibited in part by the railroad tracks that thread their way around and even through the factories and warehouses along 10th Avenue and Washington Street. 
 A group called Chelsea Property Owners has been trying to force Conrail involuntarily to abandon the northern part of the line, from Gansevoort Street to the John D. Caemmerer West Side Yards, between 30th and 33d Streets. Their application to the Interstate Commerce Commission was supported by City Hall.
"It's been nothing but an obstruction to our businesses and properties for over 10 years and we want to end that," said Douglas E. Sarini, president of the owners' group and a vice president of the Edison Parking Corporation, based in Newark, which owns a critical site under the High Line.
But Conrail, based in Philadelphia, has been talking about reactivating the High Line for use in hauling waste and recyclable materials from lower Manhattan to points north.
And on Thursday, an administrative law judge at the commission, Paul J. Clerman, denied the property owners' request.
"There is credible evidence of potential traffic for movement on the High Line," he wrote. "Restoration of this line to service would comport with the objective of the commission."
Although he acknowledged the "legitimate interests" of the property owners, Judge Clerman concluded that "the public's interest in a revived transportation service over the High Line must take precedence."
After years of isolation, the High Line could once again be linked to the mainland over Amtrak's new West Side rail line, called the Empire Connection, which runs from Pennsylvania Station through a tunnel beneath the Caemmerer yards and is scheduled to open in April. Conrail has reserved a freight easement from Amtrak, according to Jonathan Broder, a Conrail attorney, who said that the railroad has been negotiating for the waste removal service with Browning-Ferris Industries of Houston.
"We're trying to preserve valuable infrastructure at a time when the market looks very positive for rail traffic," he said. "If we are able to get the line reactivated, we have received interest from other shippers in lower Manhattan to use the line again. It could be used to bring meat into the meat market and there is an opportunity to work with the Post Office or United Parcel Service."
BOTH Community Board 2, which includes the West Village, and Community Board 4, which includes Chelsea and Clinton, have called for the preservation of the High Line -- at least long enough to examine ways to use it for freight shipments or mass transit or as a recreational route.
But the City Planning Department believes the case is closed. "Future uses -- even at fairly significant densities -- would not generate a need for a new transit service that could sustain itself at the fare box," said Robert E. Flahive, director of the planning agency's Manhattan office.
As for freight use, he said: "It didn't make a lot of logistical sense. You have a spur line with no loading and storage facilities, no place for trains to queue up. You have to provide some substantial staging area."
Mayor David N. Dinkins, who supported the general notion of reusing the line while he was Manhattan Borough President, now says its continued presence "would significantly limit the city's ability to consider other development strategies for the area."
The most ambitious strategy is that envisioned by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for the Caemmerer yards. One plan called for 3,000 apartments in towers along 12th Avenue, a 900-room hotel and 8 million square feet of office space in five enormous buildings on 11th Avenue. Given the collapse of the market, the M.T.A. is not now pursuing this project but it has supported abandonment of the viaduct.
SOME commercial redevelopment is already going on in and around the High Line route. Until the 1960's, the railroad ran as far as the sprawling St. John's Park Freight Terminal, between Washington, West, Spring and Clarkson Streets.
The terminal is now being marketed as an office building called St. John's Center, with 200,000-square-foot floors and rents of $12 a square foot. Merrill Lynch already occupies about 700,000 square feet of the million-square-foot structure. A deal is pending for 300,000 square feet more, said Josh N. Kuriloff, an assistant director of the Cushman & Wakefield brokerage, which represents the owner, Eugene M. Grant.
Also, eight floors of the 500,000-square-foot Merchants Refrigerating Company Building on 10th Avenue, between 16th and 17th Streets, are being remodeled for use by the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration. Once a cold-storage warehouse, the building had its own spur track from the High Line, which has now been severed.
The top three floors of the building are owned by Edison Parking and used for storage; the lower eight floors by Hirschfeld Realty of Manhattan and the Belz Investment Company of Memphis, which originally planned to convert the building into a factory-outlet shopping center. The architects are Emery Roth & Sons of Manhattan.
"We look for sturdy and secure buildings," said Robert A. Bryden, special agent in charge of the New York field division for the enforcement agency. "Perhaps more importantly, it has as many as 700 indoor parking spots. Keeping our cars inside and out of view is very much a plus." There is also fairly quick access to major roads, bridges, tunnels and Federal courts downtown. The project will bring up to 800 workers into the area.
Ultimately, however, the High Line's defenders fear that jobs will be lost with the removal of the viaduct, one of the last buffers protecting industrial tenants from development pressures. "There's a very strong and very viable economy there, with a lot of jobs," said Elliott D. Sclar, a professor of urban planning at Columbia University, "I'm still a believer that rail transportation is going to be very important to the stabilization and development of that area."
About demolition, he asked: "Why is there such a need to rush? No one is proposing to build anything. It's not that you're doing any harm to private interests right now."
But the property owners believe strongly that their interests are harmed. For instance, Edison Parking owns a whole block bounded by 17th and 18th Streets, 10th and 11th Avenues. The High Line runs over the eastern portion of the parcel.
"We have had inquiries from a manufacturer to develop that property and from a motion-picture studio which wanted to go there," said Mr. Sarini, Edison's vice president. "But nothing could be done because of that structure overhead. It's really a physical barrier to manufacturing development. Both of those deals went by the wayside."
The peril is not just economic but physical. "The cement underneath the tracks has fallen and almost killed one of my men," said David Duchini, president of Adolph's Trucking Company, which operates beneath the High Line, from 24th to 25th Street.
Meanwhile, demolition has begun on a portion of the viaduct, from Gansevoort to Bank Street, which was bought from Conrail by the Rockrose Development Corporation, which owns three blocks over which the High Line travels. Rockrose has already converted the Manhattan Refrigerating Company Building, between Horatio and Gansevoort Streets, into the West Coast apartments. Now it hopes to build two new apartment buildings to the south.

HEADLINE: Perspectives: The 'Cuomo Tax';
As the Gravy Train Slows, Questions Rise

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
IN real-estate circles it is universally known as the "Cuomo tax," and that surely does not displease Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
Soon after his first term as Governor began in 1983, when city and state governments alike were looking for ways to wring more revenue sooner from rising real-estate sale prices, the Governor won from the Legislature a novel form of gains tax. The state would take 10 percent of the gain in any sale of $1 million or more. 
 "There was a boom in real estate and a feeling that the people who were benefiting should make a contribution to the state," said James W. Wetzler, who became state Commissioner of Taxation and Finance in 1986.
The contribution proved heftier than the state expected. Initial projections were that the tax would raise about $80 million a year. In fact, $158 million poured in during the first year and the state's take climbed steadily each year through 1987. That was the peak year, with $792 million in net revenue.
But now the take has dropped sharply, as has the level of transactions. The slump in the market has thrown into bold relief the problems associated with the tax from the beginning.
The most striking is that its method of computing "gain" taxes even those who find that their project has produced no economic gain at all. The state wants the tax even when a project is experiencing such losses that its "sale" must be to a creditor.
As with any major tax on transfers, the gains tax has likely had a dampening effect on sales, with some owners preferring to remortgage rather than sell commercial property to avoid tax penalties. But it is residential development that the effects of the tax have been thrown into boldest relief in New York City. Developers or converters are barred from claiming a whole series of project-related costs as part of their "original purchase price," the cost basis for determing the gain on which the 10 percent tax is calculated.
Carolyn Ichel, a lawyer with the Manhattan firm of Roberts & Holland, listed the following disallowances that she said contribute to the state's magnified notion of a developer's gain: interest costs on site-acquisition loans; the post-construction cost of carrying unsold space; marketing and advertising expenses; the expense of buying Section 421a abatement certificates for Manhattan residential construction; leasing-up costs; brokerage commissions for leasing; tenant relocation expenses; marketing and advertising expenses.
"THE inequities are most glaring in the case of projects constructed for sale, or disposed of shortly after completion," she said. "In these cases virtually all the income from the project is subject to the gains tax, and the disallowance of any cost can immediately be seen as producing inflated gain."
The effects are especially notable in New York City development projects, because they frequently involve long lead times, predevelopment costs and sales-related costs -- to say nothing of the added interest and real-estate tax burdens that result from slow sales in a poor market.
In the case of conversions of rental property to co-ops or condominiums, for example, Time Equities, once one of the city's largest converters, stopped buying rental buildings for conversions as long as five years ago because of what it deemed the tax's confiscatory effect on potential sales profits.
The fiscal problems of Time Equities and other conversion sponsors who hold hundreds of renter-occupied apartments derive in part from the gains tax. The tax in effect imposed a penalty on sponsors who might have at one time made package deals with buyers before the slump, and reports of potential fiscal problems for co-op corporations unsettled the market.
Condominium and co-op sales by developers or converters have been a major source of income under the 10 percent gains tax, although the state finance agency could offer no breakdown in dollars.
In the 1990 fiscal year, 26,425 of the total 33,461 sales were of this type. The state could make no breakout of conversion and new construction. The state's position is that even an ownership entity that files for a Chapter 11 bankruptcy should pay the tax. It is appealing a decision won in United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York by 995 Fifth Avenue Associates. That bankrupt entity incurred a $2.6 million gains tax when it sold the Stanhope Hotel in Manhattan to a Japanese company.
The decision strengthens the use of the Chapter 11 procedure as a method of working out the problems of a troubled project, said Joshua J. Angel of the firm of Angel & Frankel, which represented 995 Fifth Avenue Associates.
But the gains tax can be an impediment in other workout approaches, said another lawyer, Stephen S. Ziegler of the firm of Lowenthal Landau Fischer & Ziegler, which is litigating on behalf of Time Equities in its efforts to change the state's treatment of the gain tax in co-op conversions.
If a property has declined in value below the amount due on the mortgage, the debtor would owe tax on the higher mortgage value rather than the true market value if he transferred the deed, Mr. Ziegler said. In essence, an added penalty is imposed on the owner-debtor who cannot come up with cash to pay down the debt to the market value of the property.
If there is a formal foreclosure proceeding, the tax may be even higher. The referee dealing with an uncooperative debtor may assume the gains tax will equal 10 percent of the foreclosure sale's proceeds..
THE workings of the tax in foreclosure situations, which has led to litigation, demonstrates how it has stood in the way of efforts to work out debtors' problems. But it also shows in general that the tax was conceived as a device to use in upbeat markets. It has lacked flexibility in a down market. Unlike a capital gains tax, for example, it does not allow taxpayers to offset gains with losses experienced in other transactions.
The Real Estate Board of New York in November carried its longstanding case against what it considers inequities in the administration of the gains tax to the state's chief economic development official, Vincent Tese, Commissioner of the New York State Department of Economic Development.
According to the board, the state's administration of the tax has resulted in effective tax rates of 13 to 35 percent of the true economic gain in real-estate sales. In four projects brought to the board's attention, the gains tax aggregated $4.4 million "when in fact there was no economic gain at all," said Steven Spinola, president of the board.
Another lawyer, Robert Schachat, tax partner in the firm of Wien Malkin & Bettex, gave an example to illustrate how a condominium developer in Manhattan could find himself owing a huge gains tax at a time when he "thought he was breaking even." The hypothesis is that the developer spends $10 million to buy land for an apartment project and breaks ground after three years.
In a typical case this developer will have put into the project $34 million in equity and borrowed money, but only $29 million will be allowed as the "original purchase price." The $5 million difference comes from the disallowed preconstruction interest costs and real-estate taxes of $3 million and the $2 million in construction-period interest expense allocatable to the land.
Assuming $4 million in post-completion interest payments, real estate taxes and marketing expenses, the developer will see himself as breaking even if he sells out all the apartments within two years for $38 million.
But from the tax collector's standpoint, this is a $9 million gain and $900,000 in tax is owed.
For the co-op converter the situation is even worse, said Mr. Schachat, because the state ignores "negative carry" as part of the original purchase price. This is what the sponsor must pay the co-op to make up for rents that don't equal maintenance payments for the renter-occupied apartments.
Commissioner Wetzler, for his part, believes that legislative action is needed for most of the changes in the law sought by the real-estate industry. That cannot be expected under current circumstances, he said. Any administrative changes would involve "looseners and tighteners" that would be revenue-neutral.
"We're studying the suggestions and engaging in a dialogue with the industry," said Commissioner Wetzler.
