HEADLINE: Redefining 'Affordability' for the 90's

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
MORE than a decade after soaring real estate values made "affordable housing" a rallying cry across much of the nation, economists, builders and community activists are challenging deeply ingrained assumptions about how much Americans can -- or should -- pay for housing.
Housing costs have always caused severe hardships for the poor, whose plight deepened in the 80's. But now the debate has broadened to include middle-income and affluent households, some of whom may have stretched their budgets too far in recent home purchases. 
 "The term 'affordable housing' has become a meaningless cliche," said Michael Stone, a professor of community development at the University of Massachusetts. In studies of how much people pay for rent or homeownership, he concluded that 27 million households, or nearly a third of the country's population, are "shelter poor" because they have too little left over for food, education, medical bills, transportation and other needs.
One clear shift as the real estate boom of 80's gives way to the economic austerity of the 90's is that housing has, indeed, become more affordable. While incomes have risen, mortgage interest rates and home prices have declined sharply. Analysts say more Americans can now buy homes than at any time since 1978.
But that comes as little comfort to low- and moderate-income families living in publicly assisted housing who are required to pay up to 30 percent of their income in rent, an amount fixed in Government policy that experts say is claiming too much from some households living at or near the poverty level.
And for many homeowners, the gains in affordability are at best a mixed blessing. Millions who bought in the late 80's, believing their homes would prove to be lucrative investments, went further into debt for mortgage loans than has traditionally been considered prudent. Now, caught in a nationwide real estate slump and facing the propspect of selling for little more -- or even less -- than they paid, many are staying put, cutting back on other expenses and paying housing costs that are a heavy load.
For others, just staying put has become impossible. In New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, foreclosures on homeowners rose more than 30 percent in the first nine months of 1990. Evictions of renters are also on the rise; court records in New Jersey indicate they have risen by over 25 percent since 1986, to 163,994 last year.
"There is no question that people are feeling pinched and house poor," said Robert Engelstad, vice president for mortgage standards at the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, the nation's largest buyer of real estate loans from thrifts, banks and mortgage companies.
Nor has the problem escaped the attention of home builders.
"People in the 1980's expected to hold on to a home for two or three years and sell at a profit, so they thought it was O.K. to fall behind on their MasterCard bills in the meantime," said George Yankowich, a developer in Greenwich, Conn., one of the nation's wealthiest communities.
Mr. Yankowich is seeking approval from the town's Planning and Zoning Commission to build eight condominiums priced at $95,000 to $170,000, far below the cost of most Greenwich housing.
"Buyers have become much more conservative," he added. "It just makes business sense" to build housing "at a moderate price that people will buy to live in for a long time."
Central to the debate over housing affordability are two financial formulas that had long been accepted as national guidelines but that were either adjusted or ignored over the last decade.
One rule, affecting low- and moderate-income renters, is the Government's index for how much of their income should be paid in rent. For decades, that limit was 25 percent of income, but it was raised to 30 percent under President Ronald Reagan and has since been set at 30 percent by Federal, state and city housing agencies across the nation.
For home buyers, the rule had traditionally dictated that no more than 28 percent of their income be devoted to mortgage payments, real estate taxes and home insurance premiums. The 28 percent limit was intended to prevent people from going too far into debt. It also stipulated that the totality of a home buyer's debt obligations, including payments on the home loan, car loans, credit card purchases and other personal debts, should not claim more than 36 percent of income.
But for recent home buyers, particularly in the most expensive urban areas, the guidelines have been stretched widely. A 1990 survey of hundreds of home buyers in 18 large metropolitan areas, to be released later this month by the Chicago Title and Trust Company, found that most were paying more -- sometimes much more -- than 30 percent of their income for mortgage and real estate tax payments. Deepest in debt, the survey found, were 1990 buyers in the New York area, who are now paying an average of 40.6 percent of their incomes to mortgage lenders and tax collectors.
BUYERS and lenders alike have found many ways to stretch the limits. "In most cases, the rules have been adjusted for very legitimate reasons," said Mr. Engelstad of Fannie Mae, which still adheres to a general policy in which it will buy mortgage loans held by people paying up to 28 percent of their income in mortgage, real estate tax and insurance bills.
But even Fannie Mae increased its limits in the 80's, to as high as 33 percent for some buyers.
Lenders say some of their customers, having profited from the sale of other property, agreed to make down payments of more than the normal 20 percent of the purchase price of their new homes and in turn were allowed to take out larger-than-normal mortgages.
Wealthy buyers around New York and in other expensive markets have turned to so-called "jumbo" mortgage financing from banks and mortgage companies, in which traditional limits are often ignored. And many who bought in the late 80's have now found themselves paying a larger share of their income in mortgage payments because they have adjustable-rate loans that started with artificially low "teaser" interest rates that have since gone up.
As an example, a family with $60,000 in income, willing to pay 40 percent of it for a home, would be paying $2,000 a month in mortgage and real estate tax bills. Assuming the family made a 20 percent down payment and took a mortgage at 10 percent interest in mid-1990, it might have bought a $280,000 house, a modest three-bedroom residence in one of New York's more expensive suburbs. But the $3,000 the family would have left after paying for its house each month might be spread thin to meet other expenses -- income taxes, commutation costs, education bills and entertainment, among them.
John Pfister, chief economist for Chicago Title and Trust, who conducts the survey each December, said the costs for new buyers in and around New York were even higher in the late 80's, reaching a peak in 1988, when the average buyer paid out 44.5 percent of his income for housing.
Elsewhere, 1990 buyers went only slightly less deeply into debt. Mr. Pfister said those in San Francisco are paying 40.2 percent of their incomes for mortgage and real estate tax payments; in Los Angeles, 38 percent; in Boston, 34.9 percent, and in Chicago, 33 percent.
Of the 18 metropolitan areas surveyed, only Memphis and its suburbs were found to be on the better side of the 28 percent ratio of income-to-housing costs; people there were paying an average of 27.6 percent of their incomes for mortgage and real estate tax bills, Mr. Pfister said.
While it is generating a fresh round of debate in the most expensive areas, affordable housing is much less of a problem outside large metropolitan areas. In most of the nation, where real estate prices are far lower, home ownership claims less of people's incomes.
"There are people everywhere who can't afford housing, but middle-income people really can afford a home in Saginaw," said Lee Knudson, president of the Michigan National Bank in Saginaw, where well-maintained ranch or split-level houses, with three bedrooms and two bathrooms, can be bought for under $55,000.
Mr. Knudson's city represents an extreme in housing affordability, which varies widely across the nation.
A study of 100 cities in November by Mortgage-Wright, a mortgage-banking company in Richmond, Va., found Saginaw the most affordable. It said people with the city's median income of $37,200 make more than twice as much as they need to buy a median-priced Saginaw home, costing $49,500.
By contrast, it found that in New York City and its suburbs -- the least affordable housing market -- a family with the area's median income of $36,900 would have only 68 percent of what it needs to buy a median-priced home, costing $175,000.
THE study assumed buyers had enough to make a 20 percent down payment, and would pay 28 percent of their income for mortgage payments, real estate taxes and insurance premiums.
Other research shows that housing affordability gradually improved during the 80's in most of the nation. While homes remain more expensive than in the 70's, rising incomes and relatively low interest rates have made current prices a bargain compared to those of a decade ago.
The trend is reflected in annual surveys by the National Association of Realtors, a trade group based in Washington. Comparing interest rates, median incomes and median selling prices across the nation, it found that by last November the median family income of $35,353 was 110 percent of what was needed to buy the median-priced home, costing $98,300.
That came after nine years of steady improvement. In 1981, the least affordable year -- when interest rates on mortgage loans had risen to more than 16 percent -- the national median income was only 69 percent of what was needed to buy the median-priced home, costing $66.400.
Indeed, homes in some parts of the country, especially the most expensive metropolitan areas, have become even more affordable over the last three months with a sharp decline in interest rates and a continuing slump in prices. Interest rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages, which were over 10.5 percent in mid-1990, have fallen to near 9.5 percent.
"This is an unusual window," said Mr. Pfister of Chicago Title and Trust, referring to the rate. "There have been very few periods before when we've seen interest rates falling at the same time home values are flat or declining."
But to whatever extent the current slump offers opportunities, some experts say, buyers, renters, lenders and government agencies should all reconsider what affordability means to the complex mix of American households.
"I challenge the notion that any single index of affordability makes sense," said Mr. Stone of the University of Massachusetts.
The most widespread problems, he added, have arisen in publicly assisted housing and its pervasive rules that tenants pay up to 30 percent of their income in rent. In some cases, he said, these tenants are paying less than they can afford.
IN one example, he said, elderly couples with more than $10,000 in income, and whose tax bills and other personal expenses are low, could get by if they paid more than 30 percent of it in rent if they are in good health.
But those with lower incomes are in a bind, he said. Many single old people, particularly widows without pensions, have less than $6,000 in income. Taking 30 percent of that for rent leaves "almost nothing" for other expenses, he said.
The system also puts a disproportionate burden on large low-income families, he added, who often cannot afford food, education and clothing bills for their children after 30 percent of their income is claimed in rent.
For renters and homeowners alike, "housing costs make the first claim on income," Mr. Stone said. "They are large and inflexible, and the mistake people have made is in failing to fully consider how much they really need to have left over for nonshelter expenses."
 
THE KEY TO AID ELIGIBILITY
FOR people in publicly assisted housing programs designed to enhance affordability, the formulas used for eligibility across the nation are based on Government calulations of the median income for their area. Most who qualify pay 30 percent of their income in rent. Those in programs that enable them to purchase homes usually pay 28 percent of the income in mortgage, real estate taxes and insurance bills. But in some cases the limit for homeowners, as for renters, is 30 percent.
Critics of the system argue that median income -- at least as reported by the Federal Government -- is a flawed measure because it is calculated for metropolitan statistical areas, which include cities and some of their surrounding suburbs. In New York City, programs are administered on the basis of a median income figure of $32,401 for a family of four. But advocates for the poor say a more accurate figure would be $26,000 to $28,000.
More than 30 publicly assisted housing programs are administered in New York City and funded through city, state and Federal sources. Most are targeted for families with incomes up to 50 percent of the median, or $16,200, or between 50 percent and 80 percent of the median, or $26,001 to $32,400.
In New Jersey, the Mount Laurel court decision and the subsequent Fair Housing Act of 1985 require all communities to support housing affordable to low- and moderate income families. Low income is considered below 50 percent of the median, and moderate income is considered 50 percent to 80 percent of the median.
Median incomes are calculated for each New Jersey county, and they vary widely. For example, the median for a family of four in Hudson County is $32,100, in Bergen County it is $48,000 and in Morris County it is $43,700.
In Connecticut, housing officials rely on Federal median income figures for metropolitan statistical areas. For four-member families, they range from a median of $67,300 in the Stamford area to $40,200 in the Waterbury area. -- THOMAS J. LUECK

HEADLINE: Saving Energy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your article on Dec. 30 entitled "Audubon Society Creating Power-Saving Offices" on energy efficiency renovations planned for the National Audubon Society's headquarters in Manhattan did not mention that the new, high-efficiency, gas air-conditioning system in the society's Manhattan headquarters will be supported by an estimated $45,000 in rebates available through Con Edison's "Enlightened Energy" program. We also had helped fund the Natural Resources Defense Council building's lighting retrofit project, which already is paying energy bill dividends.
'Enlightened Energy" rebates are available to Con Edison customers for a wide variety of energy-saving applications, including high-efficiency lamps, ballasts and lighting controls, motors, and air conditioning systems. We also offer free energy audits as a first step in proving the economic benefits of energy efficiency.
 
DENNIS P. QUIRK
Manhattan
 
The writer is vice president in charge of energy services for the Consolidated Edison Company.

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

DRAWINGS OF WOMEN
 Mary Bell worked as a laundress for Isabel Lachaise, wife of the sculptor Gaston Lachaise, in Boston during the 1920's and 30's. At night she would go to her attic bedroom and draw simple pictures, mostly of women, in crayon and graphite. Thirty-six of her drawings are on exhibition through March 21 at the Yale Art Gallery in New Haven, preserved and in some cases commissioned by a coterie of intellectuals that included Carl Can Vechten, Gertrude Stein and Mr. Lachaise.
 "It's interesting that these people gave so much attention to this primitive black artist, in a rather condescending way, and so little attention to the serious, trained black artists of the period," said Marie Weltzien, spokeswoman for the gallery.
 Ms. Bell died in 1942 at the age of 69. Van Vechten, the photographer and writer, had commissioned 100 drawings from her between 1937 and 1939, and he was the author of numerous letters to her, to Lachaise, and to other local intellectuals. A selection of those letters is on view through Feb. 28 in the Beinecke Library at Yale, where the drawings and letters are part of the permanent collection.
 The exhibition was organized by Mary Kordak of the gallery staff and Theresa Leininger, a graduate student in art history. The gallery, at Chapel and York Streets, is open Tuesdays from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., Sundays from 2 to 5 P.M., and Thursday evenings from 5 to 8. The library is at 121 Wall Street, open Monday through Friday from 8:30 A.M. to 4:45 P.M. and on Saturday from 10 A.M. to 4:45 P.M. For more information call 432-0601.
 
'ALICE IN WONDERLAND'
 Michael Uthoff, director of the Hartford Ballet, has choreographed "Alice in Wonderland" to the music of Bach's Brandenburg Concerti and the California sound of Red Hot Chili Peppers. Combined with the contemporary visuals of Jerome Sirlin's other-worldly sets, the production has an appropriately wild unreality that should appeal to all ages.
 The world premiere performances are scheduled at the Bushnell in Hartford on Friday and Saturday at 7:30 P.M., with matinees at 2:30 P.M. on Saturday and 1 P.M. on Sunday. Tickets are priced from $10.50 to $40.50. The box office number is 246-6807.
 
BANNED BOOKS
 A series of four book discussions titled "Once Banned, Now Classic" begins at the Turn of River branch of the Stamford Public Library, 752 High Ridge Road, on Thursday at 7:30 P.M. Led by Catherine Riordan, the first session focuses on James Joyce's autobiographical novel "Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man."
 Subsequent evenings will be devoted to "Lady Chatterley's Lover" by D. H. Lawrence on Feb. 14; Mark Twain's "Adventures of Huckleberry Finn" on March 7, and "Native Son" by Richard Wright on March 28. Ms. Riordan, who received her Ph.D. on the development of the novel from Fordham University, will discuss the sociological climate in which each of the books was banned.
Copies of the books will be available for lending, and reading them is not a prerequisite for participating in the discussions. Admission is free.
 
WINTER FESTIVAL
 Whether the weather wanders from its recent low temperatures or not, the Eighth Annual Winter Fun Festival and Ice Harvest goes on as scheduled today from noon to 4 P.M. at the Inn on Lake Waramaug, 107 North Shore Road in New Preston.
 If necessary, snow will be imported to accommodate participants in the snowman and snow sculpture competitions and in the accurate snowball throwing contest. Members of the Inn's staff said the lake stays sufficiently frozen to provide fine demonstrations of ice cutting with antique tools. The blocks are raised with special poles for transportation to the icehouse.
 Visitors may watch the proceedings, take part in the contests and bring their skates for scooting out over the lake, all without charge. A bonfire will be fueled continuously, and hot cocoa and toddies will be available. Call 868-0563 for more information.
 
WALK WITH SKIS
 Experienced cross-country skiers are invited to take a nature walk on skis at the White Memorial Conservation Center in Litchfield on Saturday at 2 P.M. Paul Gros, chairman of the Conservation Commission of the Litchfield Hills Audubon Society, will lead the group, spotting winter wildlife in the fields and woodlands of the center's grounds. Mr. Gros leads such walks regularly, drawing on his expertise in skiing, hiking, birding and photography.
 The group will start from the museum entrance, south of Route 202 between Litchfield and Bantam. There is no charge for participating. Call 567-0857 and ask for the museum to obtain more information.
 
SEASCAPES FROM NEW ZEALAND
 A. D. Blake, a marine artist from New Zealand, is having his first American show at the Wind Borne Gallery, 559 Post Road in Darien, opening on Saturday with a reception from 4 to 8 P.M.
 Mr. Blake has been a sailor since he was 6 years old, placing second in a National Championship Race off the New Zealand coast, for which he designed his own 18-foot catamaran.
 After graduating with honors from Auckland University's Engineering School, he left his career as a civil engineer to devote himself to painting. His oils cover a wide range of historical and emotional scenes of the sea, from the great clipper ships of past centuries to modern ocean racers. The gallery is open Tuesday through Saturday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.
 
ROYAL ART
 Anglophiles and art lovers will find their milieu this week at the Yale Center for British Art; two lectures and a symposium have been organized around the current exhibition, "Crown Pictorial: Art and the British Monarchy."
 Tom Wood, English portraitist, will discuss "A Royal Commission: Painting Prince Charles" at 5:15 P.M. on Thursday, and Sir Roy Strong, a British art historian, will lecture on "Cecil Beaton and the Image of the British Monarchy" at 5:15 on Friday.
 The symposium is scheduled from 10:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. on Saturday. The morning session is composed of three talks -- "Royal Building: the First Thousand Years" by J. Mordaunt Crook, professor of architectural history at the University of London; "Royal Imagemaking: the First Fifty Years" by Duncan Robinson, director of the Center for British Art, and "The Economics of Visual Culture at the Early Stuart Court" by Malcolm Smuts, associate professor of history at the University of Massachusetts in Boston.
 From 2 to 4 P.M., Linda J. Colley, professor of history at Yale, will speak on "From Distance to Splendid Domesticity: The Construction of a Royal Esthetic 1650-1850"; Hermione Hobhouse, editor of Survey of London, will talk about "Prince Albert, Patron of the Arts and Sciences," and the final topic will be "The Monarchy, the Media and the Message: Representing Royalty from Victoria to Elizabeth" by David Cannadine, professor of history at Columbia University.
 Admission to all events is free. The center is at 1080 Chapel Street and the exhibition may be seen through Feb. 17 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesday through Saturday, and from 2 to 5 on Sunday. Call 432-2850 for more information.

HEADLINE: New Approach Is Offered for a White Plains Mall

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
STUNG by the effects of the recession, a White Plains developer has scaled down his proposal for a 75-store high-fashion shopping mall on the former Alexander's department store site. He has offered instead a 25-store complex that would attract bargain-conscious shoppers.
The developer's change in plans for the Westchester Pavilion, as the project is known, suggested uncertainty about the county's economic climate. But it was praised by local retailers and city officials as providing a needed balance for the White Plains retail market. 
 They say the new proposal, which was presented to the Planning Board on Jan. 10 and includes tenants like Filene's Basement and Toys 'R' Us, will complement rather than compete with the one-million-square-foot Fashion Mall that has been proposed for the adjacent site, where the former B. Altman's building now stands. The 150 speciality stores in the Fashion Mall proposal would fill 840,000 square feet of retail space and are expected to generate $24 million in sales-tax revenue. The rest of the space would provide parking.
 
'A Marriage Made in Heaven'
 The Fashion Mall proposal is now before the Planning Board. If it is approved, the anchor stores would include Neiman Marcus and the Seattle-based Nordstrom's department store. A third anchor store has not yet been named.
Discussing the potential interplay between the two projects, one local real-estate broker said, "It's a marriage made in heaven." The broker, David M. J. Saunders, owner of Saunders and Company in Rye, which works exclusively with retailers, cited the drawing power of popular value-oriented stores like Toys 'R' Us: "It's a classic real estate situation -- an upscale regional mall next door to a power center. Is a Neiman Marcus customer a Toys 'R' Us customer? Absolutely. Everybody is looking for a deal."
The new retail mix would have particular benefits for White Plains residents, several members of the Common Council agreed last week. "When Alexanders left, we lost a level of shopping very important to many people in White Plains," said Mary Ann Keenan, a member of the Council.
The new plan, however, eliminates the six-screen movie-theater complex that would have served the city's downtown, which now has only two movie theaters, both in the Galleria Shopping Mall. "We desperately need theaters," Mrs. Keenan said. "People need to be entertained if they are to patronize area restaurants, which keep opening and closing."
The developer cited space requirements as the reason the theaters were dropped. "The multiplex industry was looking for a larger number of theaters than we could provide," said J. Michael Divney, a partner in WP Centre Associates, a joint venture of the Hamilton Development Corporation of White Plains and Fischer-MacLeod Associates of Manhattan. "We couldn't accommodate eight or 10 theaters and still provide parking."
 
Seeking the Middle Market
 The new plan would meet the needs of the county's "very underserviced" middle-class market, Mr. Divney said, by providing stores that offer "a combination of quality and value." The new stores should appeal to a broad spectrum of customers, he added, because "people of every income level have become conscious of value."
The partnership purchased the Alexander's site, bordered by Post Road, South Broadway, Maple and Hale Avenues, in 1988 for $16 million. Soon after the search for stores began, Mr. Divney said, it became clear that potential tenants were concerned about worsening economic conditions. Competition from the proposed Fashion Mall was also a factor, he conceded, saying that some tenants made unreasonable requests for improvements. "They were playing us off against the potential of the other mall," he said.
As the credit market tightened and underwriting pressures increased, Mr. Divney said, "We realized we were chasing our tail and that we couldn't accomplish our goals."
But meanwhile, the partnership found that "high-quality, value-oriented" retailers were eager to find large spaces, he said. So the new concept was developed around those needs.
The cost of the new proposal is estimated to be $55 million, about half the cost of the original proposal; at 277,000 square feet, it is about 20 percent smaller than the original proposal. It provides for "up to" 25 stores instead of the 75 first planned.
The first plan had called for the Alexander's building to be demolished. Under the new proposal, only the top level of the parking structure would be removed. The building will be completely redesigned, Mr. Divney said, to resemble "the traditional city storefronts, with numerous display windows and awnings."
 
Existing Retailers Seem Pleased
 In interviews last week, local White Plains retailers appeared pleased about the retailing plan, which they said they believed would complement and stimulate a weak retail market along Mamaroneck Avenue, the main downtown shopping area, which is mostly value-oriented.
"These are value-oriented stores that will appeal to the local area and bring in local traffic," said Julian DiDonato, president of the White Plains Merchants Association, an organization of 45 downtown store owners.
"We are real happy that the space is being used," said Mr. DiDonato, the owner of Dakota Drygoods, a men's and women's apparel store on Mamaroneck Avenue. "There is nothing worse for the downtown than a vacancy, especially one that large."
Thirty-two stores are currently vacant among the 150 located along Mamaroneck Ave, Mr. DiDonato said, the highest vacancy rate in a decade.
Local store owners are pleased that the original "pedestrian friendly" design for the Westchester Pavilion has been retained, one that features numerous street-level entrances. They hope this factor will encourage shoppers to walk to and from Mamaroneck Avenue to the Westchester Pavilion.
Mr. DiDonato said he was still concerned about the potential impact of the proposed Fashion Mall on White Plains retailing. Its enclosed design, he said, would limit pedestrian access and make the complex "an island in the middle of White Plains."
 
Would Some Stores Relocate?
 Local retailers and several Common Council members said they also were worried that existing high-quality stores in the Galleria and along Mamarmoneck Avenue would be tempted to relocate to the Fashion Mall, leaving more empty spaces.
It was these issues, as well as the pace of development here that helped elect Robert E. Greer, a Democrat, to the White Plains Common Council in the last election, giving the Democrats a majority for the first time in 15 years. With a campaign slogan asking, "How Much Is Too Much?," Mr. Greer said his victory reflected voter concern about just how much retail and office development the city needs.
The new Democratic majority on the Common Council strongly supports a $250,000 traffic study, approved unanimously in October by the the previous Council. The study might not be completed until next fall, and Democrats say they must have a completed study before they consider approving plans for the Fashion Mall.
The O'Connor Group, the Manhattan developers of the Fashion Mall, said it needs a commitment from the Common Council by April. "It's absolutely essential," said Jerry O'Connor, the company's president. "The agreement we have with Nordstrom's is for a 1993 opening, and we must have a commitment on or about April 1 if we are to have a chance of opening in 1993."
 
'Too Big a Decision'
 But Dennis Power, a Democrat on the Common Council, said: "A lot of White Plains's future depends on how we are able to deal with traffic. The city doesn't have to be held captive to one store. Nordstrom's would be very appealing, but there is more than one plan or one store we could consider. This is too big a decision."
Other members of the Council said they were concerned about the rapid pace of development in White Plains, whose population of 47,000 swells to nearly 300,000 each workday. To build too much more, they say, could alter the character of the city in unacceptable ways.
"Could this be the kiss of death for Mamaroneck Avenue?" Rita Z. Malmud, a Democratic member of the Common Council, asked about the proposed Fashion Mall. "I need careful study before I grant special permission to a new project that might greatly hurt White Plains."
Mrs. Malmud said she was concerned about the amount of retailing the city can or should sustain. "This is a city of homes," Mrs. Malmud said. "And while we want to keep a healthy commercial and retailing section, we don't want to strangle the healthy home life that is here."
Mayor Alfred Del Vecchio, a strong supporter of development in the city, did not respond to repeated telephone calls to his office last week requesting comment.
 
A Fear of Losing Nordstrom's
 Accusing the Democrats on the Council of acting in a partisan manner, Michael A. Coffey, a Republican member, said he was worried that "Nordstrom's will walk away." He liked the concept of the Fashion Mall, he said, and added: "I want to keep Mamaroneck Avenue thriving. But the retailing community is always changing."
While the merits of the Fashion Mall is debated by the Council, support for the Westchester Pavilion seems more certain. The original project received unanimous Council approval for a change in zoning soon after it was last year, and site-plan approval of the new design seems likely.
Leases with Toys 'R' Us and Filene's Basement, now in the final stage of negotiation, may be signed by the end of the month, Mr. Divney said, adding that "intense discussions" were being held with four other tenants.
When these negotiations are complete, he said, financial underwriters of the project will be satisfied and an opening by next Christmas could be possible. "Once we get over the initial hurdle," Mr. Divney said, "we won't have space for all the tenants who want to be there."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Mr. Hussein, Please Surrender

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
From the way the world's markets reacted last week, one would have thought that victory in Iraq had already been won. The Dow Jones industrial average gained more points than it ever had in a week, amid general rejoicing over early success in the air war.
The buying, which sent the Dow up 145.29 points, or 5.8 percent, to 2,646.78, reflects hopes for a lovely bullish scenario. That calls for a victory in Iraq to send the price of oil spiraling down, providing extra cash for newly confident consumers to spend. And that spending, in turn, makes the American recession short and relatively painless. 
 That scenario has a lot to recommend it, if only because the alternatives are not fun to contemplate. If things do not pick up, the high leverage of the 1980's threatens to create a wave of defaults, doing severe damage to the economy -- to the extent that the Government does not choose to pick up the tab -- or to the currency, to the extent it does.
From city hall in Philadelphia to Rupert Murdoch's three-continent media empire, the other important battles going on involve debtors pleading for cash.
Both Philadelphia and Mr. Murdoch were claiming victories last week in arranging temporary financing to tide them over until something else turns up. Philadelphia is so desperate it will pay an effective interest rate of something like 24 percent on its $150 million short-term loan. The News Corporation, which Mr. Murdoch controls, is to get $600 million from its banks while stretching out repayments on its existing loans. It is expected to pay a fee of about $85 million for the loan, plus another $85 million in three years. Unless a snag develops, the cash should be forthcoming by next week.
News Corporation owns assets ranging from The Times of London to an Australian sheep ranch, and including Twentieth Century-Fox, the studio with this year's surprise hit, "Home Alone." It earns enough money to cover its interest payments, but not, alas, enough to make principal payments. The bank deal will give it time to find buyers for a billion or two worth of assets.
It is not Mr. Murdoch's fault that there are recessions in Britain, Australia and the United States, his three primary markets. But it was his choice to pay high prices for TV Guide and other acquisitions in the 80's and to finance his purchases with short-term debt. He evidently assumed he could always sell equity or long-term bonds if necessary.
Now, with both the bond and equity markets effectively closed to him, Mr. Murdoch may be forced to surrender a significant amount of management freedom to the banks that only a year ago were clamoring for the privilege of lending him money.
Mr. Murdoch has always landed on his feet, but to do so again he has only a limited amount of time to find buyers willing to pay good prices for some subsidiaries. The best hope for News Corporation, and for a lot of other companies that borrowed too much, is that last week's rosy market scenario will turn out to be accurate.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
A Direct Hit on the Pessimists

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
One thing the intensive air attacks on Iraq did last week was knock out the war pessimists. Money managers and analysts who had worried that a war would not go well, even at the beginning, were transformed by the success the United States and its allies had in the air. Even the Iraqi attack on Israel on the second day of fighting did not significantly undermine this confidence, as reflected in the rise in stock markets in Japan and the United States Friday and the relatively small declines in Europe.
"I stand agog at what has gone on in the markets," said David Roche, an international strategist, referring to the worldwide rallies in markets Thursday, just hours after the bombing of Iraq began. 
 The main market indexes in Germany and France jumped record amounts. The Nikkei 225 in Tokyo rose more than 1,000 points, or 4.47 percent, and the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 114.60, or more than 4.5 percent, the largest one-day point gain since just after the 1987 market crash.
 "I was wrong because I assumed that Saddam Hussein was more efficient," said Mr. Roche, a managing director at Morgan Stanley & Company in London. "I went wrong militarily."
Investors counting on a negative reaction to the opening of hostilities were disappointed, showing that conventional wisdom can lead one astray. Because stocks did not fall with the start of fighting, those who had hoped to buy on a decline lost out. Indeed, the rallies were so strong and rapid, it was difficult to buy at all.
There were rude surprises in other markets, too. Gold, which was around $400 an ounce before the fighting started Wednesday night, jumped quickly to $410 to $412. But then it fell a near-record $30 Thursday and ended Friday at $374.20 on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
And as the week ended, the dollar continued to sag; by Friday it was worth less than 1.50 marks, a decline of 3 percent since the war began. There was no boost from the fighting, as many had thought there would be, partly because the battle went so well so soon. This defiance of consensus expectations is a good reminder of the weak economic fundamentals underlying the American currency.
But success so far in the war has not done much to change the opinions of pessimists and optimists on the underlying outlook for the world economy -- and the stock and bond markets that feed on its performance. As with the dollar, the fighting has not changed the need to remember the economic fundamentals still in play. Some of the problems that the world's economies and markets are facing -- including recessions marked by a dearth of consumer confidence -- can be alleviated by a quick war but aggravated by a protracted one.
Nor does the success so far of the United States-led coalition eliminate the chance for major setbacks. More attacks on Israel are possible, as well as Israeli retaliation against Iraq. And the ground fighting, which is still ahead, could get quite bloody.
The optimists, like Roger Palmer, the overall strategist at Kleinwort Benson Securities in London, believe that even with some setbacks, the markets will not fall that sharply. The reason: an abundance of investors who missed the Thursday rally, many of who will scramble to get in when there are downward corrections.
"Having already missed the boat, they will be keen not to miss it again," Mr. Palmer said. This is why the declines in Europe on Friday were so slight, he added.
The optimists also argue that the underlying outlook for markets around the world is not that bad. They say a quick war -- of which they are much more confident now -- will bring down oil prices, revive consumer confidence and insure that the slowdown in Continental Europe and Japan and the recessions in the United States, Britain, Canada and Australia will not be prolonged.
But others, including Mr. Roche and Heinz Hockmann, managing director at Commerz International Capital Management in Frankfurt, are still pessimistic about the economy, even if less so about the war. While a decline in oil prices and interest rates would help struggling economies, they point to problems in the banking systems in the United States and Japan, the general shortage of capital and the deterioration of both the Government and economy in the Soviet Union. These problems, they say, cast a long shadow over the world's economy, notwithstanding a good outcome in the war.
"There is more mood than real economic activity behind this," Mr. Hockmann said of last week's rally. "We do not see the need to jump on the train."
Another reason to question boarding is the impact of the rally itself. The sharp rises have made some markets that were good values a little overpriced.
"Yesterday, I would have said France," said Martin Paling, international investment strategist at James Capel Ltd. in London, when asked on Thursday about a market that was cheap. "But after a 7 percent rise, it needs a correction." And Germany, which had fallen sharply this year, has quickly moved back into expensive territory.

HEADLINE: Food Shortages, Now Violence Make Soviet Investing Dicier

BYLINE: By JOEL KURTZMAN

 BODY:
At the same time as war engulfs the Middle East, the Soviet Union continues to unravel both politically and economically. After five years, the democratic reforms and economic liberalization initiated by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev seem to be backfiring, threatening, among other things, the future of thousands of joint-venture plans between Western and Soviet enterprises, only a small fraction of which are in place.
Last month, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Schevardnadze resigned, expressing fears that the country was moving toward dictatorship. A week ago, Soviet troops moved tanks and machine guns into Lithuania, killing 15 demonstrators among the thousands demanding independence for the republic. The violence touched off protests throughout the country and around the world. Despite roadblocks, hundreds of thousands of ethnic Russians, Poles and Byelorussians walked to Vilnius later in the week to attend the funerals of the demonstrators and quietly protest Moscow's rule. To surpress criticism of his administration for its actions in Lithuania, President Gorbachev advocated suspending a law that guarantees a free press. The White House said the Soviet Army's actions threatened next month's summit meeting between the two heads of state. 
 Boris N. Yeltsin, the popular president of Russia, the largest and wealthiest of the republics, continues to challenge Mr. Gorbachev's leadership. At Mr. Yeltsin's urging, the Russian Parliament voted last month to reduce by 90 percent its payments to the Soviet central government, threatening the government with bankruptcy.
"The entire distribution system has broken down," said Charles Hugel, a former chairman of Asea Brown Boveri Inc.
In most cities, consumer goods are nonexistent and, despite a record harvest, food is scarce. The United States has extended $1 billion worth of credits to help the Soviet Union buy American grain, but many analysts predict even this will not be enough to stave off starvation.
The problem, according to Arthur Hartman, a former Ambassador to the Soviet Union, is that those opposed to reform have deliberately brought about the disintegration of the society.
What has happened to the Soviet Union and where is it headed? Five experts present their views.

 
 
JUDY SHELDON
Research fellow, the Hoover Institution; author of "The Coming Soviet Crash"
 The Soviet Union is now on the verge of civil war and Western investors will get burned. They are in the same position as they were just before the Bolshevik revolution. Then, France had one-quarter of its foreign investment in Russia. It lost it all. Countries that are now overinvested in the Soviet Union could be in a similar situation.
We will continue to see more sporadic incidents of violence in Lithuania, Georgia and the Ukraine and more people will get killed. It will be calculated violence that will be used in an attempt to quash the independence movement. But there is no way President Gorbachev can cow the people back into the old system.
Mr. Gorbachev is like Moses -- able to lead the people out of Egypt but not into the promised land. Unlike Moses, he won't step down voluntarily. But he can't remain. I wouldn't say that there will be anything as dramatic as an assassination, but perhaps the People's Deputies will remove him. In any event, he will be phased out. I can't imagine this situation going unresolved for another six to nine months.
At the same time, the economy is absolutely falling apart. The one who is causing most of it is Mr. Yeltsin of the Russian republic. He is saying that when push comes to shove, his territory is Russia. He is creating a pattern will be followed by the other republics, which will also say that they don't have to share their wealth with Moscow. As a result, revenues to Moscow will fall off, causing the union to disintigrate. It will go bankrupt.
In eight to 10 years, there will be a federation of republics. In terms of a model, Canada would be a good choice. But this will come after the republics really understand what they have to gain by coming together.
 
ANTHONY M. SOLOMON
Institute for East-West Security Studies, in New York City.

I am convinced that President Gorbachev has lost his maneuvering room because of the actions at Vilnius. He can no longer go back and forth between the economic reformers and the conservatives. He is now locked into the conservatives, the military and the K.G.B. The implications are that there will not be any more economic reform from Mr. Gorbachev.
From now on, the only way there will be any meaningful reform is from Mr. Yeltsin and the heads of other republics as they confront Mr. Gorbachev. Mr. Yeltsin is vigorously supporting the Baltics. He could even call for civil disobedience. He has cards he can play and he may be able to organize the other republics to go along with him.
Will the new repression be able to intimidate all 15 republics? In the short run -- a few months or even years -- yes, it will. But in the long run, you can't intimidate 290 million people. Especially as the economic situation goes to pot with a 5 percent drop in national income this year after a 4 percent drop last year.
If you look at economic reform in the Soviet Union, you see that much of it has been divorced from reality anyway. For example, there has been a big bank reform, which looks reasonable on paper. Although there is now a central bank, reform can't be meaningfully implemented as long as there is still a command-economy structure that subsidizes the losses of the large state-owned enterprises. By subsidizing losses, the Government has lost control of the money supply. For example, Izvestia, the Soviet newspaper, said that instead of a 60 billion ruble deficit in 1991, the Government would have a 250 billion ruble deficit. To pay for this, the Government can only increase the money supply. It has no other way to finance its deficit. This will add even more to inflation.
 
VLADIMIR KVINT
U.S.S.R. Professor of Political Economy; former professor in Moscow.
March will bring a drastic worsening of the economic situation in the Soviet Union because the last reserves of food will have been eaten. The cattle will have been slaughtered so there will be no meat. Hunger will make the political situation dramatically worse. President Gorbachev is now astride two beasts, the K.G.B. and the military. Western food aid will only go to feed those two beasts, it will not get to the people. I fear President Gorbachev's revolution will turn into a civil war.
The truth is that Mr. Gorbachev did not want to move to a market economy while the old economic system was still alive. Now the old system is dead, but there is no new one. The economy just can't produce. The army might force the people go to work, but it can't get them to do anything once there.
What makes me angry is that so many people are asking if Mr. Gorbachev gave the order to use tanks in Lithuania. He said he didn't know about it, but who else in the Soviet Union can give orders now? The Council of Ministers is practically abolished, the Prime Minister was in the hospital, the President's Council has been abolished and Alexander Yakovlev and and Mr. Schevardnadze, the main promoters of democracy on Gorbachev's team, are gone.
There is not a lot of hope for Western investment. The big Chevron joint venture is is largely in Kazakhstan, which is unstable. The Combustion Engineering and Occidental Petroleum projects were oriented to the decisions of the old centralized system and did not sufficiently take account of the independence movements of the individual republics. And Occidental didn't take into account the ecological catastrophes occurring in the region where it is located.
 
CHARLES HUGEL
National Foreign Trade Council; formerly with Asea Brown Boveri Inc.
 It has been evident in the last year that the country has lost its command structure, so it is possible that the troops could have killed the demonstrators in Lithuania without President Gorbachev's knowledge. With the command structure gone, the country is moving to a state of anarchy. But although people are concerned about a civil war, I can't see it happening. The people there are not armed. They have no organization and nothing to pull them together. They just don't have the ability to wage war. I also don't think starvation will occur. There is plenty of food. The problem is getting the food to the people; it is part of the anarchy.
The trend toward anarchy is what Mr. Gorbachev is trying to deal withnow. Making Valentin S. Pavlov the Prime Minister is a good sign for business. He is a trained financial person, knows Western markets and is a proponent of the market system. His son spent time in New York, working for a major bank. I think this says that the reforms are still on course; that the Soviet Union is still moving to become a market economy.
Mr. Schevernadze's replacement as Foreign Minister, Aleksandr Bessmertnykh, is also a positive sign. He knows the United States, because he was Ambassador here and has lived here. His appointment says to me that Mr. Gorbachev is concerned with the way the United States views him. I think Mr. Gorbachev will remain in power.
What the loss of a command structure means for business is that you can't get decisions that were made in Moscow carried out in the republics. The Soviet Unionwas never an easy place to do business, and these events haven't made it any easier. But it has enormous wealth. The people that run it just don't know how to run businesses. I think they are going to make it, but it will take a long, long time -- 20 or 30 years.
 
ARTHUR HARTMAN
Apco Associates, Washington; former Ambassodor to the Soviet Union.
The events in Lithuania signal quite a reactionary step backwards. The picture emerging is one of a reassertion of authority by the old elements that have been against change, those who have been in charge of the command system have now returned to stop all moves toward reform.
In addition, the reason for the poor performance of Mr. Gorbachev's reforms and for the disintegration of the economic system is that the old guard -- the bureaucrats -- fought back deliberately against the reforms in an alliance with the K.G.B. and the military.
The Soviet Union may be on the brink of civil war with the military authorities who have attempted to set up nonexistent reasons for intervention similar to the reasons they gave for intervening in Hungary and Czechoslovakia a generation ago. This is not a static situation, however. The bureaucrats have been entrenched since before the Bolshevik revolution. It was too much to hope they would be driven out in one leap.
But I am heartened by a couple of things. Some of the elected representatives in parliament are reform minded. I don't think they will go back home and do nothing.
There are also some new institutions like the Council of Nations, made up of the presidents of the republics. Most significant is that Mr. Yeltsin has spoken out against the Baltic problems and called on Russian troops in the Soviet Army in the Baltics to disobey their orders. Outside of Moscow, people are taking seriously the words used in the reform legislation. They are beginning the privatization process and forming cooperatives. They would like to take over gas and oil and the country's biggest paper plant -- something too big for them, but it is heartening.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/January 13-18

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

WAR IN THE GULF
 
Why Can't America Make a VCR to Match Its F-117?
 
Radar-jamming F4-G Wild Weasels carrying antiradiation missiles disrupted Iraqi defenses Wednesday night. As F-117 stealth fighters led the attack, the skies were initially all theirs. The first reports indicated that America's technological superiority was manifest. So why can't the United States make the world's best VCR's? Or subcompact cars? Scholars say the nation's military sophistication at best leaves its economic competitiveness unharmed. "Defense needs are not the same as civilian needs in most industries," said Michael E. Porter of Harvard Business School in his recent book. Defense products can sometimes serve other ends; the first military jet transport evolved into the Boeing 707. But sometimes, he said, military contracts merely blunt healthy business competition. Paul Kennedy, a Yale historian, goes further, saying that the nation's military responsibilities are eroding its economic advantages. "Rome fell; Babylon fell; Scarsdale's turn will come," he said. Only the week before last, the Pentagon canceled a $57 billion program to build a new Navy attack plane when the ultimate cost appeared far greater than Scarsdale and the rest of the nation can afford.

Traders in Battle
 
American traders were as awesomely prepared as the military for war in the Middle East: all set for a furious aerial battle, the destruction of Saudi oil refineries and panic buying of oil. They had pored over tables showing that when war breaks out, investors dump stocks. And so, when American jets flew virtually unopposed Wednesday night and the Saudis initially escaped with damage to a single storage tank, traders were able to change course faster than F-15's. On Thursday, the Dow climbed 114.60 points on heavy volume, the second-best day ever. Oil futures dropped by more than $10 a barrel in a day, then, on Friday, fell by $2.19, to $19.25. And yet, the euphoria may prove fleeting; William H. Donaldson, the New York Stock Exchange Chairman, warned investors against acting in haste.

Oil Companies React to War
 
The oil companies responded to the American assault with their own patriotic proclamations. Terrified of seeming to profiteer from a war, they announced wholesale price freezes and restricted deliveries of gasoline. Then oil prices fell. Companies quickly rewrote their press releases to define the frozen price levels as ceilings.
 
CNN's Coup
 
Gen. Colin L. Powell tuned in to CNN for the latest from Baghdad, and Tom Brokaw interviewed one of its correspondents when NBC's own line to Iraq went dead. On Wednesday night the network scored its highest ratings ever, with 11 million homes tuning in. Gripping accounts of the attack on Baghdad from the only three reporters able to stay on the air throughout the evening gave CNN an audience in a class with the three broadcast networks for the first time. As the networks economize, CNN boasts of its advantage in covering crises abroad. Ted Turner's challenge has been to keep everyone watching once trouble subsides.
 
Several television advertisers pulled their commercials off the air during war coverage last week. Some said that the upbeat news so far was encouraging them to return.
 
A Damper on Airlines
 
Nothing is worse for airlines than higher fuel prices and a recession. The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, lost $215.1 million in the fourth quarter, its worst quarterly loss ever. The UAL Corporation, which runs United Airlines, also expects to report its worst quarter. And the fuel costs contributed to the shutdown of Eastern Airlines. International airlines said the war had caused some cancellations, but domestic lines saw little difference. Airline executives hope that last week's plunge in oil prices will bring them relief.
 
Meanwhile . . . in Lithuania
 
With the United States and Western Europe preoccupied in the Middle East, the Soviet Army assaulted Lithuanian patriots last week. Tanks and armored personnel carriers rolled through a crowd to seize the republic's broadcasting tower. James H. Giffen, chairman of the Mercator Corporation, said the underlying issues concern control of Soviet property, tax revenues and lawmaking. He spoke of having to negotiate a Soviet oil-drilling agreement with four agencies where, in the old days, one would do. "Am I distressed by it as an investor? Yes," he said. He expects business conditions to improve when an All-Union agreement is signed, but few other analysts are as optimistic.
 
 
 
COMPANIES


Last Flight at Eastern
 
Eastern Airlines shut down at midnight Friday, the victim of labor strife, disaffected travelers, fuel costs and leverage. Founded in 1928, the airline was the favorite ticket for millions of pallid Northerners seeking to bask in the Florida or Caribbean sun. Eastern has struggled to turn a profit since filing for bankruptcy protection almost two years ago in the grip of a strike. About 5,000 of 18,000 employees face immediate dismissal. Assets to be sold include 190 planes and some routes that rivals covet. But travelers are bound to emerge happier than unsecured creditors. The court has set aside $50 million to reimburse holders of Eastern tickets.
 
A Difficult Time for Banks
 
Thomas H. Hanley, a managing director at Salomon Brothers, has analyzed the banking industry for 24 years, but the fourth quarter of 1990 shocked him. "I've never seen anything like it," he said. "It's probably the most difficult quarter during the entire postwar era." For most banks, the only question was whether earnings and bad loans were as awful as expected, or worse. Citicorp had already predicted large losses, but Manufacturers Hanover had seemed relatively safe from real estate woes. A few of the strongest banks, like J.P. Morgan and BankAmerica, had stronger earnings, and lower interest rates helped many banks improve their margins. But analysts say there is no end to bank losses in sight.
 
I.B.M. Beats the Recession
 
The International Business Machines Corporation defied the recession by reporting higher earnings and revenues in the fourth quarter. Net income rose fourfold to $2.46 billion, from a final quarter a year ago that included heavy charges for cutting the work force. The company's operating income still rose 16.1 percent. I.B.M.'s chairman, John F. Akers, cautioned that global uncertainties lie ahead.
 
Bankruptcy's Yield
 
Truth in labeling comes to Wall Street: Bear, Stearns & Company announced the creation last week of a new, merged department of bankruptcy and high-yield trading and sales. "What can I tell you?" said a Bear Stearns representative. "Bankruptcy and high yield seem to have something to do with each other." The new department's two leaders have the right experience. Nancy Havens-Hasty made a well-timed move in 1987 from the firm's risk arbitrage department to its bankruptcy group, and Donald Mullen was a managing director at Salomon Brothers in high-yield sales.
 
At Oxy, No Sacred Cattle
 
Ray R. Irani wants everyone to know that all the changes he plans at the Occidental Petroleum Corporation are no reflection on the Armand Hammer legacy. Circumstances change, Mr. Irania said. And so he christened "the new Oxy" -- his words -- last week. He intends to concentrate on oil and chemicals, sell $3 billion in assets, take a $2 billion charge against earnings and cut the dividend from $2.50 to $1 a share. It so happens that many of the money-losing businesses up for sale were Dr. Hammer's favorites, among them a Soviet petrochemical project, Chinese coal mining, Arabian horses, Black Angus cattle and the film production company whose perennial star was Dr. Hammer himself.
 
Daily News's Future Dims
 
The Daily News threatened on Wednesday to close or seek a buyer by early April unless it stems losses that it says are running at $1 million a day. The announcement gave the newspaper's nine striking unions a choice of signing new, cost-cutting contracts or facing the permanent loss of jobs. The Tribune Company, the corporate parent, demands as much as $70 million in labor cuts and the right to make future changes in work rules without having to bargain. Miscalculations may have brought The News to this point. Tribune executives did not sell the newspaper when it still had a circulation of 1.1 million and loyal advertisers; union concessions would make it far more valuable, they figured. Now at least half the readers, most of the advertisers and probably most potential buyers have deserted. Only a pile of unfunded liabilities remains.

 
 
THE ECONOMY


Few Inflation Fears
 
Was anyone fretting last week about the highest annual inflation rate since 1981? Certainly not most economists, and probably not the Fed. True, the 6.1 percent increase in consumer prices for 1990, up from 4.6 percent in 1989, could not be attributed entirely to the cost of oil. "We still have some problems," said Joseph A. Wahed, senior economist at Wells Fargo. "Service costs are high. Medical costs are high." But the raging price increases of a few months ago have quieted, leaving December's index just three-tenths of 1 percent higher than in November. Inflation seems so much less of a threat than continued recession that those close to Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan said he has wanted to lower interest rates faster all along, but those pesky presidents of the Fed's regional banks would not let him. Mr. Greenspan has made no apologies; he reportedly said last week that lower oil prices and interest rates could help ease the recession.
In Brief
 
The White House plans to ask Congress for an additional $80 billion to rescue 225 more failing savings and loan institutions. Legislators reacted sceptically. By next month, the Government expects to exhaust the $50 billion bailout fund set aside last year.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
U.S. Technology Won't Win the War

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:
The sophisiticated war equipment fashioned by military contractors may not be enough to win a war in the Persian Gulf, according to Steven L. Canby, a retired lieutenant colonel in the Army Reserve. Mr. Canby, a Ph.D. in economics from Harvard University, contends that the American military has spent too much on technology and paid too little attention to strategy. Currently an adjunct professor of national security studies at Georgetown University, he spoke about the cost of a gulf war with Joel Kurtzman of The New York Times. 
 Question. Can you assess the cost of a gulf war?
Answer. The cost of the war depends on the strategy. If we had stayed with a blockade, the costs would be very low. The main costs are the additional or incremental costs, since the basic costs, like the soldiers' salaries, are paid whether or not there is war. The incremental costs are largely the cost of ammunition, the costs of moving troops, maintaining supplies, the cost of extra training and the cost of mobilizing reserves.
The estimates of these costs are arrived at this way: If there were a war in Europe, these incremental costs would be about $4 billion a day. This war will be smaller, so the estimates are that it will cost between $1 billion and $2 billion a day should fighting start. This will be averaged over the length of the fighting.
But this estimate does not include the cost of the consumables. It does not include the cost of lost equipment or lost aircraft. For example, an F-15 jet costs between $40 million and $50 million depending on how it's equipped. At this price, during war, it won't take long before total costs are several billion dollars a day.
The loss rate for equipment is very heavy. In the first few days of the last Arab-Israeli war, hundreds of tanks and airplanes were lost. There was a very high equipment cost almost at once.
If the war is short -- and everything works -- it could be a big boost to the economy. America will be seen as great. The Taiwanese, who have been withdrawing their money from our banks for a long time, will put that money back. But if we get bogged down, it will be a big negative.
Q. America is banking on its superior technology to win. Why are you doubtful about this strategy?
A. The technology is overrated. What people forget is that most of the money has gone into the Air Force and Navy, where we are already overwhelmingly superior. It hasn't gone into new technology for ground forces. I don't think our ground forces are that superior to Iraq's when it comes to technology. We do have lots of gadgets, but in basic weapons, we're not so superior.
For example, we're inferior in artillery and our infantry weapons are roughly equivalent. We have a better tank, but the M1 is a real gas guzzler. It has wonderful electronics, but it burns so much fuel that it doesn't have much reach. And it doesn't have a bulldozer blade up front and that's a great limitation in the desert. It can't scoot into position.
The Navy has real superiority, but much of it is irrelevant. The aircraft carriers are in the Gulf of Oman and in the Red Sea, far from Iraq. The airplanes they launch have to be refueled in the air to go into battle. This limits the number of sorties.
The Air Force has problems of interdiction. Its planes are vulnerable to shoulder-held missiles and other relatively simple air defense systems. We have overwhelming air superiority, but do we use those hyper-expensive airplanes to go after trucks in the desert?
Q. Is the problem with the weapons or how they are used?
A. The problem is with how the forces are deployed. Most of the information I have says that the forces can only make a frontal attack and a shallow left hook, or flanking attack. But in this situation, that's a trap.
As long as Iraq's Republican Guards, which are its best troops, are concentrated in Basra, Saddam Hussein has a very powerful force for us to overcome in Kuwait. With that force there, we're making a mistake by attacking frontally. If we do, which seems to be the plan, we play into Saddam's hands. Superior technology and all the money we spent won't matter.
Q. Is this what the Iraqis are betting on?
A. I think Saddam Hussein came to the conclusion we would back down because our troops are headed for his most heavily defended areas. He concluded our use of ground forces is not credible.
Q. But doesn't most of the analysis say the fighting will be primarily in the air?
A. The American plan seems to have three phases: First, lots of airpower to take out the Scud missiles. I think that our forces will be successful there, but winning air superiority will not be that easy or inexpensive. A lot of planes will be lost.
The second phase is the heavy use of airpower and battle ships. There is the hope that this bombardment will destroy Iraq's fortifications for a later infantry attack.
The final phase is an infantry attack on Kuwait. But what the Israelis found out very painfully is that when Arab troops were attacked frontally, they performed well. The Israelis learned they had to attack from behind to get the Arab troops out of their positions. In the field, the Arab troops panic. But our plan is to make frontal attacks.
Q. But if the first phases are successful, won't the other parts of the plan fall into place?
A. The issue is really strategy, generalship and diplomacy. The proper way to undertake this war would be to have American and Turkish troops in Turkey. From there they would threaten Baghdad. Troops from Syria could also threaten Baghdad.
That would draw the Republican Guards out of Basra and Kuwait to defend Baghdad. It would make Iraq's best troops vulnerable to air attack as they went back to Baghdad, which would play into our strengths. It would shift the center of gravity of the fighting.
But you can't do this because the Turks won't allow it. My understanding is the Turks -- as a price for entering into this fight and for allowing American troops to attack from the north -- wanted to be able to join the European Community. But Hans-Dietrich Genscher, Germany's Foreign Minister, doesn't want the Turks in the Community. As a result, the Turks haven't been persuaded to allow our troops to pose a threat from their soil, which would give them a strategic advantage. That has nothing to do with technology.

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
A Buick Show Car Takes to the Road

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
Think luxury cars today and you'll probably think imports. Mercedes-Benz. BMW. Lexus. Infiniti. You might even think Lincoln or Cadillac, but you probably wouldn't think Buick.
A big part of that, no doubt, is the pinch-penny philosophy that led General Motors to homogenize its cars in the 80's, building Buicks on the same line with Chevys and using parts from the same bins. Certainly, the lack of distinctive design hurt Cadillac, an insult to "The Standard of the World" that has only recently been redressed. 
 But G.M.'s thinking has changed up and down the line, and Buick's Park Avenue Ultra is just the latest in a series of good examples. It is also likely to put Buick back where it once was, as Middle America's aspiration.
The Park Avenue is that rare bird, a designer's toy that grew full feathers as a production model. Fresh out of the egg, the Buick was called "Essence," and it made the tour of the auto shows back in 1989, a concept car dressed in exquisite blue green paint.
In more conservative hue (dark metallic blue, in the case of the tester), it has taken to the road as a front-drive four-door sedan, sleek, polished, full of high-tech and very pleasant indeed.
For '91, the Electra nameplate has been dropped, and the Park Avenue Ultra is Buick's flagship. It is moderately big, eight inches longer than its predecessor, and the extra space has been added to the rounded trunk. Roundness is, in fact, everywhere, and the combination of shape and flush glass has produced a thoroughly aerodynamic .31 coefficient of drag.
In addition, the body's structure has been redesigned and strengthened, both for safety and a feeling of solidity. To that end, the number of parts required to build the car has been reduced by 25 percent, and the company calls it the quietest and smoothest sedan Buick has ever offered.
Inside, our car had blue leather and -- surprisingly for a Buick -- full instrumentation, including a 7,000-r.p.m. tachometer. There was a 200-watt sound system with built-in compact-disk player, and the radio actually was easy to tune. That's because G.M., unlike most other manufacturers, has had the good sense to keep knobs on its radios instead of hard-to-use arrow switches. Compliments to the chef.
On the other hand, the Buick has rear windows that go down less than half way, and that is inexcusable in a car this size. And then there is the silly bin in the armrest between the front seats, the one made to hold tape cassettes. In a car that has only a CD player, it sort of makes one wonder.
But there are thoughtful touches, too: a cupholder and place for toll change, a good big ashtray, six-way power seats with memory, and dual temperature controls so driver and front-seat passenger can tailor two sorts of climate.
In fact, ambient comfort has been given a lot of attention in the Park Avenue, and "solar-control" glass makes its debut all round. The glass reduces solar heat by as much as 30 percent, and it cuts ultraviolet rays by almost half.
What that means is a more comfortable interior, increased efficiency for the air-conditioner and longer life for interior materials. And, just to make sure everything stays cozy, twin sun sensors on the dash compensate for interior warming and automatically maintain the temperatures selected by driver and front-seat passenger.
For safety, there is an air bag in the hub of the leather-wrapped wheel, and antilock brakes are standard. But there is further technostuff, including an oil-life monitor to help a driver cope in these days of self-service gas stations.
The monitor measures engine temperature, average revolutions per minute and vehicle speed, then calculates the projected life of the oil and tells the driver when to change it. Control of the new four-speed automatic transmission also is handled by electronics, with shift points figured out for smoothness by the same computer that manages the 3.8-liter V6.
The engine, mounted transversely, puts out 170 horsepower, sufficient to propel the 3,662-pound boulevardier to 60 miles an hour in about 9.5 seconds. That is comfortably quick, and it is enough to get you safely off the ramp and onto the highway, even if it won't win many drag races.
But Buick buyers won't care about that. What they will care about is the gas they can save, with economy rated at 18, city, and 27, highway. They will care about the pretty face, about the appointments and about the silky ride.
In fact, there is only one thing missing. With a sticker of about $29,000, you don't get to pay the new luxury tax.

HEADLINE: The War Machine Drives U.S. Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, Michael Boskin, now acknowledges that "after the longest economic expansion in the peacetime history of the United States, the country probably has entered a recession" (Business Day, Jan. 3).
The first part of that statement, referring to the 93-month-long upswing that began in November 1982, represents another neoconservative effort to rewrite history. It has been uncritically accepted by many, including your own economics reporters (see, for instance, "Why It's Too Soon to Predict Another Great Depression," The Week in Review, Nov. 11, 1990, and "Leading Indicators in 5th Drop: 1.2% November Fall Suggests No Early End to Downturn," Business Day, Dec. 29).
Dropped from sight in this version of history is the record-setting 105-month expansion of February 1961 to November 1969. Escalation of the Vietnam War took place during the last half. What counts for economic purposes, however, is not whether warfare is being waged, but the degree to which military spending is stimulating the economy.
During the first half of the expansion of the 1960's, the military spending share of the gross national product actually fell, from 9 percent in 1961 to 7.2 percent in 1965. By contrast, the first half of the 1980's upswing was powerfully assisted by the Reagan Administration's $2.2 trillion military buildup. The military proportion of gross national product rose steadily, from 5.3 percent when President Reagan took office, to a peak of 6.7 percent in mid-1986.
If the expansion of the 1960's was prolonged by Vietnam outlays, as was certainly the case, it must also be noted that the expansion of the 1980's would have begun later than November 1982 in the absence of Mr. Reagan's ballooning military budgets. From July 1981 to November 1982 the United States economy was going through one of its two deepest post-World War II recessions to date, with unemployment reaching 10.8 percent and fixed business investment declining 15 percent. During these months only military spending was growing rapidly.
 
RICHARD B. DU BOFF
Professor of Economics, Bryn Mawr College
Bryn Mawr. Pa., Jan. 4, 1991

HEADLINE: The Needs of the Old And the Young

 BODY:
The "Tenafly Journal" on Dec. 2 describes the admirable achievements of Tenafly's elderly residents in raising $190,000 in public and private funds to enhance their senior center. Their efforts as well as the generosity and assistance of the entire community are to be commended.
But it is somewhat ironic that many of these same residents (who reached out to their neighbors for help) have utilized the same unceasing energy, time and skills to defeat Tenafly's school budgets, wrestle control of the school board and wage a battle to cut numerous worthwhile programs that are directed toward the town's youngest citizens.
It is unfortunate that in these uncertain economic times Tenafly's elderly residents have sometimes failed to recognize that a civilized society must have a social pact between the generations. Just as the entire community rallied behind the elderly in their effort to enrich their later years, one would hope that they could provide a more positive influence in supporting the schools and the children.
 
NORMAN G. TEITCHER
Tenafly
