HEADLINE: Newly Militant Indians in Ecuador Unnerve Propertied Class

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: QUITO, Ecuador, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Looking forward to the 500th anniversary of Spain's discovery of the Americas, Ecuador's increasingly militant Indians say they wish that Christopher Columbus never left home.
"Five hundred years of oppression, five hundred years of resistance," is a popular slogan among Indians here, for whom the 1992 anniversary has suddenly become a catalyst for redressing centuries of European colonization. Across Latin America, Indian and black groups are drawing plans to protest anniversary celebrations.
Indian peasants have started to unnerve the largely white owners of Ecuador's large farming estates by rallying under banners reading: "Not one plantation left by 1992."
 
Part of the Landscape
 For centuries, Ecuador's European and mixed-race ruling classes took the Indians for granted as a passive part of the rural landscape -- men in ponchos and felt hats and women in woven skirts and braids toiling stoically on mountainside fields.
But last June, all that changed with what everyone here refers to now as simply "the uprising."
Up and down Ecuador's central Andean spine, a million Indians rose up in peaceful protest. For almost one week in early June, Indians barricaded highways with trees and occupied churches and estates.
"The country was turned upside down," said Benjamin Ortiz, editor of a Quito newspaper, Hoy. "We had always ignored the indigenous population. It was like the United States in the 1950's when blacks suddenly became visible."
 
Presented List of Demands
 To the shock of Ecuador's establishment, leaders of the nation's 10 Indian tribal groups presented a series of demands. The list included distribution of estate lands, official recognition of Ecuador as a multinational country, Indian control over archeological sites, Government money for bilingual education and research of traditional Indian medicine, and the expulsion of the Summer Institute of Linguistics, an American Baptist evangelical group accused by many Indians here of destroying traditional culture.
Negotiations have sputtered on and off for the last six months. Nex week, they are to resume.
Indian leaders were outraged by the Government's inital reaction -- that foreign agitators and Marxist priests stirred up the nation's traditionally docile Indian population.
"Whoever says that does not believe in the capacity of the indigenous movement and maintains a 17th-century mentality," said Luis Macas, a Quechua who is president of the Confederation of Indigenous Nationalities of Ecuador.
 
Number of Indians Disputed
 In an interview, Mr. Macas estimated that 45 percent of Ecuador's 11 million people are Indians. His opponents put the figure at 10 percent. Last November the confederation carried out an Indian boycott of Ecuador's once-a-decade census.
Independent analysts attribute the sudden emergence of the indigenous movment to a constellation of factors: Ecuador's economic stagnation in the 1980's, which dried up Indian job prospects in the cities; growing demographic pressure in what already is South America's most densely populated country, and the increasingly pro-Indian stand of the Roman Catholic Church.
"Some of the bishops are agitators, the priests are Marxists," said Ruben Espinosa Roman, a dairy farmer who is manager of the Association of Highland and Eastern Ranchers.
Mr. Espinosa, one of the Indian movement's most vocal opponents, produced a 35-page report documenting Catholic church support for the Indian uprising -- use of radio stations, parish halls and the celebration of solidarity masses.
 
Land Is the Issue
 At the heart of Ecuador's sharpening clash is real estate, and different cultural attitudes toward land.
Mr. Espinosa and his 5,000-member association argue that a distribution of estate land to peasants in 1964 crippled food production. Today, he says, most of Ecuador's food production comes from a third of the nation's arable land that remains in the hands of private farmers with estates larger than 50 acres.
He argues that Ecuador would be forced to import food if land distribution advocates have their way with the 18 percent of the nation's arable land that is now in estates of more than 250 acres.
Simon Bustamante Cardenas, president of the ranchers' association, wrote recently: "If we admit to an indigenous population of 1.2 million people and we proceed with a big, new distribution of arable land, we would have an eloquent result: one hectare per Indian and hunger for everyone, especially for the cities."
 
'Destroyed Our Culture'
 The Indian confederation, which represents the 10 Indian groups, argues that its ancestral lands have been usurped by European colonialism.
"The colonizers ignored the relationship between the Indians and their land," they said in a statement read last July at a meeting here of Indian groups from across the continent. "The European invasion destroyed our cultures."
Mr. Macas said that crop totals fell after the 1964 land distribution because Indians received arid, poorly irrigated land and because the Government did not follow through with low-interest credit, education and agricultural extension services.
Frustrated by years of fruitless legal action, Indian communities are currently threatening to take over "unused" land on about 60 estates. To defuse the pressure, the Catholic Church announced in November that it was starting an Indian land fund by buying at a steep discount $28 million in Ecuadorean foreign debt titles. The Government is to redeem the titles in local currency at a moderate discount.
 
Violence Is Feared
 Although Ecuador, an oil-exporting nation, earned an extra $270 million from higher oil prices in the last half of 1990, the Government has shown little interest in using the oil windfall to buy farm land for Indians.
Indeed, in a continent where racial politics are often played out with guns, many people fear that violence may erupt in this generally peaceful nation.
Peru, Ecuador's southern neighbor, is racked by the Shining Path, a guerrilla group that draws its recruits largely from the nation's Quechua and mixed-race population. To the north, peace talks in Colombia appear to be leading Quintin Lame, an Indian-based guerrilla group, to disarm after years of action.
In the Andean highlands here, landowners have started hiring private guards and military commanders have said that they will not allow a second mass protest to stop the nation's road traffic for a week.
"For the first time, the landowners in the highlands are arming," warned Elsie Monge, coordinator here of the Ecumenical Commission for Human Rights. "Another uprising would not be peaceful."

HEADLINE: Chinese Dissident Relives the 1989 Massacre

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 15

 BODY:
In the 18 months since the Chinese Government crushed the democracy movement that she helped lead, Chai Ling has tried to put the memory of the tanks rumbling through Tiananmen Square behind her.
But the news that Beijing recently sentenced a group of her fellow students to prison for the protests -- and planned to put more on trial -- has rekindled for Ms. Chai painful images of the night of June 3-4, 1989, forcing her to confront suppressed emotions of frustration, rage and guilt. 
 "It has all come back to me with the trials," she said in an interview on the Princeton University campus.
Ms. Chai, who was a psychology major at Beijing University when she became one of the principal leaders of the protests, went into hiding after the crackdown, in which hundreds of people were killed. She then avoided arrest for 10 months before escaping to France.
She moved to the United States last fall and has settled in Princeton, where she is a visiting scholar in a program that has attracted more than 20 other prominent Chinese dissidents and intellectuals.
She has been working to keep alive the democracy movement by lobbying government officials around the world about the plight of the students imprisoned in China.
Ms. Chai, who is 24 years old, said that when she first learned of the trials, she was ashamed that she had evaded punishment while so many others had been caught or killed.
"I feel kind of guilty," she said in a soft voice, struggling to find the words in English. "We try our best, but we don't know how we can help them. Even when we do our best, we still feel very guilty."
 
Working on Autobiography
 Ms. Chai has begun work on an autobiography in which she hopes to vent some of the emotions that she has bottled up since the crackdown.
"I want to tell from my perspective what China is like, and why such a moment could happen," she said. "The key issue for the demonstrators was that people were used to being treated like slaves, and the people naturally wanted to become human beings, have equality, dignity and freedom."
She said that despite the continuing repression, she was optimistic that the political situation in China would improve.
"It has to get better, because the people have experienced 10 years of reform," she said, referring to the period before the protests, when the Chinese leadership gradually relaxed some political and economic control. "When you've tasted freedom, it's very difficult to go back."
Ms. Chai said she longed to return to China. But she remains on the Government's most wanted list, and she said she was certain that the moment she set foot in her homeland, she would be arrested and executed.
So she waits, assuming the identity of just another foreign student, a backpack over her shoulder as she bicycles to the library each morning.
But, she said, she knows that she can never again be just a student.
"In Buddhism, they think that when people die, they can change their life and be reborn," she said. "Sometimes, I feel I was reborn even during my lifetime. I feel a part of me really died during the massacre. My old life died. We buried our past."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "It has all come back to me with the trials," Chai Ling, a leader of the crushed Chinese democracy movement, said in an interview at Princeton University. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Turkey;
Turkey's Role in Air Assault Sets Off Fear of Retaliation

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Turkey's decision to let its territory be used as a second front in the air war against Iraq has deeply divided the Muslim country, with many people worried that they now face retaliatory strikes.
The rally-round-the-flag consensus that almost always prevails here on important foreign-policy matters has broken down over President Turgut Ozal's aggressive anti-Iraq stance in the Persian Gulf war. 
 Mr. Ozal has his admirers, and some foreign diplomats said they sensed that support may be building for his argument that Turkey must play a war role to eliminate President Saddam Hussein and to share in any rewards from the hoped-for allied victory.
But opposition leaders and many influential commentators in the press have refused to close ranks with Mr. Ozal, accusing him of dragging Turkey into an unwanted war for personal glory or for potential national benefits that they dismiss as ephemeral.
 
Bombers on Turkish Bases
 Emin Colasan, a columnist for Hurriyet, a large Turkish daily, called Mr. Ozal "irresponsible" today, adding, "Who will shoulder the responsibility if Saddam's chemical and biological weapons explode over Turkey and thousands of our citizens face harm?"
Newspapers today published a poll taken by Mr. Ozal's governing Motherland Party that showed that 74 percent of those surveyed oppose Turkey's entry into the war.
Even the Government is obviously nervous about the bombing runs that American war planes have launched in the last three days, with official Turkish blessing, from the Incirlik air base near the southern city of Adana. It has not formally acknowledged that the raids are taking place, and there has been a news blackout about the subject on the state television and radio and by the more or less official press agency.
But diplomats here and reporters outside the Incirlik base said there was is no doubt that four bombing missions involving dozens of F-16, F-15 and F-111 fighters and bombers had struck at targets in northern Iraq. Presumably, they were trying to eliminate Iraqi missile launchers, but there has been no word about their degree of success.
 
Fear of Iraqi Missiles
 Like the Government, the United States Embassy has declined to discuss operations at Incirlik, where American strength is being shored up to include 96 war planes and new Patriot air-defense missiles.
There are also 42 German, Belgian and Italian planes stationed in eastern Turkey, but they are there only as a NATO tripwire in case Turkey, a member of the Atlantic alliance, is attacked by Iraq. The other 15 members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization affirmed this week that they would come to Turkey's defense if Iraq attacked.
Although it effectively has turned its bases over the United States, the Government insists that Turkish forces have not entered the war, and will not unless Iraq attacks. But critics say giving the Americans free rein at those installations amounts to a first strike by Turkey, handing Iraq the justification to hit back.
Fears of Iraqi missiles have risen despite Government assurances that the chances of an attack are remote. The Iraqi missile assaults on Israel have not reassured Turks, and tens of thousands have fled their homes in southeastern regions near the border to seek temporary shelter elsewhere.
 
Jittery Ankara Shopkeepers
 Even in Ankara, about 500 miles from the frontier and presumably in no danger, there are reports of some people leaving town and of jittery shopkeepers closing their shutters.
In general, Turks tend to be nervous about roles in Middle East disputes. Since the collapse of the Ottoman Empire in the 1920's, they have sought neutrality, achieving it conspicuously during the eight-year war between Iraq and Iran. They know that historically they are not loved by Arabs, and so they strive, sometimes almost painfully, to avoid any action that could smack, however slightly, of an offense.
That attitude is conspicuous within the military and foreign-policy establishments, two pillars of Turkish public life that feel it would not take much to bring out anti-Turkish resentments even though Ankara is on the same side as many Arab states in this crisis.
 
Despised Neighboring Despot
 Also, most Turks want to stay out of war, no matter where it may be. They recall that the Ottomans made the mistake of letting Germany pull them into World War I, only to wind up losing the war and their empire.
But Mr. Ozal's supporters reply that Turkey has to side with the West against Iraq, and also has a great deal to gain from being seen as a full partner on what they presume will be the winning side. The perceived benefits include removal of a despised neighboring despot, promises of new economic aid and military equipment from the United States and perhaps a seat at any postwar peace conference that will be held.
Mr. Ozal said in a television interview Friday night that his decisions in the crisis were not a gamble, as his opponents assert, but rather a "calculated risk."
"There is no profit without risk," he said.

HEADLINE: New York's Gordian Knot of Labor Talks, Layoffs and Pay Freezes

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
New York City's effort to get its fiscal house in order is particularly complicated because of the Dinkins administration's labor strategy of simultaneously trying to settle past, present and future contracts and ordering the first major layoffs in more than a decade.
Some financial monitors say this approach is piecemeal and short-sighted, but Mayor David N. Dinkins's aides say it is part of a broad plan to cope with extraordinary budget gaps. 
 The round-robin negotiations could last a year or more because of the multitude of unions, the shorter length of contracts and their staggered expiration dates. Raymond D. Horton, the president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private monitoring group financed by business, said, "It's nonstop bargaining and nonstop budgeting."
Until the issues are resolved, the city faces labor tension and fiscal uncertainty. Wages and benefits constitute half of the city's $28 billion budget, so contract costs affect spending, work force size and service cuts.
 
Teamsters Authorize Strike
 Each step in the negotiating process is fraught with controversy because of contract relationships, competing unions and special circumstances.
For example, the teamsters last week authorized a strike of 8,500 Housing Authority workers, hoping to win raises bigger than those at other city agencies. The union argues that the authority's Federal financing exempts it from city budget constraints.
Mr. Dinkins instructed city negotiators to limit all raises to no more than the 1.5 percent increase allocated in this year's budget, unless outside revenues were available. So far, three unions have settled their contracts, all with raises exceeding 1.5 percent -- thanks to savings achieved by reducing the amount that the city contributes to pension funds and increasing the estimates of what the funds will earn.
But reliance on pension maneuvers provoked new problems, since different city agencies are covered by different pension funds and their potential savings vary.
 
Breaking With the Past
 Traditionally, the city has agreed on a contract with a lead union, setting a precedent for raises for other unions. The uniformed unions usually held out for a bit more. Contracts ran two or three years, giving budgetary stability. When they expired, the cycle began anew.
The Dinkins administration's bargaining broke with the past. On Oct. 1, the city settled with the United Federation of Teachers for a 5.8 percent raise in wages and benefits. On Jan. 2 Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees settled for less: a 3.5 percent wage increase for the first year of a 15-month contract, an additional 1 percent in the final three months and a 0.5 percent increase in benefits.
But the city has already gone back to the unions that it settled with, seeking contract concessions to save money and avert layoffs.
And still to be settled are 130 contracts with smaller but often crucial unions, including those of firefighters and police officers.
As the city's negotiators struggle to complete those contracts, the Mayor has set the stage for bargaining for labor agreements that will begin in the next fiscal year, which starts July 1. He declared a year's pay freeze. But Mr. Dinkins cannot unilaterally enforce such a freeze; the unions can seek a raise through arbitration.
 
'A Very Puzzling Process'
 While revising existing contracts, negotiating new ones and preparing for the next round of bargaining, the city is also negotiating procedures for laying off thousands of workers.
"It's a very puzzling process," said Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation. "The most troublesome thing is the city has to come in with a credible financial plan because the city has to finance against it. An open-ended labor situation makes it very awkward. I don't how you put together a solid plan under these circumstances."
Similarly, Allen J. Proctor, director of the State Financial Control Board, which was set up in the 1970's to monitor the city's fiscal condition, said: "We're the guardians of long-term planning and orderly process. This bargaining round certainly makes long-term planning harder." He called for coalition bargaining, combining all unions, as was done in the 1970's fiscal crisis.
But the city's Labor Relations Commissioner, Eric J. Schmertz, defended the Mayor's policy: "What appeared to be short-term contracts are part of the game plan," Mr. Schmertz said. "We had this in mind all along. I'm now pleased it's beginning to unfurl, both fiscally and logically."
 
2-Year Arrangment
 The city achieved its goal in the contracts with the teachers, teamsters and District Council 37. It stuck to the 1.5 percent raise that comes from budgeted funds, Mr. Schmertz said. He said the new contracts are shorter than usual because the recession made revenue estimates unreliable. Succeeding forecasts have shown revenues dropping by hundreds of millions of dollars, justifying that caution and prompting Mr. Dinkins's pay-freeze declaration, which Mr. Schmertz said is not a ploy.
First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel described the shorter contracts, with the pay freeze to follow, as essentially a two-year arrangement that allows for very modest raises.
Recalculating the city's contribution to its pension funds to finance those raises both simplified and complicated matters.
For most city workers, who are covered by the New York City Employees Retirement System, the new contracts set an easy precedent. By reducing its contribution to the system, the city freed two percentage points to add to the workers' raise. The teachers, in a separate pension fund, added 2.5 points.
But the pension device threatens disparities for diverse groups ranging from managers to day-care workers.
The Managerial Employees Association has warned that it may sue to block the changes in the Employees Retirement System. Managers are covered by the fund, but since the Mayor has frozen their salaries, they would not be entitled to raises from the pension savings. The 7,000 day-care workers belong to a private pension fund that is unlikely to allow the city to reduce its pension contribution, said Robert W. McEnroe, director of District Council 1707 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.
 
Pension Funds
 The pension issue also jeopardizes the historic pay parity among police, firefighters and correction officers, with wages for sanitation workers at 90 percent of those of the uniformed services.
Sanitation workers and correction officers, who are covered by the Employees Retirement System, expect to realize two percentage points of their raise from pension savings.
But the police and firefighters have different pension funds with less money. The police could find savings elsewhere, by prolonging the time that officers must serve to reach top pay. But the Fire Department is in the midst of a hiring freeze, so it could not save money in that way.
The president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, James J. Boyle, suggested that schedule revisions could yield savings for raises and that changed payroll deductions could increase take-home pay.
Economies at the Fire Department have fueled discontent among firefighters, leading Mr. Boyle to a terse analysis of the challenge facing the city and its unions: "It's a mess."

HEADLINE: Small Florida Community Has a Death in the Family

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI SPRINGS, Fla., Jan. 19

 BODY:
This small community cheek by jowl with the sprawling Eastern Airlines headquarters has long enjoyed a symbiotic relationship with the airline. It was Eastern, said James Stadnik, a local pharmacist and former Chamber of Commerce official, "which made everything possible."
So after the announcement on Friday that Eastern would cease operations, Mr. Stadnik, 73 years old, said it was like "losing a member of your family." While Miami Springs is not so completely dependent on Eastern as it was in the 30's and 40's, the imminent disappearance of the company cast a pall over the town. 
 In his own personal memorial today, Mr. Stadnik took a visitor through the Miami Springs Historical Society Museum on the second floor of his pharmacy, where pictures and documents extolled the town and Eastern's connections with it. There were photos of the stewardess training school that brought generations of young women to live here, and of the homes that some pilots built, as well as evidence of the civic and economic life they helped create.
 
'It's Been -- Like Family'
 "I remember the dedication of the headquarters complex in 1947 because I was president of the Chamber of Commerce and Captain Rickenbacker and I were on the dais together to make our speeches," Mr. Stadnik said, recalling the legendary aviator who was Eastern's longtime chief executive, Eddie Rickenbacker. "I told him I had to cut my speech short because that was also the day that my daughter was born. But that's the way it's been -- like family."
Eastern's demise will have an effect well beyond this town of 12,500. The news was perhaps the harshest reminder yet for the city of Miami and south Florida in general that an industry that helped fuel its own growth is seriously troubled. About 7,000 Eastern employees live in the area.
Martin Shugrue, the trustee appointed by the Federal bankruptcy court in New York in April to run the airline, said at a news conference today: "Regretfully this will be a blow to this fine community which has nurtured us. There are many already out of work in the region and there will now be more than before. There are local vendors and suppliers who will be affected also."
 
Closing Down the Airline
 Karen Ceremsac, Eastern's vice president for corporate communications, said 3,000 to 4,000 people nationwide would be kept on to oversee the closing of the airline, including several hundred in South Florida. Those numbers will decline rapidly as the liquidation is completed, she said.
Outside Eastern's headquarters on Northwest 36th Street in Miami picketers from the International Association of Machinists marched this morning.
Paul A. Dombroski, the secretary of Local 702, said that at its peak in 1972, Eastern employed 5,600 of the union's members.
The number had declined to 4,200 in March 1989 when the union went on strike. Now 2,400 members are still picketing and receiving strike benefits of $100 a week.
 
Will the Picketing End?
 It is not clear whether the picketing will continue, said Mr. Dombroski, who himself waxed a bit nostalgic as he talked about the airline and the union's salad days.
"In the 50's and 60's, if you were employed by Eastern you had the premier job with the premier airline in a good and growing industry," he said. "The salaries were good and so were the benefits. The bad part was that if you were black or Catholic or anything other that a southern white Baptist you couldn't get a union job there, but that changed."
Don Davidson, a 28-year pilot with Eastern who is now vice president of flight operations, recalled coming to the company in 1963 when "Miami and Eastern were synonymous -- It was an exciting place."
Last spring his 25-year-old son became an Eastern pilot and even then, he said, Eastern seemed an exciting place to be.
 
No New Slogans
 "It's difficult when it sets in that there is no tomorrow for Eastern," Captain Davidson said wistfully. "I find myself being the eternal optimist. We've operated under the slogan the 'New Eastern' for the last year. Why couldn't we keep on going and be the New, New Eastern?"
Vera Gray-Wagner, who now owns the Century 21 real estate agency in Miami Springs, worked full time in the airline industry until last year as a purser for Pan American World Airways, said Eastern's demise would have a tremendous impact on real estate sales in the area.
In 1989, when the strike began, her office was besieged by speculators seeing distress sales in the area.
"It got so bad I closed the office for a few days," she said. "I've already had a couple of deals fall through in the last week after lenders found that the buyers were Eastern employees. Suddenly they weren't qualified buyers."

HEADLINE: Eastern Airlines Brought Down by a Strike So Bitter It Became a Crusade

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
As word filtered out Friday night that Eastern Airlines would shut, some members of its machinists union, which has been on strike since March 1989, rejoiced.
Some passengers and communities served by Eastern, as well as other employees, lamented the end of a 62-year-old airline that for a time dominated the routes between the Northeast and the sun, but the strikers celebrated a victory. 
 Not only had they forced Frank Lorenzo, the former chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, which owned Eastern, to give up control of the airline in April, but the thousands of non-union pilots, flight attendants and machinists that he had hired to break the strike are also out on the street.
 
At the Heart of the Shutdown
 The hatred and passions stirred by the long strike of the International Assocation of Machinists and Aerospace Workers lie at the heart of why Eastern was forced to park its 190 planes and begin selling its assets.
Certainly, other pressures weakened Eastern over the years, notably the competition brought by deregulation. When the Government began in 1979 to allow airlines to fly wherever they wanted, loosened the rules on fares and made it easy for new airlines to enter the business, upstart rivals like People Express and Air Florida forced Eastern to charge fares that did not cover its costs.
Those problems were compounded when the management at the time, led by Frank Borman, miscalculated and ordered a large number of planes, loading the company with debt when most other carriers were more appropriately cautious.
And the final blow for Eastern probably came in August, when the price of aviation fuel surged after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, greatly increasing operating costs and making it impossible for Eastern to get a grip on its debts.
 
Similar Pressures Elsewhere
 But other airlines faced similar pressures and managed to adapt. Some airlines, including United Air Lines and Trans World Airlines, had also gone through strikes.
Indeed, several large American airlines are also in acute financial distress: Pan American World Airways and Continental Airlines have both filed for bankruptcy protection, and Trans World Airlines is planning to sell some of its profitable routes to London.
Nowhere other than Eastern, however, did the labor struggle last as long or assume the form of a crusade.
And in the end, the conflict destroyed an airline that had been run by two renowned figures in aviation. Founded in 1928, Eastern was led until 1963 by Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker, the World War I flying ace. In 1975 Frank Borman, a former astronaut, became the airline's president; in his early tenure he was often asked for autographs by his employees.
Throughout the years, Eastern's strength was warm-weather vacations. The airline had many routes to Florida, special promotions in conjunction with Disney World and extensive operations in the Caribbean and Latin America.
 
New Balance of Power
 In 1984, Eastern seemed on the verge of achieving a new balance of power between labor and management. In an agreement with its three unions, which made large concessions on wages and benefits, Eastern gave 25 percent of its stock to its 38,000 workers. The unions received four seats on Eastern's board, two of them held by union leaders.
But after Texas Air and Mr. Lorenzo acquired Eastern in 1986, the alliance unraveled, the union leaders' board membership was ended and labor relations rapidly deteriorated.
Jack Bavis, the leader of the pilots union at Eastern for much of the strike, said that what had started out as a struggle to keep Mr. Lorenzo from selling Eastern's assets to bolster other parts of his airline empire became a personalized confrontation in which some union leaders were determined to get rid of Mr. Lorenzo at any cost. At its forefront was Charles Bryan, the head of the machinists union and a onetime ally of Mr. Lorenzo.
As part of their campaign, the unions turned to new tactics that inflicted huge damage on Eastern. The unions lobbied in Washington against Mr. Lorenzo and Eastern's president, Phil Bakes, portraying the airline as negligent in its safety practices.
As a result of the pressure, the Federal Aviation Administration inspected Eastern's fleet and concluded that Eastern was safe to fly. But the agency said it was concerned that the labor conflict could cause safety problems.
 
Losing Business Travelers
 Some customers had already been put off by having to cross picket lines, and the specter of safety problems led many others to shun Eastern.
This was particularly true of business travelers, who generally do not pay for their trips themselves and found little incentive to fly Eastern when it introduced very low fares.
The virtual boycott of Eastern by business travelers was devastating, because airlines rely on these full-fare passengers to make a profit.
In April, after a year in bankruptcy protection, Mr. Lorenzo was ousted from control of Eastern by Federal Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland, who said Texas Air had neglected and mismanaged it. The airline was taken over by Martin R. Shugrue, the trustee appointed by the court.
Before Mr. Lorenzo was ousted, he succeeded in breaking the strike of the pilots and flight attendants, who had followed the machinists union to the picket lines.
Using nonunion replacements, Mr. Lorenzo gradually rebuilt Eastern operations, much as he had done at Continental Airlines in 1983, after he put that airline into bankruptcy protection to break its unions.
 
Much Lower Wages
 Most of Eastern's striking pilots and flight attendants and almost all the machinists were replaced by people who worked for up to two-thirds less. New pilots, for example, were paid $27,500 a year, compared with average of $72,000 before the strike. Ramp workers made $5 an hour instead of $15.
But it was a Pyrrhic victory for Mr. Lorenzo. The rebuilding did not go smoothly. Eastern was plagued by mechanical problems, and the new people, while highly motivated, lacked experience and polish. Eastern's business remained disappointing, and the airline continued to lose money.
The safety issues aside, Eastern's prospects for a revival were probably damaged when an examiner appointed by the bankruptcy court, David Shapiro, found last spring that there were 12 transactions between Texas Air and Eastern where there was evidence of possible improper action.
As a result, Mr. Shapiro said, Texas Air, which is now known as Continental Airlines Holdings Inc., could have deprived Eastern of $280 million to $400 million. This finding seemed to bulwark the unions' earlier complaints that Mr. Lorenzo was stripping Eastern of some of its most profitable operations, like its computerized reservation service, in order to prop up Continental Airlines.
Mr. Shugrue acknowledged when he took control that the most serious problem facing Eastern was the public's concerns about safety. He quickly began an advertising campaign that tried to convince the public that the safety problems had been resolved.
But in the midst of this effort, a grand jury indicted nine Eastern managers on charges of falsifying records to make it appear that repairs had been done when they had not.
When Mr. Shugrue took over, Judge Lifland allocated another $80 million to keep Eastern flying.
At the time, Eastern had 800 flights a day and a huge hub at Hartsfield International Airport in Atlanta. But even there it faced formidable competition from Delta Air Lines, which was based in Atlanta. and is one of the nation's strongest airlines.
 
A Determined Executive
 Most airline analysts believed Eastern could survive only if it could link up with a more successful airline.
But Mr. Shugrue, a chain-smoking, restless 50-year-old, was determined to revive Eastern. He traveled constantly among Eastern's hubs in New York, Atlanta and Miami, raising employee morale and meeting with travel agents.
For a time, he seemed to be on the way to success. Low fares brought back old Eastern travelers who had defected to Delta and USAir. Even some business travelers began to give Eastern a second chance.
Then came the Iraqi invasion and sharply higher fuel prices.
And Delta, which had higher fares, than Eastern's, began to match them. Business travel began to slow as the economy deteriorated.
And despite a huge advertising budget, Eastern could not shake its image as the airline that had been torn apart by its struggle with its unions.
Yet even yesterday, with Eastern's planes grounded, Mr. Shugrue held out some glimmers of hope.
He said he continued to talk with financial and airline organizations. He acknowledged that the suspension of flights "obviously makes the task more difficult, and I truly don't want to hold out false hopes."
Few people give him any chance of success, especially since the creditors of Eastern are determined to force the liquidation of its assets.
And outside Eastern's headquarters in Miami yesterday, members of the machinists union continued to picket, jeering at nonstriking employees who were leaving with their belongings.
"We told you so," they shouted, waving signs that said, "Eastern Airlines: Rest in Peace" -- and "Rest in Pieces."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Eastern Airlines was forced to park its 190 planes and begin selling its assets after shutting down last week. Patrons at a La Guardia Airport bar looked out the window at an Eastern jet (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: PAN AMERICAN GAMES;
Cuba Puts It All On 1991 Games

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

DATELINE: HAVANA

 BODY:
A substantial number of construction workers seemed busy as usual at the new aquatics center on a gray and unusually cool morning here last week. But for all their efforts, one of the walls had still not been erected, a major support beam for the roof sat unattended on the ground, and not a shovelful of dirt had been removed from where the pool will be.
"Perhaps this one is our most difficult venue," said Renaldo Gonzalez Lopez, the executive director of the committee organizing the 1991 Pan American Games. "But I am sure everything will be finished by May." 
 Whether it's actually completed in May, June, July or even by Aug. 2, the day of the opening ceremony, on this day Gonzalez and other Cuban sports officials expressed no concern that the center might not be finished on time or the games not proceed as scheduled. In fact, most of the facilities under construction or renovation are well on target for completion, and the others are not far enough behind to cause alarm.
What seemed far more uncertain to outside observers is why a country with so many obvious economic needs would continue such massive efforts to organize an event of the magnitude of the Pan American Games.
For 30 years, Cuba has endured under a trade embargo by the United States, which left the Soviet Union as the island's major economic benefactor. Yet with its own worsening problems, the Soviet Union began reducing its trade with Cuba last year by limiting oil exports, demanding payments in hard currency and lowering price subsidies on sugar, Cuba's major export. Other important trading partners, like Eastern European countries once within the Soviet sphere of influence, also started demanding payments from Cuba in hard currency.
With the economic squeeze tightening, President Fidel Castro proclaimed in September that the country was entering a "special period" of austerity. To most Cubans, that simply meant more belt-tightening and sparse supplies growing sparser. By last week, there was little to suggest otherwise, as local citizens stood in lines to buy bread and walked by other stores with few goods to sell. All around were buildings in dire need of paint and repair, eroding sidewalks and clouds of carbon monoxide, spewed from Soviet-built cars and Bulgarian buses.
At the same time, preparations for the Pan American Games have continued, to a large degree, at the expense of these problems and others. As a requirement of the special period, work on most projects has been stopped, and proposed ventures delayed. Just about the only other uninterrupted work has been construction of new hotels and resorts, as the government turns to tourism to generate additional hard currency.
"We have a sacred commitment to the Pan American Games, and we will honor it," Castro told a group of Western journalists last week. "So the Pan American Games have been given a high priority, and they will continue to enjoy a high priority."
The Pan American Games were first held in 1951 in Buenos Aires, moving to another Western hemisphere city every fourth year. In 1987, they were staged in Indianapolis, where competition between athletes from Cuba and the United States, countries without formal diplomatic relations, provided the games their highest drama.
This will be the first time for the games in Cuba, which has been ruled by Castro's Communist Government since 1959. Most of the events will be staged here, with several others in Santiago de Cuba, a smaller city in the southeast corner of the country, 548 miles away.
The Cuban organizers expect nearly 6,000 athletes, coaches and officials from 38 countries, not to mention hundreds of journalists and other visitors. The United States Olympic Committee expects to send a delegation of 1,045 athletes, coaches and staff.
Cuba has seldom had the opportunity to receive so many foreigners, especially such a large number from the United States. For that reason, the 1991 games have become an important source of national pride, a chance to show off progress despite the onerous embargo from the north.
"Staging these games is a psychological question for Cuba," said a European diplomat based in Havana, who requested anonymity. "A Cuban, in general, is not always a convinced Communist, but he is a convinced nationalist. He's proud to organize the games; they assimilate national prowess."
The cost of the 1991 games is nearly impossible to measure because of Cuba's socialist economic system. Outside of some items that had to be purchased with hard currency, like a synthetic surface for the track in the Olympic Stadium from Germany and bowling lanes from Japan, the Havana games are home-grown. Cuban-made materials are being used for the 10 major venues under construction, including a 35,000-seat Olympic Stadium, the aquatics center, a velodrome, a tennis center with 14 courts, a regatta course for rowing and canoeing -- in each case, the first of its kind in Cuba -- plus a complex of 1,473 apartments for athletes and officials that will be turned over to the city after the games.
Four years ago in Indianapolis, where most of the venues had already existed, organizers spent nearly $90 million to stage the games.
Castro put the cost at "less than 1 percent of the current investment being made in our country." But his failure to elaborate left hanging the questions of cost and proper emphasis. These days, these questions are difficult to avoid with an increasing number of people using bicycles because gasoline has grown scarce and bus service has been cut back, oxen replacing tractors for farm work, horse-drawn carriages instead of taxis.
"When they decided to organize the games, they had no problems with the Soviet Union and the ex-Eastern bloc still existed," said the European diplomat, giving Castro the benefit of the doubt. "So Fidel had no more problems than any other countries. Then, all of a sudden, in one year everybody was surprised and everything changed."
Castro alluded to that when he noted that "none of our problems existed in November 1986," when Cuba won the right to stage the games.
And so his country has clung to its "moral and ethical principles" by forging ahead, he said, citing residual benefits that he suggests make the venture more valuable, like housing for 6,500 citizens in the village apartments, the availability of the venues for general use and a possible increase in tourism.
"It's all in the way you look at things," said a former Cuban Government official, who asked that his name not be mentioned. "Cubans may lack some of the necessities of life, but no one is starving. Compared to other Latin American countries, our quality of life is much better. We fought very hard to get the games. They mean a lot to us. It would be very hard for us now to renounce them."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Olympic Stadium under construction in Havana, where track and field events are to be held. Workers at the stadium, above, pausing for lunch in front of the Pan American Games emblem. President Fidel Castro speaking to reporters. (Photographs by Associated Press for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Pax Americana;
What the United States Has Taken On In the Gulf, Besides a War

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT takes a long time to plan a war, but it takes an even longer time to design a peace. Many people are already beginning to ask: If the anti-Iraq coalition emerges victorious from this conflict, what will the peace look like and how long will the United States have to remain heavily involved in the Persian Gulf?
In the wake of any American victory, Washington's political influence in the region could be greater than at any other time in the postwar era. Even before the war, Soviet involvement in the Middle East was on the wane, or, as Saddam Hussein derisively put it, Moscow had pulled a "disappearing act." It is quite possible that when the smoke clears America will find itself the only superpower in the Middle East and its greatest enemy might well be the illusions that naturally attend victory -- illusions about how much any outside power can reorder an ancient region that has so long defied reordering. 
 Administration officials are the first to admit that they have done relatively little thinking about the shape of peace in the Persian Gulf, largely because the focus of all of their energy since Aug. 2 has been on building the diplomatic and military coalition to confront Iraq. Now that diplomacy has failed and it has come to war, though, Administration planners have thought about peace at least enough to conclude that "victory," in their eyes, will consist of at least five elements.
 
The Elements of Victory
 Although the Administration has never said it out loud, the first element is the total destruction of Iraq's military infrastructure, weapons development factories, missile sites and as many tanks, airplanes and artillery pieces as possible. The goal is to render Iraq unable to project power beyond its borders for years to come. The unprovoked Iraqi missile attacks on Israeli cities last week drove home the point to anyone who might have doubted it that Iraq under its present leadership is an outlaw state that will stop at nothing and therefore must be destroyed militarily -- irrespective of whether it gets out of Kuwait. Even if Mr. Hussein promised to get out of Kuwait tomorrow, the coalition probably would not stop bombing.
The second element of any victory, officials say, is a total and complete Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, so that the 12 United Nations resolutions calling for this outcome will have been implemented. Historians may question whether it was ever right for the Bush Administration to make the "liberation of Kuwait" a prime war aim, instead of focusing exclusively on dismantling Iraq's offensive military capabilities, which, after all, were the real threat to stability in the gulf and therefore the real threat to American interests. Nevertheless, having made the restoration of the Emir to his throne in Kuwait a prime objective, the United States cannot now content itself with devastating Iraq and simply ignoring who rules Kuwait. The credibility of the United Nations and the United States is at stake.
The third element, Administration officials say, would have to be a new, stable balance of power in the gulf. Historically, there have been two regional powers, and two regional powers only, in the Persian Gulf: Iran and Iraq. These are the only countries in the neighborhood that have a large enough population, with sufficient economic resources and educational advancement to be able to develop potent armies. Saudi Arabia, for example, has the money and the advanced weapons, but unlike Iraq or Iran it could never put a million men under arms.
Given these realities the rules of geopolitics in that region have been very simple. When Iran and Iraq are fighting each other, everyone else is relaxed. When one dominates the other, everyone else must live in fear. Most recently, countries such as Kuwait wanted the Americans to act as a counterbalance by sitting just over the horizon. That strategy was exposed as bankrupt by Saddam Hussein when he crushed Kuwait, precisely because he knew the Americans were over the horizon and believed they were not about to budge.
In the wake of this war -- again, assuming victory by the American-led coalition -- some outside power is going to have to sit indefinitely on the horizon to make sure that Iran does not take advantage of the power vacuum in Iraq to reassert dominance. And that power will have to make certain that a wounded and embittered Iraq does not lash out at its neighbors in ways that might not necessarily be life-threatening but could nevertheless be highly destabilizing.
Guess who that power is going to be? Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has already warned, repeatedly, that the United States would have to help develop some stabilizing "security structure" in the aftermath of war. This structure would require the presence of American ground troops, air units and naval units, possibly for months, maybe for several years. Washington would hope to remove its ground forces from Saudi Arabia and from the Kuwait-Iraq border as soon as possible, and have them replaced either by an Arab League force, a force from the Gulf Cooperation Council or a United Nations peacekeeping force, with the Americans sitting offshore on naval vessels.
American officials once thought of this structure almost like a Middle Eastern NATO, but in the last few months they have learned how hard it is to build an anti-Iraq coalition from shy Arab states with their constantly shifting alliances.
So rather than a single structure, American officials now envisage a series of bilateral relationships between the United States and Saudi Arabia, between Saudi Arabia and other Arab countries, such as Egypt, and between the gulf states and themselves. The idea is to develop a muscle that is militarily strong enough to check Iran and Iraq, while politically invisible enough not to leave its members open to charges that they are lackeys of the West. This network of alliances would have to keep Iraq weak enough not to threaten its neighbors, but not so weak that Syria, Turkey or Iran begin to prey upon it.
Another element of this military balance, Secretary Baker has already said, would involve a United Nations arms embargo to keep Iraq from acquiring new chemical, biological or nuclear weapons or missiles.
American officials insist that this security arrangement would have an economic component as well. That means serious pressure from Washington on Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the other Arab gulf states to share their wealth more with their poor Arab neighbors. "Saddam really touched a hot button with his economic arguments," said Ghassan Salameh, a Lebanese political scientist at the University of Paris. "There can be no stable balance of power in the gulf without a redistribution of wealth."
The fourth element of victory, in the American view, would be the restoration of oil prices to reasonable levels. Since the war started, crude oil prices have fallen to their lowest levels since midsummer -- below $20 a barrel. Economists say that if the fall is maintained, it should restore consumer spending power and generate funds for business investment, as well as give the Federal Reserve more room to reduce interest rates in an effort to fight the recession.
"Victory in oil terms is very complex," said Thomas A. Petrie, chairman of Petrie Parkman & Company, a Denver-based oil company. On the one hand, he said, it is important that Iraq be militarily defeated so that it cannot in the future intimidate Saudi Arabia and Kuwait into pushing oil prices way up. On the other hand, it is important that Saudi Arabia and Kuwait do not feel a need to overproduce after the war in order to punish Iraq by keeping prices low and Iraq out of the market.
"It would be in our long-term interest to see oil prices at levels equal to, if not slightly higher than, they were before the war," Mr. Petrie said. "Prices that are too low simply stimulate our own demand and consumption. Prices slightly higher than $20 a barrel would be both affordable and enable us to make a smooth transition to a mix of different energies and also reduce our dependence on foreign oil."
But how much energy will the American people have for managing such a victory, should it come -- particularly when America's "vital interests" in the region are being redefined? For the past 40 years the United States has defined the free flow of oil at reasonable prices from the Persian Gulf to Western Europe and Japan as a vital interest. The United States was not particularly dependent on Persian Gulf oil, but its European and Japanese allies were. As the leader of the Western alliance, the United States felt it had a vital interest in guaranteeing the economic viability and stability of its major allies so that they could help defend the free world against the Soviet threat. But if the Soviets are no longer seen as a threat, how long will the American people consider it their vital interest to maintain a free flow of oil to Japan, especially if Japan uses that oil to surpass the United States industrially?
One burden of victory will be intensified pressure on the United States to address the Palestinian-Israeli dispute. Politically speaking, all of the Arab states that have aligned themselves with the West against Saddam Hussein will be under pressure to prove to their Arab audiences that they are as concerned about the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait as they are about the Israeli occupation of the West Bank. But settling the Palestinian-Israeli dispute has already been made more difficult by the Iraqi missile strikes on Israel and the way in which it was applauded by Palestinians in Jordan and in the Palestine Liberation Organization.
"Saddam's missile attack and the Palestinian response has undone everything positive which the last three years of Palestinian-Israeli contacts might have produced," said the Israeli political theorist Yaron Ezrahi. "The conflict is once again about existence, not about where the border between us should be. To sit here in my house in a sealed room, looking at my elderly father, my wife and my children through a gas mask, and knowing that the Palestinians are applauding means to me that there is no future for coexistence here. It undercuts every Palestinian claim that they are prepared to live with Israel."
As for his views, President Bush said last week: "When all this is over we want to be the healers. We want to do what we can to facilitate what I might optimistically call a 'new world order,' but that new world order should have a conciliatory component to it. It should say to those countries that are on the other side at this juncture, and there aren't many of them, 'Look, you're part of this new world order. You can play an important part in seeing that the world can live at peace in the Middle East and elsewhere.' "
But this war was never about healing. It was about checking a well-armed local despot who was making a bid for regional supremacy, and who broke all the local rules along the way. This war was never about competing visions for the future of the Arab world. It was about a thief who had to be stopped, and since the Arabs could not stop him alone they had to call in the West. Therefore victory in this war will likely produce little euphoria among the victors, only relief. For the Arabs, it will be a relief once the status quo has been restored, with a more stable balance of power, and a less dangerous Iraq. And for American soldiers it will be a relief that they can leave this region.
"Let's not forget something," remarked Mark Heller, a visiting Middle East expert at the Canadian Institute For International Peace and Security, "The challenge Saddam Hussein has posed is not typical of the challenges the United States has confronted in the Middle East and the response of the United States is not typical of its involvement in the area. Both are historical aberrations. So don't look for America to now be running the Middle East and don't look for the problems there to continue to take the Iraqi form. The indigenous problems there are still there and will still be there. Before we start proclaiming a new world order in the Middle East, let's not forget that a lot of the old order will still survive this war."

HEADLINE: The Region;
The Dinkins Budget Is a Long Way From the Bottom Line

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
THE worst-of-both-worlds preliminary budget that Mayor David N. Dinkins proposed for New York City last week was, as usual, only the first step down a long road. But even more than usual, the path is strewn with rocks and roadblocks and bridges to cross.
The obstacles range from the constituent groups that will howl about hundreds of millions of dollars in service cuts and city officials who will fight to protect their turf to the fiscal monitors and credit raters with whom the budget must pass muster and the City Council, which must pass it by June 30. 
 In one sense, Mr. Dinkins's call for $580 million in new taxes, and savings through spending and service cuts, was old hat to New Yorkers used to paying more for less in each of the last three years. But precisely because of the cumulative effects of the past, and the dim economic prospects for the future, this year is particularly bad.
"This is definitely going to be the toughest budget I've ever seen," said the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone. "And it's going to require a good deal of statesmanship and a willingness by many people to make the tough decisions."
In a process known more for gamesmanship than statesmanship, the challenges include potential cuts in state aid that could make the city's problem far worse, uncertainties about whether municipal unions will make concessions to minimize layoffs, the reluctance of the State Legislature and City Council to approve higher taxes in the wake of record increases last year and a special Council election next fall.
<> <> Gloomy as it is, the Mayor's $29.3 billion plan is predicated on a range of assumptions that may be too rosy. For example, the proposal assumes no increase at all in state aid, not even to cover inflation. On the other hand, it does not take into account what would happen if the state reduced aid further, a distinct possibility since it faces huge budget gaps of its own.
The Mayor's plan calls for up to 16,000 layoffs. But the work force, which stood at 247,000 last November, had been scheduled to grow at such a rate that such action would produce a net decrease of only 8,500 by June 30, 1992.
Some critics, including Mr. Vallone, are already questioning whether the Mayor has cut far enough, fast enough and in the right places.
Mr. Vallone conceded that some new taxes would be inevitable, but not before he is convinced that all fat has been trimmed from the budget. Legislative leaders in Albany, whose assent is needed for all the proposed taxes except the property tax, are already looking at the city's requests with a good deal of disapproval.
 
Increases in Some Agencies

 
 Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the State Financial Control Board, the watchdog agency created to monitor the city's finances in the fiscal crisis of the 70's -- and which could resume control over the city budget if it fell out of balance -- questioned whether some of the hard decisions had actually been deferred.
Mr. Proctor said he was surprised to see that a number of smaller agencies, including the Board of Elections and the law and personnel departments, still expected to increase the size of their work force (although not as much as they had planned), while bigger ones like the Board of Education, Sanitation Department and other agencies were slated for deep cuts.
"It is not too soon to talk about priorities, and what message comes from that," he said. "But I'm very puzzled. I'm struck at the number of secondary agencies that are still going to grow."
City officials said the biggest single proposed cut, of 6,000 jobs in the Board of Education, was included as a spur to the state to provide as much education aid as possible. As a strategy, however, it lacks subtlety and holds little guarantee of success. Moreover, Mr. Proctor questioned whether cuts of such scope in education could violate a state law that bars New York City from making disproportionate cuts in the education budget.
Many of the most sweeping kinds of cost-saving ideas, including some that have been discussed for years, were relegated to a series of rhetorical questions in the middle of the Mayor's budget message: Should the Fire Department assume more duty for emergencies, freeing the police to fight crime? Should the city's vast welfare agency be broken apart? Should authority for the East River bridges be transferred to the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, which would mean tolls?
Mr. Dinkins has named an advisory council of business and labor leaders and former city officials to answer those questions and others, but probably not in time for this budget.
Even as the Mayor searches for cuts, interested parties will resist them. Some of his own deputy mayors blocked proposals to consolidate or reshape agencies under their jurisdiction, arguing that the savings were too small to justify the disruptions. And leery as they are of raising taxes, the Council members will also find it hard to surrender to service cuts that could make their constituents even more unhappy.
 
'Not Hiding the Deficits'
 Perhaps the most troubling question is whether the city can find solutions that will work for some time -- instead of simply getting through one more year only to leave big gaps still yawning down the road.
<> <> "Our concern is to deal with the spending levels," said Hyman Grossman, a managing director of the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the Wall Street rating agency that has already placed the city's bonds on a credit watch.
"Based on the last three years, using a bigger tax package is only 50-50 in terms of achievement," he said.
Mr. Proctor of the Control Board said the Mayor benefits from the very strictness of the laws that are a legacy of the earlier crisis and that force him to present his blueprint so early.
"Clearly the world is shifting under our feet, so the numbers will change," Mr. Proctor said.
"But he's not hiding the deficits, and financially, he has tried to find enough solutions," he said. "We may disagree with his strategy and the likelihood of it coming to pass, but he's faced up to the job."
For his part, Mr. Dinkins has acknowledged the difficulties that lie ahead and the help he needs to overcome them.
"The road before us is a hard one," Mayor Dinkins said last week, "made easier only if we work together, think together and, in this time of straitened circumstances, innovate together.
"Now, more than ever, New York City's most precious resource is its collective imagination."

HEADLINE: Headliners;
In Crime, Too, Some Gender-Related Inequities

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
BY one measure, at least, violent crime seems to be declining. But as in so many other things, the trend appears to be benefitting men more than women.
According to a new study by the Justice Department's Bureau of Justice Statistics, about 2.5 million women a year are robbed, raped or assaulted, and about a quarter of such crimes are comitted by family members or men they have dated. 
 One in five of the women victimized by a husband or ex-husband said that they had suffered at least three similar assaults in the previous six months. And almost a quarter of the women victimized by an intimate received medical care, compared with only 13 percent of the victims of other offenders.
The study, based on interviews with about 50,000 households a year, found that violent crime, reported and unreported, against people over 12 years old had declined from 1973 to 1987, but that most of the decline hade been in crimes against men, which dropped about 20 percent. Of the 4 million men a year who are victims, only 6 percent are attacked by family members or women they have dated.
"The trend is that the men's rates are coming down closer to the women's," said Caroline Wolf Harlow, who wrote the report. "But the main lesson is that violent crime against women is different than crime against men because it's six times as likely to be committed by their intimates."
Violence against women has become the focus of increasing concern througout society, with new fears about campus date rape and law enforcement authorities seeming powerless to to stem a pattern of assault and murder by the estranged husbands of women already living under court protection orders. Feminist groups argue that it is a troubling reflection of how much less political and economic power women have than men.
Last week, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. proposed measures to increase penalties for sex crimes involving Federal violations, provide money for campus rape prevention programs and earmark $300 million for programs that help to combat violent crimes against women.
The Justice Statistics study said that the women victimized most frequently are poor black women living in metropolitan areas. Women aged 12 to 24 are more than twice as likely to be victimized as women over 35.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Starting With Upbeat Economy, Richards Sets Out For 'New Texas'

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
THE symbolism was heavy in Austin at Ann Richards's inauguration on Tuesday as the 45th Governor of Texas. From the winter-white dress Ms. Richards wore, to the invitation she issued to the crowd to join her as she strolled to her new office in the Capitol, everything about the day was carefully designed by the team that organized the 1988 Democratic Convention. Their buzzwords were "fresh," "pure" and, above all, "new."
As a candidate, Ms. Richards campaigned on the slogan "The New Texas." In her first speech as Governor, she welcomed 20,000 onlookers to "the first day of the New Texas." 
 Which led many here to ask: What was the Old Texas, and what can Ms. Richards do to change it?
The answer seems to depend on which side one takes in the continuing debate over how the new Governor won in the first place. Her margin was slim: Ms. Richards won 50 percent of the vote; the Republican, Clayton Williams, got 47 percent; the rest went to the Libertarian candidate. Ms. Richards's majority was barely 100,000 votes of the 3.7 million cast.
One interpretation of her victory is that many of those votes were cast not for her, but against Mr. Williams, a billionaire businessman who made a number of self-destructive gaffes, most of them in the last days of the campaign.
First, he compared rape to inclement weather, saying if it was inevitable, "relax and enjoy it." Then he told a reporter that, as a young man, he had been "serviced" by prostitutes. In the last days of the campaign he said he forgot how he marked his absentee ballot -- under state rules, he could have cast it anytime from about three weeks to five days before the election -- on the only constitutional question listed, a proposal affecting gubernatorial appointments. Finally, after refusing for months to release his Federal income tax returns, he volunteered that he paid no income taxes in 1986 because, while still one of the richest people in Texas, he lost money that year.
"She won because she wasn't him," said a Republican political consultant, Carl Rove. "I'm not sure too many Texans really wanted to have a new Texas; they just didn't want a particular candidate."
 
A Historical View
 Those who hold this view describe the Old Texas as a state on the upswing, three years after the worst of the oil bust and with average unemployment figures at the lowest levels since 1985. Oil prices, always the wild card in the economic game here, continue to fluctuate with the war in the Persian Gulf, but Texas is less dependent on oil revenues than ever before. Oil accounts for 10 percent of the state's economic activity, or half the level before oil prices went into decline, contributing heavily to the retreat of other sectors of the state economy as well.
With the rebound, the state even ended the 1990 fiscal year with a $767 million surplus. Budget analysts say that next year it will take between $3.5 billion and $4.5 billion more than the state expects in revenue to provide the current level of services. But optimists point out that those numbers are not nearly as dire as the ones faced by most other large states.
"Things are looking good," Mr. Rove said, adding that Ms. Richards does not have the mandate to make broad, sweeping changes.
Those who take the other view of Ms. Richards's election, that the voters bought her image of a New Texas, believe that Mr. Williams, with his cowboy hats and boots, represented a yearning for a romanticized past that had little bearing on the life of the average Texan in the 1990's. A vote for Ms. Richards, they argued, was an acknowledgement that times had changed and the state's problems had changed.
 
'Last of His Breed'
 "The convenient and simple explanations that Claytie lost it all by putting his foot in his mouth near the end aren't going to wash," a Democratic consultant, George Shipley, said. "Of course he lost it. But she won it, too."
<> <> Paul Burka, executive editor of Texas Monthly magazine, describes Mr. Williams as "the last of his breed," a businessman first and politician second. "The 'Old Texas' was based on the notion that government serves business," he said. "That's down the drain with Ann Richards. I don't think the voters were saying they want a bad business climate but that they care about a whole different range of things."
This school of thought finds a lot wrong with Texas and argues that Ms. Richards does, in fact, have a mandate for change. Three state systems -- the prisons, mental health institutions and schools -- are operating under court supervision. Gov. William Clements Jr., who Ms. Richards succeeds, has been fighting an order to provide more equitable financing to poorer school districts; Ms. Richards says she will try to comply with the order.
The State Legislature has been tainted by periodic scandals in recent years. The latest came earlier this month when a grand jury investigating influence peddling at the Legislature indicted the House Speaker, Gib Lewis, on two misdemeanor ethics violations. The indictment charges that he accepted a gift from a San Antonio law firm and did not report it as required by state ethics laws. Ms. Richards has endorsed a bill that would limit campaign contributions and gifts from lobbyists.
But as in any debate, there are some who hold the view that the entire discussion of why Ms. Richards won is irrelevant. The Texas constitution sharply limits the authority of the governor, and the only real power of the office is a product of the force of the officeholder's personality.
"Once you're elected, you can create the mandate," said Ernesto Cortes Jr., director of the Texas Industrial Areas Foundation, a coalition of community action groups.
"She is the Governor now; she can frame the debate," Mr. Cortes added. "Once she's the Governor, how she got there doesn't really matter."

HEADLINE: The World;
War Offers Turkey a Chance to Take a Larger Role

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey

 BODY:
THE Turks may record the Persian Gulf crisis as the occasion when they proved they still count -- assuming, that is, that the war goes well, which here means above all that not a drop of Turkish blood is shed.
Even before Turkey allowed American planes to launch bombing runs on Iraq from Turkish soil, the struggle against Iraq certainly had been costly for Turkey, and had created any number of risks for future relations with neighboring Arab states. But so far, Turkey has made the best of an ordeal by turning it into an opportunity: an occasion to acquire economic help, new military hardware and, perhaps most of all, large measures of fresh international respect. 
 Turkey's geopolitical importance was in doubt as recently as the day before Saddam Hussein sent his troops into Kuwait. After nearly 40 years as NATO's dray horse on the eastern front, Turkey was being written off in many circles in the post-cold-war era.
Its strategic value had long been rooted in the perceived Soviet menace. But when that threat seemed to evaporate, NATO suddenly no longer loomed so large and neither did Turkey's stalwart presence. And without that military trump card, a popular argument went, what chance would Turkey have of one day realizing its ambition of joining the European Community? The Community had already told the Turks to put their dream on ice for a few years. The Turks, European diplomats say, are too poor for their club, too populous, too tolerant of human-rights abuses and, yes -- off the record, of course -- perhaps too Muslim.
But the gulf crisis has greatly blunted the forget-about-Turkey viewpoint. No matter how the war turns out, the West has been reminded that Turkey lives in one mean neighborhood and that it has always been NATO's tripwire against potential dangers in the Middle East.
Most Turks seem to enjoy being back in the limelight, no one more so than their pugnacious President, Turgut Ozal. He has single-handedly orchestrated Ankara's gulf policy, tossing aside opposition objections that he is exceeding the bounds of a traditionally ceremonial office. The crisis has given him lots of television exposure overseas, which he appears to relish, but he also has vigorously promoted Turkey's interests while trying to turn the presidency into a true executive post.
Yet many Turks worry that Mr. Ozal has played a dangerous game, first by making them active participants in the alliance against Iraq, and much more so last week by letting the Americans open a second front from Turkey in the air war. People in the southeast, near the Iraqi border, fear Mr. Hussein's ruthlessness so much that they began fleeing their homes last week by the tens of thousands, even though their leaders insist they want to stay out of this war.
Ask Turks, and they will tell you that their Ottoman Empire legacy makes them unloved among Arabs, and only grief can come of getting involved in Middle East battles. Two establishment pillars in particular -- the military and the Foreign Ministry -- fret that their President is engaged in perilous brinkmanship. In late fall, two Cabinet ministers and the chief of the armed forces resigned to protest Government policies. And some in the opposition accuse Mr. Ozal of kowtowing to Washington, whose goal, they say, is to drag Turkey into an unwanted war.
While foreign policy specialists and most of the press here want Turkey to abide by the United Nations sanctions against Iraq, they also want to avoid any high-profile action. For them, that rules out all saber-rattling.
But Mr. Ozal has persistently pushed harder. After Iraq invaded Kuwait, he quickly shut off the flow of Iraqi oil through pipelines in southern Turkey. He doubled Turkish troop strength at the border, pinning down 100,000 Iraqi soldiers who might have been used at the Saudi Arabian frontier. All along, he has been a front-row rooter for President Bush, warning repeatedly from his perch on the edge of the Middle East that one must be tough with Saddam Hussein. After war erupted, he arranged through Parliament for anti-Iraq strikes to be possible from Turkish air bases, something that most Turks probably oppose as too risky. The Americans made prompt use of the opportunity.
There are future payoffs to be harvested, Mr. Ozal's supporters insist. During this emergency, the United States has sent nearly 100 advanced fighters and bombers to Turkey and is installing sophisticated Patriot air defense missiles -- equipment that the Turks covet, and some of which may remain after the war. Washington is also considering sharp increases in future military and economic aid; it has already raised import quotas for Turkish textiles. A few Turkish optimists even believe that their stalwartness will persuade the European Community to look more favorably on their application.
But the gulf crisis cannot camouflage fundamental problems here, including labor unrest, galloping inflation and growing Islamic fundamentalism that worries secular Turks. These troubles and others have combined to make Mr. Ozal broadly unpopular, and his ruling party could be toppled in elections next year.
Much, however, is likely to depend on what happens in the war. What really worries Turks is that Iraq may shatter into pieces and that Iran and Syria will swoop in to gobble them up. If that happens, Mr. Ozal says, or if an attempt is made to create a Kurdish state in northern Iraq, Turkish troops would be ready to join the fray. A few radical nationalists go so far as to argue that Turkey would be within its rights to take over the oil-producing provinces of Kirkuk and Mosul, unfairly given to Iraq, they say, when the collapsed Ottoman Empire was carved up in the 1920's.
But they are a minority voice. Turkey for now seems glad just to have its importance recognized again. Now the question is whether being NATO's bulwark against the Arabs can prove more profitable for Turks than when their guns were pointed mainly toward Moscow.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Turkish soldiers on patrol Thursday along their border with Iraq. Last week Turkey allowed American planes to launch raids from its bases. (Associated Press)
