SECTION: Section 2; Page 28; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 926 words

HEADLINE: POP VIEW;
Finally, a Lincoln Center for American Music

BYLINE: By Peter Watrous

 BODY:
A year or so ago, while on a panel about the arts in this country, I fully meant to rouse the rabble in the audience when I shouted what would become my mantra for the rest of the discussion: "There are no Lincoln Centers for American music!" A bit obvious, but effective.
The upper echelon of American culture has ignored home-grown musical contributions in favor of a music and performing system imported stone by stone from Europe. I felt safe that I would be able to use my grandstanding in lectures for years -- what could possibly change? If, by 1990, the cultural establishment was still avoiding its own backyard, why should things improve soon? 
 I was wrong, and I'm glad for it. A slender beam of light has now broken through the clouds with the unlikely announcement that Lincoln Center plans to set up a jazz department that will eventually be on the same level as the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic, though its projected annual budget of $1 million falls $22 million short of the Philharmonic's. The announcement comes in the wake of another major development: the Lila Wallace/Reader's Digest Fund has begun a $3.4 million endowment to support nonprofit jazz promoters across the country. This is extraordinary news for jazz and culture in the United States, and combined, the new programs begin to deal with some of the institutional bias against jazz.
The announcements were made at a time when there are grave discrepancies between how jazz and European music are treated with respect to prizes, contests, concert halls and public support; the differences seem especially glaring in light of how Europeans have supported and institutionalized jazz. At the same time, jazz is undergoing a renaissance, the likes of which have not been seen since the late 1950's, with more young jazz musicians willing to commit their lives to a difficult, financially precarious art. Repertory companies -- most notably the American Jazz Orchestra and Lincoln Center's Classical Jazz Orchestra -- have revived the idea that important orchestral works from jazz's past deserve live performance.
But major American musical institutions have never fully supported jazz. Obviously, new performing arts centers aren't feasible for economic reasons; free marketers argue that jazz -- because it has a network of nightclubs and developed in ballrooms of the 20's and 30's -- should support itself. But jazz isn't pop music anymore, and it lacks the kind of audience that would support, for example, a big orchestra; like European classical music, it needs underwriting to produce large-scale shows. To adopt jazz into the system makes perfect sense.
The ramifications of this sort of adoption, if done correctly, are immense. For one, it can begin the process of de-ghettoizing, which jazz must still undergo to dispel the predominate images of it as banal happy-time entertainment and primitive, spontaneous emotionalism. If Lincoln Center does what is wanted by Rob Gibson, head of the new department, jazz will appear as often as the New York Philharmonic; there may also be year-round film series and lectures along with the music. Lincoln Center's midsummer Classical Jazz program was a worthy, well-executed series for a handful of nights a year and helped fill a hall that would otherwise have been dark.
But suddenly, the music has become, at least on paper, equal in importance to everything else at Lincoln Center. And the benefits work both ways: as audiences for European classical music age and dwindle, jazz, like the Serious Fun festival at Lincoln Center, will lure a younger crowd.
This is not to argue that jazz as an art needs legitimization: it doesn't, and jazz musicians aren't going to hear this announcement and suddenly begin to take themselves seriously -- they've been doing so for 90 years. But the creation of the program makes it clear to other musical establishments and money-dispensing institutions that the environment has changed, that Duke Ellington, Fletcher Henderson, Sonny Rollins, Charlie Parker and Muhal Richard Abrahms have a place in their halls and bankbooks. If the program succeeds, it could mark a watershed in American musical history, one with political implications: the regular inclusion of black culture into the hallowed halls of white culture is unprecedented; it can't come too soon.
A jazz program with the visibility promised by Lincoln Center will also stimulate arguments and thought. Inevitably, anything undertaken on that scale will be scrutinized, argued over, loved and despised; like a reef attracting fish, it will act as a magnet for ideas, innovations, discord and debate, all of which are healthy.
At that panel discussion, someone in the audience complained that to put jazz in Lincoln Center meant the end of the music. The music's creativity comes from clubs, went the argument, and that environment acts as an incubator for ideas and allows musicians the room to experiment, to play in front of a live audience and to learn their craft. The assumption was that once the art enters the institution, all this creativity is eliminated. But a jazz program at Lincoln Center and experimentation at Manhattan clubs like the Knitting Factory or Village Vanguard aren't mutually exclusive. The inclusion of jazz at Lincoln Center is an admission that the music is no longer the mass entertainment it was in the 20's, 30's and 40's -- hardly a revelation. It's also a declaration that jazz has ended one form of life and come alive in another.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 10; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1657 words

HEADLINE: Will the Gulf War Reignite a Battle Over Stock Futures?

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
After being in the hot seat for most of last year, Wendy Lee Gramm is not about to start gloating now. "Reports of my victory have been greatly exaggerated," she said recently, in a dry twist of Mark Twain's famous retort about his death.
Mrs. Gramm, the chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission in Chicago, appears to have prevailed in her battle to retain control over the trading in stock-index futures, which the Treasury Department had tried to put under the Securities and Exchange Commission's command last year. 
 But even as the dust settles from that fight, a new threat brought on by the war in the Persian Gulf, could return Mrs. Gramm to the political firing line. The furor over stock-index futures, the contracts to buy baskets of securities at a particular price at a future date, popular in the 1980's, could well be eclipsed by worries about speculation in oil.
With warfare in the Middle East, the prices of futures contracts for crude oil, gasoline, heating oil and other commodities are expected to go through their wildest gyrations ever. Indeed, the price of oil dropped by a third, closing on Thursday at $21.44 a barrel, after the first strike on Wednesday by the United States and allied forces on Iraq.
Extreme volatility could cause poorly positioned traders to fail, disrupting commodities markets and putting Mrs. Gramm in the hot seat again. In response to the possibilities, Mrs. Gramm has put the exchanges her agency governs -- the Chicago Board of Trade and the New York and Chicago Mercantile Exchanges -- on red alert.
Among other things, the agency has ordered them to increase their capital requirements on traders, to hunt for traders who could get into trouble by the overwhelming volatility, and to set up emergency lines of credit.
"You can never say you're prepared for every uncertainty," said Mrs. Gramm. "But we have a lot of experience dealing with volatility. This is what we do."
Nevertheless, Mrs. Gramm, who has headed the commodity commission since late 1987, appears to be prepared for another round of political heat. In her power struggle with Richard C. Breeden, chairman of the S.E.C., and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, she emerged as a steely, technically sophisticated force, overcoming the image she established during Congressional hearings after the stock market crash of 1987 as a somewhat tongue-tied academic who became lost in technical details.
"She has become recognized as a strong and active champion of the agency, and she has succeeded in getting the message across," said Robert Petersen, head of the National Grain Trade Council, one of the groups that fought the Brady proposal. "She's very outspoken, even a bit of a dynamo."
 Still, when Mr. Brady proposed that Congress shift her agency's jurisdiction over stock-index trading to the S.E.C. last spring, Mrs. Gramm appeared to be destined for a political drubbing.
To defend her agency, she had locked horns with Mr. Brady, one of President Bush's closest advisers. Although the commission is an independent regulatory agency, Mrs. Gramm was waging her battle at precisely the time that she was up for renomination by the President.
She also had to overcome harsh criticism. Wall Street has long complained that trading in stock-index futures, which are central to computerized program trading, roils the stock markets.
Critics complain that the agency is unwilling to slow the speculation by raising margin requirements -- the cash deposits required to buy a stock-index futures contract -- to levels closer to those required to trade stocks and bonds.
They also worry about the agency's inability to rein in abuses like the one that resulted in the recent series of indictments against commodities traders, who allegedly favored their own accounts over their customers'.
The mini-crash of the stock market in October 1989, which many on Wall Street blamed on program trading, renewed pressure to put the S.E.C. in charge of stock-index futures. Last spring, Mr. Brady concluded that transferring power to the S.E.C. would make it easier to "coordinate" the different markets by evening out the margin requirements.
But the original Brady proposal was stopped dead in the Senate and a much tamer compromise died in the final days of the last session of Congress.
Last week, Sen. Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont and chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, reintroduced a compromise measure that leaves the agency's power intact but gives the Federal Reserve authority to set margin requirements. The measure, though, would also let stock exchanges, under the S.E.C.'s authority, introduce products that resemble stock-index futures.
Many attribute Mrs. Gramm's success in part to her polite but tenacious determination to champion her agency. Diminutive yet intensely energetic, with a fondness for light-hearted needling, she was praised in the Brady battle for sticking to the issues rather than grandstanding.
"You could fight it on perceptions or, if you had the issues on your side, you could fight it on the issues," said Leo Melamed, who retired as chairman of the executive committee of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange last week. "Her instincts told her to stick to the issues, and that turned out to be the right move."
 Marshalling evidence from academic studies, she was able to show that a shift in jurisdiction would have no effect on the gut political issue of market turbulence. "You look at the proposals, and the reasons people want change, and there aren't any that really hold water," she said.
And thanks to the coaching of Republican supporters, including Sen. Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, she also learned to couch her arguments in the rhetoric that Washington understands. "We have become the world leader under this regulatory structure," she likes to say. "We're the ones who have been the innovative leaders in these markets. You don't want to do anything that harms them."
 Most crucial to her victory was the fierce opposition to the Brady plan from agricultural groups like the National Farmers Union, the American Farm Bureau Federation, grain traders and commodity exporters. They immediately waged a full-scale lobbying offensive, fearing that reducing the commission's power could inadvertently damage its ability to regulate commodity futures like grain, which farmers use to insulate themselves against price changes.
As the debate proceeded and became increasingly mired in technical issues, lawmakers began to view it as little more than a turf battle between the agencies. On balance, that made the Brady plan seem more controversial and less compelling.
 Her nomination by President Bush in the midst of the battle for a second, two-year term as chairman of the commission also helped solidify her position. She was confirmed by the Senate in August.
In fact, the debate about the market volatility of stock-index futures has since become almost moot. The go-go 80's have evolved into the debt-worried 90's, causing trading in stock-index futures to plunge by about 40 percent since the crash of 1987. Today, the hottest pits at the Chicago Merc, which pioneered stock-index futures, trade Eurodollar contracts, used as hedges against short-term interest rates, and Treasury bond futures, or hedges against long-term rates.
The Persian Gulf conflict has suddenly thrust oil futures into that lineup and prompted the commission to prepare for chaos. For a start, the agency ordered the exchanges to run what amount to computerized war-games, in which computers simulate the impact that a major price jolt would have on particular traders.
These "what if" simulations are not new to traders. But in instructions issued on Dec. 26, the commission told the exchanges to test what seemed like unimaginable price swings -- say, a swing of as much as $15 a barrel in the price of crude oil in a single day -- to pinpoint the most vulnerable traders.
The agency has told so-called clearing firms, which provide traders with day-to-day credit, to look out for traders who, among other things, lack well-established records or who may have loaded up too heavily on a particular commodity.
In addition, the agency is pushing firms to set up special wire-transfer arrangements so that traders can move unusually large amounts of cash to cover their obligations. Fearful that big traders may default anyway, setting up what could be a domino effect of unmet obligations, the regulators have urged clearing companies to arrange extra lines of bank credit.
Finally, the exchanges themselves have dramatically increased the amount of cash traders need to put down as deposits when they buy contracts for oil, gasoline or even stock-index futures.
 
 
A BELTWAY BACKGROUND
 Wendy Gramm is an economist by training. The granddaughter of Korean immigrants -- her grandfather worked in the sugar cane fields of Hawaii -- Mrs. Gramm graduated from Wellesley College and earned a Ph.D. in economics at Northwestern University.
She met her husband, Sen. Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, when she took a teaching job in the department of economics at Texas A&M, where Mr. Gramm was a professor of economics. After Mr. Gramm was elected to Congress in 1978, she was hired by James Miller 3d at the Federal Trade Commission and later followed Mr. Miller to the Office of Management and Budget.
There, as director of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs, she played a key role in the Reagan Administration's efforts to deregulate industry -- an effort that drew fire from Capitol Hill but earned her kudos in the White House. "One of the things I've found in Washington is that you don't agree with everybody," she said.
On one occasion, President Reagan reportedly called Mrs. Gramm "my favorite economist." He nominated her in 1987 to head the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

LENGTH: 1250 words

HEADLINE: Roemer's New Tack for Old Problems

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BATON ROUGE, La.

 BODY:
As visitors to the Louisiana governor's mansion pass the guard's desk they are likely to see a photograph of the current occupant showing him in profile with his eyes squinting and his mouth tight. It is very much the angry young man that Buddy Roemer used to be.
The portrait, however, would seem to be out of date. Governor Roemer has recently taken to proclaiming himself a changed man both personally and politically. 
 Mr. Roemer, a Democrat, is seeking re-election this year, and the race promises to be bruising. His likely opponents in one of the major political events of this election cycle are David Duke, the Republican State Representative and former Ku Klux Klan leader who ran unsuccessfully for the United States Senate last fall, and Edwin Edwards, the Democrat whom Mr. Roemer unseated in 1987.
A "Roemer revolution" was what the Governor promised in 1988 when he took over a Louisiana government rotted with corruption and on the brink of financial collapse. Back then he was tirelessly righteous in demanding that people follow his prescription for civic salvation.
The preacher's fury that marked his pleas for reform is now rarely seen. Cheerful boosterism has entered his repertory along with self-deprecating jokes, as when Mr. Roemer, a former Congressman with two Harvard degrees, introduces himself as "just an old redneck from Bossier City."
Timothy Ryan, an economist at the University of New Orleans, said: "The Governor came in wanting to make major changes in a blitzkrieg fashion. But now he is taking a much more gradual approach, seeking smaller changes and assuming a lower profile himself."
 
'I Paid a High Price'
 On a more personal level, the Governor said that after going through a divorce last year, "I decided that I wasn't any good to anybody if I didn't have peace and happiness and comfort in this job."
He added: "For my first 30 months in office I tended to be angry. I had good reason to be angry. I fed on my anger. It was a source of energy, but I paid a high price for it."
Taking over what he called "a sinking ship," the Governor faced conditions that in some ways paralleled those confronting governors of financially troubled states today. Mr. Roemer introduced some modern management practices to the baroque, patronage-heavy world of Louisiana government, and he redirected spending toward environmental protection and education.
Louisiana's economic condition stabilized in the aftermath of the collapse of oil prices in the 1980's. And through borrowing and tax increases, the state government moved from monstrous deficits to balanced budgets. As a result, the rating on Louisiana's state bonds improved last month for the first time in 21 years.
But some of Governor Roemer's boldest ideas, including his plan to overhaul Louisiana's tax system to reduce the state's reliance on revenues from the oil and gas industry, were rejected either by the Legislature or by voters in referendums. As a result, Mr. Roemer has altered his tactics.
 
Complicated Campaign Likely
 No longer an angry outsider who can simply denounce the corruption and torpor of the past, the 47-year-old incumbent will have a record to defend in next fall's elections. Moreover, the political dynamics could be complicated by others on the ballot.
Mr. Duke, who appeals to white crowds by telling them how much they suffer when government helps blacks, captured 44 percent of the vote in his first statewide race, challenging the Democratic incumbent Senator, J. Bennett Johnston Jr., last fall.
Announcing his intent to run earlier this month, Mr. Duke said, "If we don't slow down the cycle of taxes and spending our state has been in for so long, I think we are headed for ruin."
Also considering a candidacy is Mr. Edwards, who dominated much of Louisiana politics in the 1970's and 1980's.
Mr. Edwards said in a television appearance last year: "Buddy Roemer is weak. It would be fun to run against him and use his campaign ads from three years ago to remind people what he said on TV then and compare them to what he has actually done."
Under Louisiana's open primary system the Democrats, Governor Roemer and Mr. Edwards, and the Republican, Mr. Duke, and any other candidates would all run against one another on the same ballot Oct. 19. If no one captured more than half the votes, the top two would face off in November.
In a recent interview, the Governor predicted a tangled three-way race. Then, putting down a cigarette, he held his hands far apart to represent Mr. Duke and Mr. Edwards.
"I'm in here," he said, indicating the space between his hands, "and I think the voters will reject the extremes. I think most of us live in the center. I think most of us build our homes on solid land."
As an example of his moderation, Mr. Roemer cited his decision to veto two anti-abortion bills passed by the legislature last summer because, he said, they did not make sufficient exception for victims of rape and incest.
 
'Serious Flamethrower
 Charles Elson Roemer 3d was born in Shreveport and attended school in Bossier City, a town of 50,000. After Harvard, he managed Scopena, the family's cotton plantation, and worked as a business executive and a banker. In 1980, he won a seat in Congress on his second try.
"I was a very serious flamethrower and maverick," he said of his time in Washington, frequently voting with Republicans on economic issues.
When he challenged Governor Edwards, Mr. Roemer was little known outside his Congressional district, but he came from behind to win an eight-way primary. Mr. Edwards, who had been twice tried and acquitted of corruption charges, declined to enter the runoff.
Governor Roemer's most sweeping objective was tax revision. He argued that the state leaned too heavily on business and allowed too many people to avoid property taxes.
In April 1989, after a long and heated campaign, the voters rejected the core of the "Roemer Revolution," defeating by 55 percent to 45 percent a constitutional amendment that would have made extensive tax changes.
"That hit me hard," he said. "I had a period of self-examination. I found that even my allies worried about my anger and I was turning off the people who I needed."
Governor Roemer went before a new session of the legislature last April and made a startling apology. He told the lawmakers: "I felt driven by the desperate conditions to take no prisoners, to tolerate minimum dissent, and to allow my anger at finding Louisiana in such dire straits to guide my approach to you and to this job. Please forgive me if you can."
Some opponents and some of those he offended are skeptical. "At first Buddy wanted us to step in line because he knew best," said Jim Carvin, a New Orleans political consultant. "Now he's saying, 'Do what I say because I'm a nice guy.' What's the difference?"
One difference is that he is now proposing incremental changes, and having far greater success. The voters have affirmed constitutional amendments that created three types of tax increases and made important changes in the way the state's money is handled.
Change has brought Governor Roemer some political risk. "The oil and chemical people feel they've been hit hard on the environmental side by Buddy but haven't seen the big changes he promised on the tax side," said Ed Steimel, a veteran Baton Rouge lobbyist for business interests. "They may back Edwards even if they think he is a scoundrel."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "For my first 30 months in office I tended to be angry," said Gov. Buddy Roemer of Louisiana. "I had good reason to be angry. I fed on my anger. It was a source of energy, but I paid a high price for it." (Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Making It

BYLINE: By Roy Larson; Roy Larson is the publisher of The Chicago Reporter, an investigative monthly that covers issues of race and poverty.

 BODY:

BREAKING BARRIERS
A Memoir.
By Carl T. Rowan.
Illustrated. 395 pp. Boston:
Little, Brown & Company. $22.95. 
 At the age of 65, after 40 years of high-profile journalism and Government service in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, Carl T. Rowan now looks back, mostly in satisfaction, at a life spent breaking down barriers imposed -- but not for long in his case -- by the structures of race and class in American society.
Mr. Rowan has been moving at a fast clip from the day he boarded a Jim Crow train in his hometown of McMinnville, Tenn., to join the Navy, where at 19 he became one of its first black officers and gentlemen. Determined after the war "to bust open the lily-white journalistic establishment in America," he enrolled at Oberlin College and was encouraged to write by an English teacher who, after reading "an angry bit of prose" he had shown her, told him, "I think you'll make it." Her affirmation, Mr. Rowan writes in "Breaking Barriers," "put 40 years of wind under my wings."
That wind carried him to The Minneapolis Tribune in 1948. After two years on the copy desk, Mr. Rowan went on general assignment with the understanding that, as he told his editor, "You will not assign me to any story simply because I'm a Negro; you will never deny me an assignment simply because I'm a Negro." For The Tribune and Mr. Rowan, the deal paid off quickly. His career soared after he toured the South in 1951 and wrote an 18-part series, "How Far From Slavery?"
His flight path after that took him on assignments at home and abroad and eventually to stints as a State Department spokesman and Ambassador to Finland in the Kennedy Administration. In 1964 President Lyndon B. Johnson named him to succeed the ailing Edward R. Murrow as director of the United States Information Agency. Since leaving that position in 1965 he has been a nationally syndicated columnist for The Chicago Sun-Times and a regular on the television talk show "Inside Washington."
If Mr. Rowan's anecdotally rich memoir is self-serving, so be it. Although there is hardly a scene where he does not give himself either the last word or the best line, that's all right, because the interests of a whole spectrum of readers are well served, too -- from subway riders looking for a quick read to serious students of contemporary American culture, who will treasure his vignettes for what they reveal about the state of race relations in this country during a half-century of convulsive change.
Not everyone will enjoy this book, of course. If he reads it, Ronald Reagan, for one, will hate it. "For all his selective amnesia and his personal charm," Mr. Rowan writes in summary of the Reagan years, "Ronald Reagan knew precisely what he was doing to America and Americans. I would never find reason to forgive him." And if there still are active members of the J. Edgar Hoover Fan Club around, they will be enraged by Mr. Rowan's lingering questions about what role he suspects the Federal Bureau of Investigation played in events leading up to the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr.
But most of all this book will infuriate several prominent black Americans because Mr. Rowan, besides breaking barriers, breaks ranks and dares to speak candidly to his black brothers, from the former Washington Mayor Marion Barry to the former Atlanta Mayor Andrew Young, from Louis Farrakhan (a "trash-the-Jews demagogue") to the Rev. Jesse Jackson (who is advised to show in 1992 "something other than his ability to run the Democratic Party . . . into the ground").
Not surprisingly, given the amount of publicity it received, Mr. Rowan devotes his penultimate chapter to a straightforward but indignant account of "the shot heard round my world." In June 1988 Mr. Rowan became a cause celebre when he wounded an intruder who was trying to break into his Washington home. The intruder was shot in the wrist by Mr. Rowan, who fired an unregistered pistol. Although the charges filed against him for possessing the weapon were dismissed by a jury, Mr. Rowan, still capable of angry prose, recalls that incident as a time when "fate came close to wiping out every honor I ever received and destroying me personally."
Mr. Rowan comes out in his closing chapter shooting verbally with both barrels, one for whites, the other for blacks.
"White leadership playing to white racism is largely responsible for America's crime, drug, unemployment, education, and other woes," he writes. "But I cannot exhort white America to a new agenda for this nation without first telling my fellow blacks how they have contributed to the malaise within this society. . . . We black people must get away from ceremony and memories and self-congratulations for deeds done a quarter century ago and deal with the problems of today."
It has never been easy -- some would say it is impossible -- to be a prophet with honor on both sides of a biracial society divided against itself. Carl Rowan has tried -- and he has done it far better than most.
 
WHAT HAS HAPPENED TO THE MOVEMENT?
 You look back over six decades and you see a lot of people, groups, individuals, political parties, that you think have let America down. In every year of breaking barriers I have thought . . . about how we black people have let ourselves down. I still see myriad ways in which we imprison ourselves.
I almost weep when I see what has happened to the civil rights movement, the bloody struggles for racial justice for blacks, Hispanics, and other minorities, and governmental and private compassion for the poor, the hopeless of this land. So much that was won over the bites of police dogs, the truncheons of bigoted cops, has been diluted -- or lost. . . .
I watched on television a black reenactment of the outrages in Selma a generation past. There were Jesse Jackson and a host of others, in Reagan-type photo opportunities, saying, "Look what we did." Tote up the costs of the airplane tickets and hotel rooms of those who put on that exercise of self-applause and see that the money could have provided hundreds of college scholarships to black kids who were abandoned by Reagan.
That reenactment in Selma didn't change a city government that is still driven by notions of "white power forever." Spending that money on bright young blacks could change another generation. -- From "Breaking Barriers."

HEADLINE: Liberating the Slaves and Himself

BYLINE: By Frederick Allen; Frederick Allen is the managing editor of American Heritage magazine.

 BODY:

ABRAHAM LINCOLN AND THE SECOND AMERICAN REVOLUTION
By James M. McPherson.
173 pp. New York:
Oxford University Press. $17.95. 
 The recent surge of popular interest in the Civil War did not begin with last fall's PBS television series; it started in 1988, with the publication of James M. McPherson's one-volume history of the Civil War era, "Battle Cry of Freedom." That 900-page book was a sprawling and comprehensive narrative; now Mr. McPherson follows it with a slim volume of short essays that go right to the heart of the meaning of the war and Abraham Lincoln's role in it. How could the two sides have espoused such opposite notions of liberty? Was the North fighting for union or against slavery? What was Lincoln's real feeling about abolition? And what, finally, did it all achieve? Such questions linger for many students of the war despite all the books. Mr. McPherson, a professor of American history at Princeton University, goes right at them in crystal-clear, well-reasoned, supremely informed essays.
The first and last of these address the giant question of what, ultimately, the war accomplished. Mr. McPherson takes issue with those who, especially in the 1960's and 70's, have argued that the Civil War changed little or nothing, that Lincoln's "new birth of freedom" never happened. The war, he argues, left the regional balance of power in the nation forever reversed, the slavery-based economy of the South devastated and blacks undeniably better off. Moreover, it gave liberty itself a new meaning. Liberty had always meant freedom from government power; the war made it mean freedom of opportunity, which only government power could guarantee. The Federal Government became the agent of freedom rather than its enemy. Many of the revolutionary gains won by the war were overturned in what the author calls a counterrevolution in the mid-1870's, when Reconstruction was abandoned, but that neither diminishes what had passed nor denies what endured.
The five intervening essays examine Lincoln himself -- as a conservative or a revolutionary, as a champion of the shifting concept of liberty, as Commander in Chief, as speaker and writer and, to use Isaiah Berlin's terms, as a steadfast hedgehog among wily, wavering foxes. A central theme connects all of the essays: that the very nature and purpose of the war changed radically from 1861 to 1865 and that Lincoln brilliantly perceived this, guided the conflict and saw it through. At first the war was a limited war, its only aim to put down an insurrection. But between the early Union disaster at Bull Run and the high point of Gettysburg, the conflict evolved into a full-scale war and then into total war -- a death-embrace struggle between two powers neither of which could survive unless the other was completely vanquished. The Union couldn't last if states were free to leave it; the South could not continue without disunion and slavery.
Lincoln uniquely grasped the significance of this as it happened. Since the institutions of the South would have to be smashed before the South would yield, emancipation would have to become a strategy of the war. Since the economy of the South would have to be overthrown, Lincoln would turn to total-war generals like William Tecumseh Sherman and Philip Sheridan. As emancipation became the cause, it would necessitate a whole new concept of liberty in America: freedom from government intrusion must yield to freedom enforced by government power. Lincoln saw this and gave it eloquent, powerful voice. And Lincoln's resolute single-mindedness enabled him to concentrate un swervingly on preserving the United States while virtually everyone around him hedged and panicked.
He did not consider abolishing slavery until it could become a weapon in preserving the Union. When he issued the Emancipation Proclamation, it liberated not only slaves but also Lincoln himself -- he was now freed, in Mr. McPherson's words, "from the agonizing contradiction between his 'oft-expressed personal wish that all men everywhere could be free' and his oath of office as president of a slaveholding republic. It fused the 'organizing principle' of liberty that guided Lincoln before 1861 with the 'single central vision' of Union that became his lodestar during the war."
The war proved that a republic could survive in a world of kingdoms and empires. It transformed the concept of liberty. It made the Federal Government supreme where the states had formerly prevailed. It obliterated an archaic, repressive economic system. It enfranchised blacks and created a nation in which -- at least for a time -- troops would protect that franchise. Mr. McPherson deftly and convincingly sketches out how Lincoln's vision and leadership made the necessary revolution possible.

HEADLINE: The Good Thousand Days

BYLINE: By Michael Kazin; Michael Kazin, who teaches history at American University, is the author of "Barons of Labor."

 BODY:

PROMISES KEPT
John F. Kennedy's New Frontier.
By Irving Bernstein.
Illustrated. 342 pp. New York:
Oxford University Press. $24.95. 
 It was "a wonderful time to come to work for the government," says William L. Batt Jr. about the celebrated thousand days of the Administration of John F. Kennedy. In 1961 Kennedy had plucked Mr. Batt from the Pennsylvania Department of Labor and Industry to run a new agency dedicated to reviving the economy of Appalachia and other depressed areas. The sunny words of this idealistic bureaucrat form the leitmotif of Irving Bernstein's careful but flawed study of Kennedy's domestic policies.
"Promises Kept" is a book with a mission. Mr. Bernstein, an emeritus professor of political science at the University of California, Los Angeles, portrays brilliant, energetic young men (and, very occasionally, women) who came to Washington with innovative ideas about curing racial discrimination, structural unemployment, substandard public education and apathy toward government -- fulfilling, in effect, their chief's campaign pledge to "move this country forward." Although seriously hampered by the conservative bloc in Congress, they accomplished far more, Mr. Bernstein maintains, than today's critics on either the right or the left have acknowledged. In his view, Kennedy "was a very successful President" and "the revisionists were dead wrong."
If one's critical yardstick for a Presidency is the number of significant bills signed or advanced far along the Congressional pipeline, then Mr. Bernstein makes a persuasive case. The author, who is best known for writing a fine three-volume history of American labor between the world wars, draws, with a series of lucid narratives, a balance sheet of the issues that Kennedy and his associates came into office to solve. At the time the President embarked on his fateful trip to Dallas, a comprehensive civil rights bill had easily cleared the House Judiciary Committee; the Peace Corps, manpower training and a higher minimum wage had already been enacted into law; final action was almost completed on a measure to pay for construction at many colleges; and, despite the expense of these new programs, Congress was about to pass a tax cut for both individuals and corporations. Only Medicare was stalled, a victim of the American Medical Association's relentless campaign against what it called socialized medicine and of widespread fears of what the first Federal health insurance program might cost.
While gracefully written, Mr. Bernstein's study is not for readers who like their history filled with high drama, intriguing personalities or glimpses of anonymous faces in the crowd. Aside from his chapters on civil rights, which retrace familiar ground, all the subjects he discusses were debated, the bills won or lost, largely within a small network of policy intellectuals, elected officials and their aides. Most had spent their careers battling over the social policy terrain first charted during the New Deal.
In passing, Mr. Bernstein does provide acute thumbnail portraits of a few liberal heroes, such as the cantankerous Senator Wayne Morse, who worked tirelessly for education bills and received Kennedy's praise as "the only man in the Senate who speaks in precise paragraphs without a text." But on the whole, Mr. Bernstein is content to demonstrate, in great detail, how well the President and his men maneuvered through the heavy legislative undergrowth, always willing to compromise in order to gain a higher, enlightened end.
And therein lies the problem. Mr. Bernstein's approach cannot refute more significant criticisms of the New Frontier (and of Lyndon Johnson's Great Society, the subject of Mr. Bernstein's next book) that transcend the question of which proposals got through Congress. Was the antipoverty program doomed from the start because it didn't attempt to redistribute income, as advocates on the left charge? Did the imposition of new Federal agencies and regulations retard economic growth and punish entrepreneurial initiative, as those on the right contend? Did the decision to emphasize aid to specific groups identified as disadvantaged -- blacks, senior citizens, the chronically unemployed -- alienate middle-class whites who could have been attracted by more universal programs?
To praise the creative energies of the New Frontiersmen and to chronicle their achievements are honorable tasks for an unrepentant liberal. But Mr. Bernstein's account cannot explain why Kennedy's political ideology, as distinct from his iconographic renown, began a steep decline in popularity a few years after his death. In domestic policy, as with the war in Indochina, the best and the brightest failed to comprehend the mounting discontent of the not-so-silent majority.
 
 
WHISPER IT IN GEORGETOWN
 Joseph P. Kennedy, the President-elect's father, had urged his brother for Attorney General. But Robert did not want the job. He was worried about the charge of nepotism. Also, "I had been chasing bad men for three years and I didn't want to spend the rest of my life doing that." Finally, he did not relish the prospect of the "Kennedy brothers" taking the heat on civil rights. He really wanted to be the number two man at Defense responsible for closing the so-called "missile gap." But Robert S. McNamara, the new secretary, thought it would be awkward having the President's brother taking orders from him. John, therefore, reluctantly concluded that Robert should go to Justice. He wanted someone he trusted near at hand and he was certain that Robert would make a fine Attorney General. Both expected sharp criticism. When asked how he would make the announcement, John said, "I'll open the front door of the Georgetown house some morning about 2:00 a.m., look up and down the street, and, if there's no one there, I'll whisper, 'It's Bobby.' " The appointment got a bad press. John tried to laugh it off: He wanted to give his brother "a little legal experience before he goes out to practice law." -- From "Promises Kept."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 19; Column 2; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4127 words

HEADLINE: HARLEM'S ARDENT VOICE

BYLINE: By Joel Dreyfuss; Joel Dreyfuss is the managing editor of Business Tokyo, a New York-based magazine. He also writes frequently about black-American affairs for various publications.

 BODY:
THE REV. CALVIN O. BUTTS 3D HAS JUST been badly disappointed by a telephone call. His effort to arrange a meeting with a major religious leader has been rejected. Sitting in his modest office, the 20th pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem pauses for a moment to regain his composure. Finally, he leans forward in the way he has of making every conversation seem intimate. An uncommon weariness creeps into his voice. "I came from the left," says Butts, joining his palms over the left edge of his cluttered desk. "I moved to the center because I have this institution." The hands shift to the middle of the desk. "I'm trying to work in the center." He shrugs inside his double-breasted suit. "I don't want people to be surprised when I finally flip out. I want people to know we did try and we were rejected."
The incident is a glimpse at the private battle that rages inside Calvin Butts. Taking control a year and a half ago of what may be the most famous black church in America, he has become one of the most visible new leaders in New York City. The early reviews from church members, politicians and fellow pastors have been good. His church, once led by the flamboyant Adam Clayton Powell Jr., is standing room only on Sundays and the collection plate is full. "Abyssinian," as old-time Harlemites call it, has long been a center of hope and social action for black New Yorkers, and Butts, as the leader of that church, has a following that draws the attention of politicians and positions him as an emerging force for social change. 
 Butts, however, is a product of the 1960's; moderation and compromise, so essential in politics, do not come easily to him. So the 41-year-old pastor is leading a double life. There is the establishment Butts: managing the construction of several multimillion-dollar housing complexes that will serve the elderly and the poor in Harlem; building coalitions with leaders of other black churches; working, until recently, as chairman of the Harlem Y.M.C.A.; joining a group of community leaders hoping to create a replacement for the bankrupt Freedom National Bank. Then there is Butts the protest leader: whitewashing billboards that pitch tobacco and alcohol to blacks and picketing the corporate headquarters of Philip Morris Companies; thundering against police brutality and economic injustice, lashing black and white political leaders for "opportunism" and a "lack of courage"; associating with controversial figures like the lawyers C. Vernon Mason and Alton H. Maddox Jr.; quoting the Black Muslim minister Louis Farrakhan; challenging pillars of the establishment like John Cardinal O'Connor and the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau.
His ambivalence is similar to the one that blacks have wrestled with for generations. What is the best way to make change? Do you build institutions or do you agitate? Do you work within the establishment or attack it from outside? Do you assimilate or create a black base?
In a city where black leadership is often defined by access to the news media, Butts is a very visible figure. He has been in the spotlight almost since he arrived at Abyssinian as a junior minister in 1972. He has been willing -- some would say eager -- to plunge into controversy and politics, prompting comparisons with the Rev. Adam Clayton Powell Jr., the politically ambitious minister who used his church base to catapult himself into elected office. "I'm just running for the kingdom of God," Butts says dutifully. But within moments of this denial he talks about the temptations of elected office.
There is no evidence of ambivalence on Sunday mornings, when Butts presides over the rousing service at the Gothic-style church on West 138th Street between Malcolm X Boulevard and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard. The congregation is solidly black and middle-class, about evenly divided between elderly and middle-aged Harlem residents and younger, more affluent black professionals who come from the West Side, the boroughs outside Manhattan, from Long Island and New Jersey. European tourists, whispering excitedly in French, Italian and German, shuffle into back pews, anticipating a "real Harlem" experience.
Butts's voice can plummet to a whisper, roar with emotion, cajole, plead and snap with humor as he talks about politics, world affairs or relations between ethnic groups in the city. But his sermons are more cerebral than a lot of Baptists are used to. His talks are sprinkled with learned references: quotations from philosophers and black intellectuals, as well as verse from psalms and spirituals.
One Sunday, Butts asks a man, whom he recognizes from the cover of Black Enterprise magazine, to stand. "I hear you're worth $2.4 million, brother; we want to talk to you," says Butts, to a ripple of laughter. On another Sunday, Butts announces the presence of Marvis Martin, a former choir member who has performed in a Metropolitan Opera production of "Porgy and Bess." She comes forward and quickly establishes the world-class quality of her voice in a spiritual that raises goose bumps. Butts's celebrations of success are not casual. In a community so often identified with failure and pathology, his digressions are reminders that it does have successes and triumphs.
Black involvement in Christianity began when slave owners decided that turning their property into good Christians might help tame the slaves. But the church's teachings, as interpreted by blacks, quickly became a rallying point for resistance, a shelter from the storm of racial prejudice and repression, a safe harbor where black people could walk out recharged and girded for the battles they must wage in a hostile world. It is important to see Butts in this context to remember his primary mission: ministering to his flock.

A MEETING IN BUTTS'S office over a neighborhood dispute shows how charming he can be. An executive and a community affairs director for a telephone company meet with Butts to respond to a community activist's complaints that the utility is cutting services to Harlem. The complaint was triggered when the phone company stopped doing business with a black-owned Harlem company that had been subcontracted to receive phone payments. The phone company representative explains that the subcontractor ran into financial problems. The phone company reopened an uptown office so that Harlem residents could pay bills, place orders and make deposits without traveling downtown.
Butts listens carefully, takes notes and asks questions. He finally seems satisfied that there is no role for him here. He banters with the phone company man. What school did he go to? What church does he attend? Butts seems genuinely disappointed that the man belongs to a congregation on Long Island.
"Well, come to our church when you can."
I will, says the phone company man.
"May I call you if I have a problem?"
Absolutely, says the man, handing over a card with his home number scribbled on the back. Calvin Butts has just acquired a direct line to the senior management of the phone company.
The issues that grab Butts's attention don't always find a tidy resolution. He has been criticized for flitting from one cause to another. "I'm working on that," he says, plowing through a stack of telephone messages and requests for speaking appearances. "I'm learning how to say 'No.' " What about his well-publicized campaign to whitewash billboards advertising liquor and tobacco in Harlem? "It's on hiatus," he concedes, complaining that he didn't get the support of other church leaders.
Some community leaders who depend on tobacco companies for financing and charitable support said their programs were damaged. "Calvin's campaign has been used by companies who did not want to do much in our communities anyway," says Lloyd A. Williams, president of the Uptown Chamber of Commerce. Butts responds that nothing prevents the companies from advertising less-harmful products. But why not continue to picket? He offers a vague explanation about not wanting to let his supporters picket without him because they might get arrested, then acknowledges that things might have gone better with more cooperation from his fellow pastors. "I might have tried harder to enlist their support," he admits.
He has begun to apply the same sort of self-criticism to his relationship with New York politicians. Butts says he has muted his comments about black politicians because of an insight acquired at a meeting with Edward I. Koch, who was then the Mayor. Koch bluntly told a group of black community leaders that he owed them nothing because they had not supported him at the polls. Butts conceded to Koch's raw political logic. He thought about how he himself had criticized a former Manhattan Borough President, Percy E. Sutton, during Sutton's mayoral campaign and how different the meeting might have been had Sutton been behind the Mayor's desk instead of Koch. "I used to fight Charlie Rangel all the time," says Butts, referring to the Democratic Representative from Harlem. "I realized: he's the Congressman. Unless you run against him or support someone against him, you might as well work with him the best you can without compromising your principles."
Butts has been able to work with politicians when he wants to. When Andrew J. Stein was Manhattan Borough President, Butts lobbied him for money for the Harlem Y.M.C.A. The minister came to his office and presented the case for the Y. Then he got Stein to come up to Harlem to see the center. Stein remembers him as forceful and persuasive. "Resources were very scarce," Stein says, "but he convinced us." The Y.M.C.A. got $750,000. Still, it's not only Butts's charm or moral suasion that draws an Andy Stein to Harlem. It's the political clout of Abyssinian and a half-century of conscientious voting habits among its members, and the perception that Calvin Butts is a leader who can influence those voters.
Some of Butts's proposals would startle those who would categorize him as another black liberal. He would order the enforcement of laws against public nuisance: gambling, public drinking and public urination. He would set curfews for teen-agers and confiscate cars in which loud music is being played. His strategy would find support among criminologists who argue that a sense of public order reduces crime. He's also shrewd about the political outrage it would cause. "On some of that stuff, you'd have fights with the unions and the civil liberties groups, but I would win the support of New Yorkers -- black and white," Butts says. "You'd get cooperation because people would begin to see the difference."
But the Calvin Butts who can sound like a mayoral candidate and calculate the mainstream political support he might win still lapses easily into his old activist posture. He complains that Ed Koch, a former nemesis, was more accessible than Mayor David N. Dinkins. He says he's been frustrated in his efforts to get a meeting with Cardinal O'Connor. (The Cardinal's office denies he's been approached.) "I get the sense there is absolutely no regard for black religious leadership on the part of these leaders," Butts says.
Further, Butts has engaged in a very public battle with District Attorney Morgenthau over the lack of administrators from minority groups on the prosecutor's staff. Morgenthau's office says the number of blacks working for the District Attorney has vastly increased during his tenure. Butts says that response fails to answer the question of black administrators. The District Attorney refused to further discuss the conflict for this article, but disagreements between the two men go back a few years. In 1985, Butts was chairman of Vernon Mason's quixotic campaign against Morgenthau. Although Mason was given no chance by political experts and had a total budget of $70,000, he collected a surprising 32 percent of the vote.
Mason's credibility has since been badly damaged by the Tawana Brawley case. However, Butts, who has been known to have furious arguments with Mason, refuses to discuss the substance of those disputes and continues to defend their friendship. Mason is an apprentice deacon at Abyssinian and a fellow graduate of Morehouse College in Atlanta. "If the Brawley case proves to be a hoax -- I don't think it has been proven -- Mason is in it only because he was lied to," Butts says.
The minister also refuses to condemn the other controversial attorney in the Brawley case, Alton Maddox, who has been suspended from practice because of his refusal to appear at a New York State disciplinary committee. Maddox, he says, was the first New York lawyer to send him a detailed paper on the problems in New York's criminal-justice system. Says Butts: "It's a travesty of justice to have him suspended." One suspects that Maddox appeals to the protest side of Butts, that Maddox is a renegade lawyer fighting for truth and justice, and the minister won't abandon him because the establishment has turned against him.

CALVIN BUTTS, WHO will soon be moving from the South Bronx to Harlem with his wife, Patricia, and three children, was born in New York City. His father worked as a chef in Manhattan; his mother was a supervisor in the city's welfare system. Until he was 8, Butts lived in the predominantly black and Hispanic Lillian Wald Houses on the Lower East Side. Many summers his family sent him south to visit relatives. His grandmothers, both committed Christians, lived a few miles apart in rural Georgia and the young Calvin spent a lot of time in churches.
In 1957, his family moved to a mostly black section of Queens. Racial self-awareness and self-help were part of family life. "My father was the kind who would say, 'If a black man opens a store, go shop in it,' " Butts recalls. He also remembers an uncle who was an ardent black nationalist bringing an early recording by Louis Farrakhan to the Butts house. The title was: "A White Man's Heaven Is a Black Man's Hell." But there was no preaching or railing against whites in his immediate family. He was bused to junior high school in Forest Hills at a time when white parents were protesting integration via busing, and he went on to attend the predominantly white Flushing High School in 1963. One measure of his ability to appeal across racial lines was evident in his senior year, when he was elected class president.
In the fall of 1967, Butts enrolled at Morehouse, one of the most prestigious black colleges in the United States and a fountainhead of black leadership. Faculty members and fellow students remember Butts as a student who stood out. One reason was that he often wore a suit and carried a briefcase and looked like a graduate student or professor. Another was that he was very inquisitive. "Calvin was always ready with the 'What if?' remembers Anna Grant, chairwoman of the sociology department at Morehouse. "But he also managed to disagree without being obnoxious."
The late 1960's was a time of anger and rebellion for many young blacks. Daniel Klenbort, one of a number of whites who taught at Morehouse, had Butts in his freshman history class. "One day he walked into class and asked: 'What would you do if I came to class with a gun?' " Klenbort remembers. "I said: 'Well, that's where discussion ends and coercion begins. I'd throw you out of class.' He seemed satisfied with that answer. I think he appreciated that I wasn't threatened by the anger. He had the militancy and he also managed to be a good student."
Butts's anger against racial injustice boiled over on the night in 1968 that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was killed. Butts and several other students joined the rioting, and he admits that they firebombed a neighborhood store. For a few unforgettable seconds, Butts found himself staring down the barrel of an Atlanta policeman's shotgun. He escaped unharmed, but that moment of confrontation convinced him that violence was not the solution he wanted to embrace.
A Morehouse education was rooted in the classics but leavened with black history and a sense of racial responsibility. Butts's list of people who inspired him reflect the dichotomy that continues to haunt his actions. On one hand he lists conventional black establishment figures: the theologian Howard Thurman; Dr. Benjamin Elijah Mays, who was president of Morehouse; Mordecai Wyatt Johnson, a renowned black educator who was president of Howard University. Then there are the revolutionaries: Malcolm X, of course; the slave rebels Nat Turner and Denmark Vesey; the abolitionist Sojourner Truth.
What gives the list coherence for Butts is religion. All his heroes were preachers, formally trained or lay. But he felt no tug to the cloth as a student. He went to Morehouse planning to study industrial psychology. But when three seminary recruiters turned up on his campus within three days, he said he thought "somebody" was trying to tell him something. He switched to philosophy with a minor in religion. When he graduated from Morehouse, he went to Union Theological Seminary in New York and soon channeled his anger into religious commitment.
Butts's new direction didn't dampen his propensity for controversy. Classmates at Union remember a sermon Butts delivered in which he started out talking about black-white relations, but, somehow, segued into condeming homosexuality. It was an unorthodox view at the liberal seminary -- but a fairly conventional position for black Baptist preachers. Today, he still says the Bible condemns homosexuality as a sin, but he has been outspoken in defending the rights of homosexuals. Richard Goldstein, executive editor of The Village Voice and a gay-rights advocate, praises Butts on his opposition to violence against homosexuals. "What sticks with me is his specifically including gay people as people who are victims of violence," Goldstein says. "Nobody's demonstrating not to be called a sinner."
Butts was recruited by the Abyssinian Baptist Church in 1972. William S. Epps, now pastor of Los Angeles's Second Baptist Church and then an associate minister at Abyssinian, was asked by Abyssinian's newly installed pastor, the Rev. Dr. Samuel D. Proctor, to recruit some young ministers for his staff. Epps was impressed by Butts: "He had a passion to do something to correct the conditions that confronted our community." For Butts, Abyssinian was the ideal place to test his theories of the ministry as a vehicle for social change.
The church's central role in social issues should be no surprise; the tradition goes back to its very beginnings. Abyssinian's beginnings go back to 1808 when 13 Ethiopian merchants had tried to worship at a white Baptist church in the Wall Street area. When they were ordered to sit in the segregated balcony, the merchants, along with several African-Americans and a white preacher from Boston, started their own church a few blocks away, naming it after the old word for Ethiopia. The Abyssinian church eventually followed the black migration further and further uptown.
When Adam Clayton Powell Sr. retired as pastor of Abyssinian in 1937, 14 years after moving the congregation to Harlem, his son Adam Jr. took over. Almost immediately, a group of black doctors asked Powell to help them get the right to practice at Harlem Hospital. He began a series of successful attacks on barriers that had made New York as segregated as any Southern city, using boycotts and demonstrations to force the telephone company, a bus company and the stores on 125th Street to start hiring blacks.
The church, built by Powell Sr. on a formula of self-reliance, ballot power and Baptist theology, was the base for Powell Jr.'s civil rights activities and a perfect platform for his leap into politics. By the 1950's, he was the most influential black politician in America and in 1960 became chairman of the powerful House Education and Labor Committee. But Powell was as much the bon vivant as he was the legislator and he neglected his base. In the early 1960's, he became embroiled in a protracted defamation-of-character lawsuit. Found guilty and fined, he initially refused to pay the sum and only ventured to New York on Sundays to avoid arrest for contempt of court. By the time he died in 1972, Abyssinian was in deep trouble.
Powell's sucessor, Samuel Proctor, refocused the church on its mission. During the 17 years of his tenure, Proctor said the annual operating budget soared from $146,000 to over $1 million. He kept a low profile on public issues and managed to avoid becoming a household name in New York. Proctor also knew how to delegate. He turned over much of the day-to-day operations to his eager young associates. Butts was initially hired as youth minister to oversee the church's programs for children and teen-agers, but became a one-man media blitz. He criticized black and white politicians, including Percy Sutton, then the Manhattan Borough President, and Charles B. Rangel, who had taken over Powell's seat in Congress. He called Mayor Koch a "racist" and an "opportunist." He accused New York's black elected officials of being afraid to take a stand on issues like police brutality. Butts traveled to Washington to urge John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan and then chairman of the House Subcommittee on Criminal Justice, to hold police-brutality hearings, which were then held in New York in 1983.
He refused to condemn Farrakhan's reference to Judaism as a "gutter religion" in 1986, triggering a boycott of an Abyssinian concert by more than a third of New York Philharmonic's players. Butts said later that if anyone had asked him, he would have condemned Farrakhan's attacks on Judaism. Instead, he said, he was being asked to repudiate the Black Muslim preacher, whose doctrine of self-help he continues to embrace. "I will not be your boy," he told Jewish leaders through the newspapers. The concert series, a marvelous extension of downtown into the increasingly isolated Harlem community, came to an end.
As Butts became identified with some of the city's most controversial figures, his ties grew to be useful to the establishment. For instance, in 1987, he served as a liaison between Mason-Maddox and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's office in setting up a special prosecutor in the Howard Beach racial assault case.
But however visible he became in the 1980's, Butts, unlike Powell, didn't neglect his work for the church. He performed the hospital visits, baptisms and funerals and other routines of a young minister. In the process, he built important ties with church members. Other young ministers came and went, but Butts stayed. "He recognized he was in a place where the action was," says Lawrence Jones, dean of students at Union Theological when Butts arrived at the school and now head of Howard University's School of Divinity. Jones also credits the management style of Proctor with Butts's progress. "Calvin never had the feeling he was just an assistant pastor. He was part of the ministry."
Eventually, Butts won over key members of the congregation. When Proctor announced he was retiring, he recommended Butts for the job. The board of deacons met and voted, in a secret ballot, to waive the bylaw requiring a search for a new pastor. Butts was then voted in, being named on 89 percent of the ballots.

CHARLES RANGEL says New York is due for a generational change of black leadership. The established leaders of the black community are all in their 60's now: Rangel, Dinkins, Percy Sutton, the former chairman of Inner City Broadcasting, Basil A. Paterson, a former New York Secretary of State. Butts is often linked to an emerging generation of black Harlem politicians whose primary political experience was forged in the 1960's: State Senator David A. Paterson, son of Basil; A. Virginia Fields, Councilwoman from Harlem, and Peggy M. Shepard, Democratic district leader from West Harlem who some expect will run for a seat on the newly redistricted City Council. While their ages and experiences may be similar to Butts's, they have made their choice to play inside the boundaries of the political establishment. Butts, meanwhile, shifts uneasily between being an impatient, dissatisfied outsider and the leader of a respected institution. He has an effective forum and is now looking for the most effective voice.
Butts's inaugural sermon as pastor of Abyssinian in 1989 signaled that restlessness. "I have a dream" he said, in a nod to Martin Luther King Jr.'s famous speech: "It's time to move from the hope to making what we hoped about and dreamed about real. Now is the time for the prophecy to be fulfilled. We must make this real."

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT Q&A: DR. KENNETH R. DARDICK;
Tips for Staying Healthier on the Road

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
WITH the weather turning colder, a lot of people are making plans for travel to warmer places. Dr. Kenneth R. Dardick of Mansfield, the author of the recently published "Foreign Travel and Immunization Guide" (Medical Economics Books, Oradell, N.J.), is a principal in the Center for International Health and developer of Immunization Alert, a computer compilation of international health data. Dr. Dardick, 44 years old, is a family practicioner. A graduate of Dartmouth College and Harvard Medical School, he was born in New York City and grew up in the Danbury area.
In a recent interview at his office, he discussed how to travel and stay healthy. Here are some excerpts from the conversation. 
 Q. How did a family practitioner get into the field of international health?
 A. Being next to the University of Connecticut. University people do a lot of traveling. So a professor comes in and says: "Look, Ken, I'm going on sabbatical, and I need to know what I need for 10 countries. I'm going to be gone for six months." Before I came along with this service, a doctor would either have to say, "Gee, I don't know what to do," or they would have to look in the book published by the Centers for Disease Control, "Health Information for the International Traveler," look up each country, try to figure out what the codes referred to, then try to coordinate one to the other.
If you go to country A, what does country B require? It was a lot of work. And the fact is, I don't care where you practice, your patients are traveling. We are a global community. It's nothing for someone to show up in my office today, who three or four days ago was in a distant part of the world.
 Q. How important is it that the average doctor know anything about international health?
 A. Let me give you an example: we've got how many troops in Saudi Arabia now? These men and women are going to be coming back to the United States, having been exposed to a variety of exotic diseases. We need doctors here who are able to diagnose them. If you're in the military and just came back from Saudi Arabia, and you've got a non-healing sore on your leg, there is a disease called leishmaniasis, and most doctors in the U.S. don't have much awareness of it, even though it is terribly prevalent in Saudi Arabia. Some of it is a little esoteric, but some of it relates to every physician seeing patients in the United States.
 Q. How much do some of these exotic diseases pose a problem for doctors in terms of diagnosis?
 A. If someone shows up in February with flu symptoms, and everyone in town has the flu, it probably is the flu. But you know, malaria looks just like the flu, and if that patient was just in Kenya, it's not inappropriate for the doctor to do a test for malaria. There was just a bulletin published by C.D.C. about two cases in malaria in New Jersey, in two people who had gone to Mexico to be treated for Lyme disease and were purposely infected with malaria. The point is, someone could come into your office tomorrow with fever and chills and have a real oddball infection.
Someone wrote an editorial for one of the premiere medical journals, with the question, in Latin, "Unde Venis?" -- "Where have you been?" It pointed out that doctors, no matter where they practice, have got to be constantly thinking that a patient with funny symptoms may have been somewhere they have to know about.
 Q. Does your advice apply just to people who've been to faraway countries?
 A. Not at all. The example I give is if you're a doctor in middle America, and your patient has been visiting Connecticut and now has a swollen knee, you've got to think about Lyme disease. The point about travel is it's not just exotic, international travel, it could be anywhere.
 Q. Do travel agents prepare people for health problems in the countries they are visiting?
 A. Most travel agents, unfortunately, have not bought into this concept of travel health. I don't want to be unkind to travel agents, but there have been studies worldwide asking what kind of advice people get from their travel agents, and it falls into two categories: either the travel agent dismisses the issue entirely or focuses on the narrow question of whether you need a shot to enter the country.
The fact is, for most of the countries in the world, you don't need a shot to get in. Say you're booking a trip to Yucatan, and you ask the agent, "Do I need any shots?" and you're told, "No." The better question would be: "Are there any health issues I should think about?" And the problem is there are a lot of them.
 Q. Have you ever advised people to stay away from a country because of a health risk?
 A. The most dangerous country is the one you're not prepared for. I've got people who've gone to the deepest jungles -- from the university I've got archeologists and entomologists -- but if they're prepared, they stay relatively well.
 Q. How can the average person find out about how to prepare?
 A. We're trying to increase the level of awareness so doctors will have some sense about the dangers. I always tell people to speak to their travel agent and speak to their doctor. The C.D.C. has a phone number travelers should know about, (404) 332-4559, their travelers' hot line. It will cost them a few bucks, but C.D.C. updates it pretty regularly, and it's worth it.
 Q. How does Immunization Alert work?
 A. Immunization Alert is a service I developed in 1983 sort of in parallel to the work I do here, but it's run as a separate business. It offers travel information really designed more for the corporate sector, in which large health departments -- the City of New York, the State of Massachusetts, the World Bank, Quantas Airlines -- all come to me for updated weekly service. If they've got an employee going off somewhere, they can punch it into their computer for information. It keeps up with things like State Department advisories, not just health alone, but social and political developments. It was the first, worldwide, to bring all of this together in one computerized service. There's still only a few of us worldwide who are doing anything like this. There's a guy in London at the School of Tropical Medicine, and another guy in Milwaukee. I also provide individual reports for travelers.
 Q. How much does it cost to use Immunization Alert?
A. For individual travelers, I charge $40, and that includes up to four different countries. It's generally a couple of pages per country. Beyond that, it's $10 a country. That is expensive, but on the other hand, that gives them what they need, and they can take that to their own doctor. For corporations, I sell a computerized service that is updated every week, and that's $700 a year.
 Q. How do you find medical care if you're in a foreign country?
 A. It's tough, and you have to do some advance planning. There is a non-profit group called I.A.M.A.T., the International Association for Medical Assistance to Travelers, in Lewiston, N.Y., which maintains a list of English-speaking doctors worldwide. It's not an endorsement of their qualifications, but they do speak English. I also strongly recommend that travelers contact a service like International SOS. If you get sick, you call their 800 number, and they will help you find a doctor, get in touch with your doctor back home, evacuate you if need be, help you with your funding.
 Q. What's the greatest common danger to the traveler?
 A. Auto accidents are the No. 1 killer of travelers abroad, for two reasons. First, because autos are inherently dangerous, more dangerous than jet planes. Second, because if you're in a third world area, you don't have 911, you don't have E.M.S., you don't have high-quality care around the corner. The broken leg you sustain in the jungle, or even in a major third world city, is inherently more dangerous than a broken leg in Taftville. Sexually transmitted diseases are another major issue. AIDS, worldwide, was spread as a traveler's illness.
 Q. What about medical supplies? Any you should bring with you?
 A. If you're taking pills, obviously take them with you. Keep them labeled in their original container, and keep them on your person. Don't pack them in your luggage, because if your luggage goes east and you go west, you're in trouble. Syringes are generally not a problem, but have a note from your physician. I always tell people not only to take an extra pair of glasses if they wear them, but carry a copy of their prescription. The general rule is, the longer you're going to be away, and the farther you're going, the more attention you pay to these issues.
 Q. Certainly one of the most common problems for the international traveler has got to be jet lag. Any tips for sufferers?
 A. There is some really good research that shows bright sunlight will help you set your internal clock, much faster. The problem with jet lag is your body says it's 9 o'clock in the morning when it's 3 in the afternoon, so you have to advance your clock. Or you go to Hawaii, and it's really earlier in the day. If you go to the east, bright light in the morning, getting out of doors early in the day, helps to advance your clock.
I tell people going to London to stay outside in the mornings, and if they're going to museums, do it in the afternoon. When you go to the west, bright light in the afternoon is much better. So if you're going to Hawaii, stay on the beach in the afternoon.
Jet lag is invariable. You can't escape it. So people just have to know that they can't crash ahead. If they're going on business, you can't just crash into intensive negotiations the first day. Try to build in one day as a buffer. Drink lots of fluids, because the planes are very dry, and you get dehydrated, and avoid caffeine and alcohol.
 Q. How about motion sickness?
 A. Motion sickness, air sickness, sea sickness, car sickness, they all derive from the same problem, an imbalance in the inner ear. The fact is your eye is seeing something different from what your body is experiencing. Movement of the head accentuates the problem. If you are prone to motion sickness, sit in your seat and try to keep your head motionless. Look out at the horizon. As far as medicine, there are those little patches you wear behind your ear, and it is the most effective medicine we have. You can't use it under 12 years old, so you're pretty much limited to Dramamine, but that makes you drowsy.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Kenneth R. Dardick, author of the "Foreign Travel and Immunization Guide." (Gale Zucker for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Interview
