SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 1; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1338 words

HEADLINE: Cross-Country Skiers Are Taking Off With a Swoosh

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
FORGET the long lift lines. Forget the long hours traveling north to the mountain resorts. If cross-country skiing is on your agenda this winter, your playground may not be far from your front door.
And if you are worried about the latest fashion for outdoor sports this season, you can forget that, too. All that is necessary to enjoy cross-country skiing is a pair of Nordic skis, boots, poles, light layers of ordinary outdoor clothing and one more critical ingredient -- snow. 
 Without traveling farther than the boundaries of Westchester County, there is sufficient open space in the form of parks, golf courses, nature preserves and trails to satisfy both the beginner and the most skillful cross-country skier. Entrance to the state and county sites is free, although some places charge a parking fee.
In northern Westchester, the county Department of Parks, Recreation, and Conservation allows cross-country skiing, conditions permitting, from dawn until dusk seven days a week at the Blue Mountain Reservation in Peekskill, Croton Gorge in Cortlandt, the Kitchawan Preserve in Yorktown, the Mohansic Golf Course in Yorktown Heights, Mountain Lake Camp in North Salem and the Ward Pound Ridge Reservation in Cross River.
In the central part of the county, the department has designated the following sites for cross-country skiing: Maple Moor Golf Course in White Plains, the Marshlands Conservancy in Rye and the Saxon Woods Golf Course in Scarsdale.
To the south, there is the Dunwoodie Golf Course, the Lenoir Preserve, the Sprain Lake Golf Course and Tibbetts Brook Park, all in Yonkers.
 
Groom Your Own Trails As You Go
 The curator at the Lenoir Preserve, Timothy K. Barton recommended the 40-acre Yonkers preserve as "very good for beginners." There are 1.5 miles of level trails available at the site. In snow, the trails -- with names such as "Great Horned Owl Path" and "Pheasant Way" are ungroomed, "the make-'em-your-own-way" kind, Mr. Barton said.
In addition to the county-run sites, there is the state-operated Rockefeller State Park Preserve in Pocantico Hills. On its 750 acres, there are 20 trails, a total of 14.8 miles going through wetlands, woodlands, meadows and fields. The park entrance is on Route 117 from the eastbound lane only.
Rockefeller Park's pathways, with names such as Witch's Spring Trail, Swan Lake Trail, Spook Rock Lane and Peaceful Path, are coded for levels of difficulty, from "even grade" to "steep." The steep half-mile Overlook Trail offers hikers and skiers a panoramic view of Swan Lake on the preserve and the surrounding woodlands, said James F. Moogan, manager of the park. Old Railroad Bed is a shorter, even trail that was once part of the New York & Harlem Railroad line.
A trail map can be got by sending a stamped, self-addressed envelope to The Rockefeller State Park Preserve, 132 Bedford Road, North Tarrytown, N.Y. 10591. By calling 631-1470, skiers can get the latest update on snow conditions at the preserve and at nearby Rockwood Hall Park in North Tarrytown.
The Old Croton Aqueduct, also operated by the state Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation and officially known as the Old Croton Trailway State Park, is another favorite among skiers. Following a snowstorm, one can spot skiers who live along the 26-mile pathway coming out of their backyards and picking up the trail as it winds its way south along the Hudson River from Croton to the New York City line. The state number for the Croton trailway and Franklin D. Roosevelt Park in Yorktown Heights, where cross-country skiing is also permitted, is 245-4434. Entry is from side streets all along the way.
For those new to the sport and for the experienced skier who wants to sharpen rusty skills, the county is offering free ski-touring clinics and workshops this winter.
Today at 11 A.M., at the Trailside Museum of Ward Pound Ridge Reservation, the county will hold its second clinic of the season. All of the workshops planned this winter will be held regardless of weather, said Mary Kay Koch, spokeswoman for the county's Department of Parks, Recreation, and Conservation.
If there is snow on the ground, the clinics will be held outdoors and participants should bring skiis and dress for the weather, Ms. Koch said. In the case of no snow, "dry clinics" will be held indoors and proper skiing techniques and shaping-up exercises will be discussed.
Among the highlights of the county programs this winter are a ski tour at Kitchawan Saturday at 10 A.M., and a "full-moon ski tour" at Mountain Lakes camp at 8 P.M. on Feb. 1. Other ski clinics will be held at the Lenoir Preserve, at 10:30 A.M. on Feb. 9 and at the Trailside Nature Museum at 11 A.M. on Feb. 10.
The county operates a weekday hot line for information on ski conditions at its sites. The number is 285-PARK.
The county ski clinics will be taught by representatives of two county sporting goods stores, Jaggers Camp and Trail Inc. in Bedford Hills and Eastern Mountain Sport in Ardsley.
 
'Anybody Can Learn'
 "Anybody who can walk can learn to ski. I've seen skiers in their 60's and 70's," said Irmgard Jagger, owner of Jaggers Camp and Trail. "You can't get in much trouble with this sport. The worst is you'll end up sitting coming down a hill. That's a very common sight in cross-country."
Chris Scheu, a manager of Eastern Mountain Sport, describes cross-country skiing, also known as Nordic skiing, as "paradise for nature lovers."
"You don't have to wait in line; you don't have to deal with tons of people," Mr. Scheu said. "It's a very quiet, relaxing sport."
"A golf course is a great place to begin," Mr. Scheu suggested. "And because they are so well-groomed, you don't need a heavy snowfall to go skiing."
Mr. Scheu noted that in the seven years he has been manager of Eastern Mountain Sport's Westchester store, interest in the sport has intensified, judging by the number of customers coming in to purchase cross-country ski equipment.
"We must sell 800 to 1,100 pairs of cross-country skiis a year," he said. "I am amazed at the number of newcomers who say they've decided to take up the sport."
He attributed the increased interest in the sport in part to the cardiovascular benefits of cross-country skiing. "If you get skiing at a good clip, it's right up there with jogging and swimming," Mr. Scheu said.
Many former downhill skiers, tired of paying to wait on lift lines and looking for more economical, wintertime pursuits, have turned to cross-country skiing, Ms. Jagger said. Except for parking fees at some sites, the state and county areas are free.
 
To Buy or To Rent
 For $200, a customer can purchase poles, boots, bindings and skiis. "And that's good equipment I'm talking about," Ms. Jagger said. More expensive packages can cost as much as $350 to $400.
Ski equipment can also be rented for the weekend for about $20, Mr. Scheu said.
Both retailers recommended waxless skis because conditions in the county in the course of day can vary dramatically. "It's better to hop on the skis and get going than to stop and pick which wax to use," Ms. Jagger said. "Otherwise you could be changing wax 10 to 12 times a day."
As for clothing, Ms. Jagger said, "You don't have to have the latest item in cross-country fashion. Just improvise." Both Mr. Scheu and Ms. Jagger stressed the importance of dressing with light layers -- polypropylene underwear, a fleece jacket, hat, gloves and wind pants and wind jacket.
 
Working Up Some Steam
 "The only time you're cold," Mr. Scheu said, "is before you have skiied 100 yards. After that, you are creating your own heat. You can really work up a steam."
Many skiers go out for the entire day carrying lunch in a backpack.
"When my children were young, I took along a pot, packaged dried soup, hot dogs, apples and a fire starter," Ms. Jagger said. "We would melt snow for the soup and cook hot dogs on a stick. This is a sport the whole family can do together."

HEADLINE: Washed Up in Buffalo

BYLINE: By Frederick Busch; Frederick Busch's most recent novel is "Harry and Catherine."

 BODY:

THE LAST FINE TIME
By Verlyn Klinkenborg.
209 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95. 
 Outsiders know Buffalo as a city of broad shoulders and of a population we now call ethnic -- Croats and Poles and Czechs -- and also as a city whose name is synonymous with bad weather. One doesn't hear much about its black population, say, or its poets, or its university classrooms. Verlyn Klinkenborg, who grew up in a small Iowa town (and who wrote about Midwestern farmers in his first book, "Making Hay"), comes into Buffalo with eyes wide and affections available. He writes, beginning of course with snow, about a neighborhood bar, once the Thomas Wenzek Restaurant, then George & Eddie's, and about the several generations of the Wenzek family who owned and operated it. Buffalo is changed forever, and the bar is gone.
Buffalo is one of a number of northeastern cities that saw their heyday before World War II, and now are suffering in small what the region is suffering in general: a long, hard decline. These are cities on the downswing, where money is ebbing steadily out along with working-class jobs, and where the traditional sense of community is in the process of being redefined. Buffalo, to Mr. Klinkenborg, represents these cities on the wane, and by recollecting for us the bar, a neighborhood and a time, he celebrates both a collective feeling and an era in the history of cities now vanished.
The Wenzeks came to upstate New York in 1906 from Galicia, then a part of Austria-Hungary, now a part of Poland. Thomas Wenzek bought a saloon in 1922 at 722 Sycamore Street. During Prohibition he and his family sold near beer and flowers; after Prohibition they ran their bar full time, and they prospered. Their son, Eddie (the father of Mr. Klinkenborg's wife, Regina), worked for them, did his duty in World War II, and in 1947 took over the bar along with his brother-in-law, George Ditzel. America's sense of itself was never the same after World War II, and Eddie changed the bar in response to what he saw as the country's appetite for sophistication: he added a new 18-foot backbar, a menu featuring pork loin instead of the traditional whole pig, highballs and french-fried shrimp. Eddie wanted, Mr. Klinkenborg writes, "to keep a family atmosphere at lunch, dinner, and on Sundays, but to make it feel postwar, less an old-fashioned workingman's bar of the sort his father created and more a fashionable late-night spot." As Eddie changed, as the bar changed, Buffalo and the nation changed too.
In letters he sent home in 1842 to be saved for the composition of what would be his "American Notes," Charles Dickens, coming to Buffalo and looking about with wide eyes, meditated on Niagara Falls, "that tremendous ghost of spray and mist which is never laid, and has been haunting this place with the same dread solemnity -- perhaps from the creation of the world." You don't, really, get a lot in "American Notes" on Buffalo or the falls. But you get plenty of darker Dickens.
So too with Mr. Klinkenborg. He can write superbly, and he clearly has a great talent for evoking a place or time. Describing old plumbing from the bar's early days, he writes of the "furlongs of steamfit pipe elbowing, knuckling, nippling its way through every building in a city like Buffalo." He is wonderful about "geraniums -- knotted, arthritic plants with the musty scent of perfumed wool." And in a Buffalo neighborhood "there is a lull in the traffic, and for a moment you can hear the silence. It swells into the yard like an abrupt tide." Here is the city under snow: "Even indoors, you can hear the hush over Buffalo. You can feel the way the heavy snowfall changes a room, the way it redefines the interior, making the walls seem closer together, the roof heavier, the insulation thicker."
What reader can resist such gorgeous writing? People blessed with marvelous voices sometimes come to believe that their voices confer blessing, no matter about what their lovely sounds are enfolded. This is sometimes true of writers, and when it is, their readers do resist. Mr. Klinkenborg intones that "the present is the only campfire in the icy wastes of time." Speaking of families at a Buffalo graveyard, he must describe "the sostenuto of a sound digestion, vigorous seethings in a kettle of life." He discusses attitudes in men after World War II and speaks of a sucker as "the one who goes for the story" -- an apt definition of the word it's meant to catch. But then Mr. Klinkenborg defines further, insisting that the word "reflects a pearlescent beatitudinal quality," as if he must show us the writer at work and not the man or situation he at first had sought to describe.
Although the author clearly likes and is interested in the story of Thomas Wenzek, Eddie his son and the other men and women of the neighborhood, he seems to be driven beyond them by his own appreciation of his transforming prose. Like Dickens in Buffalo, he records, at last, the author, not his subject. Even the book's structure facilitates such a giving in to self. It is divided into sections, each ostensibly about an individual whose story will lead us to the larger story Mr. Klinkenborg would tell. So sections are each "about" the son Eddie, now in his 70's and retired, or "about" the patriarch Thomas. But each section leads Mr. Klinkenborg to write not about the person in question but about Galicia or Buffalo, the old country or the new, and about the changing times. There are wonderful lists of store signs and of products for sale, there are lists of wonderful names. But the names don't lead to people, they become considerations of population shifts, economic shifts, shifts in ways of living. A family atomized by the structure of the book becomes further dispersed into facts about American or urban or Buffalonian life.
Are people to be seen as wholly shaped by their city or town? While Mr. Klinkenborg satisfyingly evokes ways of life, especially when he chronicles the effects of World War II on Buffalo, he seems at last to be saying that you define a person primarily by talking of his place and time. But what of the inner life of the Wenzek family? Who fought with whom? Who betrayed what husband, wife or child? How did Thomas's wife really feel about cooking all day for the bar? How about Renee, Eddie's wife? What of their children? Is a life to be defined by a certain cut of skirt, a certain style of hat? And if these lives are not to be considered in their particularities, then what in this book is at stake? On behalf of learning what about whom are these sometimes wonderful words expended?
Since there is no intimacy with the Wenzeks or their neighbors, there can be little feeling for them. In the end, we don't know how Eddie feels as the old inhabitants of the neighborhood die and as the younger generations move to the suburbs -- to be replaced by new waves of immigrants, primarily blacks from the American South.
In 1970, Eddie sells the bar to a black proprietor. It is renamed the Scorpion, closes after a short time, is first boarded up and then torn down. Eddie, now living in the suburbs, comes back to watch its demolition. If the bar is a metaphor in the history of American cities, then its disappearance, as Mr. Klinkenborg shows us, is the end of a unique time.
Eddie says a few words at the beginning, and occasionally there is speech from other people in the book. But Mr. Klinkenborg doesn't let them say much. We never learn their rhythms or diction or patterns of breath. We know the author's, though. And when Eddie, placed behind his bar, begins to tell stories about people going over into Niagara Falls, Mr. Klinkenborg interrupts. Eddie says a total of a few sentences here, and the author says the rest. In another bravura turn, he imagines how it would feel to fall over: "You would be crushed from above, ground into the talus, held down, twisted, eddied. . . ."
Verlyn Klinkenborg isn't Eddied, though. He remains outside of him and of the others toward whom he has nevertheless tried to offer considerable respect. He seems driven by his voice, however, by his need to write rather than listen. Like Dickens at the falls he must write at last about him, not it. He has, surely, memorialized the bar, now leveled to rubble in part because of a city's great changes. But the people who lived in the apartment above 722 Sycamore, their customers and neighbors in a breathing Buffalo, are all gone, and this often brilliantly written book has not summoned them back.
 
AT HOME IN HIS WORK

Eddie has everything under control. . . . He takes Canadian money at par. He knows every pose his customers use to order a drink, every grace of condescension, every tiny hauteur that needs to be blunted. He knows how to explain that at George & Eddie's there is no book to drink on. He knows how to fend off the constant offers of "Have one on me" and when to lose the bar dice. He knows how to flatter a lonely woman without entanglement or offense. He knows how whiskey will curdle and how it will parch and how, when it neither curdles nor parches, it will warm a room full of tired strangers into friendship. . . .
When the jukebox takes over from the Bavarian trio and a more urbane music -- Dinah Shore, Frankie Laine, Perry Como -- slackens the tempo, when the crowd thins but the atmosphere thickens, when the line between sport and sucker gets hard to draw, when even his father, abandoned by the last of his old friends, sets the pinochle deck aside and trudges upstairs to Freda, then Eddie has time to be at home in his work, to allow a conversation to ripen, to light his pipe with the lion-shaped head and send its pleasant smoke curling into the air. -- From "The Last Fine Time."
 
A SON-IN-LAW LISTENS
 "At first," Verlyn Klinkenborg recollects, "my listening was simply the kind of thing a son-in-law does." Eddie Wenzek, his father-in-law, had a lifetime of salty tales about the bar and restaurant operated by the Wenzek family for 50 years in a blue-collar neighborhood of Buffalo. "Where I grew up, in the Middle West," Mr. Klinkenborg said in a recent telephone interview from his home in Massachusetts, "bars were not a place where you'd hang out. What startled me was that, clearly, this business had been at the heart of a community."
Mr. Klinkenborg, whose first book, "Making Hay," vividly described the rigors of modern farming, admits to a fascination "with the remembered life of work. Almost all of us share it, yet we don't often talk about it. And the most interesting characters, I've found, are often those who have held what might seem to be the most unremarkable jobs." The more he heard about the bar and the Wenzeks' lives in America, the clearer it became to him that their history offered a unique opportunity to "re-create the experience of working-class life in one city."
"The Last Fine Time" is written in a rich, intense, exact prose. Mr. Klinkenborg, who holds a Ph.D in English literature from Princeton University, explains: "I look for subjects that offer a sense of metaphorical possibility. It's probably clear from the book that I'm as interested in the character of language as in the story itself. As I believe Joyce Carol Oates has said, the subject is fully realized only by the grace of an author's language."
While some former residents of the neighborhood, which has been transformed yet again by new waves of immigrants, speak affectionately of its old communal pleasures, Mr. Klinkenborg notes that "many also understood the toll their past had exacted." Even Eddie, "who thinks often about losing the bar, believes that if he had held on to it he might have worked himself into a heart attack."
Mr. Klinkenborg, who is 38 years old, is currently the Briggs-Copeland lecturer at Harvard University, teaching nonfiction writing. And he has just begun research on his next book, about physicians working with native Americans in the Southwest. -- RICHARD E. NICHOLLS

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
In Ads, Simple Is Replacing Slick

BYLINE: By RANDALL ROTHENBERG

 BODY:
There can be little doubt about the subject of a new advertising campaign splashed across the pages of Gourmet magazine and other publications aimed at the affluent. Beneath seemingly candid photographs of fashionable diners is a large banner that declares, "Remy Martin est l'eau de vie."
Jeff Weiss, the co-creative director of Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss, the advertising agency that declared Remy Martin cognac was the "water of life," said the campaign was typical of the direct, even obvious advertising that his youthful New York agency is doing these days. 
 He contrasts it to the subtle and occasionally mysterious advertisements that Margeotes fashioned in the late 1980's for Harper's Bazaar magazine, which also featured apparently impromptu photos but were devoid of text, barely showed the magazine and were designed, Mr. Weiss said, "to not seem like advertising."
 
Back-to-Basics Movement
 Like Margeotes, advertising agencies on and beyond Madison Avenue are being swept by a back-to-basics movement that is manifesting itself in ads that are starker and more plain-speaking. If the excesses of the booming 1980's were reflected in advertising that was opulent, slick and expensive, creative people at agencies say, the work they are producing in the constrained 1990's can be described by one word: simple.
Logos are growing larger, as in the Cutty Sark Scotch whisky ads introduced last fall that reintroduced, after a long absence, the brand's clipper-ship symbol.
Advertising that once emphasized people's life styles now showcases the benefits of products; Phillips' Milk of Magnesia, which once danced around the issue of what it did by depicting smiling middle-aged folks, now shows an unraveling roll of toilet tissue in its television ads.
"Simplicity and forthrightness are where the industry wants to be right now," said William J. Vernick, a vice president and copywriter at the giant Ayer agency in New York, whose clients include Procter & Gamble and DeBeers diamonds. "Creatives are being forced to think of more creative ways of being less creative."
 
'Simply Clever' Ads
 There are a variety of reasons being offered for advertising's new simplicity, with some affirming that basic direct ads better penetrate the clutter of loud or complex ads, and others pointing out that they are cheaper to produce than song-and-dance extravaganzas.
But whatever the cause, wild and weird ads -- exemplified by Chiat/ Day/Mojo's controversial "Reeboks let U.B.U." athletic shoes campaign of 1989 -- are being supplanted by advertising that John Nieman, the chief creative officer of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles/U.S.A., calls "simply clever."
Mr. Nieman cited a commercial his agency did in Britain. Against a plain, white background, one rock, then two rocks, then many rocks tumble back and forth. At the end appear the words "Rolling Stones U.K. tour. Sponsored by Budweiser."
The danger in identifying advertising trends is that many supposedly new developments have precedents. D.M.B.& B.'s Rolling Stones commercial, for example, appears derivative of Chiat/Day/Mojo's campaign for the Nynex Yellow Pages, which has used plain backgrounds and word-play punchlines since the mid-80's.
 
Conscious Simplicity
 What is important about advertising's new restraint is that many creative people say they are consciously trying to simplify their work, and they willingly concede that they are emulating a handful of ads from the late 80's, like the Nynex campaign and the zen-like Infiniti automobile campaign, that generated controversy because their reserve ran so counter to advertising's then-prevailing extravagance, as expressed in big-budget ads for companies like Pepsi-Cola.
Tom Thomas, the co-creative director of Angotti, Thomas, Hedge, said the new work reflected the demise of advertising that promoted products as badges of achievement, like the Scotch whisky ads that celebrated peoples' job promotions or terraced apartments and asked, "What are you saving the Chivas for?"
In its stead is rising advertising that Mr. Thomas deems "meritocratic," which, in a return to a decades-old advertising tradition, promotes real or perceived product advantages. "There are fewer yuppie-at-play commercials than we used to see," he said. "Products today have to earn their way onto your shopping list. That's in synch with the tenor of the times."
 
Several Hundred Words
 He held out as an example his agency's new ad for Saab automobiles, in which several hundred words of copy about Saab's engine, interior space, braking system and safety features are topped by the headline, "The End of the Selfish Car."
Perhaps the most direct and prevalent way that contemporary advertising is showcasing a product's strength is in television advertising that consists almost entirely of words printed on the screen.
A year ago, Ayer introduced a commercial for Phillips' Milk of Magnesia that forthrightly, but without sound, proclaimed the product's effectiveness. The spot shows a roll of toilet tissue that remains static as the words "Monday," "Tuesday" and "Wednesday" appear, sequentially, on the screen. There follows a shot of the product, then another shot of the paper twirling off the roll as the word "Thursday" comes on screen.
Many creative people say candidly, although privately, that advertising's new restraint is driven by fear. In an advertising industry mired in its slowest growth in two decades, copywriters and art directors are leery of seeming too avant-garde for clients, who have become increasingly cautious because of the recession.
 
Lower Production Costs
 Another obvious factor behind today's simple advertising is the desire among clients and agencies to reduce commercial production costs, which averaged $190,000 for a nationally broadcast spot in 1989, according to the American Association of Advertising Agencies.
But marketing psychology also underlies the move toward quieter, more elemental advertising, many creative people say. "We're in an era of trust," said Charlie Moss, the vice chairman and corporate creative director of Wells, Rich, Greene. "In film and TV, when things get complicated, consumers distrust it. You do it simply, give them proof of product reality, that will go over."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
TV Guide Growth Plan: Bigger Pages

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
Faced with increasing competition from television supplements in Sunday newspapers, TV Guide will begin testing a larger version of its digest-sized magazine in March.
"What we are testing here is essentially whether a bigger magazine at a higher price would be preferred by TV Guide's existing base of readers and whether it will attract a new set of buyers," said Joseph W. Cece, TV Guide's president and publisher. "I also think that the bigger page size could bring different kinds of advertisers for whom size is an issue." 
 The new version of TV Guide will be 7 1/2 by 10 inches, slightly smaller than magazines like People and Newsweek, and will cost 89 cents. In contrast, TV Guide is currently 5 by 7 3/4 inches and costs 75 cents.
 
Too Many Pages to Turn <HE
 The proliferation of cable channels has caused the little magazine to become somewhat unwieldy. In 1979, for instance, the average home received six or seven television channels. Today, it receives 36 or more, and that number is expected to grow to more than 50 by the end of the decade. As a result, readers of TV Guide have to keep turning pages instead of having a day's programming in one place.
Sunday television supplements also publish local, network and cable programming information. In addition, newspapers with their larger format are able to lay out a full day's programming in a grid, which is easier to read at a glance.
Moreover, the newspaper supplements present formidable competition for TV Guide because they are included in the Sunday paper at no additional cost. According to a 1990 survey of 574 Sunday papers by the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, which tracks trends in the industry, 521 of the newspapers had television supplements.
Newspapers publish Sunday programming guides as a reader service. Their value is not in advertising dollars -- indeed, many do not attract enough advertising to offset their production costs -- but in their potential to attract circulation.
 
'A Competitive Edge'
 "As newspaper markets get more competitive, like in Los Angeles, television supplements are a way of giving them a competitive edge," said Mary Berner, the associate publisher of TV Guide. "The supplements get better and better, and then as the heat goes off, the quality of the supplement often declines."
The 39-year-old TV Guide, which publishes 112 editions for different parts of the country each week, also includes articles about television, reviews, columns, a crossword puzzle and a horoscope.
The economic climate for magazines has changed significantly since 1988, when Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation acquired Triangle Publications, the publisher of TV Guide, for $3 billion. In the first nine months of 1990, TV Guide's advertising pages declined 9.4 percent, according to the Publishers Information Bureau. Mr. Cece said ad pages were off 6 percent for the year.
TV Guide's circulation is the third largest of any American magazine, surpassed only by Modern Maturity and Reader's Digest. The magazine had a circulation of 15.8 million for the first six months of 1990, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations.
In 1989 TV Guide reduced its advertising rate base to 15.8 million from 16.4 million. Mr. Cece said those 600,000 subscriptions represented a marginal readership that should not have been acquired in the first place and that cost money to keep.
 
20,000 Hours of Programming
 If TV Guide converts to a larger size, it will be the second television guide to do so recently. In October, The Cable Guide, a monthly magazine with a circulation of 9.5 million, converted to approximately the same size as the proposed TV Guide.
"We did it because of the extraordinary amount of programming that exists on cable," said Alan T. Wragg, publisher of The Cable Guide. "You can have as much as 20,000 hours a month in one household."
The Cable Guide differs in part from TV Guide in that it sells its magazine only to households that subscribe to cable systems. It is currently trying to interest cable operators in investing in TVSM Inc., its parent company.
As TV Guide did, The Cable Guide saw its advertising pages plummet last year. They were down 22 percent, according to the Publishers Information Bureau.
 
Second Guide to Cable
 Last year TVSM introduced TV Time, a weekly guide to cable programming. TV Time currently has a circulation of about 250,000 in some cable markets in San Diego, Phoenix, Los Angeles and Huntington Beach, Calif. The magazine is "system specific," meaning that it only offers readers information about the channels they have and it tells them how to find them on their television dials.
Jay Gissen, editor of TV Time, said the magazine would not expand into new markets until TVSM had found new investors.
At TV Guide, Mr. Cese said any conversion to a larger size would not take place for at least 18 months. He declined to say how much such a change would cost, but characterized it as "potentially a big deal" because the transformation would involve an investment in new newsracks at supermarkets and other stores across the country.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joseph W. Cece, TV Guide's president, hopes to attract more readers with a larger magazine. (Doug Goodman/Advertising Age)

HEADLINE: Treasury to Sell 2-Year and 5-Year Notes

 BODY:
The tentative schedule of Treasury financings this week includes an auction of new three- and six-month bills tomorrow, followed by an auction of new two-year notes on Wednesday and new five-year notes on Thursday.
By late Friday, the outstanding three-month and six-month Treasury bills were bid at 6.08 percent and 6.18 percent, respectively. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 7.11 percent and the five-year at a price to yield 7.65 percent. 
 The auction of Treasury bills, usually held on Mondays, is scheduled for tomorrow because today is the Martin Luther King Day holiday.
Expected borrowings by Government agencies this week include the Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation, which plans to sell three issues of consolidated systemwide bonds totaling $2.32 billion. On Wednesday, the agency plans to announce the interest rates for the three issues.
The following new fixed-income issues are scheduled this week:

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Gulf War Is Creating Havoc for Networks

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
The war in the Persian Gulf has cost the broadcast networks millions of dollars, scuttled program schedules and thrown the seasonlong battle for ratings into turmoil.
After three days of chaotic and extremely costly coverage, the networks began to try to restore some normality -- and some revenue potential -- to their program schedules this weekend. 
 Howard Stringer, the president of the CBS Broadcast Group, said that as the war continued, the networks were trying to be more selective about interrupting regular programming, both for economic reasons and because the constant high-alert coverage might be giving a distorted view of how long the war would last. That view was echoed by executives of ABC and NBC, who also said they were trying to shorten the length of interruptions for news.
 
'More Normal Schedule'
 "At some point, we have to get down to a more normal schedule," Mr. Stringer said. "Of course, the assumption will be that it's an economic decision, and that's true. But if we keep covering every bullet that's fired, we can help create the hysterical impression that this war is going to be over in a week."
The decisions to run entertainment programs have been influenced by the need to reduce what several network executives called the "economic hit" they were taking on the expensive coverage.
The additional costs include all communications, including satellite time, overtime for employees and travel expenses. Joseph Rutledge, a vice president of communications for NBC, said his network was spending about $1.5 million a week on the coverage. Those costs were not anticipated in the network's normal news budget of $300 million a year.
Another NBC executive, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the gross lost advertising revenue for Wednesday's prime-time hours was $3.5 million to $4 million.
 
'Best Revenue Opportunities'
 The networks have so far tried to resume normal programming on the basis of what Mr. Rutledge called "the best revenue opportunities." For example, NBC tried to go back to its regular programming on Thursday, its strongest night of prime time.
But the news of the first missile attack against Israel made that impossible. So NBC shifted its lineup of four hit comedies to Friday -- though it decided to run repeat episodes that night.
The NBC hit programs, however, performed much below expectations Friday night. According to the overnight ratings for the 25 largest television markets, NBC's usually high-rated "Cosby Show" finished third behind an ABC comedy, "Full House" which normally dominates that time period, and a news special on CBS.
David Poltrack, the senior vice president of research for CBS, said Friday's results proved that viewers simply could not keep up with the chaos in the program schedules and tended to watch what they normally watch on Friday night.
 
Closest Race in History
 The early ratings have possible implications for the overall television ratings race, which is already the closest in television history.
The results so far indicate that ABC may gain some long-term advantages from the war coverage. For the first three days, ABC enjoyed a significant ratings edge over the other networks, reflecting ABC's now clearly established leadership in broadcast news.
On Thursday night, ABC had a 14.1 national rating, beating NBC, with a 12.8, and CBS, with an 11.6. (Each rating point represents 931,000 homes.) NBC normally wins Thursday night by an enormous margin.
CNN had another strong night Thursday, with a national rating of 10, after picking up a remarkable 11.7 national rating Wednesday night. Both numbers are huge increases over the rating of less than 1 that CNN usually averages.
 
Benefits of Commercials
 ABC was the only network to run commercials Wednesday night, a move that could also help in the overall ratings race. Because NBC and CBS did not run commercials, their ratings that night will not count in the season's average, but ABC's will.
ABC gained another big advantage on Friday, when it ran its normal schedule. According to the overnight ratings, ABC had a 15.1 rating, to a 10.8 for NBC and 9.4 for CBS.
Chaos continued on Friday night as commercials interrupted other commercials and the late-breaking news that Israel had been hit again was covered in full on the West Coast, pre-empting entertainment shows that were to have played at 10 P.M.
The second act of the "Cheers" episode started up in the middle of a commercial, played for about 20 seconds and then stopped and started all over again.
ABC News broadcast videotape it labeled "exclusive" even though the same tape was playing on CBS.
Twice, CBS News ran tape that ended with the face of an ABC correspondent, Chris Wallace.
 
Interrupting 'Ninja Turtles'
 On Saturday, all three networks interrupted their morning cartoons for a military briefing. CBS stayed with the report only a short time -- because it came in the middle of the most popular and lucrative program on Saturday morning: "Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles."
One CBS executive, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said, "You have to start to ask yourself, does the public right to know extend to 5-year-olds?"
Yesterday, to protect their investments in football, NBC and CBS kept their interruptions for news to a minimum during the National Football League's playoff games.
The concern about programming schedules will spill over into the current week, especially at CBS, which faces potential "disaster," as Mr. Stringer put it, if its repeat of the highly popular "Lonesome Dove" mini-series winds up being pre-empted repeatedly.
 
Fears About the Super Bowl
 The N.F.L. says it intends to play the Super Bowl as scheduled next Sunday, but fears persist that breaking news will interfere with television's biggest yearly event.
ABC, which will broadcast the game, fears it will be interrupted in mid-play, which would wreak havoc on its commercial agreements.
And NBC and CBS fear the game will be delayed by a week. That would put the Super Bowl into February -- a ratings sweep month, one of television's most important rating periods because it sets advertising rates for the next quarter.
ABC would then be all but guaranteed a sweep month win.

HEADLINE: New Tax to Aid Canada in Trade

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
As Canadians grouse about a new tax that adds 7 percent to the price of newspapers, haircuts, clothing and just about everything else they buy, businesses on the American side of the border are fretting about the implications of the tax on their trade with Canada.
Each country is the other's biggest customer, and they have a two-year-old free-trade pact that is progressively lowering tariffs to stimulate trade and economic growth. But Canada's Goods and Services Tax, which went into effect on Jan. 1, alters the terms of trade in Canada's favor. 
 The new tax is a value-added tax, which is a type of broad-based sales tax. Canadian exporters get a rebate equal to the amount of the tax they have paid on purchases related to their foreign sales, so they are able to sell their goods abroad for less than previously.
Because the new tax substitutes for a manufacturers excise tax that was not refundable and had reached as high as 13.5 percent, Canadian manufacturers are now expected to become more competitive.
"Generally speaking, it gives Canadians an edge in their trade with us," said Paul R. Huard, vice president for taxes at the 13,500-member National Association of Manufacturers.
 
Effect on Trade
 The Canadian Manufacturers Association projected that the value-added tax would increase Canadian exports by $1.25 billion to $2 billion in American dollars annually over the next two years. The Conference Board of Canada, another business group, estimated the tax would cut imports by at least $2.5 billion in both years.
About 70 to 80 percent of Canada's trade is with the United States, so the tax is likely to increase Canada's trade surplus with the United States.
Mr. Huard and other United States tax experts said they expected the Canadian experience with the tax to become a matter of debate in the United States, where a value-added tax has been discussed for at least a decade.
"I can tell you that this thing is attracting increasing attention from staff members and from business -- from people concerned about trade and from people who have big ideas that require funding, such as national health care," said David A. Rudd, legislative director for Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina.
 
Consideration Urged
 Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International said, "If it works in Canada in reducing consumption, boosting investment and improving the trade balance, then we must consider whether it would be useful here."
Cliff Massa 3d, a partner in the law and lobbying firm of Patton, Boggs & Blow, said the United States was the only major industrial democracy without a value-added tax.
The tax is controversial in Washington, where opponents say it is regressive because in paying taxes on, say, shirts, the tax would take a larger share of of a poor person's income than that of a wealthy person. Critics also say a value-added tax is inflationary.
Canada considered the tax for five years. The Government of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney finally pushed it through Parliament last month after revisions to meet some objections.
 
Some Exemptions
 Basic groceries, residential rents, health and education expenses and some other necessities are exempt. The Government also agreed to make cash payments at the start of every quarter to people with lower incomes to help them offset the tax. The first checks have just gone out.
Yet some of the new rules confounded consumers. The tax applies to salted nuts but not unsalted nuts, for example, presumably because the latter are counted as basic food and not cocktail fare.
The Europeans adopted value-added taxes 20 years ago and Japan introduced one last year. New Zealand and South Korea also added such a tax recently.
"The point is that at a time when the U.S. trade balance is still negative, it doesn't make any sense for us not to think about raising revenues in this way," Mr. Massa added.
 In 1989, the United States trade deficit with Canada was $9.1 billion. Last year, in the latest figures, it was running at an annual rate of $5 billion.
 
Some U.S. Beneficiaries
 American companies with production in Canada could be among the beneficiaries of the tax.
James Hutchison, director of taxes at the International Business Machines Corporation's Canadian headquarters in Toronto, said that because of the replacement of the manufacturers' excise tax with the value-added tax, the cost of data-processing equipment had effectively fallen by 5 percent.
"This helps I.B.M. become more competitive in Canada," he said. "Over time, we should see a positive impact on our exports from Canada."
David G. Rehor, vice president and controller of Ford of Canada, said, "We get some advantage to the extent that all our suppliers enjoy lower costs and their prices reflect that cost advantage."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Canada's Goods and Services Tax, a value-added tax that took effect on Jan. 1, adds 7 percent to the price of clothing, newspapers, haircuts and justabout anything else Canadians buy. In Toronto, a clothing store posted a sign on Dec. 31 to remind customers that it was their last day to avoid the tax. (Canadian Press)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Figuring the Cost if War Is Long

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Some financial analysts are beginning to calculate the consequences of a long Middle Eastern war for the Federal budget deficit and the bond markets.
The first official estimates of the cost will not be available until Feb. 4, the publication date for the 1991 budget. 
 David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago, said the budget would project American costs for the operation at about $30 billion. That includes the costs of deploying the troops in the Persian Gulf and maintaining them until Jan. 16, he said, but not the additional $1 billion to $2 billion that military experts say is being spent daily to conduct the war.
"There really isn't much of a problem if the war is a short one," he said. "But if it drags on, the budget deficit this year could amount to $400 billion. At some point the market may have to cope with what will be a very large deficit. I think it is time to have a discussion on the issue."
Credit market participants have long expected the Federal deficit to climb in the current fiscal year, possibly above $300 billion, because of the savings and loan bailout, the commercial banking setbacks and the recession, which could cut deeply into tax revenues.
 
Limited Impact Seen
 A protracted war would clearly have budgetary consequences, but they need not be reflected in the budget of the current fiscal year, said Susan Hering, an economist at Salomon Brothers.
"The damage to the 1991 budget deficit may be more contained than feared," Ms. Hering said, "and the deficit may not break above the $300 billion to $325 billion range."
Limiting the impact on the 1991 budget will be the fact that incremental costs, like replacing aircraft and other sophisticated weaponry, can be stretched over several years. Moreover, still-binding budget constraints will also tend to delay, if not impede, the rebuilding process.
"The longer the war goes on and the more equipment we lose, the more expensive it is," Ms. Hering said. "But with a recession and the thrift bailout going on, this war is a small element in the deficit."
Yet, many analysts say the risk of a protracted war may force up interest rates on $21.5 billion worth of new two-year and five-year Treasury notes that will be sold at auction this week.
 
Greenspan's Concern
 Recent statements by the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, may force analysts and credit market participants to refocus some attention on the weekly money supply figures the Fed releases each Thursday afternoon.
In an interview published in The Wall Street Journal on Friday, Mr. Greenspan made it clear that the Fed was concerned about the money supply figures, which have shown no growth in three months, in large part because of a slowdown in bank lending.
The fact that Mr. Greenspan chose to single out the recent slowdown in money growth puzzled some analysts. The Fed, which a decade ago placed great policy importance on the money figures, has largely ignored the numbers in recent years, they said. Moreover, although more acute of late, the slowdown in money growth began about four years ago.
The real reason Mr. Greenspan raised the issue, some analysts contend, has more to do with divisions on the Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee than with a sudden re-discovery of the importance of the money figures.
Mr. Greenspan's comments "send a message to the more hawkish members of the F.O.M.C., who continue to fear inflation, that weak money growth is another manifestation of the general problem, which is weak economic growth," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Corporation. "Talk about money growth is a smoke screen to justify another easing in Fed policy."
 
Commerce Data Due
 A sudden drop in the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market on Friday, to well below the 6.75 percent rate that is seen as the Fed's target, prompted some analysts to wonder if the Fed had not sent a signal that it had eased policy again.
But Mr. Fine and other analysts said that with a war raging and the impact of its recent cuts in the funds rate not yet visible in the economy, the Fed was more likely to pause before moving again.
"I don't think the Fed has finished easing monetary policy, but I think they are getting pretty close," said Paul L. Kasriel, a vice president and money market economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
The only economic data of any real interest this week is due Friday, when the Commerce Department will provide its first estimate of how the economy fared in the fourth quarter.
The only real element of surprise in the report, analysts said, will be how much the economy contracted during the last three months of 1990.
At the moment, estimates range from a decline of as little as 2.5 percent to as much as 4 percent. Whatever the number actually is, it will remove any doubt that the fourth quarter marked the onset of recession, the analysts said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Sees Some Progress in Japanese Trade Talks

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Japanese and American trade negotiators resume their talks this week after an initial round that the American side characterized as showing "steady incremental progress" on some issues but little forward movement on many others.
After two days of talks on so-called structural impediments to trade between the United States and Japan, officials on both sides said Friday that the atmosphere was troubled and occasionally overshadowed by news of the war in the Persian Gulf. 
 Richard T. McCormack, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, said that while the American trade deficit with Japan had dropped from $51 billion in 1988 to $40 billion last year, Washington was concerned about the durability of the trend.
 
Barriers to Trade
 The talks do not focus on any specific products, but rather on business and financial practices that analysts say serve as barriers to trade. Tokyo and Washington agreed last summer to make many changes and are now negotiating the mechanisms by which to carry out their promises.
"It is vital that this structural initiative succeed," Mr. McCormack said, adding that the American goal of eliminating its trade deficit with Japan by the end of the 1990's was largely dependent on it.
Mr. McCormack said Japan had made progress on keeping its promises to increase spending on public works and to clear the way for the opening of more large retail stores, which would make it easier for consumers to buy imported goods.
But he and others said Japan had made little progress on American demands to ease the powerful grip of Japan's interlocking business cartels, which critics say engage in collusive anti-competitive practices and price fixing.
The Japanese say their anti-competitive practices are being curbed by newly aggressive Government regulators.
 
Corporate Fines
 The United States came to the talks with reams of material showing that in contrast to other major industrial countries, Japan does little to levy corporate fines for price fixing or antitrust behavior. The Americans say the steps Japan has taken so far will not be very effective.
Japanese officials said the session involved repeated offers by Japan of"clarified explanations" of its positions, mostly on why it could not do what the Americans demanded.
At the same time, Japan expressed disappointment at the slow pace of Washington in eliminating American structural impediments.
 
The Japanese View
 Japan takes the view, shared by many American economists, that the huge American budget deficit soaks up capital that might go into making businesses more competitive. Therefore, Japan seeks a commitment to eliminate the budget deficit, even if that involves raising taxes.
As they have in the past, Japanese negotiators declared themselves somewhat unimpressed with President Bush's budget-deficit package of last year that caused him to renege on his "no new taxes" pledge.
Kenichiro Sasae, director of the economic division of American-Japanese relations at the Foreign Ministry, said Americans had told him that officials in Washington would "redouble their efforts" to reduce the deficit this year, a promise other Japanese say privately they do not take too seriously.

HEADLINE: Varied Polish Reaction To a Rebuke Over Jews

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OTWOCK, Poland, Jan. 20

 BODY:
To Przemyslaw Kociewski, the reading from the pulpit of an official Roman Catholic Church statement condemning anti-Semitism was long overdue. But Helena Michalczyk left the white brick church in this small parish church on the outskirts of Warsaw with her suspicions of Jews intact.
Reactions here to the letter by Polish church leaders ran the gamut of this country's complex, often troubled relationship between Christian Poles and Jews. 
 The document represents the most unequivocal stand on the issue ever taken by the Polish church. It argues that anti-Semitism is contrary to the Gospel and acknowledges that some Poles were "indifferent" to the plight of Jews who died in Nazi death camps in this country.
Recited at every Catholic Mass celebrated in Poland, the letter was issued in response to the increasingly visible expressions of anti-Semitism in this country, which once had a Jewish minority of around three million but is now home to just a handful of Jews.
 
'It Has Come So Late'
 Mr. Kociewski, a musician who returned to Poland this fall after living in the United States for 10 months, said he was shocked by the open assertions of anti-Semitism that characterized the recent presidential election campaign. "This is something very loud, very dangerous, and I think this pastoral letter is very important," he said. "I'm only sorry it has come so late."
Mrs. Michalczyk, a 60-year old pensioner, remembers well the years before the war when Jews were a visible presence in this village, about 15 miles southeast of Warsaw. They had a synagogue and a tight-knit neighborhood, and they operated local shops. Today, all that remains of the Jews is a small monument, and Mrs. Michalczyk said she has heard rumors that some of the Jews might be returning to reclaim their property.
Would that be a good development, she was asked.
"No, I wouldn't say that," she replied. "They haven't done anything good for Poland."
 
'Poles Can Be Prejudiced'
 Nonetheless, Mrs. Michalczyk said the letter she heard in church today was useful to remind both young and old of the values of toleration. "Poles can be rather prejudiced," she said.
The letter was read here by the Rev. Tadeusz Polak, a 33-year-old priest who has served in this parish for two years.
He said the text was significant, but predicted that it would take more than one statement, however vehement, to reverse a trend that has become increasingly public since the fall of Communism.
"To me, this is a kind of road sign," he said. "Maybe people today weren't able to receive it properly. It must be followed up in pastoral work and in religious instruction in the schools."
Father Polak was a teen-ager when the Communists announced the 1968 campaign to remove Jews from positions in Government. He remembers a few derogatory comments about Jews by fellow students on the playgrounds. But to Father Polak, Mr. Kociewski and others, that incident made anti-Semitism the province of the Communists.
With the advent of free press and free speech in 1989, Poland became engaged in a national debate about anti-Semitism. Anti-Jewish feelings, from graffiti to occasional violence, became visible. The trend seemed to be accentuated by the hard times endured by many as a consequence of this nation's program for fostering development of a market economy.
 
Walesa Disavows His Words
 The feelings were more noticable in last year's presidential election campaign. A frequent charge made against former Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a politically unpopular leader who is a devout Catholic, is that he was secretly a Jew. Lech Walesa, who won the election, heightened tensions with his ambiguous statement that Jews in politics should "identify themselves." He later acknowledged those words were ill-chosen and issued an unequivocal disavowal of anti-Semitism.
Father Polak said he rejected the stereotype of Poles as anti-Semites. But he said that in making his rounds among parisioners, and even in talking to his colleagues who are priests, he hears many who are frustrated and seek easy explanations.
"You might call it the taming of reality," he said. "Some people need to create from irrational events something rational. So they say, 'It is the Jews.' "

HEADLINE: Haiti Turnout Is Sparse In Legislative Elections

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Voter turnout was sparse across much of the countryside today in legislative and local government contests that concluded Haiti's first fully free national elections.
Throughout the country, Haitians dressed in bright Sunday finery for morning church services, or selling goods at dusty rural roadside markets, showed little interest in the elections, and voters, when they turned up at polling places, faced none of the long, boisterous lines seen in last month's presidential race. 
 Sensing the lack of interest in the second round of voting, last week, election officials, party leaders and the president-elect, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, made last-minute appeals to Haitians to fulfill their "civic duty" and take part in the legislative elections. Today's vote will determine whether Father Aristide, a leftist Roman Catholic priest and political novice, will have a clear majority in the National Assembly or will have to negotiate with opposition parties over the choice of a prime minister and other policy matters. Results will not be known before midweek.
With Father Aristide's landslide win last Dec. 16, after a tense period of politically related violence, many Haitians say they have turned their attention away from politics until after the inauguration of a new government on Feb. 7. At that time, Father Aristide's grass-roots supporters say, they hope to see the president reign in inflation and bring to justice perceived criminals from the deposed Duvalier-family dictatorship and successive governments.
 
No More Than 25 Percent
 Jacques Gerard, a Canadian expert on elections who has led an observation team from the Organization of American States, estimated that no more than 20 to 25 percent of the eligible voters took part today. Last month voter participation was as high as 65 percent.
"For a lot of people it is all over once the president is chosen," said Desir Demeza, an election observer for a political party who manned a polling station at a church in Montrouis, a small coastal town 40 miles northwest of the capital. "Most people are just not concerned about deputies and senators."
By midmorning, several hours after the polling stations opened, election officials in Montrouis said only 25 people had voted in one station. At Carrefour Medard, another small town on Haiti's coastal highway, only six people had voted more than three hours after the start of the election.
"People say the deputies are there to protect the interests of people from their regions," said one of those voters, Andre Elizaire Poteau, a 68-year-old pensioner and former farmer, explaining his interest in the elections. "I don't know if it is true. Once upon a time being a legislator was a sinecure. We'll see if things change."
 
Aristide Rivals Assailed
 Haitian commentators have criticized leaders of several rival parties to Father Aristide's National Front for Democracy and Change, saying they failed to campaign strenuously for the legislative races out of discouragement over the president-elect's overwhelming popular support.
After hastily assembling an incomplete slate of candidates to run on his ticket, Father Aristide, a last-minute entry into the presidential race, succeeded in having 15 deputies and 5 senators elected outright in the first round of voting last month, avoiding runoffs this week for those candidates. The National Assembly includes a total of 27 senate seats and 83 deputies.
Francois Benoit, referring to the crushing defeat of his party, the National Alliance for Democracy and Progress, by Father Aristide and his allies last month, said, "Everyone was shocked, the A.N.D.P. included, not because we lost, but how we lost." Mr. Benoit suggested that there had been widespread irregularities, but international observers have described that vote as largely honest and fair.
The National Alliance, an alliance of center-right and socialist politicians, whose conservative presidential candidate, Marc Bazin, was widely considered the favorite until Father Aristide's entry into the race, fielded a full slate of legislative candidates. It won 14 deputy seats outright, but no senatorial posts.
Mr. Benoit, who is vice president of the alliance, said no party would emerge from today's elections with a clear majority and predicted an intense period of coalition building before Father Aristide is able to form a government.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Abortion Fight Goes On, State by State by State

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
In what has become an annual ritual, anti abortion demonstrators will march on the nation's capital on Tuesday to mark the 18th anniversary of Roe v. Wade, the Supreme Court decision recognizing a constitutional right to abortion.
But perhaps a better symbol of the current state of abortion politics was the briefing last week by the National Conference of Catholic Bishops' Secretariat for Pro-Life Activities. 
 It was coordinated by the public relations firm of Hill & Knowlton and revolved around polling done by the Wirthlin Group, the well-connected firm that polled for President Ronald Reagan. And the person speaking for the bishops was Helen Alvare, an attractive young lawyer who spoke of a long-term struggle for "hearts and minds," an outright ban on abortions and, in the interim, a drive in state legislatures for new restrictions.
Supporters of abortion rights, of course, have their own poll takers, media consultants, long-term and short-term strategies and attractive spokeswomen, from Kate Michelman of the National Abortion Rights Action League to Faye Wattleton of Planned Parenthood. That is exactly the point. Eighteen years after Roe, and 18 months after the Supreme Court reopened the political struggle over abortion with Webster v. Reproductive Health Services, what is striking is how institutionalized, and incremental, the battle over abortion has become.
It is no longer the front-burner issue it seemed in 1989, right after the Webster decision gave states new latitude to restrict abortion. The 1990 elections were dominated by issues like taxes, the state of the economy and the prospect of war in the Persian Gulf.
But then and now, advocates on both sides of the abortion issue have kept struggling, fighting their own form of trench warfare -- state by state, election by election. "While everyone else in the world is thinking of war in the Persian Gulf, there are probably 20,000 people out there working every day trying to get ready for 1992 on a different issue," said Harrison Hickman, a poll taker who advises the National Abortion Rights Action League.
Gary Bauer, an abortion opponent who was Mr. Reagan's domestic policy adviser, said: "I think it's fairly clear at this point that neither side can expect some fateful day where a Supreme Court decision will once again resolve the whole matter. It's going to be, I assume, a long, grind-out struggle by both sides."
Right now, for example, there is organizing under way for the battle over the Republican platform in 1992. The current platform commits the party to a constitutional amendment overturning Roe; many Republican supporters of abortion rights, galvanized by the Webster decision, hope to soften that language in 1992. "I don't see how that fight can be avoided," said Roger Stone, a Republican adviser who has argued that his party must ease its stance.
At the same time, new skirmishes are beginning in state legislatures. The National Abortion Rights Action League said that at least 30 bills it views as restrictive had been introduced in the states by the end of last week and that many more were expected.
"It's gotten to such a sophisticated and tactical level in the states," said Loretta Ucelli, spokeswoman for the league. Most of these struggles are not over outright bans on abortion, but over whether and how it should be restricted, like bills requiring parental consent for teen-agers seeking abortions.
It is a logical outgrowth of turning the abortion issue back to the states, back to the political process.
Politicians instinctively search for a middle ground, and that is particularly true on an issue like abortion, since The New York Times/CBS News Poll has consistently found Americans about evenly divided between wanting abortion to be generally available and wanting more restrictions on it.
This might suggest that, at some point, a rough consensus would be reached and the struggle over abortion would gradually wane. But this is not a struggle over a highway or a dam. On both sides of the issue, there is a core of advocates with radically differing beliefs. One side was mobilized by Roe, the other by Webster. They are dug in. In their presence, the struggle over abortion seems unending.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
The Home Front: A People Divided Knows No Peace

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
"What are we fighting for?" the Rev. Charles L. Norris, pastor of Bethesda Missionary Baptist Church in Jamaica, Queens, and a member of New York City's Human Rights Commission, demanded last week.
"So Israel can have a state? That's fine. But when the war is over, can I come back and move into Jamaica Estates or Great Neck or Richmond Hill? If I'm going to fight for something, I should be able to get equal justice under the law." 
 Today, many Americans will mark the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. by barely pausing in their understandable preoccupation with a faraway war. The questions raised by Mr. Norris, though, recall that a crisis over another gulf simmers closer to home.
The gap between blacks and whites is difficult to quantify. So are its manifestations -- including practices that, coupled with economic and social factors, may keep blacks like Mr. Norris from living or feeling welcome in some neighborhoods and from even venturing into others.
Apparent gains are sometimes illusory. New York inaugurated a black man as Mayor last year. Yet his wife had trouble hailing cabs not many years ago because some drivers -- responding reflexively to concerns over economics and fears about crime and race -- presumably figured that she was heading for Harlem, which, indeed, she was.
Mayor David N. Dinkins and his white detractors concur that he has sometimes been measured by a different standard: a harsher or a more lenient one, depending on whom you ask. That Mr. Dinkins might himself be guilty of applying a double standard was suggested to some people by his seemingly too evenhanded early responses to the boycott by a group of blacks of a Brooklyn grocery story owned by Korean immigrants.
Mr. Dinkins's sensitivity to his special status is indicated by his private response -- which he said he doesn't remember, but which a businessman vividly recalls -- to reports that the State Financial Control Board might usurp the powers of the city's first black Mayor. "If the F.C.B. tries to take over," Mr. Din kins was quoted as saying, "the Korean boycott would be nothing compared to that." It was not a threat, but a safe bet.
 The boycott drama tized the emergence of new targets and al liances in New York's changing mosaic. It further strained ties between blacks and liberal whites who had become "the closest of strangers," as the author Jim Sleeper called them in the title of his recent book.
That strain is reflected in a reluctance to go beyond finger-pointing. Some blacks may prefer feeling victimized to facing unvarnished verities about street crime's predominant perpetrators, as well as its victims. Some whites refuse to remember that even "the fallen have stories" or to acknowledge the appeal to many blacks of the Rev. Al Sharpton's broad message about racial injustice, if not his audacious delivery of circumstantial evidence. Other whites are more tolerant of racist remarks by blacks than by fellow whites.
Debate rages in the magazine The Nation. Mr. Sleeper, responding to a critical review of his book, declared that "a politics based on dramatizing racial grievances hasn't the ghost of a chance in America." To which the reviewer, Dean Haywood Burns of the City University of New York Law School, replied that the civil rights movement changed an entire society and that "if it now refuses to change even more, this may be more a commentary on the society than on its critics."
Mark Naison, a white professor who teaches Afro-American studies at Fordham University, agreed with Mr. Sleeper that, given the influx of immigrants from Asia and Latin America, "the politics of black rage and white guilt no longer serves the cause of justice in a multi-ethnic New York." Brian Boyle, an owner of the Brooklyn Dodgers Bar (whose name evokes a newly integrated team in a segregated borough) wrote that racism today may be harder to identify and "perhaps that's why many blacks see racism everywhere."
One measure of the lingering gulf in perceptions is the mail this column regularly elicits when racial shibboleths are questioned. Readers, invariably citing what they perceive to be the bias or the sensitivity of the very same column, routinely assume that this columnist is black. People believe what they want to.
Years ago, when Dr. King was stabbed in a Harlem bookstore owned by a white man, police officials contacted Mayor Robert F. Wagner's Commission on Intergroup Relations, which spread the word that the assailant was, in fact, a demented black woman. Further violence was averted because the commission had credibility. Today, though, one definition of equality may be that both sides seem reluctant to give anybody the benefit of the doubt.

HEADLINE: Group of 7 Opens Talks On Outlook

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

 BODY:
Against the backdrop of war, the top economic policy makers from the United States and its six main industrial allies gathered in New York yesterday for a two-day assessment of the world economy.
The date of the meeting was set weeks ago to give the finance ministers and chief central bankers from the Group of Seven countries a chance at the start of the year to review a variety of financial and monetary issues. But the ministers agreed that those matters would now be overshadowed by the war.
 
'Not an Emergency Meeting'
 "This is not an emergency meeting," a Bush Administration official emphasized. But he added, "The events in the gulf are of course going to be a very important part of the discussions."
Michael H. Wilson, the Finance Minister of Canada, said, "Expectations for various economies, particularly with regard to the impact of the hostilities in the gulf -- that's the key." 
 Officials from the United States and some other countries said they did not expect concrete action to come out of the meetings. But they said the finance officials and central bankers could be expected to promise to intervene in the currency markets if damaging fluctuations resulted from the war.
In addition to the United States, the countries in the Group of Seven are Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy and Japan.
"The whole purpose of the Group of Seven is to stabilize the world economy," a European official said, "and I think it is fair to say that they are concerned about market volatility with a war going on.".
The dollar, already considered undervalued, fell sharply after war broke out last week, but an American official said no intervention was needed now to bolster the dollar. A weak dollar makes American exports cheaper overseas and could be beneficial for the American economy as it struggles against recession.
The price of oil has plunged to less than $20 a barrel on the war news, an encouraging development for the seven industrial countries.
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady met yesterday afternoon with several of his counterparts, including Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Japanese Finance Minister.
A Tokyo newspaper reported over the weekend that Japan was prepared to pledge an additional $5 billion to the war effort, but neither American nor Japanese officials would confirm the figure yesterday.
"They said they'd do their share," Mr. Brady said.
Mr. Brady planned to have breakfast this morning with the German Finance Minsister, Theo Waigel, and was said to be prepared to ask the Germans for a larger contribution to the war effort.
 
Japan's Pledge
 Last year, Japan pledged $2 billion to the American-led military effort in the Persian Gulf and another $2 billion to Egypt, Turkey and Jordan, whose economies have been especially damaged by the gulf crisis.
Although the Bush Administration has not complained, many American lawmakers vigorously objected during the recent Congressional debate on the war that the Japanese contribution was too small given the wealth of Japan, its failure to make a military commitment and its dependence on Middle Eastern oil.
A Canadian official here said that while he knew nothing of the Brady-Hashimoto meeting, he was sure that "burden sharing" would be a main topic in the Group of Seven discussions.
The entire group met for dinner last night at a midtown restaurant, and a daylong meeting is planned today at the Stanhope hotel on Fifth Avenue at 81st Street. Normally, a communique is issued at the end of the final meeting outlining whatever agreements were reached.
 
Third Word Debt
 Other issues the policy makers can be expected to discuss are the state of the Soviet economy, third world debt and the future of trade liberalization talks.
Until recently, the United States was promoting measures to bring the Soviet Union into the world economy, including a partial membership in the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, but those measures are likely to be put off in light of the violence in Lithuania and Latvia this month.
In any event, those issues are sure to take a backseat to the overriding question of the effect of the war on the various countries' economies.
This is the first time a large-scale war involving the industrialized countries has broken out since international exchange rates were allowed to fluctuate beginning in the early 1970's, and economists are uncertain what that could mean.
 
Testing Old Assumptions
 The assumption used to be that the dollar would be viewed as a safe holding in a military crisis and would rise in value. But many economists believe that assumption is no longer valid, and their view seems to have been supported by the dollar's drop late last week.

HEADLINE: War News Captivates, And Commerce Slows

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
As the nation followed the war news from the Persian Gulf last week, the pace of business in America slowed.
Department stores, already reeling from a poor Christmas season, were mostly deserted late last week. In supermarkets, there were scattered incidents of customers stocking up on canned goods. 
 Pocket televisions sat on the desks at many offices, and in Minneapolis, Honeywell Inc,, the big military contractor, told employees they could watch the news, as their handiwork received its trial in battle.
At Wong's Market in Norwalk, Calif., grocery clerks shuttled in and out of an office to watch a television while shoppers paused in the aisles during radio news broadcasts played over the public address system.
"When the President was on the radio, everybody just stopped and listened," said Beverly White, a manager at Wong's.
 
Glued to Their Sets <HE
 Some retailers had few customers even to listen to the radio. "There's no question but that the national interest in following the Mideast war has had national impact in reducing store traffic," said Arthur Martinez, vice chairman of Saks Fifth Avenue, which operates 47 stores across the country. "The stores are mostly empty because people are glued to the TV sets. It's not a matter of shoppers coming in and deciding not to buy."
Many businesses have also braced for terrorist attacks. The McDonald's Corporation encouraged its franchise restaurants to be prepared to search their garbage dumpsters on short notice for suspicious objects, to empty waste baskets more often and to stay alert for unattended packages.
"A lot of these things we do already," said a company executive who insisted on anonymity. "The difference would be in the degree of diligence."
 
Closing and Moving
 The New York Stock Exchange closed its trading floor and visitors gallery to outsiders.
A home furnishings convention, scheduled to open next month in Munich, Germany, was abruptly moved to Dallas. "We want to avoid any problems that we might face in international travel," said Lee Abraham, the chairman and chief executive of the New York-based Associated Merchanidising Corporation, which organizes the annual event.
Employees at some companies insisted they were able to work while listening and occasionally glancing at a television. "It's sort of similar to being in high school or college and doing my homework with the TV on," said David Rothenberg, a 26-year-old real estate developer who brought a small television to his New York office. "After years of experience, I'm pretty good at it."
Lewis A. Kaplan, a partner at the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison in New York, said 10 people crowded around a radio in his office to hear the President's speech. "We chewed up about half an hour listening," he said.
 
Tired and Less Efficient
 A senior Federal Government economist who insisted on anonymity said he knew of no research on whether the distraction of a national crisis had any measurable impact on productivity. But he said he was tired and less efficient from staying up late to follow news accounts.
"These things key you up, and you find it hard to get to sleep," he said. "And I took some work home last night and didn't get it done because I watched the television."
Many companies, including General Electric, Johnson & Johnson, Morgan Stanley and I.B.M., have limited or banned international travel for their employees.
Mr. Rothenberg, the real estate agent who works for the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, said he had been looking forward to flying to Japan over the weekend, but was forced to cancel the trip on Thursday because of safety concerns.
