HEADLINE: Personal Bankruptcies Mounting With the Trepidation Lessening

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 20

 BODY:
Throughout most of the 1980's, Paul Bernier, like many people here, prospered. He owned a 20-year-old contracting business. He also owned a fairly modest $300,000 home in this wealthy Fairfield County town.
In the last 18 months, though, Mr. Bernier's company has collapsed under the Northeast's falling real-estate market. His debts run into the millions. His home, which was used to guarantee several business loans, will probably be sold. And last November he filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 7 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. 
 "I really didn't have much of a choice," he said.
Mr. Bernier, who is 39 years old, is one of a record number of people who have filed forpersonal bankruptcy in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut in the last year as the Northeast has led the country in the growth of bankruptcies.
 
Dramatic Increases
 They have filed for various reasons: loss of a job, a business failure, mounting household debts, overwhelming medical bills, lost lawsuits, declining home equity. They also appear to have filed with less trepidation about the ramifications of bankruptcy.
"Nowadays, people who have good credit can't get credit, so what does it matter," Mr. Bernier said.
In the last year, the number of personal bankruptcies has risen dramatically in the New York metropolitan region, soaring to its highest level in history, according to the American Financial Services Association, a Washington trade organization that tracks bankruptcy filings.
In Connecticut, there was a 52 percent increase in nonbusiness bankruptcy filings, to 4,521 from 2,973 for the 12-month period ended Sept. 30, 1990. In New Jersey, there was a 47 percent rise to 12,748 filings from 8,645.
In the Federal Bankruptcy Court's Eastern District of New York, which covers Long Island, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island, filings rose 39 percent to 10,094 from 7,260. In the Southern District of New York, which includes Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester County, filings rose 28 percent to 5,606 from 4,363.
 
Above National Average
 The increases for the three states compare with a 15 percent rise nationally. Only Vermont, New Hampshire, Massachusetts and Rhode Island recorded percentage increases larger than Connecticut did for the period.
"Every month it seems to go up," said Thomas H. Abraham, the clerk of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Hartford, who predicted that bankruptcies in Connecticut would increase by an even larger margin when figures for the final quarter of 1990 were computed within the next few weeks.
The current wave of bankruptcies, which outnumber those filed during the 1981-82 recession, began in late 1985 after a three-year period in which filings were on the decline, said Judy Kent, a spokeswoman for the American Financial Services Association. "Since then, the rise has been continuous," she said.
Ira B. Charmoy, a Bridgeport bankruptcy lawyer, said the number of filings stemmed from the region's ailing economy. He added, though, that no single factor like rising unemployment has caused the surge in bankruptcies in the Northeast.
No significant law changes have been adopted in the last 12 years that would make filing for bankruptcy more desirable today. In fact, the type of debts that cannot be written off through bankruptcy has been expanded to include debts like judgments incurred because of a drunken-driving offense.
 
Borrowing on Homes
 Even so, in the New York metropolitan region several bankruptcy trends are discernible. Dr. Robert W. Johnson, a senior research associate at the Credit Research Center at Purdue University in West Lafayette, Ind., said many filings in the Northeast appeared to be by individuals in construction or real estate.
He also said many of the bankruptcies appear to be connected to the deflation in the housing market. "People have been borrowing on their home, and, in some cases, the dollar value of the loan has become greater than the value of the house," he said.
Mr. Abraham, the bankruptcy court clerk, said there has also been a marked increase in Chapter 13 filings, which enable debtors to keep their homes if they continue making mortgage payments and partial payments on their other debts, sometimes as little as 10 percent, over a period generally no longer than five years.
Chapter 7 filings, which are more common, erase all debts in exchange for liquidating all assets, with exemptions generally totaling no more than about $10,000 in cash and home equity. Assets like automobiles, as well as other loans or lines of credit, can be retained if the individual loan is reaffirmed in full with the lender. Chapter 11 bankruptcies, generally restricted to corporate bankruptcies, are also used in rare instances by individuals with small businesses.
"There have been an awful lot of foreclosures, which bring the Chapter 13's up," Mr. Abraham said.
 
'Facing the Reality'
 Vincent J. Freccia, a Stamford bankruptcy lawyer, said debtors were deciding more quickly to file for bankruptcy than they had in the past. "They are facing the reality a lot more quickly," he said.
Creditors have noted this trend, too. Through higher prices, they pass on to consumers about $10 billion a year in bankruptcy-related losses. "We are very concerned that bankruptcy is being looked at as the first alternative rather than the last resort," said Kenneth R. Crone, vice president and director of the bankruptcy recovery program at Visa USA in San Francisco.
The bankruptcy boom is also being felt in the regional consumer counseling offices operated by the National Foundation for Consumer Credit, a nonprofit group based in Silver Spring, Md.
 
More Viable Option
 At the foundation's New Haven office, the branch manager, Will L. Parkerton, said more people were seeking help managing their debts than ever before. "We are seeing 350 to 400 people a month, double the number a year ago," he said. "We can't see someone coming in today until early February."
Mr. Parkerton added that bankruptcy seemed to become a more viable option during economic downturns because debtors often could not work second jobs, collect overtime or maintain a two-paycheck family to cover household debts.
A typical client, he said, earns $26,000 a year and owes about two-thirds of a year's salary in installment debt, excluding mortgages. Those who opt for bankruptcy usually have a similar level of income but owe about a full year's salary.
He also said about 15 percent of his current clients had debts so large that they were urged to consider bankruptcy. "The degree of encouragement we can offer people these days is less," he said.
 
A 'Badge' of the Recession
 Mark S. Carron, a bankruptcy lawyer in Westport, said clients were often less concerned with the social stigma of bankruptcy than the practical difficulty of re-establishing credit. "As more and more people use it, it becomes a badge of the 1990 recession," he said.
Paul A. Dingwall, 30, of Bridgeport, who filed for Chapter 7 bankruptcy protection in 1988 after losing a $250,000 lawsuit filed in connection with several small businesses he owned, said the limitations on credit that follow bankruptcy made it difficult, if not impossible, to start a business, buy a home or rent an apartment. "I wouldn't recommend it unless it was absolutely necessary," he said.
Others are more skeptical about assertions they have heard about not being able to obtain credit for up to 6, 7 or 10 years. "There is no magic number for how long your credit is shot," said Francis J. Browne, a Stamford bankruptcy lawyer.
Dr. Johnson of the Credit Research Center said bankruptcies might influence potential hirings, promotions or security clearances. He also said many people who filed for bankruptcy often had trouble renting apartments and generally found it impossible to obtain a mortgage.
 
Re-establishing Credit
 He cited a study by the center, however, that showed that of 25,000 people who had filed for bankruptcy, many received credit within a fairly brief period. He said 9 percent had some new credit within six months after filing bankruptcy, 17 percent within one year, 33 percent within three years and 50 percent within five years.
Bankruptcy lawyers have also noted a growing astuteness about re-establishing credit. They said some who filed for bankruptcy obtained credit later by keeping open at least one old line of credit, generally by reaffirming a debt or erasing the balance on a credit card and not reporting it during the bankruptcy proceedings.
They also often re-establish credit by using credit cards that require a cash deposit equal to the line of credit.
"Bankruptcy has a bad name," Mr. Carron, the Westport lawyer, said. "What it really is is the Federal Fresh Start program."

Among them are Paul Bernier, shown outside his house in New Canaan, Conn. "I really didn't have much of a choice," Mr. Bernier said. (Stephen Castagneto for The New York Times) (pg. B4)

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: HIGH TECH;
War Hero Status Possible for the Computer Chip

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
If the Pentagon's claims of success in the Persian Gulf war bear up, a hero of the conflict will be the ubiquitous computer chip, no larger than a fingernail and usually made of silicon, which processes reams of information in an instant for planes, bombs, sensors and cruise missiles.
"It's the triumph of silicon over steel," said John E. Pike, a senior analyst at the Federation of American Scientists, a private group in Washington. 
 Yesterday, the chip's prowess was evident as highly computerized Patriot anti-missile missiles flashed from their launchers in Saudia Arabia, streaked skyward and destroyed Scud missiles in a ball of thunder and flame.
Military experts say the computerized weapons of the international force in the Persian Gulf war seem to be working much better than expected. While cautioning that the overall performance of the new weaponry is not yet known, experts say computers big and small have clearly endowed the equipment with vast new powers of precision and coordination.
Large computers are now synchronizing the forces arrayed against Iraq and churning out detailed battle plans. Computerized jammers are snarling Iraqi defenses. And smart weapons with tiny computer "brains" are zeroing in on targets with deadly precision.
 
Information vs. Volume
 "What's making all this work is weapons based on information instead of the volume of fire power," said James F. Digby, a Rand Corporation analyst who wrote an influential paper in 1976 on precision-guided munitions. "It reduces greatly the tonnage of explosives you have to ship over."
Experts stress that the computerized arms are anything but invincible, as driven home by the difficulty in locating mobile Scud missiles experienced by planes and satellites carrying computerized sensors.
Even so, many experts say the gulf war appears to mark the coming of age of computerized weaponry, a goal that has been much heralded and criticized for 15 years as the emerging systems acquired a mixed record of success and failure.
"I'm impressed," said Herbert F. York, a former head of Pentagon research and development who teaches at the University of California. "It took such a long time. And it's still extremely expensive. But some of the disappointments I've felt over the years are being washed away."
 
Censorship May Hide Failures
 Among the highly computerized systems in the war are Navy Tomahawk cruise missiles, Pave Tack laser-guided bombs, Air Force F-117A Stealth fighters and the Army Patriot anti-missile systems whose interceptions of Iraqi Scud missiles in flight is a wartime first.
Many experts cautioned that the public's view of the war is limited by Pentagon censorship and selective presentation of facts so that computerized failures are generally not known.
"Everything is looking pretty good and I must say I'm impressed," said Eugene J. Carroll, a retired rear admiral and deputy director of the Center for Defense Information, a private group in Washington. "But all the news is coming through a filter. We see the hits but not the misses. Management of the news has put an emphasis on the success of our new weapons."
Pierre Sprey, a Washington-based defense consultant and longtime advocate of simpler military systems that rely less heavily on computer chips, dismissed much of upbeat news as disinformation.
 
Effectiveness Questioned
 "They're retargeting a lot of the places where they already claimed great success," he said. "The bombing just isn't that accurate. In the future, the ineffectiveness is going to become painfully obvious."
The promise of computerized weaponry was first demonstrated in the Vietnam War. The Air Force, for example, flew several hundred unsuccessful sorties to knock out the Thanh Hoa bridge, with 10 planes being shot down. Finally, four Phantom jets armed with Paveway I laser-guided bombs destroyed it in a single run.
But as new, more advanced generations of smart weapons emerged in the 1970's and 80's, they engendered fierce debate as field trails revealed shortcomings and failures. The computerized arms were widely faulted as too costly, ambitious and unreliable to be suitable for war.
The criticism was bolstered when technical glitches hit some military actions, including the 1983 invasion of Grenada, the 1986 raid on Libya and 1989 invasion of Panama. The height of high-tech failings occurred in 1988 when the Navy cruiser Vincennes, equipped with the highly computerized Aegis radar, the world's most advanced naval air defense system, mistakenly shot down an Iranian commercial airliner, killing all on board.
 
Chips to the Rescue
 Given this history, private military analysts were openly apprehensive this fall and winter about a possible war in the Persian Gulf, especially because of the challenge of coordinating the vast multinational force. Predictions of chaos abounded, with experts saying the majority of the first casualties would be self-inflicted.
Instead, the omnipresent computer chip appears to have come to the rescue. At American military headquarters for the war in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, a bevy of large computers has generated the overall battle plan and every day churns out hundreds of pages of detailed action orders.
"We have a lot of computers," Lieut. Gen. Charles A. Horner, commander of the American Air Force in the gulf, told reporters last week. "You can bring together the tens of thousands of minor details, radio frequencies, altitudes, tanker rendezvous, bomb configurations, who supports who, who's flying escort, who's -- there are just thousands and thousands of details, and we work them together as one group, put them together in what we call a common air-tasking order, and it provides a sheet of music that everybody sings the same song off."
Another quiet aspect of the chip revolution is tiny, computerized radio receivers that pick up signals from the American military's orbiting Navstar satellites, allowing tanks, ships and plane to pinpoint their positions, reportedly down to an accuracy of less than 100 feet. That navigational data, in turn, is often fed into smart weapons before they speed toward targets.
 
Computers Read 'Maps'
 "The more precise their initial position, the more precise their journey will be," said Ron Hertenstein, vice president for research at Forecast International, Inc., a Newtown, Conn. firm that markets defense and aerospace information.
For instance, the aerial assault against Iraq was kicked off by waves of 18-foot Tomahawk cruise missiles fired from Navy warships in the gulf and the Red Sea. Flying low and largely undetected, the smart missiles hit key targets such as Iraqi command centers.
The Tomahawks, never before used in combat, have tiny on-board computers that read internal "maps" and process information from sensors to perform course corrections in flight.
Mr. Hertenstein of Forecast International noted that accuracy also cuts down on civilian causalities.
 
Jammers Disorient Radar
 "We can attack a target in the middle of Baghdad and keep the damage to innocent people to a minimum," he said. "That certainly does make the situation more acceptable if not palatable."
Another highly computerized system is electronic warfare planes, including the Navy's EA-6B Prowler and the Air Force's EF-111A Raven. These aircraft have electronic jammers that send out high-energy pulses to disarm or disorient enemy radar and other communications.
The jamming devices are directed by powerful computers that first sense an enemy's frequencies and then tailor false signals to fog an enemy's radar display with bright spots, making it impossible to find real information.
Admiral Carroll of the Center for Defense Information laid the "pronounced ineffectiveness" of the Iraqi armed forces to such computerized impediments.
 
Patriot Modified for Missiles
 "We've penetrated their system so severely with our jammers and spookers that they can't see us coming and their antiaircraft batteries are absolutely blind," he said.
Also impressing many experts has been the active defense of the alliance by the Patriot system, which uses a phased-array radar to track enemy targets and a powerful bank of computers to actively guide anti-missile missiles toward their targets.
The Patriot initially was developed to shoot down enemy aircraft, not high-speed missiles. But in recent years it has been modified, mainly through the use of enhanced computers, to defend against limited missile attacks.

HEADLINE: Dr. King's Widow Asks End to War in the Gulf

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 20

 BODY:
On the eve of a Federal holiday honoring her husband, Coretta Scott King called today for an immediate cease-fire in the Persian Gulf and an end to what she described as a system that puts militarism ahead of education.
"Our most urgent short-term priority at the international level is a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf," Mrs. King said in her annual "State of the Dream" speech. She spoke at the Ebenezer Baptist Church, where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. once preached. 
 Mrs. King urged her audience "to become involved in working to stop this war" and to put pressure on elected representatives to "call for a cease-fire."
"In 1991 we have to work closer together, to protest and march and speak out more often until preparing for education is a greater priority in every nation than preparing for war," she said.
Dr. King, whose birthday will be recognized by a Federal holiday on Monday, would have been 62 years old on Jan. 15.
In Blacksburg, Va., today, about 30 Ku Klux Klan members marched to protest the holiday. A handful of Klan members were pelted with eggs and snowballs when they rallied at the State Capitol in Albany.
In her speech, Mrs. King commended the Israeli Government and people "for not retaliating against Iraq."
"It takes courage and wisdom to refuse to be sucked into the cycle of retaliation," she said, "and I hope and pray that Israel will be able to continue to exercise restraint."
She stressed that her opposition was "against the war, not the warriors."
Mrs. King also called for more spending on education, saying it must become a higher priority.
If self-financing programs like Social Security are subtracted from the Federal budget, she said, "the U.S. is spending 55 cents out of every taxpayer dollar on the military, compared to just 2 cents for education."
The real hostages today, she said, "are American school children, the nation's 3 million homeless people, the 20 million Americans who experience hunger every day and the 37 million Americans who have no health insurance."
She said that one-fourth of all black men from the ages of 18 to 29 are in jail or in some other phase of the criminal justice process and that one-quarter of black males under 25 have never held a job.
"African-American communities across the nation are experiencing Depression-level unemployment," he said.
She said the Federal Government should begin to substantially increase financing of education and job training programs, and she called for a Congressional commission to study the plight of black males.
Education and job training are needed so young people "can become productive, taxpaying citizens who can help support their families."
"We cannot eradicate illiteracy and other social problems," she went on, "until we eradicate the scourges of militarism from the face of the earth."

HEADLINE: Unions at Javits Center Are Accused of Abuses

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB

 BODY:
When the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center opened in 1986, the center's officials pledged to keep exhibition costs low and mobsters out.
Five years later, exhibitors complain of high labor costs and featherbedding, and law-enforcement officials say that Mafia racketeering raises operating costs for exhibitors. 
 The most frequent complaint from show managers and exhibitors is the high cost of setting up a trade show -- more than in any other American city. "Even if takes two seconds to get something done, you have to pay for a minimum of one hour and you might have to use three people," said Dr. Howard B. Menell, who was in charge of a dental trade show in November. "Most of our exhibitors complain that it's too expensive."
Dr. Menell said cleaning bills for his group, the Greater New York Dental Meeting, rose last year to $6,300 from $3,300 in 1989. And exhibitors in other trade shows flinch when describing routine charges of $80 for an electrician to plug in a lamp.
 
Chronic Theft Problems
 Another chronic problem cited by Police Department officials is the systemic theft of supplies and equipment, with reported losses ranging from $500,000 to $1 million annually.
Recalling the theft of a carton of 525 artificial eyes at the International Vision Exhibition last April, Sgt. Michael W. Gerhold, commander of detectives in the 10th Precinct, said the booty, valued at $16,115, was probably worthless to the thief.
"Everything walks out of that place, glass eyes, computers, jewelry, furs, stuffed animals -- whatever is on display," Sergeant Gerhold said.
But many exhibitors feel they have no choice but to put up with costs and the problems with union labor, because the Javits Center, in the nation's largest and most affluent marketplace, is an essential part of doing business. Last year, about 3 million people attended 90 events in the vast building between West 35th and West 39th Streets and 11th and 12th Avenues.
In an effort to reduce operating costs, the New York State corporation that runs the center established binding arbitration for resolving disputes over work rules and the number of employees needed for shows. Officials also obtained a no-strike pledge from four major unions. But many exhibitors say these measures have failed to cut costs significantly.
Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, said his office and state police detectives were jointly investigating "allegations of corruption" at the center. He declined to provide details.
Investigators familiar with the inquiry said they were focusing on the carpenter and teamster locals and on possible charges involving extortion, larceny and "no-show" jobs.
And in a civil suit filed last September, Federal prosecutors in Manhattan charged that the carpenters' union in the city was controlled by the Genovese organized-crime family and that the center was a hiring hall for mobsters and former convicts.
"Convention Center jobs are very desirable because they offer easy work at overtime rates, together with the opportunity to make even more money by shaking down exhibitors, thefts and other rackets," a former carpenters' union official, Marcello Svedese, said in a court affidavit.
Vincent (Fish) Cafaro, who admits being a former member of the Genovese family, claimed in an affidavit that Mafia leaders "had considerable influence" in the hiring of center carpenters.
In the suit, brought under the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, known as RICO, prosecutors asked the Federal court to appoint trustees to oversee the New York District Council of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners. The council appoints the shop stewards who largely select carpenters hired at the center.
The council's president, Paschal McGuinness, who is a defendant in the RICO case, said in a recent statement that "there is no basis, in fact or in law" for the charges.
Prosecutors identified the carpenters' chief steward at the center, Ralph Coppola, as "a Genovese family associate." The suit contended that Mr. Coppola reports to Liborio (Barney) Bellomo, whom prosecutors identified as a capo in the Genovese family.
Anthony Fiorini, who is the carpenters' assistant chief steward in the center, is Mr. Bellomo's brother-in-law, the suit said. Prosecutors cited another assistant to Mr. Coppola, Nicholas Cirillo, the president of the carpenters' Local 17, as having ties to organized crime. Mr. Coppola, Mr. Fiorini and Mr. Cirillo did not return telephone calls.
 
Union Denies Abuses
 In its separate investigation, the Manhattan District Attorney's office is looking into the activities of the carpenters' union and three other major unions, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Local 807, the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Local 3, and the Exhibition Employees Union, Local 829.
"All I can tell you is that none of the officials in this union are involved in shakedowns," said John G. Hohmann, secretary-treasurer of Local 807. He also denied that the union created "ghost" or no-show jobs.
Allegations of irregularities at the center were turned over to Mr. Morgenthau's office three years ago by Alair A. Townsend, who was then the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development. Ms. Townsend, in an interview, said there had been numerous complaints from exhibitors about abuses, and that former Mayor Edward I. Koch directed her to give the information to Mr. Morgenthau after center officials had failed to move promptly to deal with the problems.
 
Union Workers Required
 A 13-member public-benefit corporation, the Convention Center Operating Corporation, establishes policies for the center. It has a contract with the Ogden Allied Services Corporation to provide cleaning and maintenance services and to book shows and fairs with trade-show organizers.
The organizers rent space to exhibitors and hire a service or decorating company that employs workers to load and unload equipment and install the booths and electricity. The service companies have contracts requiring them to use only union workers.
Labor costs at the center are as much as 50 percent higher than at convention halls in other big cities. General rates in the center for electricians, for example, are $78.50 an hour, and $108 an hour for overtime.
Some 125 to 400 carpenters, electricians, teamsters and laborers work daily, depending on the number of shows and meetings.
Common complaints by show managers and exhibitors include a rule requiring three electricians instead of one for relatively simple tasks and demands by workers for payoffs to expedite loading and unloading of materials.
But many show managers said the added costs in New York were offset by larger audiences and better sales opportunities. "The labor problems are not nightmares," said Susan Werlinich, the marketing manager for Expoconsul International, a Princeton, N.J., company that organizes trade shows.
Benjamin C. LaRosa, the center's vice president for operations and labor management, also said complaints were exaggerated. But he noted that the corporation had no control over the hiring of union employees.
Asked if the corporation should do more to supervise employees and stop corruption, he said: "That's something we are looking into. But we're waiting for the investigations to finish, to see what they find."

HEADLINE: REBELS ARE POSING THREAT IN PANAMA

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA, Jan. 20

 BODY:
The leaders of a military revolt last month have eluded capture with the aid of active-duty officers and constitute a terrorist threat to the United States-installed Government, American and Panamanian officials say.
Eduardo Herrera Hassan, a retired colonel who was seized by the United States forces that were called in to stop a coup attempt on Dec. 4, was originally identified as the leader of the rebellion. But Panamanian and American officials said he was a front man for a retired captain who escaped with at least 50 heavily armed rebels. 
 Several officials said members of Panama's security forces know where the rebels are hiding but are unwilling to tell loyal police, putting into question American-supported efforts to reform the military after of the December 1989 invasion by the United States.
 
Pledge From U.S.
 The rebels were members of the army under the former Panamanian leader Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. That army was defeated in the American invasion, and the rebels are not thought to have a coherent ideology aside from restoring the military as Panama's dominant institution. Deane Hinton, the United States Ambassador to Panama, has pledged Washington would deploy the 10,000 troops still stationed in Panama if they are needed to stop another coup attempt.
A ranking United States military officer said the rebels "are capable of assassinations and acts of terrorism. There is no doubt about that. They certainly have the weapons and the training to do this kind of thing."
The Panamanian police said the rebels were responsible for several armed robberies and the slaying of at least one Panama City policeman in recent weeks, suggesting that they are attempting hit-and-run attacks to confuse and demoralize the Government's reconstituted 10,000-man Public Force police.
While the rebels are thought to have too little popular support to engage in a prolonged offensive, officials fear they can cause enough damage to slow the private investment needed to rebuild the economy, which was shattered by two years of economic sanctions and the invasion.
They are particularly concerned that the renewed attacks could complicate efforts to build a professional police force, a central element of United States policy here.
Members of the Public Force, almost all of whom were once colleagues of the rebels, remain suspicious of President Guillermo Endara's Government because it has taken away many of their traditional perks, like free food and transportation. The Government has fired 100 members of the Public Force who were suspected of supporting the revolt.
 
'Divided Loyalties'
 The Public Force police have gone through months of American training and patrols with United States troops. Washington has provided patrol cars, radios and other police equipment. With help from the United States Justice Department, the Government has established a police academy that is designed to infuse the force with new blood as the old Noriega soldiers are phased out.
But a United States official said the police had still displayed "divided loyalties."
The official said the security problem is compounded because the rebels are better equipped than the Public Force. He said the rebels had used Uzi and M-60 machine guns, M-16 and AK-47 assault rifles, gas masks and bulletproof vests in their attacks and could easily buy RPG rocket launchers on the Panamanian black market.
Such weapons are in abundance from the Noriega era, when the regime created weapons caches in preparation for an invasion. Many of the caches remain undetected.
"There are no Panamanian forces who have the capability to stop these guys," the American official said.
United States officials believe there are at least two organizations of former Noriega troops, both with ties to members of the current security force.
The most threatening band is thought to consist of former captains and lieutenants operating around Panama City. This group is led by retired Capt. Jorge Bernal, a high-strung but charismatic officer who engineered the December helicopter rescue of Mr. Herrera and the taking of the Public Force headquarters.
Mr. Bernal's band of 50 to 100 men might have sparked a revolt by the Public Force if not for the United States troops. The rebels, realizing they could not defeat the Americans, escaped by crashing through a barricade of pickup trucks. A handful of them later appeared at foreign embassies to seek asylum; the rest remain at large.
In an open letter that was photocopied and passed around the Panama City last September, Mr. Bernal declared himself to be a follower of the late Gen. Omar Torrijos, the left-leaning populist dictator.
"Bernal is supposed to be a very dangerous individual," commented Vice President Guillermo Ford. He said Mr. Bernal's group consisted of "the best trained men of the old regime." "Security is one of the biggest problems we have," Mr. Ford added.
The other rebel band, consisting of former soldiers, pro-Noriega militia and criminals, operates in the highlands of Chiriqui province in western Panama.
Officials say they are not sure whether a group calling itself M-20 is a seperate organization or whether the name is used by the two bands.
The M-20 has claimed responsibility for a series of minor attacks in the last 11 months, including a grenade attack on the United States Embassy on Jan. 15. One grenade exploded, causing minor damage but no casualties.
 
'Keeping the Flame Alive'
 Ignacio Occhi, a pro-Noriega newspaper editor, said the rebels were no longer connected to the imprisoned dictator who is awaiting trial in Miami. He said "they haven't gotten popular support yet because people haven't reached their limit of tolerance" with the Endara Government. "But the men are keeping the flame alive."
Mr. Occhi said the man who represents the greatest threat to the Government is retired Capt. Eliecer Asuncion Gaitan, who was General Noriega's top security aide. Mr. Gaitan, who is considered highly violent, took refuge with General Noriega in the Vatican Embassy during the invasion.
Mr. Gaitan escaped from the Nunciatora in September, some foreign diplomats suggest with the assistance of Mr. Bernal, and has reportedly been seen in Colombia and Argentina. Mr. Occhi said Mr. Gaitan "will make his move when he is sure he can win."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Eduardo Herrera Hassan with followers outside the National Police Headquarters in Panama City last month during a failed rebel coup. After seizing the building, he was captured by American troops. But according to American and Panamanian officials, the rebels staged the capture to allow the real coup leader to escape. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: More Banks Turn to Wall St. to Sell C.D.'s.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
American banks are turning to Wall Street brokerages with increased frequency to help them attract new depositors by selling the banks' Federally insured certificates of deposit.
At a time of weak earnings and growing problems with bad loans, the bankers have been having difficulty raising money from large institutions, and are now trying to increase deposits from individuals, reaching them through brokerage firms with large networks of branch offices. 
 And the banks are taking such action with the knowledge and blessing of the very bank regulators who harshly criticized some savings and loan institutions in the 1980's for doing much the same thing.
The current situation, though, has this difference: The savings and loans sold the certificates of deposit through brokerage firms at a time when they were nearly insolvent, as a way of continuing rapid growth and unsound lending; the banks are using the technique not to finance rapid growth, but to augment their sources of money.
"Selling C.D.'s through the brokers provides us with nationwide distribution and a stable source of funding," said Kenneth Krolczyk, vice president at First National Bank of Chicago. "Most of the buyers are individuals, and the cost tends to be low."
A New York banker, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, noted that large institutions that buy multimillion-dollar C.D.'s "are not there in the volume we have seen in the past, and brokered C.D.'s have helped fill that gap." In 1990, C.D.s issued in amounts of more than $100,000 by large banks fell by $17.6 billion, to $211.8 billion, according to Federal Reserve data.
The C.D.'s sold through brokers are also a low-cost replacement for commercial paper and the medium-term note, which have become more difficult and costly to sell. For example, many of the nation's largest banking companies must pay investors more than 10 percent to sell them notes due in two years, but they can issue Federally insured C.D.'s through brokers at rates of 7.5 percent or less.
For the bankers, the sales of insured certificates of deposit through brokerage firms are a way of collecting more money from consumers without increasing the rates offered to all local depositors. For banks in areas where competition keeps interest rates high, like New York City, selling C.D.'s through brokers allows them to collect money in other parts of the country, like Detroit, where interest rates are lower.
According to securities dealers, 9 of the nation's 10 largest banks -- all but J. P. Morgan & Company -- as well as dozens of smaller institutions have been using brokerage firms to sell insured certificates of deposit.
 
Popular With Investors
 Wall Street firms like Merrill Lynch & Company and Shearson Lehman Brothers are finding that the insured bank C.D.'s are popular with customers worried about the lack of insurance on other kinds of investments, like money market mutual funds. Merrill Lynch said bank C.D.'s of less than $100,000 sold through all brokers rose $7 billion, to $39 billion, or by about 22 percent in the year ended June 30, 1990. More recent data are not available, but Merrill Lynch officials estimated that activity has continued to grow rapidly.
"The Federal deposit insurance coverage on the C.D.'s is a very attractive feature to our customers," said Richard M. Fuscone, chairman of Merrill Lynch Money Markets Inc. But he added that Merrill Lynch did not handle C.D.'s of the weakest banks, noting that "we cooperate fully with the regulators to be sure that we are not undermining the safety of the banking system."
Mr. Fuscone noted that half the banks that ask Merrill Lynch to sell their C.D.'s are turned down. Merrill Lynch routinely holds millions of dollars of bank C.D.'s in its inventory -- far above the $100,000 insurance limit. So it is keenly interested in avoiding banks that are likely to fail or to encounter difficulties and unfavorable publicity that would reduce the value of their C.D.'s.
 
Sales by Weaker Banks
 Even if Merrill Lynch decides not to deal with a weak bank, other firms may do so. In the last year, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's regional offices have given temporary approval to 101 undercapitalized banks to sell C.D.'s through brokers. Of those banks, 65 have obtained approval in Washington to continue beyond the 90-day temporary limit. Banks that meet regulatory standards for capital do not need prior approval to sell C.D.'s through brokers.
"We will squeeze banks which are near failure and want to rely on brokered C.D.'s," said Jesse G. Snyder, an assistant director at the F.D.I.C. But "by and large we recognize the benefits of the practice" for banks that use brokered C.D.'s as a lower-cost, more stable source of money.
The importance of brokered C.D.'s is illustrated by two large regional banking companies whose recent troubles have made it more difficult for them to rely on large investors.
The Midlantic Corporation in Edison N.J., a banking company which owns the second-largest bank in New Jersey, began selling one-year and two-year C.D.'s through brokers in the second quarter of 1990. By Sept. 30 of last year, a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission showed that it had $870 million in brokered C.D.'s outstanding, or more than 10 percent of its outstanding certificates of deposit issued in amounts of less than $100,000. For the banking industry as a whole, less than 1.4 percent of deposits are brokered C.D.'s.
 
Losing Other Sources of Funds
 While brokered C.D.'s and other kinds of consumer deposits were increasing, Midlantic was losing other sources of money. From the end of 1989 to Sept. 30, 1990, C.D.'s of more than $100,000 fell by $606.3 million, or about 22 percent, to $2.13 billion. And other short-term borrowings at the New Jersey banking company fell by 32 percent.
At MNC Financial Inc., a Baltimore banking company that owns Maryland National Bank and American Security Bank in Washington, brokered deposits totaled $2.7 billion as of Sept. 30, or 32 percent of its $8.43 billion portfolio of C.D.'s of less than $100,000. Because of its weakened financial condition and a rapid increase in problems with bad loans, the company was required to obtain regulators' approval to continue selling C.D.'s through brokers.
A study by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York found that 19 of the 43 banks with assets of more than $10 billion at the end of 1989 used brokerages to sell C.D.'s in amounts of less than $100,000. At those large banks, the brokered C.D.'s accounted for about 2.9 percent of domestic deposits. But among all banks, there were 80 that used brokerage firms for at least 10 percent of deposits and 31 that raised more than 20 percent of deposits from brokered C.D.'s.
While demand for broker-placed C.D.'s is growing among banks, there is a cloud on the horizon. One suggestion for changing the Federal deposit insurance program would do away with the practice of allowing up to $100,000 of Federal deposit insurance to pass through to individual beneficiaries of pension funds that have bought "bank investment contracts." One concern is that the change would also apply to the brokered C.D.'s.

HEADLINE: Eastern's Rivals Stand to Benefit

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The shutting of Eastern Airlines on Friday night is likely to benefit Delta Air Lines and Pan American World Airways in particular, because they have competed directly with Eastern's largest business, carrying passengers from the Northeast to Atlanta and Florida.
Other airlines will gain fewer passengers but will have the opportunity to expand operations in Florida, Georgia and New York by buying Eastern's gates and landing rights. 
 But for the public, the demise of Eastern is likely to make it more expensive to take winter vacations in Florida. The airline had been a leader in discounting fares, as it tried to overcome public concerns about its safety and labor strife.
Unless all of Eastern's planes are bought by other carriers and put in service, which seems unlikely because the industry is furloughing thousands of workers as traffic stagnates, then the overall supply of airline seats will fall and prices will tend to rise.
 
Rivals May Move Quickly
 "The fares themselves won't move up that much, but there will be adjustments to capacity" as airlines set aside fewer seats for discount fares, said Daniel M. Kasper, the director of the transportation practice at Harbridge House, a Boston consulting firm.
William D. Berry, a Delta spokesman, said competition from other airlines would insure that fares to all of Eastern's destinations would closely reflect the cost of serving them.
Rival carriers are free to move quickly to offer new or expanded service on Eastern's domestic routes because of the Federal Government's deregulation of the industry in 1978, said Richard P. Magurno, a former attorney for Eastern who now specializes in airline litigation as a partner at Lord, Day & Lord, Barrett Smith in New York. Eastern sold its Latin American routes to American Airlines last summer and is now almost entirely a domestic carrer.
USAir, American, Continental and Trans World Airlines competed less directly with Eastern in serving Florida. United and Northwest Airlines, which are strongest in the Midwest, shared few routes with Eastern.
Eastern's experience in bankruptcy, for which it filed in March 1989, is likely to make the recently begun bankruptcy proceedings of Pan Am and Continental more difficult.
Both carriers want their creditors to allow them to continue flying. They also want travelers to continue buying tickets.
When Eastern filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, its assets exceeded its liabilities to unsecured creditors, like aircraft and engine makers. The creditors gave Eastern permission to continue operating. But the carrier lost so much money that the unsecured creditors are likely to receive little money, if any.
 
Testing Creditors' Patience
 Mr. Kasper said the Eastern experience could mean that Pan Am and Continental creditors would be less patient. And both airlines' customers may be alarmed by the spectacle of Eastern's ticket holders crowding airports and beseeching other carriers for seats after Eastern suspended service.
"Ticket holders and the potential ticket holders are going to remember the pictures on the television and the articles in the newspaper," he said.
Pamela Hanlon, a Pan Am spokeswoman, said the carrier had obtained a $100 million financial guarantee of its tickets from United Airlines and was preparing a reorganization plan for its creditors.
Continental has good relations with its creditors and does not have the labor problems that disrupted Eastern, said Arthur Kent, a spokesman for the carrier.
Martin R. Shugrue Jr., the trustee appointed by the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan nine months ago to try to guide Eastern out of bankruptcy, said on Saturday that he would seek investors to return the carrier to the skies. He said he would not begin liquidating the carrier immediately and would explore the possibility of leasing planes to the military for use in ferrying troops to the Persian Gulf.
But Karen M. Ceremsak, an Eastern spokeswoman, acknowledged yesterday that "the revival of the airline is at best a long shot." Management does not want to raise any false hopes among the company's 18,000 full-time employees that a resumption of service is likely, she said.
 
Leases Become Valuable
 Eastern has been looking for investors for many months without success, and Ms. Ceremsak said that after further study over the weekend, Eastern had decided it would not be able to lease planes to the military because it could not afford the crews to fly them.
If Eastern is liquidated, as seems very likely, rival carriers would bid for Eastern's leases of airport gates, as well as its landing rights at LaGuardia Airport in New York, where congestion aloft has made these rights valuable.
Delta Air Lines Inc., which is based in Atlanta, says it wants to buy some Eastern gates at Hartsfield International Airport in Atlanta. The plan is expected to arouse the interest of the Justice Department's antitrust division, because Delta already has a large hub there, said Mr. Magurno, the airline litigation specialist.
Delta fills all of one terminal at Hartsfield, shares another with Eastern and still another with other carriers, Mr. Berry said. Delta would like to take over the Eastern gates in the terminal it shares with the carrier, so it could consolidate its operations in two terminals, he said.
Mr. Berry said that Eastern had gates in still another terminal that did not interest Delta, and that even with Eastern's suspension of service, more than 80 percent of the passengers flying out of the airport could choose among two or more airlines.
"We definitely will make Justice familiar with anything we might announce with Eastern," he said.
 
Low Fares Draw Complaints
 United Airlines has been widely mentioned as another potential buyer of Eastern assets. Anthony T. Molinaro, an airline spokesman, declined to comment yesterday on whether the carrier was interested. Northwest and T.W.A. are also viewed as possible bidders.
Some experts contended in the weeks leading up to Eastern's collapse that its fares were unsustainably low, and that the carrier's continued operation for nearly two years under Chapter 11 protection had become unhealthy for the industry.
The bankruptcy code "allows a carrier to operate in the marketplace which, under normal economic circumstances, wouldn't be there," said Russell Thayer, a former president of Braniff Airways who now is a vice president of Airline Economics, a Washington consulting firm. "A number of carriers have complained about Eastern being able to charge so little money."
 
Last Remaining Strength
 Eastern's last remaining strength, after the sale of its Latin American routes last summer to American Airlines, lay in flights between the Northeast and Florida. Low rates on these routes this winter have been one result of Eastern's presence.
Discounted tickets from the Northeast to Florida used to sell for half the price of discounted transcontinental tickets, but have sold for a third of the price in recent weeks. At least part of this change, though, reflects the increasing cost of operating longer flights, as jet-fuel prices have risen during the Persian Gulf crisis.
Delta in particular responded to Eastern's low prices by cutting its fares. Yesterday, Delta continued to advertise $158 round-trip tickets to Florida from New York.
 
T.W.A. Plans Layoffs
 KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan 20 (AP) -- Trans World Arilines has announced plans to begin laying off more than 1,400 flight attendants Monday, citing "the situation in the Middle East," the airline's flight attendants' union said yesterday.
 A union official, Mary Ellen Miller, said the union was "vehemently protesting" and was exploring its legal options on grounds that T.W.A. was stopping pay without proper notice.
 A recorded telephone message to members of the Independent Federation of Flight Attendants said the T.W.A. layoff schedule called for 800 furloughs in New York, 394 in Los Angeles and 229 in St. Louis.
 American Airlines had said on Friday that layoff notices were issued to an unspecified number of ground-service employees because of reduced flight schedules. A company spokesman, John Hotard, would neither confirm nor deny a report, published on Friday in The Dallas Times Herald, that 240 employees would be laid off. American said it was cutting its flights because unionized pilots were clling in sick during an extended contract dispute.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Eastern Airlines jets parked in Miami on Saturday. The shutting down of the airline last week may benefit rival carriers, who are likely to gain customers while offering fewer tickets at discount prices. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Subway Plan On Homeless Is Abandoned

 BODY:
The Transit Authority's ambitious plans for mass sweeps to clear the subway system of homeless people have largely been abandoned, undermined by winter weather and the reluctance of transit officers, officials say.
While the rules adopted last fall against loitering and panhandling are not being dropped, their enforcement has returned to an ad hoc, rather than concerted, effort by the transit police. 
 The subway agency has instead turned to new approaches, primarily the stepping up of outreach efforts to lure the homeless out of tunnels and stations and into hospitals or shelters, said Debra Perry, associate director of government relations for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Transit Authority's parent agency.
"We realized that the plan was too broad," Ms. Perry said. "It couldn't be enforced."
 
A New Code of Conduct
 Last October, the M.T.A. announced "Operation Enforcement," a sweeping plan to counteract declining ridership by driving vagrants and beggars out of the subway system. The plan called for strict enforcement of a new code of conduct, which prohibited panhandling, littering and lying down on subway seats and benches.
The plan was criticized by advocates for the homeless, and met with skepticism among the rank and file of the transit police, although it had the strong backing of William J. Bratton, the Transit Police Chief.
The plan was quietly dropped in recent weeks in the face of the criticism, the ineffectiveness of initial efforts and the waves of cold weather that drew homeless people into the system far faster than the police could remove them, said a spokesman for the transit police, Albert W. O'Leary.
Chief Bratton is not abandoning any of the new rules, but is leaving their enforcement to the discretion of individual officers, the transit police said.
And many transit officers have said that there was little they could do to stop the thousands of homeless people from loitering in stations. "We have always said we're not social workers, we're police," Mr. O'Leary said. "Unfortunately, we really have no ability to control the homeless."
"It always feels like we're just moving them around," said a transit officer at the 175th Street IND station who refused to be identified. "If the homeless aren't breaking the rules, if they're just riding the trains and minding their own business, we leave them alone."
So a special operations unit, the Homeless Outreach Program, which began as a volunteer group nine years ago, now conducts most of the Transit Authority's outreach efforts for the homeless. It recently was increased to 20 officers, from six two years ago.
In November, the unit began operating two buses to transport homeless people from subway stations to city shelters. When the temperature drops below 32 degrees, four vans operate from midnight to 8 A.M. About 437 homeless people have been taken to city shelters since November, said Lieut. John Romero, executive officer of the outreach program.
 
Outreach Services at Stations
 The M.T.A. has also recently approved $450,000 for an outreach, referral and data-collection program in Grand Central and Penn Stations, Ms. Perry said. And it is contracting with community-based organizations to provide outreach services at 29 subway stations on the A and E lines. Financing for that program is $50,000.
But the two railroad stations remain closed to the homeless overnight.
Advocates for the homeless, while applauding the Transit Authority's decision to abandon the plan for large-scale rousts, say the new efforts are not enough.
"The Transit Authority is doing as little as possible," said Joseph G. Rappaport, coordinator of the Straphangers Campaign, a nonprofit group. "The patience of people who ride the subways is wearing thin.
 
'Critical Economic Times'
 Advocates for the homeless have been lobbying the transit agency for years to finance more social-service programs, and they complain that money for them is a low priority.
"It's inexcusable at this late date that the M.T.A. is holding back on funding for the homeless," said Peter P. Smith, president of the Partnership for the Homeless.
But the M.T.A. says there are limits to what it can do, particularly at a time when service reductions are being considered to close a $272 million deficit. "We're all operating under critical economic times," said Ms. Perry.
Homeless people can be found in hundreds of spots within the 700 miles of tunnel and 468 stations that make up the subway system. Four stations in which the problems are most acute are the Second Avenue and Broadway-Lafayette stations on the IND, and the 103d Street and 168th Street stations on the West Side IRT. The transit police said the two downtown stations have become havens for the homeless because of their proximity to the Bowery.
A human howl echoed from the tunnel north of the Second Avenue F train station one night last week, just as a special unit of the transit police had begun a routine search to evict the homeless.
On the concrete platform, a homeless man lay shaking from convulsions and foaming at the mouth. An open crack vial was nearby.
Within 10 minutes, Emergency Medical Service paramedics had arrived with a stretcher, carefully making their way across the 600-volt third rail. They carried the man about a quarter of a mile along the tracks to the subway platform and into a waiting ambulance.
"We were lucky we went in tonight," said Lieutenant Romero. "For every one that we save, there are hundreds more in there."
 
'I Just Read My Newsaper'
 The unidentified homeless man was released from a hospital hours later.
The transit police said the homeless continue to find ways to skirt the illegality of panhandling and loitering in the subways.
"I just read my newspaper and no one bothers me," said a homeless man who calls himself Street, as he begged for money on a northbound A train. "It's not that the transit police are overlooking their duty, it's just that they have a heart."
Conrad Cook is another homeless man who prefers the subways to city shelters and has resisted the Transit Authority's efforts to change his mind. The 32-year-old native of Jamaica was roused during a recent sweep from a mattress where he was sleeping next to the tracks in the Second Avenue tunnel.
"This tunnel is where I like to be," said Mr. Cook, who has been taken to two city shelters by the transit police but has returned to the subway. "It's quiet and no one's going to rob me."

HEADLINE: More Mexicans Come to U.S. to Stay

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO

 BODY:
In a marked shift in immigration trends, increasing numbers of Mexicans are coming to the United States to stay rather than to work for a few months as seasonal farm laborers, new studies show.
Since many of the illegal aliens are bringing their families to join them, the shift is expected to produce a greater demand for social services like schooling and health care. In addition, experts say, the trend is likely to reinforce the increasing dependence on low-cost immigrant labor by some urban enterprises and to add to social frictions that are already being felt in some communities. 
 Those who are staying include people like Leonardo Vilchis, a 28-year-old church social worker who emigrated from Mexico City. "The longer you stay here," he said, "the easier it becomes for you to blend in with the whole society and the more comfortable you become."
He said his parents, both architects in Mexico, had found work in San Diego 10 years ago washing dishes and now own a small restaurant.
"We were thinking we would make some money and then go back," he said. "Afterwards, with time, we adapted. Everyone started enrolling in school and getting more stable jobs, and we decided to stay."
 
Drop in Seasonal Changes
 In one sign of the shift from seasonal labor, recent figures on apprehensions of illegal aliens by the United States Border Patrol show a reduction in seasonal fluctuations. Until recently, monthly figures showed a consistent dip by as much as 50 percent or more in winter, when agricultural workers have typically returned to Mexico.
But last year, Border Patrol officials said, there was little seasonal variation. In both November and December, the Border Patrol said, it apprehended about 33,000 illegal aliens, an increase of more than 20 percent over the previous year.
The Immigration and Naturalization Service figures also show an increase in the number of women and children stopped as they tried to enter the United States.
"We have seen a changing trend for the past five or six years," said Ted Swofford, a supervisory agent with the Border Patrol, "but it has just become more pronounced in the last year."
The number of apprehensions represents only a fraction of those who entered the United States, but precise numbers of illegal aliens working either in seasonal or year-round jobs are not available.
 
More Work in Cities
 More and more migrants seem to be coming from Mexican cities and finding work not in the fields and orchards of America but in cities, where they are increasingly filling the need for low-paid workers.
"People start getting to understand the system, getting to know the language," Mr. Vilchis said. "They develop networks of friends who know where to go to school, how to find jobs. If there's papers you need, they know where to find the papers. As we develop confidence in the country, we see the possibility for bringing the family."
At the same time, returning home becomes a less attractive option. "There's no way you can leave your stable job when everything is so unstable in Mexico," Mr. Vilchis said.
Although some experts dispute the figures, Wayne A. Cornelius, the director of the Center for United States-Mexico Studies at the University of California in San Diego, said: "The I.N.S. statistics are just another indicator of the general process. Mexican migration to the United States has become much less tied to seasonal agriculture in this country. That's a permanent shift, and nothing's going to reverse it."
 
Signs of a New Approach
 He quoted recent studies by immigration experts that estimated that no more than 10 percent to 15 percent of Mexicans in California, Texas and Arizona now work in agriculture.
Mr. Cornelius said the greater numbers of women and children crossing the border also appear to be signs of a more long-term approach to migration, reflecting the resettlement of entire families in the United States.
In 1986 the Border Patrol in California apprehended and expelled an average of three to five unaccompanied children, ages 5 to 17, each day, according to figures compiled by Jorge Bustamante, the director of the Center for Border Studies in Tijuana, Mexico. In the first quarter of last year, the daily average had risen to 15.
Poverty has driven more Mexican women and children into the work force, where they are subject to the same pressures as men to migrate in search of employment, Mr. Cornelius said.
In the San Diego area, women now go door to door seeking housecleaning work, as men seeking work as gardeners have done for many years. Here and in other border cities, domestic work has become almost institutionalized as an occupation performed almost exclusively by female illegal aliens.
Mr. Cornelius, who is publishing a study on the shift by illegal aliens toward permanent residence in the United States, said the increasing number of poor immigrant families settling in American cities would place more demands on such social services as schooling and public health.
 
Growing Reliance on Migrants
 He said that urban employers, much like American farmers who have long been dependent on Mexican labor, may increasingly find themselves relying on recent immigrants to work in enterprises like car washes, restaurants, hotels, laundries, hospitals and factories.
He also forecast a rise in hostility toward the illegal aliens where they are highly visible, as American society struggles to accommodate itself to their presence. Such hostility is already evident in some communities in San Diego County, where immigrants camp in shantytowns and stand on street corners seeking work for the day.
Mr. Cornelius said the increasing demand in the United States for cheap immigrant labor was the primary reason for the shift from seasonal migration.
The continuing economic crisis in Mexico that has driven increasing numbers of rural people to Mexico City is another factor, he said. The Mexican capital is becoming something of a way station as migrants who cannot find work there continue on to the United States.
In addition, he said, the amnesty provisions of the 1986 immigration law allowed many illegal aliens to acquire stable, year-round jobs. Many are now sending for their families and becoming anchored in the United States.
Finally, he said, a "chain of migrants" has become established in which those already in the United States help the new arrivals find jobs and housing.
"The shift from a Mexican immigrant population dominated by transient, 'lone male' agricultural workers to a much more socially heterogeneous, year-round, urban-dwelling immigrant community is unlikely to be reversed," Mr. Cornelius wrote in his study.
"High emigration communities in central Mexico are being transformed increasingly into rest and recreation centers for families whose principal base is now in the United States."

HEADLINE: Budget Cuts Jar University of California

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20

 BODY:
The University of California, regarded by many as the nation's leading state university system, faces its deepest crisis since Gov. Ronald Reagan fired its president and slashed its budget nearly a quarter of a century ago.
The cause this time is not a Governor's angry determination to punish the campuses for student unrest, but California's deepening budget crisis. Still, the results are expected to be much the same: cuts in enrollment, faculty and staff, postponement in building new campuses to serve this fast-growing state and loss of its envied academic prowess. 
 Meeting with the Board of Regents at the Riverside campus on Friday, President David P. Gardner said "unprecedented steps" would be needed to maintain the quality of the 122-year-old system.
He said the budget drawn by the state's new Governor, Pete Wilson, fell "so far short of funding U.C.'s essential needs that our programs of teaching, research and public service, accessibility to eligible students and our historic policy of charging only modest student fees cannot be sustained."
 
Other Troubled Campuses
 Mr. Wilson's 1991-92 budget, released Jan. 10, raises tuition and fees by 20 percent and does not provide money for salary increases for the university's faculty and staff. William B. Baker, vice president for budget and university relations, said the system's operating budget faces an absolute cut of $2.2 million, to $2.191 billion, in the next fiscal year; that is $295.5 million less than the regents had requested.
The troubles here find an echo on campuses across the country as public universities cope with shrinking budgets by putting off repairs, reducing administrative staffs and leaving teaching positions vacant. In states like Massachusetts, where recession has hit hardest, officials are laying off faculty members and eliminating programs.
"Lights are dimmer, library hours are shorter and the library often doesn't have the books that students ask for," said Terry Zoulas, a spokesman for the Massachusetts Board of Regents.
And everywhere, decisions about what to jettison have created dissension among the administrative staff, faculty and students. "The easy cuts have all been made," said Chancellor D. Bruce Johnstone of the 64-campus State University of New York, who must trim $40 million from the budget this year. "There are no pockets of fat left."
 
California's Golden Age
 No state has invested more in the idea of public higher education than California. The University of California system, with its flagship campus at Berkeley, has 7,400 faculty members and 166,500 students on nine campuses. The separate California State University system has 368,000 students and 21,000 faculty members on its 20 campuses.
The University of California system reached what might be called its golden age under President Clark Kerr from 1958 to 1967. He oversaw the opening of three campuses and the decentralization of the system. Berkeley, in many eyes, surpassed Harvard as the nation's leading research university.
But when the campuses, particularly Berkeley, were swept with the Free Speech Movement, student sit-ins and antiwar demonstrations, Mr. Reagan made it a campaign pledge to clamp down on demonstrators. A few days after taking office in January 1967, he imposed sharp cuts on the system's budget and organized a majority of the regents to oust Mr. Kerr.
Under Mr. Reagan and his successor, Edmund G. Brown Jr., a Democrat, the system lost much of its academic competitiveness.
 
Deukmejian's Support
 But the election of George Deukmejian in 1982 brought a new flowering. Though a fiscally conservative Republican who fought to contain increases in spending for most other programs, Mr. Deukmejian protected the university system. Its budget grew by 15 percent a year in the economic boom of his first term, and by 3.5 percent a year in the last few years.
Now, higher education can no longer be shielded from budget cuts, said a spokesman for Governor Wilson, Bill Livingstone. Many other state programs are legally protected, he said, adding, "The U.C. system is a bargain at the prices it charges."
Despite the cuts, Mr. Kerr, now 79 years old and president emeritus of the university, said he saw no similarity to the days when he was fired.
"It's really a totally different situation from when Reagan came in," he said by telephone from his office on the Berkeley campus. "Reagan did not know anything about the university. Governor Wilson is very well informed. But he faces a much tougher budget situation than Reagan. His budget is very tough on the university, but my impression is the university has been teated equally."
 
Outgrowing the Campuses
 What makes the cuts particularly difficult is the timing. The state's population increased by about 20 percent in the last decade, according to the 1990 census, and enrollment in the University of California system set a record last fall. Officials had planned to add up to three more campuses over the next quarter-century.
All that has been thrown into doubt now. "We've got a major problem," Mr. Baker said. "It can only be dealt with by increasing fees, cutting back enrollment and laying people off." He said the system would have to cut 4,000 jobs, through early retirement, attrition and layoffs.
President Gardner said Friday that a delay in building the 10th campus, planned for the fast-growing Central Valley, would probably be announced at the regents' February meeting. A delay could result in new restrictions on enrollment, he said. The last new campus was opened in 1965 in Santa Cruz, and nearly all campuses have reached their capacity.
Fears are growing that California's commitment to providing a high-quality higher education to all academically qualified residents may be ebbing. The university's master plan requires the system to admit the top 12.5 percent of high school seniors.
The university charges no tuition to California residents, only "registration" and "educational" fees; non-residents pay tuition. The 20 percent increase means that fees paid by residents would rise to $1,949 next year from $1,624 this year, and tuition and fees for out-of-state students to $7,699 from $6,416. Similar cuts and fee increases would also be imposed on the California State University System.
The increase in fees has stirred deep unease among professors and students. "It's wrong-headed," said Francis Carney, a political scientist at Riverside. "The greatness of the university is that it is the people's university."
Aaron Walden, a graduate student in English who is a leader of the Graduate Student Association on Riverside, said, "The crucial problem with such an increase has to do with maintaining access to university education in California, particularly for lower- and middle-income groups."
The most sobering fact facing the university is that the Governor's budget cuts were based on the optimistic assumption that the economy would remain flat for the first half of this year and rebound by mid-year. Should that assumption prove wrong, all state agencies and schools could face still deeper cuts.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: ISRAEL;
Israeli Tension Eases a Bit, as New U.S. Help Arrives

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Jan. 20

 BODY:
After a welcome quiet night, the Israeli Government began trying today to move the nation out of its state of siege, while warning that more Iraqi missile attacks probably still lie ahead.
The Government also worked at another difficult task. It tried to reconcile the conflicting goals of deferring any retaliation against Iraq in deference to American concerns while also projecting the nation's strong, brash image to its enemies abroad. 
 Behind all this, and apparently helping at both tasks, Israel found itself increasingly falling under the political and military protection of the United States.
The Government and news reports made a great show out of the largescale United States emergency airlift overnight that delivered two Patriot missile batteries complete with American military crews, for defense against Iraqi missiles.
Forty C-5A Galaxy transport planes landed at Ben-Gurion International Airport, complete with American crews, and Israeli television showed extensive footage of American soldiers, in helmets and uniforms, unloading the equipment.
"The Patriot missile systems have arrived, they have been deployed and they are operational," Col. Raanan Gissen declared at a news briefing. Several officials said the missiles would be helpful against a future missile attack, though no one here thinks they will solve the problem.
President Bush called Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir twice, on Friday and Saturday; during most of last year the two men did not speak to each other at all. And tonight Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger arrived in Jerusalem for consultations with Mr. Shamir and other officials.
"The arrival of the Patriots and the special American delegation coming to coordinate with us, all these things demonstrate a very big improvement in relations with the United States," said Avi Pazner, a senior aide to Mr. Shamir.
The state of emergency that has been in place since Thursday was lifted this morning for the southern third of the country, which has not been a target for any of the 12 Iraqi Scud missiles that fell here on Friday and Saturday mornings.
 
Still Advised to Stay Home
 And even in Jerusalem, Tel Aviv and the rest of the country, where people were still advised to stay at home, near their gas masks and safe rooms, many people at least stuck their heads out of doors for the first time in five days.
As he stepped out of a Cabinet meeting this morning, the first since the nation came under attack, Health Minister Ehud Olmert said: "We're trying to quickly resume a normal life style again. The Government has decided that this is the purpose."
But at the same time, all the ministers arrived for the Cabinet meeting with gas masks in hand, and Mr. Olmert added: "The threat of missiles fired at Israel has not been eliminated. It's still liable to happen." Other officials said they would not be surprised if another attack came tonight.
Schools remain closed nationwide today, and most workers and businessmen stayed home too.
While President Saddam Hussein's attacks have been no threat to the security of the state, they have shaken its people to the core.
Even with no alerts Saturday night, people everywhere said they lay awake, waiting for the sirens to go off again. One senior Government official said, "Every time someone started his car, I was sure it was another alarm."
A Jerusalem mother said she'd been afraid to take a shower until today, worried that the sirens would sound. And everywhere today, Israelis continued to carry their gas masks with them, even for walks to the corner grocery.
 
'Have to Live Normal Lives"
 "We have to live normal lives so that our enemies won't think that by attacking us they are defeating us," Mr. Shamir insisted in an interview, broadcast nationwide tonight. The atmosphere of fear is destroying the economy, he added, and then he pointed to the British performance during the Nazi bombing in World War II as an example "where people lived with situations like this."
The Israeli Government has decided not to strike back at Iraq, at least for now, despite a longstanding policy of swift, lethal retaliation for any attack. Privately, officials said the debate had turned on the question: What does Saddam Hussein want us to do?
"And the answer seemed to be: He wants us to retaliate and break up the coalition," a senior official said, referring to the American-led forces facing Iraq.
As Yossi Ben Aharon, the Prime Minister's chief of staff, explained it: "Restraint is not always negative. It all depends on your capacity, your intentions and your potential for achieving your goals in a confrontation. At this time, the United States and its coalition partners are pouring hundreds, if not thousands, of tons of bombs and missiles on Iraq."
At the same time, the Defense Ministry issued a statement declaring: "The position of the Israeli Government has not changed. Israel reserves its right to decide how and when to respond to the Iraqi attacks."
