HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: IRAQ;
IRAQI SAYS ALLIES FACE HARDER WAR

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 20

 BODY:
President Saddam Hussein of Iraq sought to rally Arab supporters and embattled Iraqis today, saying his forces had used only a fraction of their weaponry to fight and win what he again called "the mother of all battles."
News reports from Baghdad depicted Iraqis scavenging for food, lining up for gasoline and drawing water from the Tigris river. But travelers from the besieged Iraqi capital reported no sign of public readiness to challenge the Iraqi leader's stewardship of the war, despite disillusion and disquiet. 
 In a seven-minute address on the Baghdad Radio -- his second since the outbreak of the Persian Gulf war -- the Iraqi leader forecast a long battle and renewed calls for a holy war around the world against forces "of evil, treason and corruption everywhere."
 
Barrages of Missiles
 Not long after the address, the Iraqis launched repeated barrages of Scud missiles toward Saudi Arabia.
And a Cable News Network reporter in Baghdad, Peter Arnett, said the Iraqi television carried a live broadcast showing seven men indentified as captured allied pilots. Mr. Arnett said that the men -- three Americans, two Britons, an Italian and a Kuwaiti -- were interviewed and that some of them criticized the allied air strikes on Iraq. It was not known whether the statements were coerced.
Mr. Hussein's military speech, his missile strikes at Saudi Arabia and the broadcast of the prisoners' interrogation contributed to his effort to keep morale from flagging in the face of the intense and ceaseless allied bombardment.
 
Holding Aircraft in Reserve
 And the Iraqi leader's military assessment came at around the same time that Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the commander of American forces in the Persian Gulf, said on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" and said President Hussein may be seeking to husband his air power for use later in the war.
The Iraqi leader, seeking support both within his own country and among Palestinians and other Arabs who call him their champion, said Iraq's "ground forces have not entered the battle so far, and only a small part of our air force has been used." Western assessments, too, say that only a small proportion of Iraq's estimated 700 combat aircraft have been destroyed, and that the rest are being hidden in bunkers.
"The army's air force has not been used, nor has the navy," the Iraqi leader said.
 
'The Scale of Death'
 "When the war is fought in a comprehensive manner, using all resources and weapons, the scale of death and the number of dead will, God willing, rise among the ranks of atheism, injustice, and tyranny," he added.
"When they begin to die and when the message of the Iraqi soldiers reaches the farthest corner of the world, the unjust will die and the 'God is Great' banner will flutter with great victory in the mother of all battles," he declared. "God is Great," is Islam's central incantation and rallying cry. President Hussein has ordered it inscribed on the Iraq national flag.
His comments seemed intended specifically to respond to questioning among Iraqis about the absence of strong defenses against waves of allied bombing and missile attacks.
The question of the morale of those Iraqis remaining in the city, has become more pressing since the allied onslaught seems partly intended to convince the country's 17 million people that their leader is powerless to defend them.
 
Party Headquarters a Target
 According to Western news reports, one target of the United States and other Western attacks has been the headquarters of the Baath Party, the ubiquitous organ of state power that President Hussein and his associates have molded from a clandestine, secretive body to a powerful and feared sinew of control.
Baghdad Radio reported today that an allied missile had struck the town of Tikrit, President Hussein's birthplace north of Baghdad, suggesting that part of the allied intention was a psychological campaign to crack the military's will to fight on. The Radio listed a total of 10 allied air and missile attacks in places ranging from Baghdad to the far north of the country.
Such efforts have drawn sharp responses from Iraqi officials. "We are confident of victory," Information Minister Latif Nasif al-Jassem told a British television interviewer before most Western journalists were ordered out of Iraq yesterday. "We can say with all confidence and all faith and all belief in God and in our great leader Saddam Hussein that the battle was settled in our favor with the help of God."
 
Tomahawk Shot Down
 The only non-Iraqi correspondent of a major new network known to be still sending reports from Baghdad, Mr. Arnett of CNN, stayed on despite yesterday's order and is working under Iraqi censorship. In a voice report today, he gave a vivid account of the Iraqi downing of a Tomahawk cruise missile -- the first confirmed destruction of one of the weapons that has played a decisive role in the allied war effort.
Mr. Arnett said parts of the exploded missile landed in the grounds of the Rashid hotel, across the Tigris from central Baghdad, sending a blast through the hotel and blowing in windows.
The downing of the missile followed a Baghdad Radio commentary belittling the cruise missiles. The allies, the commentary said, had "found out that the cruise missiles, with which they have terrified the world, are more cowardly than all their cowards and their treacherous cowardly weapons."
The commentary praised as "clever hunters" Iraq's anti-aircraft gunners who, according to the Iraqi Radio, have down over 150 allied aircraft. The United States and other allied air forces say they have lost 15 planes.
Iraq, too, has focussed in recent days on assertions that Israel had become embroiled in the war -- despite allied assertions to the contrary -- by firing missiles at an Iraqi base and by deploying aircraft, disguised as allied warplanes, from Turkey and Saudi Arabia.
 
'The Zionist Enemy'
 "We have proof that the Zionist enemy has used its aircraft from the lands which American and its allies have used against our people, including Saudi territory," Baghdad Radio said.
The target of such assertions is not only the people of Iraq. As Baghdad has sought to drawn Israel into the hostilities through missile strikes on Tel Aviv, it has also sought to cement a constituency among Palestinians exhilarated by the first Arab missile attacks on an Israeli city.
More than one half of Jordan's population is of Palestinian descent, so passions here vacillated dramatically between initial anger and gloom at the start of the war to exuberance at the missile strikes on Tel Aviv.
Random conversations in stores and on the streets here today indicated that many Palestinians and some Jordanians believed that the Iraqi version far more than the Western version of events. "There was some disappointment that Iraq did not send missiles into Israel for a third night running," said Jalal Ayub, a 55-year-old store-keeper. "But we know that Iraq is just holding its forces in reserve. We know Israel is in the war."
 
Smoke and Fire Over City
 Sentiment within Baghdad is more difficult to gauge. A Reuter despatch today by Maamoun Youssef, an Iraqi correspondent, said a huge fire lit up large areas of the city overnight and heavy column of smoke hung over the capital at dawn.
The report said meat and other food had rotted in freezers because of power-outs and cats and dogs were feeding on the resultant piles of garbage. Bread and water were both scarce, the report said, but quoted an official as saying morale was high.
It said Baghdad residents near the Tigris that flows through the city had been seen scooping water in plastic containers, while Government offices, shops, bakeries and restaurants were closed.
The report said hundreds of motorists were lining up for gasoline at the few remaining filling stations able to operate without electric power, presumably from hand-pumps. Another despatch, however, suggested that some of the controls of the rigidly policed land were beginning to slip.
It noted that Iraqis -- long fearful of even the traffic police -- had taken to running red lights and driving the wrong way on one-way streets, offenses that once carried heavy punishment. A currency black market is flourishing openly, despite the long prison terms associated with economic crimes.

HEADLINE: After 303 Years, Sunday Is a Workday at Lloyd's

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
David Peachey, an aviation underwriter, did not seem to care much that he was helping to make history at the Lloyd's of London insurance market today, which was open for the first Sunday in its 303 years.
What he did care about were reports that Iraq might fire missiles at Turkey in retaliation for Turkey's allowing coalition warplanes to launch attacks from its air bases. The disclosure about the bases has caused insurance rates for commercial planes flying to Turkish regions near Iraq to double since late last week; for each landing, the carrier must pay about a quarter of a percent of the plane's value. In normal times, the rate for commercial planes is five-hundredths of a percent of the plane's value a year. 
 Nor was Christopher W. Rome, a marine underwriter at Lloyd's, preoccupied with the break from Lloyd's tradition. He seemed to be jolted by pictures of coalition minesweepers dealing with a mine in the Persian Gulf. "The greatest threat I see are floating mines," he said, adding, "It's absolutely inevitable that ships will be blown up by mines before long."
Mr. Rome had just agreed to provide $50 million in excess liability insurance for an American oil tanker en route to Ras Tanura, a Saudi Arabian port in the gulf about 160 miles south of Kuwait. His charge for seven days of coverage was $156,250. "That is three times what it would have been 10 days ago, but there was no fighting 10 days ago," he said.
 
Saturday Work, Too
 That policy covers liability for harm to the ship's crew and cargo, the pollution that might occur if the ship were hit and the cost of removing the wreck.
Rates for other coverage have been soaring, too. Hull rates -- or insurance for the ship itself -- have gone up to as much as 5 percent of the ship's value for vessels bound for ports like Ras Tanura. Mr. Rome was charging 3 percent on Jan. 15, shortly before the outbreak of war, which began in the early hours of Thursday.
Excluding the reporters who flocked to Lloyd's building on Lime Street to record a bit of history, there were about 150 people, including about 100 underwriters, working today. About the same number put in a busier day Saturday, the first Saturday Lloyd's has been open since 1965, after Hurricane Betsy struck the New Orleans area. There are as many as 4,000 people at Lloyd's on weekdays.
With the war zone widening, fears of terrorism rising and information about the coalition's progress in blunting Iraq's military capability still sketchy, many underwriters are quoting rates only 24 hours in advance -- explaining why they were working during the weekend.
"I'm surprised how many ships, particularly tankers, have continued to go into the gulf to Saudi oil ports," said Stephen Merrett, an underwriter and chairman of the Lloyd's marine underwriters association. He said there were "several hundred" ships in the gulf, including merchant ships carrying supplies for the coalition forces.
 
Saudi Port Traffic
 Not all of those ships are privately insured. In a war, some governments typically offer war-risk coverage for most or all of the value of their flag ships.
The United States insures at its own expense merchant ships of any flag that are have been contracted by the Defense Department to carry military cargo. The Government can also offer war-risk insurance at a rate below that available from the commercial market for merchant ships of any flag that are serving the economic or defensive interests of the United States. On Saturday, the Maritime Administration decided to offer such coverage, and so far has had requests from owners of more than half a dozen ships.
As an indicator of shipping activity in the gulf, Lloyd's offered some information on the number of merchant ships calling at two main Saudi ports: Ras Tanura and Jubail, which is about 130 miles from Kuwait. There were 42 ships bound for Jubail and 7 ships docked or about to dock, a slight drop from the respective figures of 43 and 12 on Jan. 15.
There were 38 vessels bound for Ras Tanura and 9 at the port, compared with 31 and 13 respectively on Jan. 15, Lloyd's said.
 
Queries on Offshore Platforms
 Several underwriters said there was a surge of interest in coverage against terrorist attacks. Mr. Rome said he had received a number of inquiries over the weekend from oil companies that had not previously had terrorism coverage for offshore platforms outside the gulf. He also had a similar query from a utility in California.
Despite terrorist threats to attack airports at Western cities and a warning that a terrorist attack might be imminent in Bangkok, Thailand, several Lloyd's underwriters said they had not raised their rates for planes flying to those places. But Mr. Peachey made it clear that rates could soar at the first sign that the threats might be realized.
"We haven't panicked," he said. "Rates are carrying on as they were. But they are being constantly reviewed."
Alan Lord, deputy chairman of Lloyd's, said that, depending on demand, Lloyd's might be open next weekend, too. He pointed out that one person who would be horrified at the notion of conducting business on Sunday was Edward Lloyd, the proprietor of the coffee shop where ship owners and individuals willing to insure their ships and cargoes met three centuries ago. "He was a church warden," Mr. Lord said.

HEADLINE: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: LATVIA;
SOVIET COMMANDOS STAGE LATVIA RAID; AT LEAST 5 KILLED

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Monday, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Soldiers from a special unit of the Soviet Interior Ministry gunned their way into a Latvian government ministry building on Sunday night, then left early this morning, according to reports from Riga, the Latvian capital. At least five people were reported to have been killed.
Officials and witnesses said 50 to 100 soldiers of the O.M.O.N., a special forces unit known as the black berets, had attacked the lightly guarded and nearly vacant Latvian Interior Ministry at about 9 P.M. They fired a fusillade of tracer bullets and after a 90-minute gun battle occupied the five-story building. 
 The building was then surrounded by police loyal to the Latvian government, which is seeking independence from Moscow. The black berets, who oppose independence, left at about 3 A.M. today.
 
Five Are Reported Killed
 Spokesmen for the republic's Parliament said five people had been killed, one of them a Latvian journalist, and nine had been wounded. Reports from Riga said crowds of angry Latvians had gathered along Freedom Street after the shootout, but there were no reports of further clashes.
The raid came a week after an attack by Soviet Army troops against the nationalist government of Lithuania, in which 15 people were killed. More than 100,000 people marched to the Kremlin on Sunday to denounce that bloodshed and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's increasingly hard line. [Page A13.]
Reuters quoted the Latvian Deputy Interior Minister, Zenon Indrikov, as saying that only about 15 people had been on duty in his ministry's building, and that resistance had proved useless. The black berets were reportedly armed with automatic weapons.
The Interior Ministry, which is responsible for the republic's police, reportedly had not been barricaded by supporters of the government, as the Parliament and the Council of Ministers had been after the attack by the Soviet Army a week ago on the communications center in the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius. The army was not engaged in the action today in Riga, where neither the communications nor Parliament building was attacked.
Officials in Moscow made no immediate comment on the incident. The Latvian radio said the republic's Prime Minister, Ivars Godmanis, who led the Popular Front that ousted the Communist government in elections last year, had called to demand an explanation from Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov, but that Mr. Yazov had denied any knowledge of the attack.
After the attack in Vilnius, President Gorbachev denied any advance knowledge of the assault, but he endorsed the action of the troops. Mr. Gorbachev has also left no doubt of his impatience with the drive to independence in the three Baltic republics, which he has assailed recently in sharp statements.
 
Kremlin's Role Is Unclear
 The latest assault raised initial fears that Soviet Army troops had decided to move against the separatist Latvian government as they did a week ago when tanks were used in Lithuania. But Latvian officials said Sunday's attack seemed to be limited to the black berets and was not the feared assault by by the regular army.
The degree of Moscow's complicity in the Riga attack is unclear. The black berets, an elite unit of about 150 men, have refused to acknowledge the authority of the elected, separatist Latvian government. Earlier this month, in an operation sanctioned by Moscow, the government printing plant was seized by the black berets. They have also gone on shooting sprees in Riga, and on Jan. 16 they were accused of killing a government driver who was shot through the head in his car.
Such incidents have fueled the Soviet Government's assertions that the situation in Latvia is explosive, but there is no direct evidence that the latest attack by the black berets was guided or sanctioned by Soviet authorities in Riga or in Moscow. So far neither the Latvian nor the Soviet Government has made evident efforts to curb the unit. The new Interior Minister in Moscow, Boris K. Pugo, is the former first secretary of the Latvian Communist Party.
 
Pro-Moscow Group's Declaration
 The incident came the day after Tass published a statement by the "All-Latvian Committee of National Salvation," an anonymous, self-appointed body opposed to the independence sought by the elected government. The committee declared that it was taking over all state powers and dissolving the government.
The Latvian government rejected the statement and declared it invalid, but its publication raised fears that the Soviet authorities might be laying the groundwork for a crackdown. A similar declaration had served as the pretext for the military action in Vilnius.
Latvian officials noted that the Tass report of the Salvation Committee's declaration had been issued three days after it had been adopted in Riga. The delay was not explained, but the coincidence with the attack by the black berets added to the sense of menace.
The statement said that "ruling circles had brought Latvia to the brink of national catastrophe" and were leading the republic to a "bourgeois dictatorship" and "economic collapse." The committee said it was taking charge "for the time it takes to stabilize the situation." It concluded that "Soviet Latvia must remain in a renewed U.S.S.R."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Soldiers in a special unit of the Soviet Interior Ministry fired their way through the Latvian Interior Ministry yesterday, killing four people and injuring at least eight. Volunteers helping one of the injured. (Reuters)
 
Chart: 'Latvia at a Glance'
 
Vital Statistics
 
Capital: Riga
 
Area: 24,595 square miles
 
Population: 2,681,000
 
Agriculture: Principal products included grain, sugar beets, flax, potatoes, meat milk, vegetagbles and eggs.
 
Industry: Steel, paper, fiber, plastics, fertilizers, chemical electricity, garments, lumber.
 
History
 
Since the 13th century, Latvia has been ruled by Germans, Poles, Swedes and the Russian czars. Latvians proclaimed their independence in April 1918 after the October Revolution, winning recognition from the Soviet Union in 1920.
The republic was annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940 after a secret agreement between Stalin and Hitler. The annexation is not recognized by the United States.
Independent political organizations developed under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms, and the Communist Party split into pro-Moscow and pro-autonomy factions. Last May 4, the Latvian Parliament, elected in the first free balloting in the republic since it was annexed declared independence from Soviet rule. Mr. Gorbachev declared Latvia's independence moves illegal.

SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 979 words

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: THE ANTIWAR MOVEMENT;
NEWS FROM FRONT BLUNTS PROTESTS

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Before the bombs began falling over Baghdad, David Pierce was a staunch opponent of military action in the Middle East. Now he feels that the United States has no choice but to keep fighting.
"A lot of people who were against fighting the war have switched sides," said Mr. Pierce, a 40-year-old carpenter from Takoma Park, Md. Despite his doubts, he came with his wife and two children to Saturday's antiwar demonstration near the White House. 
 Mr. Pierce said he went to clarify his own thinking and to show moral concern. "Things aren't as clear-cut to me anymore," he said, "but I just think now that we've started fighting, we have to stay the course."
Mr. Pierce's change of heart reflects a big obstacle facing the nation's budding antiwar movement. After picking up enormous momentum before the American attack on Iraq, the movement has been slowed by a number of forces, including the rally-round-the-flag spirit of a nation beginning a war.
 
Not a Video Game
 "It's a very difficult time," said Bonnie Garvin, spokeswoman for the National Campaign for Peace in the Middle East. Her organization is planning a demonstration here for next Saturday, which organizers hope will attract more than the 25,000 who showed up for the march on Saturday.
"When bombs are falling, there's a natural inclination of people to rally round the flag and not seem unpatriotic," she said. "And what we're seeing on television is just this Pac-Man game, as if it's just a clean little video game and there are no bodies being torn apart, no people dying."
If the antiwar movement is to catch hold, it will be because of people like Roger Quillen and his wife, Lynn. "We own our property, our own business and our home, but I'd give all my material possessions up in a minute if it would bring peace," said Mr. Quillen, a 48-year-old lobsterman and fish market owner from Charlestown, R.I., who joined the march on Saturday.
 
Seeking a 'Smarter Way'
 People like Paul Foley, a 35-year-old department store worker from Boston, Emile Gourieux, a 19-year-old student from Bowling Green, Ky., and Patience O'Connor a 43-year-old planner and real estate developer from Washington, came to the protest with a deep fear that the war is a moral calamity.
"I just think there's a smarter way to do this; we're looking at so much blood being shed," Ms. O'Connor said. "What we're doing is deflecting all our energy away from problems at home."
Such concerns are widespread. Before the conflict, polls showed the nation deeply divided on whether to fight and confused about the reason for war. But the beginning of fighting has produced a strong surge of support for the war and for President Bush.
A New York Times/CBS News Poll of 908 adults interviewed Saturday found that 74 percent of the respondents approved of the war effort and 82 percent approved of the way Mr. Bush was handling his job. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
 
If the War Drags On?
 Antiwar organizers say such a pro-war surge is common and will dissipate if the war drags on, and if the high-tech air war is replaced by a bloody ground war with higher casualties.
Already the movement is split, with the coalition that sponsored Saturday's march representing the more radical edge. Its organizers call for an immediate withdrawal of American troops from the Middle East, the removal of American bases from the region and an Arab solution to Iraq's takeover of Kuwait.
The National Campaign for Peace in the Middle East was formed in response to fears that the coalition leaned too far to the left.
There was no ideological uniformity at Saturday's rally, and no consensus. Some protesters called for an immediate withdrawal of American troops. More common were calls for a cease-fire, and negotiations or renewed reliance on economic sanctions.
 
United on Fundamentals?
 Opponents of the war say that their differences reflect diversity rather than fundamental division and that the peace movement has a far more broad-based grounding than the protests against the Vietnam War in the 60's and 70's.
In fact, the movement has already seen local protests, participation from veterans and families of servicemen and mainstream support in a way rarely seen in the Vietnam protests.
An example is the Piedmont Peace Project in Kannapolis, N.C., made up of about 500 cotton mill workers, farmers, truck drivers and other workers. Some, like Oneil Russ, a 55-year-old meat inspector and veteran, have children in the gulf.
Members say the war offers nothing for working-class people. Linda Stout, the group's director, said: "We constantly remind people we're proud of our folks in the military. But at the same time, they didn't join to fight a war for oil profits."
Antiwar protests have cropped up not just at universities with a history of protest activity but also at places like the University of Montana, where 20 protesters disrupted a nationally broadcast basketball game Thursday night by lying on the court.
But Ms. Stout and Ms. Garvin agree that even among working people skeptical of the war there is a deep cultural divide with the most prominent elements of the antiwar movement.
 
Disgust With Flag Burning
 And a groundswell of pro-war rallies and angry comments on radio talk shows and in letters to newspapers indicate that the harsh views toward antiwar protest that marked the Vietnam era may be as strong now.
Still, antiwar activists say their movement has reached a level that took years to develop in the Vietnam era. Supporters say that, once the costs at home and abroad become clear, deep doubts will resurface. "My brother is on his way over there, and he completely supports what I'm doing," said Jeanne K. Whalen, who was carrying a sign reading "Love Our Troops -- Hate the War."

Paul Gourieux traveled from Bowling Green, Ky., to express his sentiments. (Lisa Berg for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
High Tech and Spirits at Rio Rock Festival

BYLINE: By JON PARELES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Rock festivals have entered the computer age with Rock in Rio II, the 10-day, nine-concert series that opened on Friday night here at Maracana Stadium.
An enthusiastic audience of 100,000 people ready to dance, sing, shout, wave their arms or light matches on cue was dazzled by patterns of green laser light and bathed in computer-controlled spotlighting. Giant video images of the stage show appeared as the performers stage blasted songs to a sound system with remarkable punch and sonic detail. When performers spoke from the stage in English, subtitles in Portuguese appeared on the video screens; Prince would shout, "All night long!" and a few moments later "Anoite toda!" would appear on screen. For electronic excellence, Rock in Rio II may be unsurpassed. 
 In the record books, Rock in Rio II will fall just short of its predecessor, which in 10 days in 1985 built up the largest attendance ever at a rock festival. About 100,000 people attended opening night of Rock in Rio II on Friday, 50,000 short of the sellout that would have helped break the record. Yet it was hard to imagine how more people could have been squeezed onto the soccer field and into the stands. (Tonight's show, with Guns 'n' Roses headlining, was sold out in advance.)
Brazil is experiencing a recession, and ticket prices that are relatively low by United States standards -- about $10 to $30 for eight-hour shows -- seem expensive here. Since the outbreak of war in the Persian Gulf, filling stations here in Rio have been closing at 8 P.M. each day and all day Sunday to reduce consumption, limiting car travel. (Brazilians may find it more convenient to watch the festival on Globo TV, which is broadcasting it live; in the United States, MTV will have excerpts on Feb. 9.)
The festival has noted but not dwelled upon the war. At Saturday's concert, two audience members carried a sign that said, in English, "Make Love Not War -- Rock in Rio II," while antiwar leaflets were distributed outside the stadium.
Performers have expressed hopes for peace with little further comment, drawing cheers before the next love song or dance tune. "There's a war going on," Prince said onstage in Saturday's wee hours. "I don't know what's up, but I think we'd all be better off living for love." The reggae singer Jimmy Cliff, who opened the festival on Friday night, drew a roar of applause when he called on President Bush and Iraqi President Saddam Hussein not to create another Vietnam War as a convenient lead-in to his song "(No More) Vietnam."
On Saturday night, the Engineers From Hawaii, a band from Porto Alegre, Brazil, sang its biggest hit, about a young man who liked to sing Beatles and Rolling Stones songs and then died in Vietnam. A few songs earlier, the Engineers prefaced one song by saying that rains and mud slides in Rio de Janeiro in the few days before the concert had killed more people than the Gulf war.
Most concertgoers -- among them two sons of Brazil's president, Fernando Collor de Mello, and actors from Brazil's hugely popular television soap operas -- came to dance. Whenever a band picked up the tempo, whether it was Joe Cocker's version of "Unchain My Heart" or the Engineers' earnest folk-rock in Portuguese, tens of thousands of hands waved in the air, and bodies shimmied. Every chorus of a hit drew hearty sing-alongs. The enthusiasm has helped lackluster performers like Colin Hay, the former leader of Men at Work, and ignited better ones, like Santana, whose Latin rock moved to peak after peak.
Local touches make Rock in Rio II different from festivals in North America. Only in Brazil would intermission entertainment include scantily clad samba dancers performing alongside inflatable animals, the women's images blown up three stories high on the video screens, or a batucada band playing carnival music between sets to send the entire audience into motion. Vendors circulate with hot coffee and cold soft drinks , dancing as they hold their insulated carriers aloft.
Concertgoers received booklets of lyrics by the English-speaking performers, a promotional effort by a language school. Among the 60 concession stands built within the stadium for the festival are not only typical T-shirt and hot dog vendors, but a bookstore dedicated to rock biographies and a computer software outlet.
The festival has offered some glimpses of the younger generation of Brazilian rock bands, who have clearly grown up on American and British rock and MTV. Yet there are surprises. Supla, a bleached-blond Billy Idol imitator, at one point leaped and spun like a Brazilian capoeira dancer. And the Engineers From Hawaii, whose appearance recalls Loggins and Messina, mix echoes of Sting, the Who, Elton John and John Cougar Mellencamp in trimly crafted songs that clearly mean a lot to their audience, which sang along on nearly every one. The Engineers and Lazzo, a Brazilian reggae singer who joined Jimmy Cliff for one song, drew as much applause as the imported acts.
Prince, who has not toured the United States with his current band, played a set that was alternately explosive and self-indulgent as he worked to be ever more encyclopedic. Challenged, perhaps, by the success of M.C. Hammer, Prince's new band includes three dancers, one of whom raps (far more skillfully than M.C. Hammer); Prince also built a song on a tape-loop of James Brown, as rappers do.
His 90-minute set opened with a funk workout -- part Bo Diddley, part Parliament-Funkadelic, part James Brown -- that had Prince spinning and hip-swiveling in what he introduced as the latest dance craze, "the Horny Pony." But he broke the momentum with slow arena rock, heavy metal, pop and ballads ("Nothing Compares 2 U," sung by Rosie Jane Gaines with Prince on piano, losing parts of the crowd as 3 A.M. came and went. He also had a problem with the language barrier; the kind of exhortations that help turn Prince's North American concerts into call-and-response parties were lost on much of the audience, with subtitles arriving two beats too late.
In many ways, Rock in Rio II embraces current rock's least endearing trends. The sponsorship of multi-national corporations -- from Coca-Cola (which paid $3 million to place its logo everywhere), to the record companies that have postered Rio de Janeiro with advertisements, to MTV, which recently opened MTV Brazil -- threatens a worldwide homogenization of popular music. But when heavily promoted performers arrive at Rock in Rio II, they're likely to discover that the local audience is the festival's true star.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prince performing at Rock in Rio II, a 10-day music festival, at Maracana Stadium in Rio de Janeiro. (Marcelo Duek for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
National Dairy Board Drops DDB Needham

BYLINE: By KIM FOLTZ

 BODY:
The National Dairy Board has dropped DDB Needham, Chicago, as the agency for its cheese account. The board decided to consolidate the $20 million account, which had been handled by DDB Needham for more than three years, with other business handled by Grey Advertising, New York.
Grey has handled the $15 million ice cream and $11 million butter accounts since 1987. McCann Erickson, San Francisco, will continue to handle the client's milk and dairy food accounts, which have about $59 miilion in combined billings.
"After a review, we decided to make this move to increase efficiency," said Yvonne Dock, manager of public relations of organization, which is based in Arlington, Va. "While the comparison was close, Grey came out as more economical for us in terms of staff."
Executives from DDB Needham and Grey declined to comment on the switch.

HEADLINE: Mr. Bush Pours Oil on Troubled Traders

 BODY:
Mideast war is supposed to send oil prices skyward and oil-importing economies downward. But that's not what happened last week. Allied forces bombed Iraq and Kuwait -- and oil prices nosedived more than 30 percent, the biggest one-day drop in history. That caught oil companies flat-footed. Indeed, expecting prices to rise, they were promising to freeze prices as a gesture of good will against charges of profiteering.
The price drops were due in part to the stunning success of the early bombing raids, which convinced traders that Saudi oil fields would be safe. But another key factor was shrewd planning by the Bush Administration. A week earlier, it and other Western nations announced that, at the outbreak of war, they would jointly release two million barrels of oil a day from government stockpiles. Mr. Bush backed that pledge to the hilt by announcing as soon as the shooting started that the United States would release more than a million barrels a day from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, which contains 600 million barrels stored in underground salt caverns. 
 Oil prices respond to fear every bit as much as to supply cutbacks. Hoarding, not an OPEC embargo, created most of the gas lines during the 1970's. And hoarding, not insufficient supply, was driving oil prices higher as traders nervously approached the Jan. 15 deadline for Saddam Hussein's withdrawal from Kuwait. The fear dissolved only after the allies knocked out Iraq's capacity to cripple Saudi oil production and the U.S. pledged to release reserve oil.
Some energy brokers are now claiming foul. They say the Energy Department battered the oil market by promising to release oil from the reserve needlessly. But the facts show otherwise. Oil prices have merely returned to levels of two weeks earlier -- before panic gripped the market.
The Bush Administration suffered, and deserved, criticism for refusing to release reserve oil last summer, when Iraq invaded Kuwait. But now officials have finally put the reserve to good use.
The combination of encouraging war news and enlightened reserve policy has stripped oil prices of the fear factor, returning them to pre-August levels. That's not likely to please the oil companies, but it is wonderful news for the economy.

HEADLINE: Put Moscow in a Deep Freeze

BYLINE: By Orrin G. Hatch; Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, is a member of the Senate Intelligence Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Since U.S. economic aid and other manifestations of improving U.S.-Soviet relations have been based on continuing Soviet reform, President Bush needs to do more than reproach Mikhail Gorbachev.
After the Soviet use of force in Lithuania and, yesterday, Latvia, the U.S. should call off the planned summit meeting, and should terminate the $1 billion in agricultural credits and cancel the planned waiver of the Jackson-Vanik restrictions on most-favored-nation trade status. Mr. Bush should also foster direct ties with Soviet republics that hold genuinely free elections and adopt far-reaching market reforms. 
 While President Gorbachev and some Western leaders may reject explicit linkage of the Baltic question to other East-West issues, linkage exists as a political reality. Western public opinion, particularly U.S. Congressional opinion, will turn cold so long as Moscow tries to keep the Baltic states on a short leash.
Too often in debate about U.S. policy toward Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia, the issue has been framed as a choice between granting full diplomatic recognition to democratic governments or doing nothing -- a false dilemma. The U.S. should undertake diplomatic steps short of full recognition that would advance Baltic independence and increase in Moscow's calculus the international political costs of coercive policies.
First, the U.S. should adopt a Baltic relations act basically similar to the Taiwan Relations Act of 1979, which governs relations with Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic relations. The primary objective of the act would be to establish with each Baltic state unofficial diplomatic liaisons similar to the American Institute of Taiwan and its Taiwan counterpart in the U.S.
These institutes, nominally independent of the U.S. Government, would upgrade U.S.-Baltic relations and serve as the point of contact between the U.S. and Baltic leaders. They would facilitate the kinds of normal international transactions, such as political communication and cultural exchanges, that routinely take place with Taiwan. And they would seek to encourage economic investment in the Baltic states, particularly through the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, as market reform is adopted.
Second, the U.S. should sponsor the Baltic states as members of international economic groups, like the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. After all, GATT has juggled the competing claims of China, Taiwan and Hong Kong, and its charter accommodates membership by governments with less than full sovereignty.
The key GATT membership requirement is that a government control its economy. The Baltic states have that power under Moscow's Declaration of Baltic Economic Autonomy in 1989, and have taken substantial steps in wresting control of enterprises from Soviet ministries, as well as negotiating independent trade pacts with other Soviet republics.
In any forthcoming U.S.-Soviet economic pacts, the U.S. should insist on provisions that recognize the international legal standing of the Soviet republics and permit more liberal economic relations for reformist republics like the Baltic states than for the rest of the Soviet Union, particularly in the areas of technical assistance and foreign investment.
While Mr. Gorbachev and his central Government hesitate in adopting even half-baked market reforms, the Baltic countries have expressed unequivocally the intention of adopting full-fledged market reforms, including the restoration of private property and free-market prices.
He understands that the old system, based on coercion, stifles economic progress. A new system based on consent requires transformation of the country into a loose confederation, and acceptance of the inevitability that some republics, particularly the Baltic states, will choose to secede, even if they keep close economic and political ties with Moscow.
President Bush is now obliged to pursue policies that make Mr. Gorbachev understand that he faces a choice between an isolated Soviet Union mired in poverty and paralyzed by national hatreds and a new Soviet confederation that can join the community of nations and achieve prosperity commensurate with its great natural wealth.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Reacting to War
The U.S. is circulating to allies and businesses proposed restrictions on the export to third world-countries of chemical and biological material and missile technologies. The proposals reflect fear that nuclear and chemical weapons and missiles could proliferate -- a worry heightened by the prospect that Iraq may use poison gas in the Persian Gulf war. [Page D1.]
Europe's economy caught a cold in August when oil prices jumped after Iraq invaded Kuwait. A quick allied victory in the gulf war could help provide a cure. [D2.]
Lloyd's of London was open on Sunday for the first time 303 years. Insurance rates for planes and ships have soared, and many underwriters now make quotes only 24 hours in advance. [D4.]
The pace of business in America has slowed as the nation closely monitors war news. [D4.]
 
International
Canadians are grousing about a tax that adds 7 percent to the price of newspapers, haircuts, clothing and just about everything else they buy. On the U.S. side of the border, businesses are fretting about the tax's implications for trade with Canada. [D1.]
Top economic policy makers from the Group of Seven nations gathered in New York to review a variety of financial and monetary issues. But those matters are now overshadowed by war. [D1.]
Japanese and U.S. negotiators resume trade talks this week after an initial round that the Americans characterized as showing "steady incremental progress" on some issues but little forward movement on many others. [D2.]
 
The Economy
American banks are turning to Wall Street brokerages with increased frequency to help them attract new depositors by selling the banks' Federally insured certificates of deposit. [D1.]
Increasing numbers of Mexicans are coming to the U.S. to stay rather than to work for a few months as seasonal laborers. [A14.]
 
Companies
The shutting of Eastern Airlines is likely to benefit Delta and Pan Am in particular, because they have competed directly with Eastern's largest business, carrying passengers from the Northeast to Atlanta and Florida. [D1.]
 
The Media Business
CNN has basked in the glow of the world's praise for its war coverage. But the 24-hour news network's enhanced prestige may not translate into new advertising revenue. Ad Scene. [D1.]
While most big advertisers are reluctant to tie ads to the war, some media companies are not quite so shy. Kim Foltz: Advertising. [D7.]
The networks began to try to restore some normality -- and some revenue potential -- to their program schedules, after three days of chaotic and extremely costly news coverage. [D6.]
Advertising agencies on and beyond Madison Avenue are being swept by a back-to-basics movement that is manifesting itself in ads that are starker and speak more plainly. [D6.]
TV Guide will begin testing a larger version of its digest-sized magazine in March. [D6.]
 
Today's Columns
Some financial analysts are beginning to calculate the consequences of a long Middle Eastern war for the Federal budget deficit and the bond markets. Credit Markets. [D5.]
Military contractors have gotten a psychological lift from seeing many of their advanced products work as advertised in combat. But analysts generally agree that the war does not change the industry's fundamental outlook. Market Place. [D4.]

The chart at the top of the Business Digest yesterday summarizing market activity last week misstated the results in some editions. HEADLINE: Ba Liep Journal;
Family Braves a Cruel Sea and Just 2 Come Back

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BA LIEP, Vietnam, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Dang Chi Cuong came home today to his father's house in this little village in the Mekong Delta, eight months after he left by boat with his wife and two children.
"We met disaster on the sea," Mr. Cuong said simply as his 9-year-old son clung mournful and bewildered to his leg. Thai pirates intercepted their boat of 77 people, he said. They raped the women, including Mr. Cuong's wife, Le Thi Han, then tried to kill all witnesses. 
 Mr. Cuong's wife, 30, and their 6-year-old daughter, Dang Thi Bich Tuyen, were killed. Mr. Cuong and his son, Dang Ngoc Phuoc, jumped into the ocean and floated on bits of driftwood for four days until Thai fishermen rescued them. Of the 77 people on the boat that day, May 13, 1990, only 7 survived.
The fishermen, who were as kind as the pirates were barbarous, took the survivors to a Thai holding camp for Vietnamese boat people. Representatives of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees heard their story, Mr. Cuong said. As for Thai officials, "they were not interested."
Asked about his destiny, Mr. Cuong stared into the distance, holding his son's head to his hip. "I could not know what would happen," he said at last. "There was no way to know."
 
In the Wrong Army
 Mr. Cuong was wearing one of the nonsense-English T-shirts popular all over Asia. He bought his in Bangkok with some of the $50 bonus the United Nations High Commissioner provides each Vietnamese adult who agrees to return home. His shirt displays the British, French and American flags and reads: "Do! Family. Fun for every day in the year."
His father, Dang Van Mai, 56, fluttered his hands, upset by the commotion this homecoming had caused -- the official visitors, a foreigner, the gawking neighbors. Mr. Mai was a soldier for the wrong army, the South Vietnamese Army, and he gets no pension. "I knew what happened to him and his family," Mr. Mai said. "I was very sad to hear it."
Mr. Mai lives with his wife and three other children in a wretched, smoky hut of thatch in this poor village in Cuu Long Province, without electricity, down a long dirt road lined with rice paddies and cut by canals. Now, seven will live there.
Mr. Mai has no work; his wife, Nguyen Thi Sau, 53, does odd jobs, either in the rice paddies or in the houses of others, and is paid about 3,000 dong a day -- 44 cents at the official rate of exchange. "It was almost enough for us," Mr. Mai said. He did not know that his son would receive money from the United Nations for agreeing to return -- $30 a month for a year for himself, $15 a month for the boy. "He will need the money for his son," Mr. Mai said. "It's up to him to begin his life again."
Neighbors found Mrs. Sau to tell her that her son and grandson had returned home. Rice-stalk thin, she said next to nothing, and began to cry. Embarrassed, she wiped her tears away with the back of her hand and spoke softly to Phuoc, her grandson. He knelt in front of her, his face averted, picking at the knee of her black peasant trousers. She held his shoulders and whispered in his ear. "He misses his mother," she finally said.
Mr. Cuong said he had been working at his father-in-law's sugar mill. "But there was not enough money and my wife was often sick," he said. She wanted to go to a third country, to the United States, to get a better life."
They paid about $1,000 each for the passage, borrowing money. Some of his wife's cousins also went along, and also perished. What will he tell his wife's family?
"I will go to them and tell them exactly what happened," he said. Will he feel embarrassed before them? "I did not know what would happen on the sea," he said again. "I could not know."
 
Failure Is Expensive
 Many Vietnamese who leave by boat bear the hopes of their families. If they succeed in resettling, they can take over their direct relatives. Failure, however, is expensive and embarrassing. Mr. Cuong said he knew of such cases, but refused to say if his was similar. Mr. Mai said he had not known his son was leaving. A United Nations official said, "It is illegal to leave by boat, so they are afraid to speak of it."
Mr. Cuong said he did not know that by leaving in May 1990 he had missed a cutoff for Vietnamese boat people imposed by Southeast Asian countries in March 1989. Previously, all Vietnamese boat people were regarded as refugees and guaranteed resettlement; those arriving afterward are screened, and only those with a "well-founded fear of persecution" qualify as refugees. The others, economic migrants, who are making up about 85 to 90 percent of those screened, will have to return to Vietnam.
The United States has opposed involuntary repatriation, so the High Commissioner has tried to induce Vietnamese to agree to return. Mr. Cuong and his son are among 344 Vietnamese who have flown home from Thailand. So far, about 7,500 Vietnamese have returned voluntarily, 6,300 of them from Hong Kong. But more than 100,000 remain in the region's camps, and new arrivals are still running at about 2,500 a month.
Asked why he agreed to return, Mr. Cuong looked toward his son, still huddled with Mrs. Sau. "After my wife died, I didn't care any more," he said. "I wanted to come home."

HEADLINE: Careers;
Opportunities in Health Care Appear Good

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
RECESSION or not, health care is a growing industry offering good jobs.
James N. Heuerman, a partner of Korn/Ferry International, the management recruiting firm, stresses that the opportunities appear good even though health-care institutions are putting increased emphasis on holding down costs. His firm recently financed the latest in a series of studies called "Health Care Employment -- a Survey of Early Career Opportunities." It was done for the Association of University Programs in Health Administration, which has 1,500 university members.
"The studies come out every two years," he said. "If you look over the last three, you find a diversity of positions beginning to surface in health care." 
 Mr. Heuerman recalled that 20 years ago holders of master's degrees in health-care administration typically found jobs with 300-bed community hospitals. "It was one of the few industries where a relatively young person could walk into a vice presidency without starting as a number cruncher." he said.
Now, he said, many people with such degrees are joining health maintenance organizations, insurance companies, ambulatory-care organizations, consulting firms and long-term care facilities. "They start at $35,000 a year and work their way up," he said. "I think health care will continue to be a good opportunity."
Mr. Heuerman, who holds a master's in health-care administration from the University of Minnesota, said the industry should provide job stability despite the deepening recession.
Job opportunities are also expected to expand in health-related sidelines. For example, Joan Marks heads the graduate-level Health Advocacy Program at Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville, N.Y.
"It's a small program that began in 1980 but the only one of its type in the country," she said last week. "About 100 have completed it." Those who complete the 36 credit hours, plus an internship, receive a master of arts or master of professional studies degree. Their starting salaries are around $35,000.
"Health advocates serve as a liaison between patients and the institution," Ms. Marks said. "I think you could describe a health advocate as a neutral person to whom problems can be presented by the patient, whether it involves a doctor, nurse, social worker or hospital service. The health advocate provides a link to the appropriate service needed and is especially valuable at a time of nursing shortages."
Hospitals, always concerned about malpractice suits, want to know about patients' problems before they become unmanageable. As a result, she said, more and more hospitals are offering the service. "About 50 percent of the hospitals around the country have formal patient advocacy programs, with departments ranging from two persons to 13," Ms. Marks said. Among those with large staffs are Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York with 13, she said.
"It is an excellent career for the middle-aged," she added. "Some of our students are in their early 40's. The job requires maturity, perspective, ability to relate to people in distress, and all this comes more easily with age."
She has 22 students currently, and wants more.
At New York University's School of Continuing Education, Miriam Aaron is the coordinator of a new program that awards a Certificate in Worksite Wellness. Its graduates are trained to organize and manage fitness programs within companies; this might involve aerobics, sports, nutrition classes and advice on alcohol and drug abuse.
Explaining that the first class of 40 students started last fall, Ms. Aaron said that most wanted to enhance their skills in the health field. "Two women came to us from Consolidated Edison, where one is an occupational health nurse and the other in the training department," she said.
"Often companies underwrite the tuition," she added. "I think most of the students are exploring career changes. Some hospital nurses think about switching to jobs in industry."
As layoffs among New York City municipal workers increase, she expects more students who held city jobs to sign up for the next semester, which begins Feb. 4.
"Most students tend to be in their 30's and 40's," she said. "In the class of 20 that I teach there are 5 men."
Ms. Aaron said that many large companies, including Johnson & Johnson, had so-called wellness programs in place. "I think the growth will be in the increased recognition of the need for wellness programs by small employers," she said, explaining that small companies might hire outside companies to handle their programs.

HEADLINE: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: Europe;
European Nations Prepare to Impose Sanctions on Moscow

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Angered by continued Soviet military actions in the Baltic states, European Community and NATO governments are preparing to apply economic and other sanctions against Moscow after Sunday's violence in the Latvian capital of Riga, European officials said today.
The officials recalled that Moscow was warned after last week's killings in Lithuania that further repression in the Baltics would damage its relations with the West. Now, they said, the 12 community governments had no choice but to follow up their words with action. 
 The North Atlantic Treaty Organization, which joined the community in condemning the deaths of five people in Riga on Sunday, is also planning what American officials described as "a closely coordinated series of actions" to show disapproval of Moscow's hard-line policy in the Baltic states.
"We've tried using political persuasion and it hasn't worked," Denmark's Foreign Minister, Uffe Ellemann-Jensen, said. "Now we must use economic means."
 
Threat to Stability
 Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary, still formally allied with the Soviet Union through the now-moribund Warsaw Pact, also warned in a statement that Moscow's crackdown against the "legally elected governments" of the Baltic states could threaten stability throughout Central Europe.
So far, it is unclear what measures are to be adopted against Moscow. It is apparent, though, that Western governments are turning to sanctions reluctantly, not only because of the need to maintain Soviet support for the anti-Iraqi coalition, but also for fear of a return to the East-West tensions of cold war days.
Today, while condemning the killings in Riga, Germany and France made no reference to possible reprisals. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said Germany was interested "in the democratization process of the Soviet Union continuing." France urged Moscow to negotiate its differences with the Baltic states.
In contrast, Britain's Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said Soviet repression could jeopardize European aid programs. "The Soviet Union cannot expect to have the kind of friendship and cooperation which has been building in the last three or four years with the West if in the Baltic states it goes back to Stalinist tactics," he said.
 
Options for Response
 In planning its response, the European Community, which until recently was strongly backing President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's efforts to modernize the Soviet Union, has various options, the mildest of which might be suspension of a high-level meeting with Soviet trade officials scheduled for this week.
But it could also suspend a $550 million technical assistance agreement, a $680 million credit for Soviet food purchases and a 1989 trade and cooperation agreement aimed at stimulating Soviet trade and increasing scientific and technological exchanges.
Senior European officials said that, for humanitarian reasons, a separate $340 million emergency food aid program for the Soviet Union, which was approved by community leaders in Rome last month following appeals for help from Moscow, would not be affected.
United States officials said other sanctions could be announced by individual governments, but NATO itself may also adopt measures. These could include withdrawal of an invitation for President Gorbachev to visit NATO's Brussels headquarters this year and a reduction of military contacts with Moscow.

HEADLINE: Varian Net Climbs 63%

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 21

 BODY:
In the first sign that its turnaround efforts are paying off, Varian Associates Inc. today reported sharply higher first-quarter earnings. One of the pioneer Silicon Valley companies, Varian had been sluggish in recent years.
For the quarter that ended on Dec. 28, Varian had earnings of $12.4 million, or 64 cents a share, up 63 percent from $7.6 million, or 39 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago. Sales grew 10 percent, to $316.1 million, from $285.4 million in the first quarter of the 1990 fiscal year.
"The first-quarter earnings progress indicates that our drive to achieve better operating performance is now taking hold in all of our businesses," J. Tracy O'Rourke, Varian's chairman, said in a prepared statement. He said he was encouraged by continued strong orders, particularly in the current recession.
Three of Varian's four major businesses had double-digit gains in orders, led by semiconductor manufacturing equipment, at 26 percent.
Varian's stock jumped $2.375 a share today, to $35.75, a high for the year, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Drifts Lower As Focus Turns to Economy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar drifted lower in quiet trading yesterday as traders turned their attention from the Persian Gulf war to the weak United States economy.
Traders said this was the first time since war erupted last Wednesday that the currency market focused on the dollar's economic fundamentals instead of the currency's appeal as a safe holding in times of turmoil. 
 Trading was thin and wound down by early afternoon because of snow in the New York area and observance of the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday. Many banks were closed.
Currency analysts said it was difficult to single out factors behind the dollar's decline because relatively few traders could influence the direction of sparsely traded markets.
There were indications, though, that the market focused on the Government's expected release Friday of its report on the gross national product, a key economic indicator released every quarter.
"It's the first number we'll have really confirming the recession," said David Marshall, senior currency analyst for MMS International Inc.
Signs of economic weakness generally erode the dollar's value and prompt investors to seek currencies from countries with stronger economies.
Mr. Marshall said his firm was forecasting a 3.8 percent decline in the G.N.P. for the fourth quarter ending Dec. 31. That drop would be substantial enough to indicate another decline in the first quarter of 1991, he said.
The G.N.P. is the nation's total output of goods and services and the broadest measure of economic health.
Yesterday, the British pound strengthened in New York to $1.9615 from late Friday's $1.9513. In London earlier, sterling rose to $1.9535, from $1.9420 late Friday.
In New York, the dollar closed at 131.95 yen, down from Friday's 132.50 yen. Earlier, in Toyko, the dollar fell 0.82 yen, to a closing 132.75 yen, and in London, it was quoted at 132 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.4875 German marks, down from 1.4975; 1.2465 Swiss francs, down from 1.2560; 5.0565 French francs, down from 5.0930; 1,118.00 Italian lire, down from 1,126.50, and 1.1585 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1590.

HEADLINE: Cuomo's Staff Stays Largely Intact and in Shadow

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Perhaps the surest measure of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's concern about the state's fiscal condition is that he has allowed so little turnover in his staff at the beginning of his third term.
While campaigning for re-election last fall, Mr. Cuomo predicted that there would be many fresh faces in his administration and suggested that a new term would provide a natural transition point. 
 "There are people who I couldn't ask to do another four years," he said in September, stressing the financial and physical sacrifices of his staff.
But with the state facing the most severe budget crisis of Mr. Cuomo's tenure, the Governor has chosen to make only minor alterations in a team that he values for its experience.
 
Budget Battle Delays Departures
 He has persuaded some aides, including Gerald C. Crotty, his chief of staff, to stay at least until the end of this spring's grueling budget battle. Several commissioners who were rumored to be job-hunting have yet to leave and only two top aides from the Governor's central staff have left.
The aides who have departed -- Evan A. Davis, the Governor's legal counsel, and Gary G. Fryer, who held the titles of press secretary and counselor -- have been replaced with loyal insiders who did not require on-the-job training while the state's budget gap was expanding.
Mr. Davis was succeeded by Elizabeth D. Moore, who had directed Mr. Cuomo's Office of Employee Relations. She is the first black adviser in the upper echelon of Mr. Cuomo's staff.
Mr. Fryer's responsibilities were divided between Andrew J. Zambelli, who was promoted from senior deputy secretary to counselor and director of communications, and Anne W. Crowley, who became press secretary after serving as Mr. Fryer's deputy.
 
Originally Thought Middleweight
 Mr. Cuomo's central staff was much maligned when he first took office eight years ago. Reviewers dismissed it as decidedly middleweight -- lacking in big names, overly dominated by white men, and top-heavy with holdovers from the administration of Mr. Cuomo's predecessor, Gov. Hugh L. Carey.
Although some of those traits persist, the staff is credited for fitting well with Mr. Cuomo's hands-on management and for running an efficient, if not always inspired, operation. And Ms. Moore's appointment has alleviated what Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine said was "concern that we would sit down at the table and it would just be white males."
Assembly Speaker Mel Miller said his opinion of the Cuomo staff had improved. "With the Governor, who is incredibly hands-on, the staff gets less prominence," he said. "But it doesn't mean the staff is dumber or less capable. Someone who needs more prominence isn't going to last."
Mr. Cuomo argues that his decision to not disrupt his staff at such a sensitive time will keep his administration focused on the state's budget problems.
 
Critics Cite Lack of Vision
 But some lobbyists and legislative aides, while praising the staff's competence and dedication, warn that the dearth of new blood could worsen what they see as the administration's major shortcoming -- its lack of inventiveness. Several cited Mr. Cuomo's State of the State speech, which they complained lacked priorities and focus, as a recent sign of staleness.
"I give them high marks for access," said one lobbyist. "I give them high marks for attentiveness. I give them high marks for good intentions. I don't know whether I'd always give them high marks for vision."
If conservatism sometimes prevents Mr. Cuomo from realizing his full political potential, his aides think it has protected the Governor from rash decisions and poorly considered strategy.
In his early days as Governor, Mr. Cuomo was fond of comparing his staff's organizational chart to "the spokes of a wheel." The Governor regularly reaches out to a central staff of 14 people, while frequently consulting with lower-ranking aides, the directors of state agencies and a broad array of informal advisers outside Albany.
 
The Hub of the Wheel
 With Mr. Crotty, whose title is secretary to the Governor, the central staff comprises Mr. Lundine; Henrik N. Dullea, the director of state operations; Ms. Moore; Mr. Zambelli; Ms. Crowley; Vincent Tese, the director of economic development; Fabian G. Palomino, the special counsel; Dall W. Forsythe, the budget director; Mary Ann Crotty, the deputy director of state operations; Michael J. Dowling, the deputy secretary for human services; Francis J. Murray Jr., the deputy secretary for energy and environmental affairs; John J. Poklemba, the director of criminal justice, and Brad C. Johnson, the director of the state's Washington office.
Their salaries range from $98,399 for Mr. Crotty to $76,444 for Ms. Crowley. Mr. Palomino has drawn no salary as special counsel since last week, when he was named president of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, where his salary is $125,000.
The "spokes of the wheel" system contrasted with the more detached style of Mr. Carey, whose chief of staff, Robert J. Morgado, served as a strict gatekeeper to the Governor's office.
Because Mr. Cuomo reclaimed many of Mr. Morgado's responsibilities, and because the Governor does much of his own talking, Mr. Crotty and his colleagues rarely break into public view.
 
Underrated Chief of Staff
 That low visibility has made Mr. Crotty an underrated chief of staff, legislative negotiators and lobbyists say. By designating Mr. Crotty as his top trouble-shooter, Mr. Cuomo has placed increasing confidence in him, and Mr. Crotty's subordinates universally praise his calmness under pressure and his reasoned, nonideological approach to problem-solving.
But legislative leaders also point out that Mr. Crotty and his colleagues have not always had the authority that others have had in previous administrations. Mr. Cuomo's desire to do much of his own negotiating sometimes slows the wheels of government, they say.
"You don't always know if the staff sign-off is the real sign-off," said Mr. Miller, the Assembly Speaker. "And when a principal digs in and his position becomes public, it takes months to dig out."
If there has been a key to the staying power of the Cuomo staff, it has been the Governor's ability to minimize infighting by extending his reach past a small inner circle.
 
Access and Morale High
 "Because they are all so integrated into the process, there is less reason for their being suspicious of one another," Mr. Cuomo said. "You only get backbiting when you have fiefdoms and individuals who are isolated."
And by granting so much access to so many staff members, Mr. Cuomo has kept morale high. "There's no question that I work 20 hours a week more because of it," said Gene B. Sperling, a speechwriter and political aide who joined the staff last February.
Like Mr. Cuomo, whose only "vacation" in eight years was spent reading at the Executive Mansion, the Governor's staff works torturous hours. The average day often begins with a phone call from Mr. Cuomo at 6:30 A.M. and ends with one after midnight.
"The Governor has a tendency to overwhelm and overshadow everything around him," said Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation and a frequent Cuomo adviser. "His staff suffers a bit because they're in the shadow of this very powerful light. But they have neither the desire nor the ability to compete with him."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Securities Mixed in Light Day

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in thin trading yesterday in a session that would not have taken place but for the war in the Persian Gulf.
Before the fighting began in the gulf, participants in the Government securities market had planned to take the day off in observance of the Martin Luther King Jr. Birthday. 
 Even though the market was open, most investment houses had only skeleton crews at their trading desks. And the traders that did show up for work were informed around midday by the Public Securities Association, a trade group, that activity would stop at 1 P.M. because of a snowstorm in New York.
An article published yesterday in The Independent, a British daily, saying that Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, had proposed a coordinated reduction in global interest rates to representatives of the world's seven leading industrialized nations at a meeting in New York helped to push down short-term interest rates somewhat.
Meanwhile, developments over the weekend, including Iraqi missile attacks on Israel and Saudi Arabia, made clearer the possibility that the war in the gulf could be a drawn-out affair, a realization that persuaded traders to sell bonds.
Analysts said the report in The Independent probably said more about the Fed's intentions over the near to medium term than about those of other central banks.
"It seems more likely that Greenspan was signifying that the United States has more easing to do over the next three to six months," said Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and economist at S.G. Warburg & Company.
"I don't see the Germans agreeing to lower their interest rates, and if the Germans can't do it, most of the European countries can't do it either."
Because of the holiday, the Fed was closed yesterday. So too were most major banks.
At the close of trading in the secondary market for Treasury securities, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 106, down 15/32, to yield 8.20 percent, up from 8.17 percent late Friday.
 
Treasury Note Issues
 Among Treasury note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 103 1/8, down 1/8 point, to yield 8.03 percent. And the 7 1/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 9/ 32, up 2/32, to yield 7.08 percent.
Rates on short-term Treasury bills fell slightly.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 6.03 percent, down four basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates dipped by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 6.15 percent.
The weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills, normally held on Mondays, was postponed until today because of the holiday.
In addition to the bill auctions, later this week traders will be asked to bid at auctions of more than $21 billion worth of new two-year and five-year notes.
"We will be a supply-dominated market for the next few days unless something happens in the Middle East," one government securities trader said. "Because there is so much uncertainty in the Persian Gulf, that will make this a difficult period for the market."
Activity in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and tax-exempt municipal securities was nearly nonexistent, traders said.
As a consequence, prices of most issues in both markets were essentially unchanged on the day.

HEADLINE: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: Washington;
Bush Appeals to Kremlin Leaders To Refrain From Force in Baltics

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
President Bush said today that he was increasingly concerned about violent repression of nationalist independence movements in the Baltic republics by the Soviet authorities.
"I would again appeal to the Soviet Union leaders to resist using force," Mr. Bush said at an impromptu meeting with reporters on his return from a weekend at Camp David to the White House. He was referring to reports of killings on Sunday in Riga, the Latvian capital, by elite troops from a Soviet Interior Ministry unit. 
 Last week he appealed directly to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to put a stop to the use of force in the Baltic capitals after an attack by Soviet soldiers on the nationalist government of Lithuania that also caused deaths.
 
Sanctions Under Consideration
 At a White House briefing, Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman, said the Administration, along with Western allied governments, was considering "sanctions and other kinds of measures" against the Soviet Union as a means of underscoring its concerns although he said that "no decisions have been made."
He was speaking of a meeting of 15 ambassadors of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization earlier in the day in Brussels, where punitive steps against Moscow were discussed.
Administration officials said the latest incidents added to their skepticism about holding to plans for Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev to meet a little more than three weeks from now. Last week, Administration officials said the summit meeting was "up in the air."
This afternoon, a State Department official noted that the Administration had called the Soviet Embassy on Sunday to express "our great concern" about the shootings in Riga but had received no response. The official said, "We are seeking to maintain U.S. officials in all three capitals on a virtually continuous basis" to gather information and convey American concerns in the Baltic republics. He said the policy was to "promote a peaceful process to resolve the disputes."
These remarks were made against a background of mounting demands from Congress for concrete actions against Moscow, including stopping the planned extension of trade benefits and agricultural credits.
 
Personal Ties to Gorbachev
 The Bush Administration, like the Reagan Administration before it, has tended to base its overall relationship with the Soviet Union on the comfortable personal relationship developed first between President Gorbachev and President Reagan and then between Mr. Gorbachev and President Bush. That relationship has been strained by the killings in the Baltics, regardless of whether Mr. Gorbachev was directly responsible.
The Administration also intends to demonstrate its concern by having Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d receive government officials from Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia on Tuesday.
Two of the officials, Deputy Prime Minister Dainis Ivans of Latvia and Vice President Bronius Kuzmickas of Lithuania, are also scheduled to address Congressional members of the United States Commission on Cooperation and Security in Europe. Mr. Baker is also to receive Endall Lippmaa, an Estonian government minister.
Last week, Republican and Democratic members of the so-called Helsinki commission -- named for the Finnish capital, where 35 countries signed an agreement in 1975 on mutual cooperation and security -- sharply criticized Mr. Gorbachev because of the violent crackdown in the Baltics.
Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, suggested today in an article on the op-ed page of The New York Times and in an interview on Cable News Network that Washington establish "unofficial diplomatic liaison" with the Baltic republics and sponsor their membership in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

GRAPHIC: Photo: After Sunday's violence, Latvia is preparing its own police unit, but the state prosecutor's office in Moscow issued a statement ordering Latvia to suspend all legislative acts contradicting Soviet Constitution, and to disband illegally armed units. A Latvian slept with rifles at the Lithuanian Parliament. (Agence France-Presse)
