HEADLINE: Mongolian President in U.S. to Sign Trade Agreement

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Mongolia, a fledgling democracy wedged between the Soviet Union and China and long isolated economically, will sign its first trade agreement with the United States on Wednesday as part of efforts to broaden exchanges, officials of both Governments said.
The signing, which could lead to lower tariffs and more joint ventures, is scheduled as a high point of a trip to the United States by the newly elected President, Punsalmaagiyn Ochirbat, the first Mongolian leader ever to visit here. He arrived in this country on Sunday night. 
 Long under Moscow's dominance but transformed last year from an authoritarian state to a multi-party democracy, Mongolia sees an expansion of economic ties with the United States as a means of reinforcing market-oriented reforms, said Dalhjavyn Sandag, a diplomat at the Mongolian Embassy here.
In addition to more trade, he said, his Government sought technical assistance and credits from the United States and membership in both the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, organizations that provide economic help to many third world countries.
International economic officials say they expect Mongolia to become the 155th member of the two Washington-based organizations later this year.
 
Hides and Wool Exported
 While Mongolia's main exports include products like hides, wool and metals, the country could become a market for American commercial aircraft, computers and oil-related equipment, Bush Administration trade officials say.
Several Mongolian joint ventures with American companies are getting started, American officials said, including a processing operation for camel's hair for coats and blankets and another for processing dairy products.
An investment law passed last year in the Mongolian legislature seeks to encourage ventures that will increase much-needed foreign exchange. Among the main provisions of the law are a three-year tax holiday and tax exemption for repatriated earnings.
The trade agreement, to be signed by the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, and Mongolia's Minister of Trade and Industry, Sedochiryn Bayarbaatar, is intended to provide a framework for improved commerce.
It removes obstacles to opening offices to advertise, meet with potential purchasers and otherwise promote commerce, and assures that each country's laws and regulations are made available to the other.
 
Dependent on Soviets
 Closer commercial relations with Washington are intended to reduce economic dependence on the Soviet Union, which has been Mongolia's main trading partner and dominant political influence for most of this century.
A land of only two million people whose forebears sent armies as far afield as central Europe in the 13th and 14th centuries, Mongolia was under Chinese suzerainty in the three centuries before it became an autonomous state under Soviet protection in the 1920's.
Mongolian officials are especially eager to reduce their total dependence on Soviet oil, which eats up proceeds from a third of its exports. Moscow has recently cut shipments of oil to Mongolia and raised prices, adding to the sense of urgency.
A number of oil companies, including Shell and Amoco, have expressed interest in starting explorations in Mongolia.
Prospects for finding at least enough oil to meet the country's needs are seen as good, according to a report by Exploration Associates International of Houston, which made a geological survey for the Government, in Ulan Bator.
Another source of concern is the country's crushing debt of 9 billion rubles to the Soviet Union. Government officials say it cannot be repaid, and have asked Moscow to write it off. Moscow has offered to postpone scheduled payments for 10 years on an interest-free basis.
As there is no internationally recognized value for the ruble, the two governments are arguing over what the debt is worth in hard currency. Moscow values the ruble for purposes of the debt at $1.75, making 9 billion rubles worth about $16 billion. Ulan Bator places the total debt closer to $1 billion.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Public Opinion;
Poll Finds Deep Backing While Optimism Fades

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

 BODY:
The American public's initial soaring optimism about the war against Iraq has flattened a little, but support for the war remains broad and President Bush's approval rating continues to stand at a record level, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
Last Thursday, the day after the bombing began with little apparent Iraqi response, 40 percent of the public said they thought the war would be over in a few weeks. By Sunday only half as many held that view. There was a smaller decline in the percentage who said the war was going "very well" for the United States. 
 But approval of how Mr. Bush is handling the Presidency stood at 86 percent in Thursday's polling, and on Sunday it was at a statistically equivalent 84 percent. The 79 percent who said Thursday that the United States was right to attack was about equal to the 76 percent who said so on Sunday. Before the war, the country was evenly split between attacking and waiting for the economic sanctions to have more impact. The margins of sampling error were plus or minus four percentage points for the 544 people interviewed Thursday and three percentage points for the 867 interviewed Sunday.
The four-day telephone survey of 3,002 adults nationwide began the night after the first attacks on Iraq, and was designed to measure day-to-day shifts in opinion. A companion survey of 550 adults examined the views of those who opposed warfare before it began and shifted to support it once the bombs started falling. Those switchers appeared to expect an easier war than they once had and to have started paying more attention to the issue once war began.
 
'Something Needed to Be Done'
Asked to explain why they shifted, the switchers also indicated that their patience, like Mr. Bush's, had been exhausted. Michelle Fabiano, a 23-year-old teacher in Glasco, N.Y., said: "I just thought it got to a point where something needed to be done. So much was invested -- our troops, other countries.' "
Wallace Anderson, a 71-year-old retired civil servant and World War II veteran from San Antonio, said: "If you're going to have a war, go ahead and have it. In World War II they didn't mess around."
While the poll found that support for war, rather than continued reliance on economic sanctions, had increased sharply in all population groups since the weekend before the attack, some major differences remained.
Only 47 percent of blacks said the United States was right to start military action, and 43 percent said it should have tried sanctions longer. Among whites, 80 percent favored war and 16 percent preferred sanctions. That gap was about as wide as the prewar gap, when 52 percent of whites and 23 percent of blacks favored military action if Iraq was not out of Kuwait by Jan. 15.
Differences between men and women narrowed. Before the war, 56 percent of men and 40 percent of women said they favored force after Jan. 15. Among the 3,002 surveyed after war began, 81 percent of men and 70 percent of women said the country was right to attack.
 
Record Approval
 Approval of Mr. Bush's handling of his job went from 66 percent the weekend before the war to 84 percent for the four-day survey, reaching the mark that the Gallup Poll recorded for President Franklin D. Roosevelt just after Pearl Harbor.
The phenomenon of Presidents gaining public approval when deeply involved in foreign crises has a long history, but Mr. Bush's gain was one of the two sharpest ever measured, comparable to the 16 percentage points that President Richard M. Nixon gained in 1973 when the Vietnam peace accords were signed.
President John F. Kennedy gained 13 points from the Cuban missile crisis in 1962. President Lyndon B. Johnson's approval rating went up 8 points after the bombing of Hanoi in 1966.
But other events have produced smaller changes. President Ronald Reagan's bombing of Libya in 1986 was popular, but his approval rating only went from 64 to 70 percent, and Mr. Bush's invasion of Panama in 1989 won him a gain of 9 percentage points.
Some of those previous gains dissipated quickly, while others lasted many months. The poll could not offer any clues about the durability of Mr. Bush's gains, but even if bad news from the front spurred a quick decline, the gain thus far is immense.
 
Good View of State of Nation
 The war has also produced a sharp rise in the general view of the state of the nation, as measured by one question that Republican poll takers favor. When those polled were asked if they thought things in this country were going in the "right direction" or were "off on the wrong track," 57 percent said "right direction" and 31 percent said "wrong track." The last time any poll found as big a majority saying the country was going in the right direction was in January 1985, when President Reagan's second term was beginning. A Washington Post/ ABC News Poll at the time found 59 percent taking that view.
Other major findings from the latest survey were that 77 percent of the public said they were "proud" of the United States role in the Persian Gulf and that 81 percent said the United States should not just force Iraq out of Kuwait, but also "see to it that Saddam Hussein is forced from power."
In a question that was asked only on Sunday, 47 percent said they thought the "United States military is holding back information about mistakes and setbacks in the Persian Gulf," while 45 percent said they believed that the military was providing an "accurate account."
 
How the Polls Were Taken
 The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Jan. 17 to 20 with 3,002 adults throughout the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii. The survey consisted of four independent dai8ly samples, with 544 interviews on Thursday, 683 on Friday, 908 onSaturday and 867 on Sunday.
 In a separate poll, The Times and CBS News also conducted re-interviews with a panel of 550 adults from Jan. 17 to 19. This group amounted to 82 percent of 674 people who had been interviewed Jan. 5-7, before the war in the Persian Gulf began.
 The margin of sampling error for the sample of 3,002 was plus or minus two percentage points. For each of the four daily samples and for the panel re-interviews it was plus or minus three to four percentage points.

HEADLINE: Statement of the Group of 7

 BODY:
Following is the statement issued yesterday by the finance ministers and central bank governors of the Group of Seven after their meeting in New York:
 The finance ministers and central bank governors of Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States met on Jan. 20 and 21, 1991, in New York City for an exchange of views on current international economic and financial issues. The managing director of the I.M.F. participated in the multilateral surveillance discussions.
The ministers and governors reviewed their economic policies and prospects and reaffirmed their support for economic policy coordination at this critical time.
They noted that although growth in all their economies had slowed, expansion of the world economy continues, and the pace of activity could be expected to pick up later this year.
They noted that growth remains particularly strong in Germany and Japan.
Implementation of sound fiscal policies, combined with stability oriented monetary policies, should create conditions favorable to lower global interest rates and a stronger world economy. They also stressed the importance of a timely and successful conclusion of the Uruguay Round.
The ministers and governors also discussed the situation in global financial markets in light of uncertainties arising from the gulf war and developments in the Soviet Union. They agreed to strengthen cooperation and to monitor developments in exchange markets.
The ministers and governors are prepared to respond as appropriate to maintain stability in international financial markets.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Linking a Bond's Quality and Yield

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
IN the decline of long-term interest rates last week on the surge of optimism that followed initial successes in Iraq, lower-quality bonds did less well than higher-quality issues.
The result is wider spreads between yields on high- and lower-quality bonds, reflecting both nervousness over the Middle East and concern over recession at home. 
 The widening spreads are reflected in both the corporate and municipal markets, but some analysts say that considering the recession, the spreads remain narrow and could grow.
"The prevalent theme in the corporate-bond market seems to be that quality spreads have widened and there are good values," said Douglas Langley, a vice president of Stone & McCarthy, a Princeton, N.J., research firm. But he cautioned that it was still early to be looking for values in lower-rated corporates because of significant risk that spreads will widen further.
Mr. Longley pointed to the spread between the average yield on corporate industrial issues rated Aaa or Aa by Moody's, the highest ratings, compared with those rated A or BAA, the next levels down but still above "junk bond" status. On Jan. 14, before the bombing of Iraq, the average yield for the better-rated issues was 9.75 percent, compared with 9.98 percent for the slightly lower-rated bonds, a spread of 23 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
But by Friday, the better-quality issues had seen their yields decline to 9.48 percent while the yield on poorer-quality issues slipped to 9.85 percent, a spread of 38 basis points.
Rising spreads between high-quality and lower-quality corporate bonds generally imply a flight to safety, Mr. Langley noted, and such increases are typical in a recession.
Using a different set of monthly figures, he calculated the movements in rates in each of the last seven recessions, dating to 1953. In general, rates fell in the recessions, with Treasury rates performing better than corporates, and high-quality corporates doing better than lower-quality ones.
That has been the case this time as well. Assuming that the recession began in August, and using monthly average yields, Mr. Longley found that the spread between Aaa and Baa corporate bonds, as rated by Moody's, had risen 38 percent by December, compared with a rise of 46 percent in the 1981-82 recession.
Yield spreads have also started to widen in the tax-exempt municipal-bond market, but relatively modestly. David J. Madigan, a municipal bond strategist at Merrill Lynch, said the difference in yields between relatively low-rated state generalobligation bonds -- those rated BBB by Standard & Poor's -- and those with the top rating of AAA, was now 65 basis points, up from about 50 basis points at the end of last year.
While that spread is much larger than the narrow 15-point spread that prevailed last April, it is relatively low by historical standards, especially given the recession, and Mr. Madigan said he thought the spread could increase.
It appears that many investors still think that risk of default is something that affects only corporate junk bonds -- those rated less than Baa or BBB -- and is less likely to affect either investment-quality corporates or general-obligation municipal bonds.
A sign of that confidence is that general-obligation bonds issued by Philadelphia now are quoted at yields of 9 percent to 9.10 percent, down from around 10 percent at the peak of concern about the city's suspect financial condition.
"Nobody really believes that the State of Pennsylvania will let Philadelphia fail," said Mr. Madigan, pointing to the bailout of New York City 15 years ago as a precedent.
James Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, said the failure of municipal spreads to widen much so far might reflect that many investors in the municipal market have not focused on questions of credit quality.
"People are quite single-minded in the municipal bond market," he said. "They want not to pay taxes, and I don't think they think about much else."
That, of course, could change if there is a default by Philadelphia or any other large issuer.

HEADLINE: Group of 7 Backs Action on Markets

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

 BODY:
The chief economic policy makers of the United States' six main industrial partners expressed support yesterday for the nation's war effort and promised to take steps to stabilize the international financial markets if the Persian Gulf war caused damaging fluctuations.
"From every single one of the other six ministers, there was appreciation of the job the allies have done in the gulf," said the United States Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady. He spoke after a daylong meeting in New York City of the finance ministers and central bank governors from the Group of Seven countries. 
 A communique issued after the meeting stated that the ministers and governors were "prepared to respond as appropriate to maintain stability in international financial markets."
 
Issue of Soviet Union
 The communique dealt with developments in the Soviet Union only in passing. But ministers said after the meeting that the discussions had involved what Norman Lamont, the British Chancellor of the Exchequer, called in a news conference "very strong condemnation indeed" of Moscow's military intervention this month in Lithuania and Latvia.
In addition to the United States and Britain, the Group of Seven countries are Japan, Germany, France, Italy and Canada.
Outside the main meeting, held at the Stanhope Hotel on Fifth Avenue at 81st Street, across from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Americans continued one-on-one discussions with Japanese and German officials to persuade them to give more money to support the war. Last year, the Japanese pledged $4 billion and the Germans about $3 billion. The United States and Britain are insisting on larger sums this year.
Of the seven countries, only Japan and Germany do not have troops in the Persian Gulf region.
Mr. Brady said the Japanese would announce a substantial contribution soon. On Friday, Japan responded to the outbreak of the war with a new pledge of financial aid but did not give a precise figure.
The Associated Press yesterday morning quoted a senior Foreign Ministry official as saying that the Japanese intended to give $10 billion in additional assistance to the allied coalition in the gulf.
Negotiations with the Germans seemed to be going more slowly, officials said. The German Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, told reporters after having breakfast with Mr. Brady that the Germans needed a fuller accounting from the Americans of how much money was needed before they made a commitment.
Further negotiation is expected between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the German Foreign Minister.
The communique indicated that the ministers and central bankers also discussed fiscal and monetary policies and international trade. It stated that the officials expected "the pace of activity" in the world economy "to pick up later this year."
The United States, Britain and Canada are in recession; the economies of France and Italy are growing little if at all, but the economies of Japan and Germany are still strong.
Although the discussions involved a number of topics, the focus was clearly on the war and the economic issues growing out of it.
The basic message the officials hoped to leave, Mr. Brady said, was that "the telephones will remain open" and that the various governments stood ready to step in if action became necessary to tamp down market volatility, including a plunge in the value of the dollar.
He noted that the dollar had fallen somewhat since the war began but said it was not worrisome so far. "If it does take unusual jumps and turns, we're ready to do something about it," he added.
Asked whether measures were still in the cards to bring the Soviets into the world economy by giving them special status at the International Monetary Fund, Mr. Lamont said, "Any question of any relationship with the I.M.F. would have to be considered very cautiously and is not on the agenda at the moment."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady after the Group of Seven meeting yesterday in Manhattan. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq;
CAPTURED AIRMEN MOVED TO TARGETS

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 21

 BODY:
The Iraqi military announced today that it had dispersed captured allied airmen "among scientific and economic targets, as well as among other selected targets."
The Iraqi statement indicated that the captured pilots were being used as so-called human shields to deter allied air attacks. 
 It would not be the first time that Iraq had used such a strategy. After the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, thousands of foreigners were prevented from leaving Iraq. Some were held at military bases and strategic sites before the last were freed in December.
 
'Brutal Treatment' Angers Bush
 The announcement, a day after Iraqi television broadcast interviews with seven captured allied pilots, provoked a stinging response from President Bush. The President condemned the "brutal treatment" of the prisoners and said it would not alter American strategy in the war. [Page A10.]
In its announcement, the Iraqi military denounced the first five days of allied bombing as deadly to civilians and "devoid of the minimum human standards." It added, "Because of this rocketing, it was decided to disperse the more than 20 prisoners of war to civilian, economic, education and other targets."
Iraq's assertion that it now holds more than 20 prisoners of war is its higest yet. The Pentagon has so far listed 21 allied servicemen as missing in action, 12 of them Americans.
There is no indication yet that the captured pilots have been placed at military targets. If carried out, such a move would contravene Article 23 of the Third Geneva Convention on war prisoners, according to the International Committee of the Red Cross in Geneva.
The convention says prisoners may not "at any time be sent to, or detained in, areas where he may be exposed to the fire of the combat zone, nor may his presence be used to render certain points or areas immune from military operations."
 
Captives Paraded in Baghdad
 On Sunday, the Iraqi television broadcast interviews with seven men identified as allied pilots, some of whom were bruised and cut. There was also footage of captives being paraded through Baghdad. Portions of that television footage were aired today in the West. President Bush's response came after he had seen the film.
The International Committee of the Red Cross said it had not been permitted to visit the prisoners. A spokesman said parading prisoners in public was also a violation of the Geneva conventions.
The Baghdad Radio quoted a military spokesman today as saying that the decision to disperse the prisoners took effect last night.
In a reference to the five-day aerial onslaught against Iraq and occupied Kuwait by the United States and its allies, the spokesman said: "Since the aggression has been devoted until now to bombarding civilians and economic and scientific targets within the cities, this has harmed civilians in terms of martyred and wounded.
"As one of the methods that should be adopted," the spokesman continued, "it has been decided to distribute the captured pilots, numbering more than 20 prisoners, among scientific and economic targets, as well as among other selected targets. This took effect as of the night of 20 and 21 January, 1991."
 
Iraq Announces Missile Damage
 As it gave its account of Sunday's Iraqi missile attacks on Saudi Arabia, which the allies say were thwarted by Patriot ground-to-air missiles, Iraq said in a communique that the strike "inflicted significant losses on enemy positions, men, weapons and equipment." The communique raised Baghdad's tally of downed allied aircraft to 160. The United States and its allies acknowledge losing 15 planes.
Baghdad's supporters say President Saddam Hussein's strategy has been to absorb the huge first strike by allied missiles and warplanes in preparation for an eventual land war. The Iraqi leader said on Sunday that he had deployed only a fraction of his forces.
A commentary on Baghdad Radio today claimed victory for President Hussein "in the first round of the great showdown of the mother of all battles" by denying President Bush a quick breakthrough.
 
A Statement on Defenses
 "Bush's evil dreams have been shattered and scattered in the air together with the wreck of his aircraft and missiles," the commentary said. "Bush's wager on a swift and decisive battle was shattered together with his black dreams."
Since allied commanders acknowledge that Iraq has survived the first five days of the war with its air force largely intact in underground bunkers and its occupying force in Kuwait dug in behind formidable defenses, the intent of such commentaries is apparently to persuade Iraqis and Iraq's Arab supporters that the country is not defenseless against the massive allied onslaught.
Moreover, some Arab diplomats say, the longer President Hussein holds out, the greater his stature will increase in the Arabic-speaking world. "Even in the Arab countries supporting America, like Egypt and Syria, you can hear people on the street saying, 'Hey, this guy's got something,' " a diplomat said, speaking on condition of anonymity.
The few reports trickling out of Baghdad suggest that the allied bombardment has sent residents fleeing from the city.
 
Citizens Stay Put
 One of the latest accounts came from a Reuters news agency photographer, Patrick de Noirmont, who said he and two colleagues were beaten by Iraqi soldiers as they sought to flee the capital in a taxi. In an article written here after the photographers were freed and allowed to leave for Jordan, Mr. de Noirmont described Baghdad as "a ghost town of empty streets and shuttered shops."
Relief officials in Jordan anticipate a large influx of refugees from the war, but some say they believe that the intensity of the bombardment and the absence of communication from Baghdad may be persuading many to remain in basements and bomb shelters.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Captured American fliers shown on Iraqi television, from left: Warrant Officer Guy Hunter Jr., Lieut. Jeffrey N. Zaun and Lieut. Col. Clifford M. Acree. Their families expressed relief and concern. Page A10. (CNN)

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Bombers;
Giant B-52 Grows Old Virulently

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
More than 30 years after the lumbering aircraft first rolled off the production line and 18 years after they tramautized Hanoi in the Christmas raids of 1972, Air Force B-52 bombers are hammering targets throughout Iraq and Kuwait.
One of the oldest and by far the biggest combat plane flying against the Iraqis, the B-52 has been so extensively remodeled since its Vietnam days, to bolster its accuracy and make it safer from enemy attack, that little more than its airframe and hulking silhouette remain the same. 
 "It's like you took a 1959 Ford Fairlane with the original engine and stuff," said Maj. Dick Cole of the Air Force in a telephone interview from the Pentagon, "and you put in a new stereo and maybe a trip computer and some other electronic wizardry. And maybe you've done this two or three times."
Of the 744 B-52's that were built between 1955 and 1963, all but 247 have been retired, including the "D" models which were the most widely used in Vietnam. Those earlier versions of the bomber carried more than twice the bomb loads of the "G" models that are now attacking in the Persian Gulf. In the newest reconfiguration much of the space that was once used to hold bombs now accommodates banks of computers that have increased bombing precision.
 
A Terrifying Wallop
 Even with half their old bomb capacity, the surviving B-52's deliver the biggest and perhaps most terrifying wallop in the American air arsenal. They operate equally well during the day or night, the Air Force says, and are immune to most variations in weather.
Even the Vietnam era B-52's were renowned for the accuracy of their bomb attacks. Miles above the targets and barely able to distinguish the flash of their exploding bombs, the crews had no sensation of the havoc erupting on the ground. Modern computers, the Air Force says, have only reinforced the accuracy.
A B-52G can carry 51 bombs of either 500 or 750 pounds. Using the 500-pound bomb, the total payload is only 1,000 pounds more than the F15-E fighter-bomber.
But tactics play a big part in the effectiveness of the B-52. The F15-E and other fighter-bombers are designed to peel off one at a time and dive at their targets, while B-52's typically attack in formations of three, unleashing all their bombs at once from altitudes of six or seven miles and blasting a swath of up to a half mile wide and perhaps a mile long.
 
Enemy Can't See or Hear It
 "You turn the target into something that looks like a moonscape," said Major Cole, a former B-52 crew member.
Flying at high altitude, he said, the B-52's "can't be seen or heard until the bombs start falling and then it's like rolling thunder.
"It's a great psychological effect," Major Cole said. "You scare the hell out of them."
The B-52, "has got a mystique about it," said Maj. Gen. John L. Borling, deputy chief of operations at the United States Strategic Air Command Headquarters in Omaha. "Because of its destructive power it has an ethos, a sense of awesomeness."
 
Prehistoric-Looking Creature
 The plane carries a crew of six and is three or four times bigger than other American fighting aircraft. Its huge wings, spanning more than 60 yards, have wheels near the tips to prevent them from scraping the ground. They droop under the weight of eight jet engines and literally seem to flap slowly as the prehistoric-looking creature bounds down the runway, struggling to fly.
The B-52's operating in the current crisis are based several hours away from the combat zone, as they were during the Vietnam War, to protect them and their ground crews from hostile fire on the ground.
In the Christmas bombing of Hanoi, great sections of the city were demolished. At that time General Borling, whose fighter had been shot down, was a prisoner of war in North Vietnam. He recalls the earth shuddering as the B-52's delivered their bombs.
In South Vietnam, B-52's were often dispatched against concentrations of North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops. Survivors were sometimes found dazed, staggering and bloody. Many defectors said fear of the B-52's had caused them to give up.
 
The B-52 Bomber: Still Potent
 
HISTORY
 
The heavy bomber was initially planned as a turboprop plan in 1948, but was built as a turbo jet after improvements in jet engines' fuel economy. By 1951, the plane was being designed to carry up to four nuclear bombs at high altitudes for a range of 7,000 miles, or long enough to fly from the continental U.S. to the Soviet Union without refueling.
 The first B-52 was delivered on June 29, 1955, the last was delivered on Oct. 23, 1963; the U.S. never sold the plane to other nations.
 The 744 B-52's purchased from Boeing between 1955 and 1963 averaged a little more than $8 million per plane ($35.3 million in 1990 dollars).
 The price of improvement made since the 1960's has cost several times the original price of the planes.
 
PAYLOAD
 
The B-52G, themodel being used in the Gulf War, can carry up to 51 gravity (dumb) bombs of 500 or 750 pounds apiece internally and 12 smart missiles externally.
 
IMPROVEMENTS SINCE ORIGINAL DESIGN
 
Originally designed to fly 5,000 hours before structural fatigue, most B-52's are now expected to achieve at least 15,000 hours. It is estimated that the planes could be used in active duty until 2035, 80 years after the first delivery.
 In the mid 1960's the wings and fuselages were reinforced and corroding metals were replaced with new alloys. The reinforced plane can now fly at lower altitudes. The range of the B-52G was increased to 7,500 miles without refueling.
 The electronics on the B-52 have beenupdated numerous times. Recent improvement include equipment enabling the planes to communicate with Air Force satellites, electro-optical systems to provide quidance inlow-level flights at night or in bad weather and radar-jammers and lasers used to guide smart weapons to targets.
 
Sources: "Modern Bombers", "Boeing B-52 G/H Stratofortress", Aeroflax Datagraph, Jane's All the World's Aricraft, Periscope date base.

HEADLINE: Roadblocks to Equivalency Exam Deny Many a Chance for Success

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
For thousands of New York City residents with no high school degree, passing the equivalency test is the key to getting a job, getting off welfare or pursuing vocational or college studies. But educators who prepare people throughout the city for the test say the route is increasingly obstructed by delays and bureaucratic complications that put lives on hold for months or more.
Most commonly, the snag comes when people are ready to take the test, the General Educational Development, or G.E.D., exam, which is given nationally. After applying for seats at the exam they often must wait as long as six to eight months for reservations.
 
'An Absurd Situation'
 A state education official who is charged with administering the test contends that the concern is being overstated, since students unable to take the test at a site that is too crowded can find other places that offer availability. But local officials, students and others familiar with the test argue that the problem is more severe: an unresponsive bureaucracy that refuses to address a shortage of slots. 
 "It is an absurd situation," John Casey, director of the Mayor's Office of Adult Literacy, said recently. "We have thousands of people completing preparation programs with the expectation that they can sit for the test and then go on and do whatever they want, go to a university, get a job. Now they are being asked to wait for months."
Such complaints are heard from a number of groups. They range from Promesa, a drug-rehabilitation program in the Bronx, to the Henry Street Settlement House in lower Manhattan, from the St. John the Baptist Parish Center in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn to District 65 of the United Auto Workers and the city's Human Resources Administration.
To a lesser degree, the complaints expressed in New York City have been voiced elsewhere, said Douglas Whitney, director of the G.E.D. testing service of the American Council on Education, which prepares the test given in all states.
"It appears to be one of the more serious problem locations, but there are problems elsewhere," he said in a telephone interview last night.
Noting that about half the states have no pre-registration process but offer the test on a walk-in basis, he said, "There are complaints about how long it takes to register in states with registration, even in those where the waiting period is much shorter than in New York, say four to six weeks."
For an individual student, the consequences of waiting months for the test, while skills grow rusty and confidence ebbs, can be severe. Educators say that delay can diminish the chances of passing, and failure can mean continued dependence on welfare. What impact that has on a city hoping to reduce its welfare and unemployment rolls is incalculable, for no one knows how many people fall by the wayside.
One of those who waited for six months before getting notification of a test date was Julia Medina, a single mother of five from the Red Hook section of Brooklyn who is on public assistance. "I was ready to take it in June when everything was fresh in my mind," said Miss Medina, who attended school only through the seventh grade but studied for three years at the Carroll Gardens Neighborhood Women's Adult Literacy Center.
 
A Missed Opportunity
 An admission card for the exam arrived on Dec. 1. It told her to report to Sheepshead Bay High School on Dec. 5 for the seven-and-a-half-hour test, which is given over two days. "With so few days' notice, I just couldn't get anyone to stay with my children, so I didn't take it," she said. "I was very upset. I have been waiting so long."
Miss Medina, 37 years old, who dropped out of school 23 years ago after becoming pregnant through rape, is hoping to enroll in a nursing program at New York City Technical College in Brooklyn. She cannot do that without her equivalency diploma.
Shirley Frederick, 30, another welfare mother in the group, who hopes to become a nurse, is in similar straits. "It's hard to focus on paper, hard to do homework after all these years," she said. "I've had the idea to give up, but when I watch my three kids I say I must keep going even when the door is slammed in my face." Ms. Frederick finally got a test date -- with two days' notice -- this month after waiting since spring. She was turned away when she arrived five minutes late because of a baby-sitting problem.
Students and administrators of G.E.D. courses report other problems, including difficulty getting in touch with people who set up the test appointments and a wait of 8 to 10 weeks for test results. In addition, allegations have been made that preferential treatment in the distribution of test seats is given to the Board of Education and the City University of New York, the largest providers of preparation classes in the city, leaving smaller groups scrambling for what remains.
But the officials of both the board and CUNY, which are able to reserve blocks of seats for the tests, say they also encounter difficulties securing enough spaces.
The exams are offered at five schools in Manhattan, three in Queens, four in the Bronx, two in Brooklyn and one on Staten Island, and though some sites have been closed or relocated, there has been no overall decrease in the city in the last few years.
 
Backlog of Applications
 Esteban Colon, education manager for Promesa, has stopped sending applications for his students to the schools in the Bronx. "Waiting lists are too long," he said. "If you apply in October, you don't get in until April." Instead, he said he sends those willing to travel to the High School for the Humanities, at 351 West 18th Street in Manhattan, where he has had better luck.
But Joel Rubin, the chief examiner there, has a huge backlog of applications. "At this point, I should be filled till April and am actually booked till the second week of July," he said.
Mr. Rubin, who is a full-time school teacher -- he would not say where for fear of being deluged with phone calls about the test -- said 160 people can be accommodated at each test at his site. In most sites, the test is given about once a month. But at the High School for the Humanities it is offered every week and during the summer, making it the most popular place.
Mr. Rubin files applications and responds to them only as vacancies arise, a practice he agreed could lead people to think they were being ignored. "We don't send postcards until two to three weeks before people are actually tested," he said. "So there is no notification going to people now telling them they must wait till July."
 
Charges Are Denied
 Carolyn Byrne, director of the state Department of Education's division of testing, the agency responsible for the exam in New York, said there was no basis for any of the charges.
"We test 85,000 people a year statewide," she said. "Can you imagine any program that touches 85,000 people that doesn't have some malcontents? I think we are running the program extremely well. There is no problem."
But Mr. Casey of the Mayor's Office of Adult Literacy said the problem was largely caused by "a citywide shortage of testing slots."
Ms. Byrne countered that there were more than enough spaces and that they were offered often enough at 71 sites in schools and other places across the state. Her department has an annual budget of $800,000 for the test.
"I think that what we have here in terms of sites and schedules is very realistic," she said. "There is no evidence that people who want to take the test over a particular period of time are not able to. But as far as I can judge by talking to examiners in every borough, seats are going empty."
Each of those sites is supervised by a chief examiner, who is hired as an independent contractor through the city's Board of Education. The examiners, typically principals, teachers or guidance counselors, have a great deal of autonomy. They schedule the exams, subject to state approval, and mail out the admission cards. They determine which applicants take the test on which date. They also choose the proctors and other assistants.
 
Cultivating Test Administrators
 Directors of G.E.D. programs say they are forced to be manipulative, cultivating site administrators or Board of Education staff members assigned to procure and allocate the slots for the board.
"You need to develop a relationship with a testing center, so that your students can have some priority," said Virginia Kwarta, executive director of the Steps/Basic Skills Academy, a program in Harlem. "We have a part-time employee who proctors at G.E.D. exams, so she is able to make arrangements. We have never had to wait more than a month."
Ms. Byrne contended that if students were flexible about where they took the test, they would have few difficulties. She ticked off a list of schools that ordinarily have vacancies, among them Christopher Columbus High School in the Morris Park section of the Bronx, Harry Van Arsdale High School in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn and Adam Clayton Powell Junior High School in Harlem.
Since November 1989, Angela Surkis, coordinator of the Carroll Gardens Center's G.E.D. program, has kept a diary of the problems she says she has had trying to get test spaces. She and her colleague, Carmel Rosa, the center's executive director, say their students have been shut out of several sites. They attribute the problem to the number of seats allocated to the Board of Education and CUNY.
Ms. Rosa said they had no problems in the past, when a Board of Education instructor who taught unrelated classes at the center intervened.
"Then about a year and a half ago, the board said, 'You can't have your students tested through our program anymore,' " Ms. Rosa recalled, "probably because we were beginning to have more than one or two students who were ready, and that's when our nightmare began."
But officials of both the board and CUNY said that they, too, were experiencing delays.
"How many slots we reserve is negotiated with the site administrator," said Myra Baum, assistant coordinator in the Board of Education Office of Adult and Continuing Education. "We are the largest program in the city, but we only use a small portion of the slots, say 20 percent. So at any one test site, we might have from 25 to 50 seats."
For her students, Ms. Surkis said: "Waiting is terrible. We have to keep them prepared psychologically and keep their skills up for the next six months. But the people we teach have family situations and lives that are so chaotic it is impossible for us to predict where they will be in six months."
In the view of Toby Emmer, director of the education program of District 65 of the United Auto Workers, such hurdles convey a tough message. "People are told, 'Work hard, study hard and you'll get ahead,' " she said. "But the message has become 'You'll be lost in the morass of bureaucracy.' "

HEADLINE: Mexican Films Abroad

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 21

 BODY:
By the accounting of any major Hollywood production, the movie set built in an old electrical generating station here was scarcely worth a budgetary footnote. A creative paint job substitutes for expensive stage props, and a lump of smoking coal took the place of elaborate special effects.
But to the director Arturo Ripstein and his small team of skilled local film makers, the joint American-Mexican production of his moody new project, "Woman of the Port," now in final editing, is nevertheless a heartening step toward new commercial possibilities for Mexico's 50-year-old film industry. 
 In a country long dominated by official film tastes or by giant United States film companies seeking good locations and cheap labor, Mr. Ripstein's new film is the product of a rare pairing of independent American and Mexican production companies as equals.
Intended to grant unhindered artistic freedom to Mr. Ripstein, one of Mexico's best-known and most idiosyncratic directors, the production is the kind of sophisticated intellectual project that has traditionally characterized the small world of Mexican art films.
 
Seeking a Wider Audience
 But as the avowedly commercial project of private producers from each side of the border, the film is also geared to reach beyond Mexico's limited moviegoing public and win distribution to a broad international audience, from New York to Berlin.
"It is very difficult to make films here because once it is made, nothing happens to it; it is just put on a shelf," said Mr. Ripstein, whose earlier work was honored last month with a retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art in New York. "But with this kind of production, you know that they will try to take care of your film -- and try to make it available to the largest possible audience."
Like other films by Mr. Ripstein, who began his career as an assistant and protege of the renowned Spanish director Luis Bunuel, "Woman of the Port" is an impressionistic emotional drama far removed from the fast, plot-oriented action films that dominate the box office in Mexico and much of the world.
Written by Mr. Ripstein's longtime film collaborator and wife, Paz Alicia Garciadiego, based on a short story by Guy de Maupassant, the screenplay centers on a case of unknowing incest between a sailor and a young port-town prostitute who turns out to be his daughter, conceived in another bordello encounter many years before.
 
Thriving but Isolated Industry
 That seamy story line and its sometimes surreal treatment are hardly the stuff of mainstream movies. But Mr. Ripstein's directorial skills, and the relative success of his earlier films, including "Love Lies," convinced executives of an independent American film company, Chariot 7 Productions , that "Woman of the Port" could be a path-breaking Mexican entrant into the international art-film market.
"We are not doing this to lose money," said Allen Persselin, one of two producers from Chariot 7 who are overseeing the film, which is to have a final budget of $5 million to $6 million. "There has yet to be a Mexican breakaway hit, and it's due."
The cross-border compact was then sealed when Chariot 7 reached an agreement to co-produce the film with a private Mexican production company, Dos Producciones , led by a successful local television and film producer, Hugo Scherer.
Mexico's diverse landscapes and cheap, skilled labor have long made the country a favorite setting for the production of American films ranging from "Under Fire" to "Total Recall." Extensive Government subsidies and involvement in the film industry here have also fostered a thriving, if poorly marketed, Mexican film making community.
But neither arrangement has created any lasting, creative cooperation between the two countries. Film projects here of United States and other companies are concluded as abruptly as they are begun, with little direct artistic impact or involvement from the Mexican side. And Mexico's film industry has remained isolated, without the effective distribution and technical quality that could give it true international reach.
 
2 Arts in Collaboration
 With the co-production arrangement, the producers of "Woman of the Port" hope to combine United States marketing and technical expertise with Mexico's artistic best to yield a strong hybrid capable of competing in the world art film market.
The film is being made entirely in Spanish, with an all-Mexican cast and crew, and will require subtitles for distribution in non-Spanish-speaking countries. But the film shot each day was sent to Los Angeles for high-quality processing, and all of the post-production and distribution of the film is being handled by laboratories and marketing companies in the United States.
None of that unusual effort has had much immediate impact on Mr. Ripstein's style of working, which has paired the art of making films with the art of stretching a small budget.
On a chilly day on the set last month, a few plastic buckets slowly dripping water from overhead, some smoke and a handful of glaring Christmas lights combined to create a vivid waterfront bordello scene that was high in atmosphere and low in cost. It is the kind of bare-bones film making that Mr. Ripstein and the film's producers say they hope will eventually be a matter of artistic choice rather than of economic necessity.
"Success means doing the film you want to do, the film you dream of," Mr. Ripstein said, relaxing in his director's chair with a cup of coffee during a lull on the set. "It means you have the small liberty of doing what you wish."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Arturo Ripstein directing a scene from his new film, "Woman of the Port," on location in Mexico City. (Mark A. Uhlig/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Modern Art in the Eyes of Commedia dell'Arte

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:

Conversations With a Clown
By Michael Welzenbach
210 pages. Atlantic Monthly Press . $19.95.
 Michael Welzenbach's first novel, "Conversations With a Clown," begins with a clever premise: In the year 1999, a jaded art critic named Corry Peters meets an elderly man who claims to be Pierrot, the famous white-face clown of commedia dell'arte. Pierrot takes the critic on a guided tour through the past, introducing him to painters like Picasso, Modigliani, Goya and Watteau. In the process, Peters receives a lesson in art history and esthetics, a lesson that will make him reconsider his pessimistic view of art at the end of the millennium. 
 As depicted by Mr. Welzenbach, who is an art critic himself, Pierrot emerges as a cranky, garrulous pedant. He is continually launching into long-winded speeches about the creative process and reminiscing about famous artists he has known. Like all Pierrots, he is locked in the famous eternal triangle, battling the brutish Harlequin for the affections of the beautiful but elusive Columbine, but he is not the shy, love-struck simpleton traditionally associated with commedia dell'arte. Rather, this Pierrot is a fiercely opinionated fellow with a quick temper and an even quicker tongue.
 He loves to gorge himself on junk food and he seems addicted to alcohol and cigars. He lives on Manhattan's Lower East Side in a grungy apartment crammed with portraits of himself done by well-known artists. He says he is approximately 500 years old.
 When he first meets Pierrot, Corry Peters is despairing about a piece he has to write for a newspaper about the state of modern art. Peters says he is sick of the politics and commercialism of the art scene, fed up with post-modernist high jinks and deconstructivist criticism, and dismayed by contemporary artists' self-indulgence and lack of craft.
 "I've thought for some time now," he says, "that certain values have gotten lost; the belief in art for it's own sake, for example. It's almost as if, since the last efforts of pure abstraction -- Minimalism -- in the 70's, there's been a purely cynical, purely political approach to making art. And I'm not sure I can honestly say why this has happened, but I can say that I don't particularly like it, and that I don't see much of a future for painting."
 In response to this gloomy assessment, Pierrot declares that "the urge to make art is as old as mankind" and "it will continue, no matter what the current state of affairs politically or economically." Things are cyclical, he argues, and barren periods will be followed by periods of rebirth and inspiration. He proceeds to regale Peters with some stories about his encounters with Goya and Modigliani, then takes him on a trip back in time to visit the Japanese painter Hokusai.
 When Mr. Welzenbach focuses on Pierrot's adventures in the art world and his continuing battles with Harlequin, the results are both entertaining and informative. He offers interesting, gossipy theories about the creation of several masterpieces, and he provides amusing asides about Pierrot's relationship with individual painters.
 Unfortunately, he never makes the most of his central premise. The pervasive influence that Pierrot and other commedia dell'arte characters have exerted on the modernist imagination (as delineated in a recent study by Martin Green and John Swan called "The Triumph of Pierrot") is completely neglected: the clown's effect on such painters as Georges Rouault and David Hockney is ignored, as is his effect on such masters of film as Chaplin, Keaton, Federico Fellini and Ingmar Bergman.
 In other respects as well, "Conversations With a Clown" manages to disappoint. Although the book is set in 1999 with the purpose of satirizing developments in the art world, Mr. Welzenbach's portrayal of that period lacks imagination and bite. The world he has created seems like a very tired extrapolation of the art world today, and his jokes about the likes of Jeff Koons and Andy Warhol also feel overly familiar.
 To make matters worse, Pierrot's statements about art are alternately as pompous as a graduate school paper and as trite as a greeting card message. He goes on and on about the importance of magic in creativity, the dialectic between reality and imagination, the connection between "the sublime and the absurd."
 "If you want to see the purest and most compelling form of magic," he tells Peters, "watch a bud develop on the twig of a tree in spring. Spend a few weeks just watching, until it unfolds completely into a bright new leaf, pulsing with life. Or watch a baby being born."
 "It takes courage," he adds, "to be an artist, my friend; to look at reality clearly; to form one's own opinions. To make magic."
 Elsewhere, he declares: "A painting, in terms of the many moments in which it can be beheld and contemplated, is not a fleeting thing. It is, for better or for worse, a dual entity: an image on the one hand and an object on the other. 'Art' occurs when a dialectic is provoked between what an object is and what it signifies."
 Such statements reveal that Mr. Welzenbach's Pierrot is neither a real clown nor an inspired scholar of art. In the end, he is simply a rank sentimentalist and a well-intentioned bore.

HEADLINE: Big Game Revealing a City's Changes

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla.

 BODY:
Henry Carley lives on the west side of town, only a couple of miles from Tampa Stadium. The last time the Super Bowl was played there, in 1984, he felt as distant from all the hoopla as if he were 1,000 miles away, he recalls. Carley, who is president of the local chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, had no interest in being inside the stadium. He says he only wished the black community could have shared in some of the considerable profits generated by one of America's greatest sports events.
"The Super Bowl is about money," Carley said last week. "And last time we were basically onlookers."
 
Several New Events
 Things are a lot different this time around. This year, Carley is the co-chairman of one of the featured events of Super Bowl week, the Bamboleo Parade, a Saturday extravaganza with marching bands, a street festival and floats. The grand marshal of the parade will be Lee Roy Selmon, the former Tampa Bay Buccaneer. Other events will include a salute to black sports legends, a Doug Williams golf tournament and a festival in Ybor City, the historical Cuban district. 
 The 1991 Super Bowl Task Force, a group headed by two of the city's most influential white businessmen, has named two black men to head a community-relations committee. But perhaps most important, Carley said, several minority-owned businesses have won lucrative contracts from the National Football League for the game.
"There's much more involvement this time, black and white," said Carley, who is the affirmative-action officer for Hillsborough Community College. "There's been a heightened awareness. In 1984, there was not even a thought given to a black man."
Some 100,000 visitors, many of them corporate and political movers and shakers, will arrive in Tampa this week for the festivities leading up to the game Sunday. The game itself, which is televised to 750 million people around the world, is only part of an event whose impact on a city has been compared to that of a national political convention. Hotels, restaurants and other businesses are anticipating an estimated $125 million in revenues, with a total economic impact of $200 million.
"The Super Bowl introduces you to the world in a big way," said Barbara Casey, the coordinator of the Super Bowl Task Force. "You don't have to say Tampa, Florida, anymore."
The Super Bowl can also highlight a community's problems, and bring the frustrations of many of its members to the surface.
"It's more than a window into a town," said Jim Steeg, director of special events for the N.F.L. "It's a bay window."
Last month, Paul Tagliabue, the N.F.L. commissioner, said he would stand by his recommendation to move the 1993 Super Bowl out of Tempe, Ariz., because the state does not have a holiday honoring Dr. Martin Luther King.
A week before the Super Bowl in Miami two years ago, the fatal shooting of a black man on a motorcycle by a Hispanic police officer in the predominantly black Overtown neighborhood set off three days of looting and torchings of buildings and cars. While the disturbances were not caused by the Super Bowl, the N.F.L. was criticized at the time for not making enough of an effort to include minority-group members in the festivities.
"I think Miami was the awakening for a lot of people," Carley said.
 
Parade of Pirates
 Here in Tampa, Super Bowl XXV brought about the cancellation of what was the biggest annual event here for 86 years: the Gasparilla Parade, a winter extravaganza that featured 500 of the city's most powerful men swaggering through the streets dressed up as gun-toting pirates.
Tampa officials made the parade part of their pitch to the National Football League for the Super Bowl. But after Tampa was awarded the 1991 Super Bowl, a racial dispute erupted over the parade, which has always been sponsored and organized by an all-white, all-male private club, Ye Mystic Krewe of Gasparilla.
The club's top officials refused the demands of a coalition of black residents, including Carley, that the club be integrated immediately. Instead, they canceled the parade.
The Super Bowl Task Force had to scramble to put together a new parade, and Carley became the co-chairman of that effort.
Tampa has 286,000 residents, 23 percent of whom are black. One black sits on the seven-member school board, one on the seven-member County Commission and one on the seven-member City Council. There are only a handful of black executives.
Carley said the publicity over the Super Bowl and the parade may have given blacks new standing. "The Super Bowl is a window of opportunity," he said. "We need to seize the time and take advantage of it."
 
Out of 'Virgin Territory'
 In addition to meeting increased sensitivity on the part of the N.F.L. as well as the Tampa power brokers, Carley said, the black community was better organized this year to take advantage of the Super Bowl.
"We were in virgin territory in 1984," he explained. "We didn't know what to expect. A number of Tampa people, white and black, didn't do too well. But it was much more devastating for the black community because we didn't have as many resources. We don't have any large hotels -- or small ones."
David Cornwell, the director of equal employment for the N.F.L., saidthis Super Bowl represents the greatest involvement yet between minority-group firms and the N.F.L. This year the league has set up the first Super Bowl Village -- a corporate hospitality tent complex around the stadium -- and minority-group firms will be supplying the audio visuals, security and clean-up as well as selling Super Bowl souvenirs like T-shirts, coffee mugs and key chains.
"Starting with Super Bowl XXIII in Miami, we started talking about the perception that we were not responsive enough to minorities," Cornwell said. "We wanted to make sure the minority community felt excited about the Super Bowl. Super Bowl Village was a perfect opportunity to give minorities more involvement."
Leonard Levy, the owner of a printing company, is the vice chairman of the 1991 Super Bowl Task Force, and was the chairman in 1984. He said that he went to the Super Bowl in Miami two years ago with his friend Walter Baldwin, an insurance company executive who is the chairman of the 1991 group.
"Mr. Baldwin was concerned," Levy said. "He said: 'We want peace in our community. We don't want any unrest.' We decided we had to make sure we involved the black community early on. The first time nobody had really thought that much about it."
The two men formed the community-relations committee two years ago. The co-chairman is Jesse Hill, a marketing representative for an insurance company. Hill said the committee planned events like the salute to black sports legends and the festival in Ybor City.
 
Working Through Barriers
 "The local task force has been very supportive," Hill said. "However, it was not always that way. We had to work through some barriers."
Last March, Drew Pittman, a black businessman, was awarded the contract to be the distributor of Super Bowl XXV souvenirs. "This is a stepping stone," he said. "I'm doing this to help Drew Pittman make it down the road."
Another black resident of Tampa, Michael Perch, is installing all the audio visual equipment for Super Bowl Village, including 110 television monitors in the corporate tents. Perch said the Super Bowl contract has given him access and credentials he never had before.
"We're not just another audio visual services company anymore," he said. "Now we're the company that did the Super Bowl. We've gotten calls from corporations in the area who are now interested in doing business with us. There's an old boy network operating here and in a lot of other cities. We want to get more involved, and the Super Bowl has helped the process along."
This year, for the first time, Henry Carley was offered a chance to buy Super Bowl tickets, at $150 apiece. He declined. He will be watching the game on television, just as he did in 1984.
"I have no false illusions about the Super Bowl curing the socioeconomic needs of the minority community in Tampa," he said. "It all depends on what we do with it. We have to take in stride and move on."

HEADLINE: New York City Shouldn't Set Up a Center to Buy Recyclables

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Facing the Recycling Facts" (editorial, Jan. 3) applauds Stephen Polan, the New York City Sanitation Commissioner, for going slowly on recycling programs. In light of Mr. Polan's concern for costs, it is surprising to see the department propose a buyback center for recyclables on the West Side of Manhattan. 
 If the department's plan is approved, the city will spend more than $175,000 to buy baling, compacting, crushing and other processing equipment; approximately $800,000 over two years to subsidize overall operation costs, and up to $92 a ton to be paid to the contractor, the Manhattan Bowery Corporation, for many recyclables that are now purchased on the open market for far less. (Manhattan Bowery Corporation has no experience setting up and operating a recycling facility.)
Why should the city spend money to equip a buyback center when the private sector handles the collection, processing and marketing of millions of tons of secondary materials annually at no direct cost to the taxpayer?
Moreover, by paying artificially high prices for recyclables, the Department of Sanitation will put small, private recyclers at a competitive disadvantage. Thus, rather than increasing the amount of recycling done, the net result will at best be a shift in recycling from the private to the public sector. At worst, a well-established network of private sector recycling will be undermined.
Especially during this period of fiscal crisis, it makes no sense to ask the public to support a buyback center that could be run more economically and efficiently in the private sector. Such buyback activity is already happening every day in New York City. On this particular proposal, rather than go slowly, Mr. Polan would do better to stop.
 
HARVEY JAKOB
President, N.Y.C. Chapter, Institute
of Scrap Recycling Industries
Brooklyn, Jan. 8, 1991

HEADLINE: Why Make Public Employees Pay for Deficits?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As state, city and Federal governments struggle to close budget gaps, the use of a pay lag has again appeared, soon to be imposed on New York State workers and possibly on others. In the New York version, all state workers would work five days without pay and receive an additional week's pay on leaving government. 
 For good reasons, meeting a payroll on time is a basic operating responsibility of private employers. However, governments often exempt themselves from niceties (compare civil rights, job safety, lie detectors), so why not defer the pay of public employees? Doing so allows a government to save money now but still receive the covered services and thus avoid the problems entailed in layoffs or furloughs. Elected officials, especially Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, seem to like the idea.
Arguments against it have been subdued, concentrating on its fiscal aspects. A pay lag allows the state to enjoy a long-term float on salaries owed. But much more deserves to be said against it.
Most fundamental is the violation of fair labor practices. Public employees are legally prohibited from using labor's most important weapon, the strike. Certain concessions are granted in return, such as requirements for negotiation and arbitration, and the continuation of contracts. Impounding the pay of workers violates these protections, regardless of enabling legislation passed to make it "legal." Even the deferred concept is not all it seems.
On WCBS radio recently, Governor Cuomo indicated that the state would keep the money when state employees died in service. Of much broader scope would be the effect on those who retire into state pension systems. Presumably, the pension payments would start only when the retiree goes off the payroll, in which case the pay lag would get converted to a smaller pension lag, which the state never pays. Would people voluntarily choose to work for such an employer?
Another way to look at the lag is as a very selective tax. The proposal of the unions to cover desired expenditures by small additional taxes has been generally derided. After all, voters have increasingly been turning down bond proposals and voting out politicians who dare to raise taxes. So instead of asking a little more from many through a tax increase, the state puts a big hit on a few. The only
conceivable justification is that state employees are especially responsible for the state's fiscal woes.
As a City University professor subject to increasing state funding and control since 1976, I can attest to increases in workload, to deteriorating support services and salaries frozen at 1989 levels. I have little doubt that most state workers have been making similar sacrifices and that more of the same lies ahead. If any group of state employees is to be held responsible, it would be elected officials at the state level, most being the very legislators who approved the pay lag but so far have exempted themselves.
Why should state workers in particular lend the state a week's salary? How about trying the same thing on all county and municipal workers subsidized by the state? Better yet, try asking all wage earners in the state to hand over a mere day's pay.
This leads to the related question of once started, where does it stop? State workers already deferred two weeks of pay in 1983 and now must give another week. Somewhere down the road, another week will seem reasonable, and who knows how much more after that? Imagine 21st-century retirees collecting deferred pay for months after they stop working. Besides lengthening the lag, it can also be broadened.
In addition to hitting more public employees or even all wage earners, the state could also try these ideas: a tax-refund lag (pay 1990 refunds a year later), a welfare-payments lag (give the last payment a month after the recipient leaves welfare, as an incentive), even a general-payment lag (add several months to the lag on everything the state pays for).
Naturally, these devices need not be limited to New York State. Other states can do the same thing. So can cities, counties and the Federal Government. The possibilities are almost limitless once governments step beyond equating employee payrolls with services rendered in the same fiscal period. The lag concept could become the voodoo economics of the 1990's, maybe even good enough to carry Governor Cuomo into the White House!
 
LESLIE H. AULT
Closter, N.J., Jan. 4, 1991

HEADLINE: 'Africa-Centered' Proposal Outlined for a Trial School

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
In considering a plan for a high school for black and Hispanic boys, the Board of Education appears to be embarking on a far-reaching experiment to promote racial and cultural pride and transform what some see as the European slant of traditional instruction.
A 21-page proposal circulating privately among board officials shows that the school, the Ujamaa Institute, is intended to be "Africa-centered" and would cultivate "Seven Principles" distilled from traditional African values, including unity, collective responsibility, economic cooperation, creativity and faith. 
 "To believe with all our heart in our parents, our teachers, our leaders, our people and the righteousness and victory of our struggle," is the way the proposal defines the principle of faith.
The school's American history course, the proposal says, would be taught "from an African-American frame of reference," and foreign-language study would include Swahili and Yoruba in addition to Spanish. A majority of teachers would be black men, a feature that has been frowned upon by the United Federation of Teachers.
 
A Separatist Outlook
 While some teachers have long woven black and African history and culture into the standard curriculum, there are few if any publicly financed schools that have have made such instruction the heart of their identity.
The proposed school could open as early as next fall, with 300 to 400 students, on the campus of Medgar Evers College in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.
Critics say the Ujamaa school would provide indoctrination, not education. They warn that it would foster a separatist outlook among young black males and hostility toward whites.
"They're trying to use our public schools to build and maintain racial unity, to foster so-called black self-determination and to expand the racial ghetto to develop cadres of politically correct thinking, ethnocentric, breast-beating racial braggarts," said Michael Meyers, a New Jersey state education official.
Mr. Meyers is director of the New York Civil Rights Coalition, which includes the New York Civil Liberties Union and 21 other groups. He says the proposal is full of myths and half-truths and calls it "fashionable, rhetorical and racist."
 
'All People Will Be Welcome'
 Basir Mchawi, whom Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez hired specifically to plan the experimental school, rejects such charges. He contends that the Ujamaa Institute would be a high school "in which all people will be welcome" and "will look at many cultures but do so from the perspective of African-American people." He said that when he used the term "our struggle" to explain the principle of faith, he intended it to apply to all humanity.
The very idea for Ujamaa seems to have turned the 1950's and 1960's quarrels over segregation on their heads. Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, whose research undergirded the 1954 United States Supreme Court's decision in Brown v. Board of Education rejecting "separate but equal" schools, says that even when segregation is sought by blacks it stigmatizes children and creates feelings of inferiority.
But Jawanza Kunjufu, a Chicago pioneer of the concept of schools for black boys, says urban schools are already segregated as a result of housing patterns, tracking practices and other factors. "So long as the class is already segregated, why not turn it into a class for winners?" he said.
The Ujamaa Institute would not exclude whites, Asians or females. But its raison d'etre is its concentration on young black and Hispanic males, though Hispanic boys seem to be mentioned only as an afterthought. Noting that black males are over represented in statistics on crime, drug abuse and dropout rates, the proposal says the school's strategy is to instill cultural pride in young men, create bonds among them, and inspire them with successful black adults.
"By emphasizing the special needs of the African-American male," the proposal says, "Ujamaa Institute acknowledges the fact that young African-American males have simultaneously become societal victims and victimizers."
The arguments over the school also offer a capsule version of the national debate over curriculum. Many critics attack social-studies instruction for concentrating on Western civilization. They can be broadly divided into two camps: multiculturalists, who think studies should be laced with contributions from many cultures, and Afrocentrists, who think that, for black students, the curriculum should stress the African and black American heritage.
The Mchawi proposal claims to be both Afrocentric and multicultural. Dr. Gwendolyn C. Baker, president of the Board of Education, who read the proposal, was flattering at a board meeting where Mr. Mchawi and Assemblyman Roger L. Green of Brooklyn presented the plan, but she insists on a school that is multicultural.
 
Seemed to Disown Proposal
 Complicating the debate is the role of Mr. Fernandez. He has often seemed to disown the proposal when reporters have inquired, yet he hired Mr. Mchawi to develop it. Before he came to work at the Board of Education, Mr. Mchawi, 41 years old, was a teacher and administrator at two independent schools in Brooklyn, Uhuru Sasa and Shule Ya Mapinduzi, both closed, that he says can serve as models for Ujamaa.
Mr. Fernandez, evidently hoping to minimize controversy, has never publicly released the Ujamaa proposal, but has issued his own memorandum that mentioned none of its Afrocentric features.
Yesterday, his press secretary, James S. Vlasto, said Mr. Mchawi was being asked to draft a new plan that he suggested might not contain some of the present elements.
Also at issue in the board's consideration of the proposal is Mr. Mchawi's long association with Robert (Sonny) Carson, a convicted kidnapper who helped organize the boycott of two Korean groceries and has said he is anti-white. Mr. Carson has also been a controversial figure in the Brooklyn public schools. Mr. Mchawi says they have never had a "working relationship."
 
Pythagorean Theorem?
 In his proposal, dated Dec. 14, Mr. Mchawi defines Africa-centered as meaning that "it is the African experience which forms the center of analysis."
"One of the problems with much existing curriculum is the perspective bias that is often imposed in texts that view European history and culture as the paradigm by which all human experience should be measured," it reads.
As an illustration, Mr. Mchawi said schools teach that the Pythagorean theorem was developed by the Greek mathematician Pythagoras. Mr. Mchawi asserted that knowledge of the theorem existed 1,000 years before Pythagoras, but that Alexander the Great sacked libraries in Egypt that might have attributed it to Africans.
The proposal has very little to say about conventional academic subjects. On biology, it says only that "attention will be given to great biological scientists from the African world such as Imhotep, Charles Drew and Daniel Hale Williams" and that students would focus on the effects of "certain behaviors on their bodies" such as smoking crack and surviving during pregnancy on "potato chips and Pepsi."
 
'The Quality of Life'
 "What you have before you is a concept," Mr. Mchawi said when asked why the plan was so skimpy on curricular details. He said the school would meet all state and city requirements for a diploma.
The Seven Principles, or Nguzo Saba, which also include self-determination and purpose, Mr. Mchawi said, were synthesized from traditional African values by a California professor, Dr. Maulana Karenga, in the 1960's. The proposal says they address "things that young people need to do to improve their personal lives and the quality of life in their community."
Mr. Mchawi denied that the Principles might make white, Hispanic or Asian pupils feel excluded. "We talk about the universality of the Ten Commandments," he said. "It doesn't mean that it wouldn't be applicable to other people."

A picture yesterday with an article about a proposed high school for black and Hispanic young men was published in error. It showed Dr. Edison O. Jackson, president of Medgar Evers College, not Basir Mchawi, who was hired to plan the school.
