HEADLINE: Washington Offers Mountain of Debt To Save Forests

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
COULD foreign debt be the lever that moves poor countries to save their rain forests? President Bush apparently thinks so. The White House is backing a bold program to channel billions of dollars that Latin American governments owe Washington into local conservation projects.
"Debt for nature" swaps are not new. Private groups are already busy raising cash to buy up foreign debt, trading the I.O.U.'s back to the financially troubled debtors in return for commitments to acquire parks and conserve environmental resources in eight countries. 
 What is new is the possible addition of vast quantities of Government money to the pot -- and the prospect of a systematic, well-financed defense of tropical forests that serve as a natural sink for greenhouse gases and shelter the lion's share of the world's plant and animal species.
William Reilly, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency and the program's most influential champion, believes that a successful reshuffling of some $12 billion in foreign aid loans by the United States would mobilize $100 million a year for conservation projects. The approach could also serve as a model for European and Japanese governments, which carry another $38 billion in Latin American debt.
No less important is that the plan requires the participation of local environmentalists, who have often been excluded from decision-making. John Sawhill, the head of the Nature Conservancy, an active promoter of debt-for-nature swaps, argues that the resulting public-private partnerships could tilt local interests in favor of environmental protection.
The big question now is whether Washington, preoccupied by war in the Persian Gulf and recession at home, is sufficiently committed to the swap idea to plow through the political and financial obstacles. Much depends on the Administration's flexibility in determining which Latin debtors are eligible. For its part, Congress will either have to allow some creative accounting on the debt shuffle or will have to add new foreign aid money to the budget.
Thomas Lovejoy, an ecologist now at the Smithsonian Institution, dreamed up the idea of linking foreign debt relief to the financing of environmental projects in debtor nations in 1984. At the time, crushing foreign debts had led most poor countries to cut back on environmental protection. Why not wipe out part of the debts denominated in dollars and yen for commitments to spend cruzeiros and pesos on conservation?
But it was private organizations, not governments or commercial banks, that turned theory into practice. In the very first swap in 1987, Conservation International, an American group, paid $100,000 for an uncollectible $650,000 that Bolivia owed to Citicorp . The group then agreed to wipe out Bolivia's $650,000 debt in return for its promise to protect a 3.7-million-acre buffer around the Beni Biosphere Reserve and to spend the equivalent of $250,000 in local currency to manage the reserve. Since then, 14 other debt-for-nature swaps have been carried out, reducing external debts and protecting forests in Ecuador, Costa Rica, the Philippines, Madagascar, Zambia, the Dominican Republic and Poland.
Clever financing arrangements, along with the enthusiastic cooperation of environmentally sensitive governments, have magnified the effects of the $16 million investment far beyond initial expectations. But as Mr. Sawhill of the Nature Conservancy points out, dependence on charitable donations has limited the overall impact on the global environment to "peanuts." That is why environmental groups, led by the World Wildlife Fund in Washington, worked hard to make a case for Federal intervention.
They struck pay dirt last June when Mr. Bush included debt-for-nature swaps in his "Enterprise for the Americas" initiative, a broad effort to pare debt, liberalize trade and stimulate investment in Latin America and the Caribbean. In October, Congress authorized swaps for some $1.7 billion in debts incurred in the sales of subsidized food. The President is expected to ask that the swaps be extended to loans made by the United States Agency for International Development, as well as Export-Import Bank and Commodity Credit Corporation loans originally used to subsidize United States exports.
To be eligible, debtor countries will have to pass muster on a number of criteria -- what one environmental lobbyist calls the "flaming hoops." They must be actively working to make deals with their other big creditors, in particular the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the commercial banks. And they must open their borders to foreign investors on reasonable terms.
The carrot is substantial debt relief. The Administration is targeting a 50 percent write-off. Payments forgiven by the United States Treasury would be converted to local currencies and deposited in a national environmental funds.
The money could be used for anything from conservation training to restoration of the world's oceans and atmosphere. But outlays would be planned and supervised by boards that included private citizens nominated by the United States Government.
Many a slip is still possible. While environmental interests played a major role in passing the legislation, "different people in the Administration have different priorities," Mr. Sawhill noted.
Jamaica, Chile, Bolivia and Costa Rica all reportedly have advocates in the Administration, and will probably be the first to cut Enterprise for the Americas deals. But if the United States takes a hard line on debt arrears or foreign investment rules, environmentally critical countries like Brazil and Peru will not qualify anytime soon.
 
Possible Inflationary Effects
 Another worry is the host nations' receptivity. Debt-for-nature swaps on a large scale will require countries to reorder economic priorities. Unless governments cut back on other spending when they agree to spend more on the environment, the arrangement will be inflationary.
Outright rejection of swaps as an impingement on sovereignty, the position taken by Brazil's former President, Jose Sarney, is no longer fashionable in Latin America. Indeed, Latin American politicians seem more inclined to follow the lead of Costa Rica, which has touted debt-for-nature as a way to sustain jobs in tourism and develop agricultural techniques that will allow sustainable development.
It is still not clear, though, whether elected officials will buy the idea of independent boards, which could compete with established interests. "Will they really allow anybody outside the government to have guaranteed funding?" asked Lamond Godwin, a vice president at the American Express Bank who has served as an adviser on a number of private debt swaps.
Perhaps the most serious obstacle to swaps is the issue of how they will be treated in the Federal budget. The Administration expects to to arrange deals that maintain the level of payments to Washington that would otherwise be expected.
 
Issue of Budget Accounting
 Debtor countries would come out ahead, since they would no longer need to reschedule unpaid debts each year and would be able to liquidate their debts in a reasonable time frame. But since there would be no real loss of income to Washington, the Administration contends that there ought to be no effect on budget accounting.
If, for example, a country is now paying $1 million in principle plus $4 million in interest each year on an $80 million debt, it would go on writing annual checks to the United States Treasury for $5 million. But all the $5 million would be declared repayment of principle, allowing a far faster liquidation of the debt balance. The $4 million annual interest, converted to local currency, would go into the national environment fund.
This socially redeeming sleight-of-hand does not, however, sit well with the professionals who keep the books for Congress. Some want the Treasury to treat debt reduction the way a private creditor would write off a bad loan, taking a loss in the year the deal is signed. Congress would be obliged to appropriate funds to cover the paper loss, adding to the budget deficit.
That is not a problem in principle: if debt-for-nature swaps are worth doing, the logic goes, they are worth paying for. But as a practical matter it would probably torpedo large-scale swaps. "If there is a single budget item less popular than foreign assistance," said one senior Administration official, "I'm not aware of it."
 
Causes for Optimism

 
 Environmental groups are nonetheless optimistic. Many of their leaders believe that Mr. Bush is committed to their cause and is eager to offset his image as a proscrastinator on the problem of global warming. Moreover, there is no serious opposition to debt-for-nature swaps in Congress, and there probably will not be unless the plan runs afoul of the budget process.
Once off the ground, they believe, the initiatives will be imitated in Europe and Japan. Debt-for-nature provisions could also be routinely integrated into the rescheduling of hundreds of billions of dollars in debts owed to the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. If the optimists are right, the only practical limit on their scale will be good ideas for making conservation compatible with economic development.
 
Alchemy of a Debt-for-Nature Swap
 
In March 1990, the Development Trust of Puerto Rico, a charity, spent $116,400 to buy $582,000 worth of the outstanding debt of the Dominican Republic, owed to the Swiss Bank Corp-oration. The trust then donated the right to collect the debt to the Nature Conservancy in Washington
 
The Nature Conservancy then swapped this asset to the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic for $581,000 worth of local-currency bonds. These bonds, paying 12 percent interest, are held bythe Pronatura Fund, a consortium of Dominican conservatioon groups. The interest and principle support four projects, including a national park with the world's largest population of crocodiles.
 
Source: The Nature Conservancy

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
G.E. Sets Thorn Deal; Lamp Chief Is Chosen

BYLINE: By Daniel F. Cuff

 BODY:
The General Electric Company completed its deal yesterday to buy Thorn EMI P.L.C.'s $360 million European light bulb business and named David E. Momot to be president and chief executive of the newly created company, G.E.-Thorn Lamps Ltd.
Mr. Momot comes from a stint at the Genlyte Group, a maker of lighting fixtures, where he was president and chief executive, and which he joined in 1989. He is no stranger to G.E., having worked there for 30 years until 1989. 
 "We want to establish a larger presence in the European market and we will use the relationship with Thorn in support of that," Mr. Momot said yesterday.
He said G.E. would have "an enhanced position from a market standpoint," realizing the fruits of wider technology and economies of scale "by integrating the G.E., Thorn and Tungsram operations." Tungsram is a Hungarian lighting company that has been in a joint venture with G.E. since early last year.
Mr. Momot said the plan was to keep the Thorn and Tungsram brand names in Europe. Coincidentally, as G.E. was making its announcement of the Thorn purchase yesterday, it also announced the suspension of an upbeat G.E. television commercial that underscored the Tungsram tie and the emergence of democracy in Eastern Europe; it was inopportunely shown during a news program on Soviet crackdowns in the Baltics.
Mr. Momot said yesterday that the purchase of the Thorn light business would move G.E. from No. 5 to No. 3 in European market share. G.E. is making a cash payment of $57 million, the first installment of a $138 million sale price, payable over three years. G.E. will have a 51 percent interest and after three years Thorn's minority interest will transfer to G.E. Thorn is retaining its international business in light fixtures.
Mr. Momot, 54, is experienced in the fixture side of the business more than on the lamp side. He ran G.E.'s lighting fixtures division at Hendersonville, N.C., from 1984 to 1989 before leaving for Genlyte. Earlier, he worked in a number of G.E. assignments from motors to aerospace.
Mr. Momot is a graduate of the State University of New York Maritime College in the Bronx. After service as a naval officer he joined G.E. In his latest G.E. post Mr. Momot will be based in London, his first overseas assignment.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Texas Utility Concern Names New Chairman

BYLINE: By Daniel F. Cuff

 BODY:
The Central and South West Corporation, a big electric utility holding company based in Dallas, changed top managers yesterday and announced its 40th annual dividend increase.
"We're very proud of that," said the company's new chairman and chief executive, E. R. Brooks, known as Dick. "There are only three other corporations on the New York Stock Exchange with longer records." 
 Mr. Brooks, who has been with the company for 30 years, takes over on Feb. 1 from Merle L. Borchelt, who is retiring after 42 years there. Mr. Brooks was named president a year ago and will retain that title.
The company, based in Dallas, provides electricity for customers in Texas, Oklahoma, Louisiana and Arkansas. It has continued to increase its dividend as a matter of investor policy despite the region's economic difficulties, which have resulted in lower earnings, and a fight for rate relief for its $2.3 billion investment in a nuclear plant that has not yet produced a cash return.
Yesterday, the company announced a 14.5 percent income increase for last year and attributed it primarily to regulators' rulings, including the deferral of some carrying costs on the nuclear project
Mr. Brooks said that at age 53 he would have several years to tackle the utility's challenges. "We have what we think is a good strategic plan," he said. Future growth in earnings and dividends depends on how the company invests its cash during the years ahead, but Mr. Brooks said he did not plan to go far afield.
"We would never diversify outside of our core business," he said. "Almost anything not regulated would probably be more competitive than we would be able to be nimble with." The company, he said, passed up an opportunity to buy MCI, the long-distance telephone company, several years ago, and although MCI is now huge, Mr. Brooks said the utility probably did the right thing.
Mr. Brooks stressed "good conservative management," adding, "We know what we're doing in the core business."
The company said Mr. Brooks had been identified early as a chief executive candidate by Mr. Borchelt and Durwood Chalker, Mr. Borchelt's predecessor.
When he graduated from high school in the West Texas town of Slaton, Mr. Brooks said his ambition was to be an engineer, a classical pianist or a football coach. He choose electrical engineering at Texas Tech University and gradauted in 1961, joining the utility that year. As for the piano, he still plays for fun.

HEADLINE: The Spy Who Went Into Retailing

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGLEBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW

 BODY:
Marian Zacharski has a finely tuned sense of irony, and he ought to. A decade ago, he was sentenced by an American court to life in prison, a Polish agent who paid a high penalty for stealing military secrets. Today, six years after his release in a spy exchange, he is a leading businessman in Poland, director of this country's most profitable retailer.
"Each day, all that is becoming more distant," Mr. Zacharski said of his years as a foot soldier in the cold war in the guise of a sales representative for a Polish machine-tools company. "History has moved forward. I owe a lot to America. If I've become a seasoned businessman, it was because of the years I spent in America. It was my university of life." 
 With his perfectly coiffed gray hair, starched white shirt and lightly accented colloquial English, Mr. Zacharski epitomizes Poland's new breed of Westward-looking entrepreneurs. While competitors struggle to cope with the new principles of free-market economics, he has a sure grasp of his marketing strategy. He wants to emulate J. C. Penney, not K Mart, and hopes to build relationships with customers eager to buy previously scarce consumer goods.
The state-owned company he heads, Pewex, was the nationwide chain of stores that sold imported items for dollars, German marks, or other hard currency. It is being privatized and today, with the border open to imports, Pewex accepts payment in Polish zlotys.
Sitting in his office on the 12th floor of the Marriott Hotel in downtown Warsaw, Mr. Zacharski speaks confidently of prospects for doubling gross sales this year, to $2 billion. One advertising gambit he plans has a distinctly Western flavor: Pewex is playing host to a tour this spring by the American figure skating troupe the Ice Capades. Mr. Zacharski says the company must diversify to maintain market share.
American intelligence officials remember Mr. Zacharski for skills other than his marketing acumen. To them, he was the ultimate professional. His prowess in recruiting a disgruntled engineer at Hughes Aircraft as his American agent is still studied at the F.B.I. academy as a textbook example of how a resourceful spy plies his trade.
 
'Very Talented'
 "I knew he was very talented, and I was convinced he was a very talented spy," said Robert Brewer, a private lawyer in San Diego who prosecuted Mr. Zacharski in 1981. "I'm not a bit surprised that whatever venture he got involved in, he would succeed."
Indeed, Mr. Zacharski is a rarity among intelligence operatives East or West in his ability to prosper in a subsequent career. The attributes of a capable spy -- grace under pressure, personal charm, daring -- would seem to be ideal for business executives. But the United States has had enormous difficulty helping defectors from Soviet and Eastern bloc intelligence services find work in the West. And today, intelligence agents dismissed by the new democracies in eastern Germany, Czechoslovakia and Poland are also said to be struggling to find an employer who can make use of their abilities.
From 1977 until his arrest in 1981, Mr. Zacharski worked as what is known in espionage jargon as an "illegal." It is considered the riskiest job in the spy business.
 
Some Face Prison
 Most intelligence officers enter foreign countries as diplomats who enjoy immunity from arrest. They are closely watched by counterespionage agents and if caught are simply deported. To avoid surveillance, some spies pose as students, tourists or business executives. Their handlers work particularly hard at inventing credible cover stories because these illegals face imprisonment if detected.
In Mr. Zacharski's case, his cover as a sales representative for a Polish company was as much a vocation as spycraft. He recalled with evident pride his success in selling machine tools to American companies.
He was more circumspect about details of his espionage career, declining to say when and how he was enlisted. But it was still easy to see why he was both a successful spy and a formidable salesman. He fixes a visitor with his light blue eyes, and he has a knack for creating a warm, congenial atmosphere even in a short conversation.
 
'Like a Game'
 What was it like to be a spy?
"It's something in which you have to turn your emotions off," he recalled. "It's a job, and the same time, it's something like a game between certain types of agencies."
Mr. Zacharski grew up in the northern Polish city of Sopot, and attended college in Warsaw, studying business. At some point, he was enlisted in the Polish intelligence service, which was working closely with Soviet intelligence to steal Western technology.
"I consider myself a great patriot," Mr. Zacharski said of his decision to become a spy. "To me it makes no difference whether Poland is Socialistic, Communist or a feudal country. To me, it's that it was Poland. My country is Poland and I do everything possible for it."
Mr. Zacharski came to the United States in 1975, accompanied by his wife and daughter.
For several years, he worked as president of the Polish American Machinery Corporation, with headquarters in Elk Grove Village, Ill.
 
The Personal Touch
 Listen to how Mr. Zacharski describes the attributes of a great salesman: "Business is not done between companies. It's done between people. Before you sell your product, you have to sell yourself."
Mr. Zacharski was doing both in the United States. In 1978, he met William Holden Bell, an aerospace engineer at Hughes Aircraft in El Segundo, Calif., who was embittered and having financial problems. Mr. Zacharski moved into the condominium complex in which Mr. Bell lived, befriended him, played tennis with him and slowly eased him into espionage.
"This was a classic case in which an intelligence officer correctly assessed his target. Mr. Bell needed a friend and Zacharski just recruited him beautifully," said Kenneth Degraffenreid, former head of intelligence programs at the White House.
Over the next three years, prosecutors said, Mr. Bell was paid more than $110,000 for secrets on military radar systems, including the technology for the radar-evading Stealth aircraft then under development. In 1981, he was caught by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, confessed, and agreed to wear a hidden microphone to entrap Mr. Zacharski. The plan succeeded, and the handsome Polish emigre was arrested on June 28, 1981.
 
A Life Sentence
 Mr. Bell was sentenced to eight years. Mr. Zacharski went before a Federal judge for his punishment on Dec. 14, 1981, a particularly inauspicious moment. The day before, Poland's Communist Government had imposed martial law. Mr. Zacharski said the life sentence was not a surprise.
Though he would not have been eligible for parole until June 2011, he said he never gave up hope. He asserts that his biggest worry was whether he could get a job when he returned to Poland. In 1985, he and three other agents were traded for 25 spies being held in Eastern bloc countries. Months later, the Government named him to a post in Pewex and he soon went to work as head of the consumer electronics division. He became general director last year.
It is not yet clear whether he will head Pewex when the company is sold into private hands. Mr. Zacharski says he has the qualifications, pointing to a 74 percent increase in sales last year.
 
Political Concerns
 Of late, Mr. Zacharski's prominence has attracted some unwanted political attention. Lech Walesa, the new President of Poland, ran on a platform of sweeping the Communist elite, or "nomenklatura," from posts in business and industry. Though Mr. Zacharski was appointed to Pewex by the Communist Government, he was chosen director in a competition last year.
He was recently the subject of an unflattering article in Tygodnik Solidarnosc, the weekly paper with close ties to the Walesa camp. The article recounted published reports linking Mr. Zacharski's operations in the United States to the Soviet intelligence service, the K.G.B.
"They are trying to create an atmosphere that I am a foreign object in this country, and this is complete nonsense," he said.
These days, Mr. Zacharski seems to have little nostalgia for his years in the back alleys.
"No, I don't miss it," he said. "At a certain point in your life you do certain things. At that point in my life, I was young and brave. Now, I am old and settled," said the 39-year old Mr. Zacharski, with only the hint of a twinkle in his eye.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Marian Zacharski, Pewex director, who epitomizes Poland's new breed of Westward-looking entrepreneurs. (Withold Jaroslaw Szulecki for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Mexico City Journal;
Down the Years, a Father Hunts His Stolen Son

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Gil Abeyta's interest in Mexico was set in motion on July 15, 1986, while he and his wife were asleep at their home in Colorado Springs. Sometime that night, Mr. Abeyta says, a stranger entered the unlocked house and stole his 7-month-old son, Christopher, who has not been seen again.
In the four and a half years since then, Mr. Abeyta and his wife, Bernice, have crisscrossed the United States in search of their missing child, badgering police officials, hiring private detectives, and following up hundreds of reported sightings that offered hope of finding their son. 
 But their search has come to focus increasingly on Mexico, where they believe Christopher may have been hidden or even sold for adoption beyond the reach of American authorities, and where their personal quest has now broadened into a public crusade on behalf of Mexico's own missing and abandoned children.
In a countrywide tour of Mexican towns, villages and regional capitals, Mr. Abeyta and his small, privately financed caravan of family members, friends and Mexican supporters have become a traveling political lobby.
 
A Void in the System
 They have brought pressure on local authorities, organized a network of private citizens in more than 30 cities to investigate sightings of missing children, and publicized what they say is the need for a comprehensive agreement between the United States and Mexico on the joint investigation and resolution of missing children cases.
"I came here looking for my son," Mr. Abeyta said, meeting with a reporter at a modest Mexico City hotel that has served as his base of operations in the capital. "But what I found was a void in the system between Mexico and the United States on this issue. There were no treaties, no agreements, no kind of support."
Like other third-world countries, Mexico has long suffered from the problems of neglected or abandoned children whose impoverished parents cannot afford to care for them. In addition, the long border with the United States, where there is high demand for adoption-age children, has made Mexico a prime suspect as a source of illegal traffic in infants who are bought and sold for adoption in the United States and Europe.
Mexican officials say the scale of that clandestine trade is difficult to measure with any certainty. But residents of poor neighborhoods throughout the country frequently describe relatives and friends who they say have given up unwanted newborns in return for payments of as much as $10,000 from illegal adoption brokers.
 
Talk Too of Smugglers
 Anecdotal evidence also abounds of coyotes, or black-market agents, who operate from northern Mexico and will buy -- or steal -- adoption-age babies on either side of the border to fill specific requests from prospective adoptive parents.
The potential involvement of such smugglers, together with repeated reports from local citizens who believed that they had recognized Christopher from press and television coverage of Mr. Abeyta's loss, first brought Mr. Abeyta to the northern Mexican state of Chihuahua two years ago in search of new clues to his son's disappearance.
Mr. Abeyta, who quit his job as a Federal labor official to devote full time to the search for his son, says that trip failed to provide direct new evidence for locating Christopher. But he says the number of abandoned and neglected children he encountered -- together with local accounts of child-trafficking -- convinced him that Mexico was a critical element in a larger problem of missing and abducted children.
"At first, if a child was not Christopher, I would just forget him and move on," said Mr. Abeyta, 48, who learned Spanish as a child from his Spanish-immigrant parents. "But I kept running into other questionable children that had no identity, no history, that had been abandoned in Chihuahua, and appeared to be from the United States."
"Some had apparently been left with relatives or friends, but no one knew where they had come from," Mr. Abeyta said. "The issue was that they were kids that did not fit into the place where they were living."
 
Strong Backing From Officials
 Although some Mexican officials remain highly sensitive about allegations of child trafficking in their country, Mr. Abeyta's overtures have received strong support from many Government figures, particularly in Mexico City, where local officials recently established the nation's first agency dedicated exclusively to finding the whereabouts of missing people.
"We have the deepest respect for Mr. Abeyta's efforts and are doing everything we can to help," said Hernan Figueroa Cal y Mayor, the director of the capital's new Center for Aiding Lost and Missing Persons, who has been a vigorous supporter of Mr. Abeyta's work. "This is the sort of thing where no one is going to stand in his way."
Mr. Abeyta says the goal of his efforts is to establish the kind of smooth cooperation on such issues that already exists between the United States and other countries such as Canada. Although most missing-child cases in the United States are handled by the police and private groups, a special federally financed agency, the Center for Missing and Exploited Children, was created in 1984 to coordinate information and publicity about missing children.
Among the most important steps to be taken, Mr. Abeyta argues, would be the expansion of local efforts like Mr. Figueroa's agency to give Mexico an analogous national institution dedicated to missing children. Such an agency, he asserts, could then oversee the establishment of cooperative information networks to track missing children on both sides of the border, and regular exchanges of police information.
 
Other Measures Suggested
 Other measures, he said, would include the tightening of immigration restrictions at border crossings to prevent the undetected smuggling of small children, most of whom now pass unchallenged as long as they are with an adult.
Those goals, Mr. Abeyta admits, are likely to take some time to become a reality. But each step toward their realization, he believes, can only bring him closer to finding Christopher, whose memory has propelled the entire undertaking.
"When you lose a child like this," said Mr. Abeyta, who has six other children, "it's like a movie projector starts running in your head. You can't stop imagining what might have happened, where he might be."
"There is only one way to turn that projector off," he said, "and that is to find him."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
A System to Speed Computer Data

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
From a computer-filled trailer next to the Tampa stadium where the Super Bowl will be played on Sunday, photographs taken on the field will be relayed over telephone lines to newspapers in two minutes. That is about 10 times faster than has been possible in the past.
The system that rapidly sends photographs is only one of many new products emerging now that technical experts have agreed on a standard method for condensing computer images for faster transmission and more economical storage. The method, which blends sophisticated software with powerful specialized chips, squeezes the series of zeroes and ones that represent computerized images into far fewer bits of information so that the data take much less time to send. The method permits the condensed data to be reconstructed after arriving at their destination with no visible loss in quality. 
 Just as an internationally accepted standard for compressing facsimile images spawned mass production that drove down the price of facsimile machines, the internationally accepted standard for compressing the more complex images stored in computers is expected to encourage the introduction of a variety of inexpensive consumer products. They will feature high-resolution color images that can be stored, retrieved and manipulated. Such products include not only improved newsphoto transmission systems but also video telephones, facsimile machines, copiers and printers that will be able to send and edit images as simply as text, and television-computer hybrids that allow the viewer to edit images much as today's word processors edit text.
"The big shift is from today's analog television to digital images," said Andrew Lippman, associate director of the Media Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, Mass. "Television is learning the language of the computer."
A simple compression method is already used in high-speed facsimile transmission systems. Without compression it would take nearly an hour to transmit a simple 8 1/2-by-11-inch sheet of paper. But the internationally accepted Group III facsimile standard replaces blank lines with a short code that indicates that the line is empty. Other lines can be compressed by being encoded as lengths of black and white spaces.
The new standard for compressing digital images is already in commercial use and will be formally released in March. It was developed by an international standards group known as the Joint Photographic Expert Group, or JPEG. Later this year a second standard for full-motion digital video will be defined by a parallel group, the Motion Picture Expert Group, or MPEG. The MPEG standard is expected to offer image compression in ratios exceeding 100 to 1, making it possible to store and retrieve more than an hour of video images on a single compact disk.
 
How It Works
 The internationally accepted JPEG compression system works this way: A color image is converted into rows of dots, called pixels. each with a numerical value that represents brightness and color. The picture is then broken down into blocks, each 16 pixels by 16 pixels, and then reduced to 8 pixels by 8 by subtracting every other pixel. The software uses a formula that computes an average value for each block, permitting it to be represented with less data. Further steps subtract even more information from the image. To retrieve the data, the process is simply reversed to decompress the image.
A specialized chip compresses and decompresses the images hundreds of times faster than is possible on a standard desktop computer.
MPEG offers even greater compression by taking advantage of the fact that full-motion video is made up of a sequence of still images. Because many successive frames consist of large areas that are not changed -- like a blue sky background -- it is possible to reach far higher levels of compression.
But the current MPEG standard will lack some of the flexibility of the JPEG standard, which treats each image separately and therefore makes editing easier. Some companies, like Supermac Technology in Sunnyvale, Calif., see JPEG as an ideal standard for creating full-motion digital editing systems that permit computers to capture television video and store and edit the images on large Winchester or erasable optical disks. Current video-editing systems permit users to capture only single images.
 
'A Huge Bottleneck'
 Sophisticated compression standards are necessary if the promise of high-resolution digital video is to be realized, industry executives say.
"There is a huge bottleneck to working with images as opposed to working with text," said Robert R. Tillman, president of Storm Technology, a Palo Alto, Calif., company making products that use JPEG.
Consider the staggering storage requirements of a single color picture. A standard full-color digital image displayed on an I.B.M.-compatible computer requires about a million characters of computer text, or one megabyte, of storage capacity on the computer's disk. By contrast, the novel "Moby Dick" requires only 1.3 million characters.
The problem is exponentially compounded for engineers hoping to display full-motion video on a computer screen. To display 30 frames each second -- the rate needed to achieve smooth motion -- two billion bytes of storage are needed for a single minute of video.
The storage problem is even worse for color printing applications. Printing an 8 1/2-by-11-inch color picture at a resolution of 300 dots an inch, which is typical for an office laser printer, would require more than 25 million bytes of disk storage space.
Today's standard office personal computers generally come equipped with hard disk drives that store 20 to 40 megabytes. That is adequate for most text-only computer applications, but too little for the new class of graphics and color-image programs.
 
Licensing Agreement
 Last month the JPEG standard took a significant step toward broad acceptance for both specialized graphics and standard office applications when Adobe Systems Inc., publisher of the Postscript printer language, announced that it was licensing the JPEG compression software technology from Storm Technology.
Postscript is a standard computer printer language widely used in the desktop and higher-quality publishing industries. After Adobe adds the JPEG software to a future version of its Postscript, it will greatly ease the burden of sending large computer files in the Postscript format to computer printers.
Moreover, some computer companies like Next Inc. have begun to add to their machines chips built expressly to run the JPEG software. Next is using a custom JPEG processor made by C-Cube Inc. of San Jose, Calif.
The JPEG standard permits the user to select the degree of compression, and therefore how close to the original the decompressed image will appear.
At Sunday's Super Bowl, five newspapers, including The New York Times, will cooperate in using a system to digitize photos taken during the game. The pictures will then be run through the JPEG compression process and transmitted by modem to the newspaper offices. The new process will save two hours for newspapers on the East Coast, which will be closer to their production deadlines when the game is played, said Steven P. Schaffran, president of the Color Group, an Albany, Calif., company that is coordinating the process.
 
Making Digital Images Easier to Store and Send
 
Digitized images take up an enormous amount of computer memory. A 4-by-5-inch photograph being prepared for newspaper publication takes up hundreds of thousands of bytes of information, making transmission slow and difficult. JPEG, a new standard for compressing digitized images, reduces the information in such photographs and keeps the loss of visual quality at a minimum.
 
Photographs are composed of many tiny dots, called pixels. In a digitized color photograph, each pixel contains shade and brightness information, represented numerically. JPEG works by dividing the image into blocks of pixels, then assigning each block several numbers that describe its characteristics. This eliminates the need to process the image pixel by pixel.
 
Some pixels are removed from a block to reduce the information it contains. The amount of data removed depends on the amount of compression desired.
 
To further compress the image, each block is given a base value, shown here in the upper left hand corner by the letter B. All other pixels in the block are then assigned numbers that describe their shade and brightness in relations to the base value. In later steps, these values are simplified mathematically, but remain proportional. The loss of detail is minimal, because enough information about shade and brightness variations within the block is maintained.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Charity Begins In Washington

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
DECEMBER, the peak month for philanthropy, is history. And when the figures are totaled, 1990 will almost certainly prove to have been another record year for giving: By the reckoning of the American Association of Fund Raising Counsel, contributions in real terms have risen in 26 of the last 34 years.
Lest one grow too comfortable in the glow from a thousand points of light, consider this unsettling discovery by Ralph L. Nelson, an economist at Queens College in New York: Adjusted for rising incomes and a handful of other factors, Americans' inclination to give appears to have declined sharply over the last few decades. 
 The charitable explanation, favored by philanthropy professionals, is that sharp cuts in the tax benefits associated with contributions have discouraged giving. But Mr. Nelson argues it is possible, even likely, that the sense of private obligation to the commonweal is eroding.
Giving in 1989 totaled $115 billion, a 173 percent increase in real terms over donations in 1955, the association said in its annual report. Some $54 billion went to religious organizations, which used much of the cash to support churches and parochial schools -- endeavors that are not everyone's idea of philanthropy. But the residual $61 billion in non-religious contributions, triple the 1955 figure, still looks impressive.
Or does it? In spite of the fact that Americans are far richer than they were in the 1950's, the percentage of their incomes going to charity has hardly budged. In 1958, contributions represented 2.09 percent of G.N.P. -- a bit less than the 2.19 percent figure in 1989, a bit more than the 1.99 percentin 1985. Mr. Nelson uses an econometric model to explain why.
The model, updated last year for "Giving USA," the Fund Raising Counsel's annual report, confirms that total contributions are positively related to total personal income, the size of the population in the prime giving age group, 35 to 64, and stock market prices near the end of the year. The political party occupying the White House seems to matter, too: Americans are a bit more generous when Republicans are in power.
No great surprises there. What may surprise is that Mr. Nelson also isolated an independent downward trend in giving that has offset much of the gain that might have been expected as Americans got rich. If income growth were to stagnate, the equation suggests that contributions would actually fall by about 3.4 percent annually.
What could account for this inclination to selfishness? Tax rates surely influence giving. The lower the tax bracket, the smaller the tax savings associated with an extra dollar in donations. And top rates have indeed fallen sharply: In 1948, the taxpayers in the top bracket kept just 18 cents of the last dollar earned, while in 1989 they were allowed to keep 67 cents.
Uncle Sam, in effect, used to match an $18 gift to charity with $82 of its own. Last year, with the maximum tax bracket down to just 33 percent, a sacrifice of $18 in private spending power evoked a government match of about $9.
But taxes are apparently only a part of the explanation. Back in 1975 the Harvard economist Martin Feldstein estimated that the rising "tax price" of giving at most accounted for a 1.4 percent annual downward trend -- less than half the decline isolated in the Nelson equation. And to Steven Knack, an economist at the University of Maryland, the implication is clear: Americans' sense that they are obliged, as individuals, to care for the community is slipping.
One reason they feel less obliged is that they have created a welfare state to meet their collective obligations. Few Americans, surely, would prefer to return to the bad old days, when the unemployed depended on the Salvation Army for hot soup and Uncle Ed lived in the spare bedroom because he had no pension. But there could be a serious price to pay for this apparent erosion of communal values.
Well-run government may be able to manage the basics -- feeding the hungry, caring for the sick, educating the illiterate. But it is never going to be up to the task of giving the needy a sense of belonging. And it is by nature a better caretaker than an innovator able to adjust quickly to devastating new plagues like teen-age pregnancy.
The subtler problem is that the private and public welfare states may prove to be complements rather than substitutes: If the impulse to private charity is eroding, support for public charity may not be far behind. That is only speculation, of course. But taxpayers' reluctance to cope with homelessness and drug abuse -- even to pay to fill the potholes -- is hardly reassuring.

HEADLINE: Panama Canal a Worry to Shippers

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA, Jan. 22

 BODY:
International maritime officials are expressing concern that the condition of the Panama Canal is slowly deteriorating and that Panama will be unable to manage the waterway properly when it takes full control in 1999.
The 1977 Carter-Torrijos Treaties envisioned a gradual transition in management of the canal from American to Panamanian hands with no loss in efficiency or security. But an increasing array of troubles is raising the question of whether a developing country with a population and economy smaller than many American cities can be expected to run one of the most complex engineering enterprises in the world. 
 "Efficiency has dropped constantly over the last 10 years," said a Panamanian shipping agent who asked not to be identified. "The perception of the world shipping community is that service is deficient."
 
Still an Important Link
 The 51.2-mile canal is no longer vital to the United States Navy, but it remains an important link for trade between Latin America, the United States, Asia and Europe. It carries 5 percent of the world's ocean-going commerce, a figure that could increase considerably if the war in the Persian Gulf increases insurance rates for shippers who would otherwise use the Suez Canal.
The potential for a future breakdown of service opens the possibility that Panama and the United States may have to renegotiate parts of the canal treaties to guarantee some American role in the management and protection of the waterway into the next century.
The canal railroad and ports, which have been in Panamanian hands for more than a decade, are in an advanced stage of decay. The canal locks, while still managed by a United States Government agency, are also showing growing signs of disrepair.
"Its not the same canal in terms of efficiency and safety that it was when I came here 12 years ago," said Gerard Petroni, an American canal pilot.
 
Growing Malfunctions
 As he guided the Columbus Australia, a German container ship sailing from Philadelphia to New Zealand loaded with cosmetics and frozen onion rings, through the Pedro Miguel Locks, Mr. Petroni complained about growing delays because of malfunctions of the water gates and of the locomotives that pull the ships through the locks.
"I can't remember one transit in the last two years that has happened without something going wrong," he said.
Mr. Petroni said the rotting away of rubber and wooden guards on the sides of the locks were responsible for a number of minor accidents, including the denting of ships that cost $50,000 and more to fix.
The Panama Canal Commission is currently headed by a Panamanian administrator, but it remains a United States Government agency with a board of directors whose majority is American. The agency, along with the entire canal, will be transfered to the Panamanian Government at noon Dec. 31, 1999.
 
Maintenance Is Criticized
 "Maintenance is a word the Panamanian Government has never heard of," complained Adrian Holmes, operations manager of C. D. Fenton, one of the largest shipping agencies here. "The port pilings are deteriorating, causing more ship accidents all the time. The oil pipelines off the docks are leaking. The launches are in bad repair. The railroad is useless."
Mr. Holmes said his customers, which include Mobil, Dole, and Star Shipping, may decide to phase out use of the canal and use the railroad "landbridge" across the continental United States instead. Decreasing traffic would mean disaster for the Panamanian economy, and force Panama to increase tolls for other shipping.
Panama City has yet to plan its final takeover of the waterway. Canal workers have been left wondering whether the Panamanian Government will retain their salary scales and benefits, which are far higher than Government workers enjoy. Young educated Panamanians who might otherwise have chosen to work at the canal are selecting more certain career paths.
 
Earlier Government Blamed
 President Guillermo Endara says his Government will begin to concentrate on current and future canal operations in the coming months.
"The international maritime community has had a very bad experience because of the past autocratic government," Mr. Endara conceded. "We inherited the ports and railroad in such bad shape that we are having trouble getting them back in shape. We need a lot of money and equipment, because the equipment was not maintained and was stolen. We can't change that overnight."
Mr. Endara pledged that "with democracy, we will be able to manage the canal." But he said Panama would need substantial technical and financial support from the United States and Japan to do the job.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Trading Is Bolstered By News on Rates and War

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most foreign currencies yesterday on signs that the Federal Reserve will not aggressively lower interest rates and worries that the Persian Gulf war may be escalating.
Against the German currency, the dollar closed at 1.4950 marks, up from 1.4925 on Monday. Against the Japanese currency, it closed at 132.30 yen, up from 131.95 on Monday. 
 The Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, told a Congressional committee that the initial economic shock of the gulf crisis had largely worked its way through the economy but added that an aggressive lowering of interest rates could be "counterproductive."
"He'll ease if he has to, but he doesn't see the need at the moment," said David Wilson of Girozentrale New York.
Lower rates usually hurt the dollar because investors can get more return in other curencies.
Traders had speculated that the Fed would be more active in pushing down interest rates to revive the economy.
In testimony before the House Budget Committee, Mr. Greenspan also warned of the dangers of further dollar declines. He said a lower dollar added to inflation pressures and might contribute to instability in financial markets.
While the comments of the Fed chairman initially helped the dollar yesterday, the United States currency rose further after Iraq fired missiles against Israel.
The dollar is a traditional safe holding for investors during war.
The British pound closed at $1.9455, down from $1.9565 on Monday. The dollar ended at 1.2590 Swiss francs, up from Monday's 1.2510. The dollar closed at 1.1585 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1595 on Monday. It closed at 5.0840 French francs, up from 5.0575 on Monday.

HEADLINE: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: EUROPE;
Baltic Assaults Lead Europeans To Hold Off Aid

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 22

 BODY:
In the strongest Western response to date, the European Parliament blocked a $1 billion European Community food-aid package for the Soviet Union today to protest the crackdown by Moscow against pro-independence groups in the Baltic republics.
The 12-nation community, which on Monday night suspended a high-level meeting with Soviet trade officials scheduled for later this week, also announced that it would slow execution of a $550 million technical assistance agreement with Moscow after the latest violence in Latvia. 
 "We have to make the Soviets see that their behavior cannot be accepted," said Jean-Jacques Kasel, a senior Foreign Ministry official from Luxembourg, which currently holds the rotating presidency of the community.
 
Human Rights Complaint Planned
 Mr. Kasel, who said individual European governments could also announce sanctions against Moscow, added that the community would file a formal human rights complaint against the Soviet Union in the framework of the 34-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe.
In a separate move, France and Germany, which have already condemned the killing of at least four people by Soviet Interior Ministry troops in Latvia on Sunday, announced they were making a "joint approach" to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev with a view to promoting a dialogue between Moscow and the Baltic republics.
But the clearest political message today came from the Budget Committee of the 518-member European Parliament, which withheld approval of food aid for the Soviet Union after Moscow repeatedly ignored community appeals that it temper its hard-line policy toward Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia.
The committee's chairman, Alain Lamassoure, said the aid package would be reconsidered at the next session of Parliament, in Strasbourg in late February. "The repression in the Baltics has made it impossible for the Parliament to take an immediate decision," he told reporters.
 
U.S. Offer Stands
 The European Parliament has no authority to veto the aid package since it was approved by community leaders. But by exercising its right to discuss all international accords, it chose to postpone the debate as a way of signaling its disapproval of Moscow's recent behavior.
The United States offer of up to $1 billion in credit guarantees for the purchase of agricultural commodities by the Soviet Union remains in effect. That offer was announced Dec. 12 by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. A bill submitted last Friday by several Republican senators would suspend those guarantees pending certification by President Bush that the Soviet threat to the Baltics had ceased.
Questioned in Washington today on whether the Bush Administration supported the European Parliament move, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said, "If the E.C. judges that's the best way they can do it, I suspect we would support them, although we have historically been concerned about using food as a weapon."
While the community has agreed to "go slow" on dispensing aid to the Soviet Union, however, it is apparent that the 12 member governments have not agreed on what, if any, further action should be taken. Denmark is pressing for economic sanctions, while France and Germany favor a more flexible stance.
Last April, President Francois Mitterrand and Chancellor Helmut Kohl played an informal mediating role in the Baltic crisis when they sent a joint letter urging Lithuanian leaders to slow their campaign for independence to avert an open clash with Moscow.
 
Keeping Lines Open
 Now, by making their "joint approach" to Moscow, the two leaders reportedly want to warn that continued Soviet repression in the Baltic republics could sour East-West relations. By not joining calls for sanctions against Moscow, though, they are also keeping open their lines of communication to Mr. Gorbachev.
Through the European Community, France and Germany have nonetheless made it clear that the killing of at least 15 people in Lithuania last week and any further violence in the Baltics would threaten economic cooperation agreements with the Soviet Union.
Among the options available to the community are the suspension of numerous programs, including the $550 million technical assistance agreement and a $680 million food credit. The community had said it would not halt $330 million worth of emergency food aid, but this has now been blocked by the European Parliament.
So far, the strongest demand for sanctions against Moscow has come from Denmark which, along with its Scandinavian partners, feels both geographically and culturally close to the Baltic republics. Denmark has formally proposed that the community suspend all its aid programs to the Soviet Union.
"We cannot accept that Soviet troops attack the legally elected authorities in the Baltic states," Prime Minister Poul Schluter said today. "No one knows exactly who gave the orders, but one thing is clear: the responsibility rests with the top leadership."

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: ISRAEL;
Israel Asks U.S. for Extra $13 Billion

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Basking in warm praise from Washington for its sacrifice and restraint since the gulf war began, Israel today presented the United States with the bill: $13 billion.
Explaining the figures during a meeting this morning with Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger, Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai said $3 billion was compensation for actual and expected damages to Israel caused by the war and $10 billion was additional aid needed to resettle Soviet Jewish immigrants. 
 "We are expecting two types of aid" spread over the next five years, Mr. Modai said: direct economic assistance as well as loan and investment guarantees.
 
'Our Needs Are Very Clear'
 "Of course we are suffering," said Yossi Achimier, a spokesman for Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. "Our needs are very clear, and we expect we will be helped by the Americans."
This afternoon, Israeli officials said they believed they had a reasonable chance of winning at least a significant part of this additional aid because they had heeded the American request not to retalitate for Iraqi missile attacks. But after the deadly missile attack on Tel Aviv tonight, it seemed much less certain that Israel would be able to remain restrained.
Mr. Shamir's office said the Prime Minister would meet with Mr. Eagleburger on Wednesday to discuss the missile attack. Mr. Eagleburger and several other American officials are here to coordinate the two nations' approaches to the gulf war.
Israeli officials said Mr. Modai's presentation today was not a formal request because the numbers are not firm. Mr. Modai suggested that Israel may in fact need more.
The United States Embassy said the request was received without promise or comment. An official noted that any appropriation of that scale would have to be approved by Congress.
If all or part of the aid package is approved, it would be only one part of a range of physical, monetary, political and emotional benefits Israel is receiving after the Iraqi missile attacks and Israel's decision not to retaliate, at least for now.
Mr. Eagleburger's warm words for Israel at a news conference on Monday were in marked contrast to the tenor of conversations between the Shamir and Bush administrations over the last year.
It has been less than a year since Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, testifying before a Congressional committee, scornfully recited his office phone number and told Israeli officials that when they were serious about advancing the peace process in the Middle East they should call.
While American relations have grown warmer, from the Israeli point of view world press coverage has suddenly turned positive, too. In addition to the 300 full-time resident foreign correspondents here, at least 700 others representing virtually every significant news organization in the world have arrived to cover the gulf war.
The Government has set up press centers at two hotels in Jerusalem and Tel Aviv. And every day Government officials offer briefings, tours, explanations, translation assistance and almost any other form of help the visiting journalists might want.
For the first time in years most journalists are writing or airing sympathetic pieces about Israel, the victim of Iraqi aggression. It wasn't long ago that much of the news coverage centered on the Palestinian uprising and the army's harsh handling of Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
If Israel receives additional aid requested from Washington, it would be on top of the $3 billion in economic and military assistance this state already gets from the United States each year, more than any country.
In addition, this year the United States agreed to guarantee $400 million in special loans to pay for housing Soviet Jewish immigrants, though Mr. Modai said the money hadn't yet arrived.
The Administration also agreed to provide $700 million in surplus military equipment from Europe, though again most of it has not been delivered. And by American estimates, Israel will also receive roughly $650 million more in a variety of supplementary benefits and programs this fiscal year.
 
Where Money Would Go
 A senior Finance Ministry official said $400 million of the $3 billion in compensation Israel wants would go for the costs of keeping the military at its highest level of alert for the last 10 days.
Another $1 billion would be to make up for the losses to the economy caused when the nation closed down for four days. Until today, almost everyone was told to stay home because of the Iraqi missile threat.
Another $1 billion was attributed to losses in the tourism industry. Since the gulf crisis began in August, few tourists have visited Israel.
"Syria, Egypt Turkey -- they got more aid than Israel because of their participation in the international coalition," the senior Finance Ministry official said. "But they haven't been hurt as much as we have."

HEADLINE: GREENSPAN DOUBTS NEED FOR TAX RISE TO MEET WAR COST

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, urged Congress today not to raise taxes to pay for the war in the Persian Gulf.
The Bush Administration has said it does not plan to ask for a tax increase. But some lawmakers and economists disagree with that judgment, and the issue is likely to dominate Congressional hearings and colloquies on economics in the months ahead. 
 Since no one knows how much the war will ultimately cost, Mr. Greenspan said, it is better to borrow the money at least for the time being, even though that would mean a substantial rise in the deficit.
But Mr. Greenspan, the Government's most influential economic policy maker and its leading forecaster, also insisted that taxes should not be cut or spending increased to stimulate the economy and counter the recession.
 
Risk of Mistakes
 "Assessing the economic outlook is especially daunting at the present time," Mr. Greenspan asserted in testimony before the House Budget Committee. He said it might be months before the proper course of action regarding taxes, spending and interest rates became clear, and he noted, "The risks of making policy mistakes are high."
Speaking in his customary oblique style, he refused to say whether he expected the Federal Reserve to drive interest rates lower. "Decisions on that score will depend on developing trends in financial markets and the economy," he said.
But under especially sharp questioning by Representative Barney Frank, a Democrat from Massachusetts, Mr. Greenspan conceded that if the nation's money supply did not start growing in response to the Fed's cutting of short-term rates over the last three months, further steps would be needed to get banks to lend more money.
 
Remembering Vietnam
 Remembering the Vietnam experience, many politicians and economists here have begun discussing how to pay for the war in the gulf, which Mr. Greenspan said was costing hundreds of millions of dollars a day. In the late 1960's, the Johnson Administration imposed a surtax to finance the war in Vietnam, but most economists now agree that it came too late and that the inflation that resulted from trying to fight the war without paying for it inflicted serious damage on the economy for many years thereafter.
Mr. Greenspan maintained that today's circumstances were potentially different from those that existed at the outset of the Vietnam War. Then, he said, the military's inventory of planes, tanks, ships and other equipment was deemed inadequate, and the result was a rapid expansion of Pentagon spending and Government borrowing to finance it. Now, Mr. Greenspan said, with the military buildup of the 1980's and the end of the cold war, military stocks are ample.
Assuming the war is relatively short and the lost equipment does not need to be replaced, he continued, "the economic impact is quite materially different fromthat which occurred during the Vietnam War."
Mr. Greenspan acknowledged that the war in the gulf would vastly increase the budget deficit, but he said that might not be consequential. The war, he said, was a one-time cost and was not "the same thing as introducing a new ongoing program that commits the Government into expenditures for the indefinite future."
Representative John Bryant, a Texas Democrat, said the United States might have to maintain a military presence in the Middle East for years to come. "This cost isn't going to end when the war ends," Mr. Bryant said.
That, Mr. Greenspan said, raised the question of whether America's allies like Germany and Japan should not bear a portion of the long-term cost.
 
Official Economic Estimate
 Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office and Congress's chief economist, plans to release an official estimate on Wednesday that the gross national product fell by 2.6 percent in the last three months of 1990 and will fall by another 1.7 percent in the first three months of this year. At the same time, Mr. Reischauer will release a letter from Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, saying the Bush Administration is estimating an economic slide of 3.4 percent in the fourth quarter of 1990 and 1.3 percent in the first quarter of 1991.
Under the law, the estimates of two consecutive quarters of negative growth, the popular definition of recession, prompt an automatic vote in the Senate and a possible vote in the House of Representatives to undo the spending cuts and tax increases that were enacted last year to lower the budget deficit.
The leadership in both houses opposes such changes, and President Bush has said he will veto the changes if Congress approves them. Thus, the spending and tax levels and the rules enforcing them are unlikely to be altered.
 
Policy Balance Needed
 Mr. Greenspan clearly agreed with that judgment. "Concerns about the appropriateness of a policy of fiscal restraint in a period of weak economic performance are understandable," he said. "However, they must be balanced against the benefits that will flow from adhering to a budget strategy that is geared to the longer-run needs of the economy."
Thus far, Mr. Greenspan said, he has seen "some hints" in economic data indicating that the worst of the recession may be over but he quickly added, "We must also recognize the possibility that overall activity may decline further before an upturn takes hold."
He said the Fed was concerned that the country's money supply had remained flat all fall despite sharp reductions in interest rates. One school of economics, called monetarism, holds that the money supply is the best measurement of how the economy is performing, and in the late 1970's and early 1980's that was the dominant view of the Federal Reserve. In recent years, however, the Fed has paid relatively little attention to the money supply and has concentrated on manipulating interest rates.
Mr. Greenspan's statement represents something of a reversal of the recent course. "I would think that the money supply in this particular environment will give us reasonably good signals relevant to how the economy is emerging," Mr. Greenspan said. "This is something which I would not have said two years ago, but I think we're beginning to see the money supply as being useful as a reflective force."
 
 
Pace of Lending Slows
 The money supply depends mostly on lending by banks and other financial institutions, and Mr. Greenspan said the unexpectedly slow pace of bank lending this fall had led money supplies to be inadequate. He suggested that if the situation did not improve, "further actions will be required."
Presumably, that would mean lower interest rates, but the chairman did not say so.
Mr. Greenspan said he thought the chances were better than "50-50" that an actual recession would not have occurred had it not been for the higher oil prices and uncertainty that followed the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. But he agreed that economic growth had been extremely slow all year, and he offered a somewhat new explanation for that.
The strong growth in the late 1980's, he said, caused Americans to buy so many cars and houses and office buildings that there was "a glut on the market." When people and companies no longer needed those things, a slowdown resulted from the fall in demand.
"I'm not sure the Administration or Congress or we could have materially altered that or should have," Mr. Greenspan said.

HEADLINE: Pope Urges a Convert Drive, Even Where Muslims Ban It

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Pope John Paul II, in a new encyclical, issued a clarion call to Catholics today to go out and spread Christianity, emphasizing the need to evangelize in all parts of the world, including those where Islamic laws forbid proselytizing.
He urged Islamic countries to lift those laws as well as others that forbid Muslims to convert to another faith. Without identifying the nations but evidently referring to Middle Eastern, African and Asian countries where missionaries are refused entry, the Pope exhorted, "Open the doors to Christ!" 
 The document is the first encyclical since 1959 to be devoted to missionary activity and to argue so forcefully that spreading the faith should be one of the most important tasks of Catholics. In the United States, the encyclical will probably strengthen financial support for missionary efforts overseas and make theologians engaged in dialogue with other religions more cautious in their statements.
The encyclical letter "Redemptoris Missio" -- its title in English is "The Church's Missionary Mandate" -- is the eighth issued by John Paul II. An encyclical demonstrates the importance the Pope attaches to an issue, and as a formal expression of papal teaching, is an authoritative message for Catholics worldwide.
 
'Negative Tendency' Cited
 In an introduction, the Pope said the document was intended to help overcome a "negative tendency" in the church, where internal and external difficulties have weakened the missionary thrust toward non-Christians. He said the number of people who did not know Christ had doubled in the last 25 years and was constantly rising.
At the Vatican, papal aides said the Pope was above all responding to the rapid growth of Islam, which has overtaken former Christian areas in the Middle East and Africa and which through large-scale migration is making inroads into southern Europe. To a lesser extent, they said, he was reacting to limitations placed on churchwork in Asia and to the rapid rise of Protestant fundamentalism in Latin America, a traditional Catholic stronghold.
John Paul also focused on the church's relations with other religions and philosophies. He was sharply critical of churchworkers and theologians who in his eyes have gone too far in their sympathy for other religions while making no attempts to convert its members. This tolerance has lead to widespread indifference among Christians, which he said was one of the main reasons for the lack of interest in the missionary task.
Such thinking, he said, "is based on incorrect theological perspectives and is characterized by a religious relativism which leads to the belief that 'one religion is as good as another.' "
 
No Mention of Judaism
 He did encourage missionaries and Christian groups in their dialogue and respect for Buddhism, Hinduism and Islam. But, he said, this does not lessen their duty to proclaim the teachings of Jesus Christ or "cancel the call to faith and baptism which God wills for all people." Citing here from a letter he wrote last year to the bishops of Asia, he made no mention of Judaism.
Difficulties outside the church, he said, are many. Some countries refuse entry to missionaries, he said. In some countries, the Pope said "not only is evangelization forbidden but conversion as well, and even Christian worship." Addressing himself to theose "who for various reasons oppose missionary activity," he declared, "The church repeats: Open the doors to Christ!"
At a news conference, the Rev. Marcello Zago, the Superior General of the Order of Oblates of Mary Immaculate, said the Pope referred "to most North African and Middle Eastern nations where Christians may practice privately but it is against the law to convert Muslims."
"Saudi Arabia forbids any cult that is not Moslem," he added.
Papal aides said that in many areas of Africa, proselytizing by Muslims has led Islam to expand much faster than Catholicism.
Jozef Cardinal Tomko, Prefect of the Congregation for the Evangelization of Peoples, inisisted that dialogue between Catholicism and Islam remained fundamental and must continue. Referring to the war in the Persian Gulf, he warned, "We must not fall into the trap of calling this war a war of Christianity against Islam."
 
Islam the Main Challenge
 Father Zago also told reporters that many Vatican officials saw the relations with Islam as Catholicism's main challenge of the future. "And the only way is a dialogue," he said. "That's why the Pope has spoken out so strongly against the war."
John Paul also had harsh words for the modern world and its "soulless economic and technical development," a world of "marvelous achievements" that neverthless seems to have lost the sense of existence itself. "The temptation today is to reduce Christianity to merely human wisdom, a pseudo-science of well-being," he said.
The most painful difficulties facing the church's missionary task, he wrote, are those in the church itself, and he referred to the dramatic drop in new priests in recent decades, the loss of religious practice and values in historically Christian countries, the in-fighting among Christians and the friction between fundamentalists sects and Catholics.
The 153-page encyclical, Vatican officials said, is the result of almost five years of work. It drew on extensive questionaires sent to church organizations and bishops around the world more than four years ago. Its writing took almost two years. The Pope signed it Dec. 7.

HEADLINE: Asians Lead Virginia's Population Increase

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Virginia's population rose by 15.7 percent to 6.2 million in the last decade, with an influx of Vietnamese, Cambodians and other Asians accounting for 11 percent of the state's total population increase, the Census Bureau said today.
The state's population growth was fueled by a decade of economic prosperity and sharp increases in immigration. Like that of other Sun Belt states, it easily outstripped the national increase of 10.2 percent from 1980 to 1990.
Virginia was the second state, after Vermont, for which the Census Bureau provided racial breakdowns.
Although Asian-Americans make up only 2.6 percent of Virginia's population, their numbers increased by nearly 93,000 statewide, with the majority clustered in Northern Virginia.
The state's black population, slightly more than one million in 1980, increased by 154,000, bringing it to 1,163,000, or 18.8 percent of Virginia's population. The white population increased by more than half a million, to 4.8 million, but the percentage of whites in Virginia slipped slightly, to 77.4 percent from 79.1 percent.
The state's Hispanic population doubled, and is now 160,000.
