HEADLINE: Michigan Faces Painful Choices in Cutting Budget

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LANSING, Mich., Jan. 22

 BODY:
Michigan legislators today faced the kind of excruciating fiscal dilemma that is likely to lie ahead for many other states. They had to vote on whether to eliminate a state-financed welfare program that helps 125,000 poor residents, or accept smaller cuts in a wide array of social programs that help millions of people throughout Michigan.
But even the smaller, broader-based cuts would carry an unpleasant extra jolt: Because those programs are financed by both the state and Federal Governments, any reductions approved in Lansing would bring at least similar reductions from Washington, if not more. 
 In fact, some Michigan officials warn that the across-the-board state cuts, which would amount to about 9.2 percent from each program in the State Social Services Department, could mean a complete loss of Federal money for the Medicaid program. They explain that the Federal Government requires a certain minimum level of state contributions to programs like Medicaid before Washington contributes any money at all, and that the 9.2 percent cut would put Michigan's contribution below that level.
Michigan's new Governor, John Engler, a Republican who pledged during his campaign to reduce the scope of state government, has joined with the Republican-led State Senate in backing the elimination of the state-financed welfare program.
But today, a committee of the Democratic-controlled State House of Representatives refused to go along. The committee rejected the plan of Governor Engler and the State Senate in a vote that was along party lines.
The action set off the automatic across-the-board cuts in all social service programs, at least until the Governor and the lawmakers agree on another way to save $1.1 billion from the $8.9 billion state budget that went into effect last Oct. 1. The cuts are necessary to meet the state's constitutional requirement of a balanced budget.
 
Democrats Want Other Cuts
 Democrats say the state could largely spare the Social Services Department and find other ways to balance this year's budget, including drawing on a $400 million emergency reserve fund and reducing a program that provides property tax rebates. Then, in later years, they would keep the social service programs intact by extending existing taxes to cover more products, businesses and services. But Republicans say the last thing they want to do is raise taxes in the middle of a recession.
The House Appropriations Committee has scheduled six public hearings across the state this month to acquaint people with the proposals.
One of the Governor's representatives, Gerald H. Miller, who is director of the State Department of Social Services, said the House committee's action today would force the department to make unconscionable reductions in programs. It was Mr. Miller, faced with the Governor's orders to reduce his department's spending by $243 million, who had proposed eliminating the state-financed welfare program.
He said that the across-the-board reduction, which would come from the state's $2.6 billion spending on social services, would bring about the withdrawal of $207 million in Federal matching grants, for a total reduction of $450 million.
Worse still, the across-the-board budget reduction, which takes effect immediately, reduces the state's contribution to shared Federal-state programs to levels that violate Federal law. States, for example, are not permitted to reduce their contributions to Aid to Families with Dependent Children below the contributions they made in 1988.
Michigan's across-the-board reduction cut spending on that welfare program far below 1988 levels. The immediate result is that Michigan would no longer be eligible for many Federal subsidies, the largest being Medicaid.
"It's very clear that we will have to send a notice to the Federal Government that we are going to drop out of the Medicaid program," Mr. Miller said, referring to the program of health care and nursing care for people who have exhausted their savings.
 
Cuts in Other Deparments
 The remainder of the total $1.1 billion reduction in spending would come from a 9.2 percent cut in the programs of all departments except education, where a 2 percent cut would be made in higher education programs.
Democratic committee members brushed aside Mr. Miller's gloomy forecast and said there would be more negotiations on the budget between the Governor and legislators after the public hearings.
A few Republicans, too, expressed something like optimism. "The crisis will bring about some meaningful and productive changes in the system," said State Representative Shirley Johnson, who asserted that many people were receiving social benefits but did not need them.
But the remarks of most lawmakers reflected their anguish over the decisions. "Governor Engler's proposal was pretty bad," said State Representative Donald Gilmer, a Republican from southwest Michigan, "but the Democrats' is even worse."
At the center of this battle is the state program, which is called General Assistance here and in most other states that have a similar program. It provides subsistence-level grants to people who have been turned away from every other Federal income subsidy program. Beneficiaries include young men who have never found a job, single adults who are mentally or physically impaired, unemployed couples who have exhausted their jobless benefits, and parents who work too many hours to be eligible for the Federal welfare program, but earn too little to feed their children.
 
Other States Trim Programs
 Financially troubled states are now looking to this program for savings. Arkansas, Louisiana and Oklahoma eliminated their General Assistance programs in the last few years. Many other states, including West Virginia, Wyoming, Nevada and Kansas, have substantially reduced benefits.
Apart from Michigan, which has one of the nation's largest programs, other states have not formally proposed great reductions in General Assistance this year. But fiscal experts in Washington say many other states may have to consider it. "A lot of legislators in last year's and this year's legislative sessions around the country have been saying that General Assistance is something they may have to cut back," said Timothy J. Eckels, a Washington consultant who did a comprehensive survey of these programs last fall for the Government.
If legislators do not act to curtail the programs, expenditures are expected to rise sharply this year as the recession and increasing unemployment rates force more and more Americans to seek public assistance.
 
One Woman's Plight
 When Michigan legislators, mostly Republicans, talk about cutting the program, they often say many recipients are able-bodied and could find work. But if the program were eliminated altogether, it would affect not only freeloaders but also people like Irene E. Guisbert, a 59-year-old widow, who lives in Iron River, an economically depressed town near the Wisconsin border.
Mrs. Guisbert lost her factory job in 1986 when an auto parts manufacturer closed. She said she could not find another job and, after exhausting employment benefits, applied for General Assistance. She now lives on the monthly grant of $246, plus $100 in food stamps. "I don't have any skills and I don't have any money to move away to find a job," Mrs. Guisbert said. She is taking courses at a local community college to become a social worker.
According to Michigan statistics, its General Assistance program has 126,000 recipients, including 95,000 single and married adults and 8,400 families with 17,000 children. A majority of the recipients are white men from 22 to 40 years old and, although half of the state's recipients live in the Detroit area, the fastest growing portion of the case load is in suburban counties. The average monthly grant for a single person is $217 and $458 for a family with two children.
While the caseload has declined from its peak in the mid-1980's, the number of families have increased by over 50 percent because of stricter eligibility requirements for the main Federal welfare program.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Eastern to Sell Northwest Its Washington Operations

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
The carving up of Eastern Airlines continued yesterday, as Northwest Airlines agreed to buy the carrier's gates, landing and takeoff rights and other operations at Washington National Airport for $23.2 million.
The Northwest purchase follows by a day the announcement by Delta Air Lines that it had agreed to purchase 18 Eastern gates at Hartsfield International Airport in Atlanta and an international route for $42.9 million. 
 Eastern shut down late on Friday after running short of cash and being unable to generate enough traffic to cover its costs. The carrier, the nation's eighth largest before it halted operations, had been under Federal bankruptcy protection for nearly two years.
 
Terms of Agreement
 Under the agreement with Northwest, Eastern would sell 5 gates and 76 landing and takeoff rights, as well as ticket offices and jetways.
"This move is of major strategic importance for us," said John H. Dasburg, the president and chief executive officer of Northwest, the nation's fourth-largest airline.
He said the carrier would increase its flights from Washington next month and then undergo a large expansion in March.
Both sales must still be approved by Judge Burton R. Lifland, the chief judge of the United States Bankruptcy Court of the Southern District of New York in Manhattan.
 
Other Strong Assets
 Even though Eastern still owns valuable assets, including additional gates, maintenance operations and aircraft, some doubt has arisen that its unsecured creditors will get anything back on their debt.
The quick sale of the assets is what the creditors had hoped for. According to a person familiar with the creditors' thinking, they want to make sure that Martin R. Shugrue Jr., the trustee appointed by Judge Lifland to run Eastern, does not have a chance to revive the carrier.
Eastern's creditors and Mr. Shugrue became increasingly alienated from each other as he sought to revive Eastern by using money that had been set aside for the creditors just as there seemed little chance to stem the airline's losses.
 
More Domestic Strength
 Eastern's sales to Delta and Northwest are expected to strengthen the carriers at important domestic hubs, including Washington and Atlanta.
Delta, for example, has its main hub in Atlanta and controls 48 gates there. With the Eastern purchase, it will control half the gates at the hub.
Hubs have become very important to airlines, since they can provide flights to many points and can feed those flights from surrounding cities.

HEADLINE: 2 Baby Bells Report Dips In Profits

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
Two of the seven regional Bell companies yesterday announced write-offs and lower fourth-quarter profits from operations. The stocks of the two companies dropped sharply as a result.
Excluding one-time charges, fourth-quarter profits fell 6.3 percent at the Pacific Telesis Group and 1 percent at the Bell Atlantic Corporation. A slowing economy cut into telephone traffic and the installation of new phone lines. 
 With one-time expenses included, profits at Pactel tumbled 39 percent for the quarter and surged at Bell Atlantic, which took a large charge against earnings in the fourth quarter of 1989.
 
Share Prices Drop Sharply
 Shares of Pacific Telesis fell $3.125 yesterday, to $41.25, while Bell Atlantic's stock plunged $4, to $50, both on heavy volume on the New York Stock Exchange.
Jeffrey A. Heyser, the executive director of investor relations at Pacific Telesis, said investors were disappointed because "they thought we were immune from recession," and the company turned out not to be.
Pactel and Bell Atlantic each suffered sharp drops in the growth rates of new telephone lines and medium-distance phone calls billed by local telephone companies. "For the first time, we're seeing the impact of a softening economy on the local telephone industry," said Jack B. Grubman, a telephone industry analyst at Paine Webber who canceled his buy recommendations for both companies yesterday and reduced his estimates of their 1991 earnings.
 
After-Tax Losses
 The companies, created by the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in 1984, each took $60 million after-tax losses for their businesses that have suffered the most from the economic downturn. Pactel is quitting the real estate business, which it entered several years ago, and has said it will sell its entire $475 million portfolio of office buildings and industrial sites over the next several years.
Bell Atlantic reduced the value shown on its balance sheet for non-telephone financial services, which include leasing equipment and lending to other companies and real estate projects. The company announced on Oct. 26 that this charge would only be $40 million, but said yesterday that it was forced to increase the charge because the market value of these assets continued to slide.
Following are details of the companies' results:
 
Pacific Telesis
The San Francisco-based company, which provides most local phone service in California and Nevada, reported fourth-quarter profits of $196 million, or 50 cents a share, down from $322 million, or 79 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales dipped to $2.44 billion from $2.48 billion.
Excluding one-time charges, profits fell to $268 million from $285.6 million. But the actual deterioration in operating results was slightly greater because Pactel paid lower taxes in the fourth quarter of 1990 as it accelerated depreciation of some of its assets.
 For all of 1990, Pactel earned $1.03 billion, or $2.58 a share, on sales of $9.72 billion. A year earlier, the company had profits of $1.24 billion, or $3.02 a share, on sales of $9.59 billion.
 
Bell Atlantic
The parent of the main local phone companies for New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware, Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia and the District of Columbia earned $236 million, or 65 cents a share, on sales of $3.11 billion in the fourth quarter.
In the comparable 1989 period, the company's profits were $57.9 million, or 15 cents a share, on sales of $2.89 billion.
Bell Atlantic gained only 37,000 new lines in the fourth quarter, down from 127,000 a year before, said Cynthia M. Ciangio, a company spokeswoman. The number of medium-distance calls billed by local telephone companies, traditionally one of the main sources of local phone company profits, grew 2.7 percent in the quarter, down from 8.5 percent a year before.
For 1990, Bell Atlantic earned $1.31 billion, or $3.38 a share, on sales of $12.3 billion. In 1989 the company had profits of $1.07 billion, or $2.71 a share, on sales of $11.45 billion.
Stephanie Georges, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, said the results showed a weak economy in the mid-Atlantic region but also successful efforts by Bell Atlantic to control costs.

HEADLINE: General Electric Reports 6% Rise in Profits and Revenues

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
The General Electric Company said yesterday that its net income and revenues both rose by 6 percent in the last three months of 1990.
Earnings increased to almost $1.24 billion, from $1.17 billion in the last quarter of 1989. And its revenues rose to $17.2 billion from $16.2 billion. 
 Although G.E. did not discuss the fourth-quarter performance of any of its businesses, which include the NBC Broadcasting group, as well as the investment firm Kidder, Peabody & Company, the conglomerate indicated that the gain represented a continuation of trends evident throughout much of last year.
Strong growth at businesses like aircraft engines and power equipment that operate with long lead times continued to compensate for declines in other groups, notably plastics and the NBC Broadcasting group.
 
Report Due Next Month
 G.E., based in Fairfield, Conn., releases more detailed information on the performance of its businesses with its annual report at the end of next month.
The company's earnings per share for the quarter rose faster than net income -- by 9.2 percent, to $1.42, from $1.30 last year -- because General Electric bought 41.7 million of its common shares since November 1989, as part of a five-year, $10 billion buyback program.
G.E. took a $100 million charge against its earnings in the quarter to pay for a previously announced restructuring, which included some layoffs, to improve margins in several critical businesses, including aerospace, aircraft engines and appliances. The charge was largely balanced in the quarterly figures, the company said, by an unspecified gain on the sale of its Ladd Petroleum unit to Amax Inc. for $515 million plus working capital.
"It was a reasonably solid quarter, considering what's going on in the economy," said Robert W. McCoy Jr., who follows the company for UBS Phillips & Drew.
 
$4.30 Billion Net Income
 General Electric said its net income for 1990 rose by 9.4 percent, to $4.30 billion, from $3.93 billion in 1989, while its earnings per share rose by 11.2 percent, to $4.85 from $4.36. Its revenues totaled $58.4 billion, up by nearly 7 percent from $54.6 billion in 1989.
John F. Welch Jr., the chairman and chief executive, said companywide productivity improvements played a leading role in helping G.E. overcome the pressure on earnings from rising oil prices, the sluggish domestic economy and declining consumer confidence.
GE Financial Services was also a major contributor to earnings, reporting a 15 percent gain from the 1989 quarter, excluding GE Americom, a satellite carrier that was transferred to the Financial Services operation from Technical Products and Services. The GE Capital Corporation, which accounts for most of the financial group, recorded strong gains despite troubles in its investments in leveraged buyouts and commercial real estate.
 
Data Lacking on Units
 Financial services also includes the company's insurance unit, ERC, and the 80 percent stake in Kidder, Peabody, but General Electric declined to discuss the performance of either subsidiary, both of which are operating in troubled industries.
The company said that overall operating margins reached 11.6 percent in 1990, a company record. General Electric's shares fell 75 cents each yesterday, to $56.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: WASHINGTON;
Baltic Officials Meet With Baker And Congressional Panel on Crisis

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d received officials of the three Baltic republics today to hear their views of the latest actions by the Soviet authorities to repress independence movements in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania.
The representatives of the three republics urged the United States to send a high-level American delegation to the Baltics and to extend more specific recognition of their democratically elected governments as independent regimes. 
 The three are Deputy Prime Minister Dainis Ivans of Latvia, Vice President Bronius Kuzmickas of Lithuania and Endall Lippmaa, Minister Without Portfolio in the Estonian government.
A Bush Administration official described their 30-minute session with Mr. Baker and their subsequent one-hour discussion with some of the Secretary's senior aides as "a good meeting" in which both sides offered ideas on the Baltic crisis. "Both sides talked on the pros and cons of what could be done and what would and would not work," the official said.
 
Request Meeting With Bush
 The Baltic officials have also asked to be received by President Bush, and several members of Congress have urged the President to do so.
Earlier in the day, two of the Baltic officials addressed a Congressional panel and found themselves outdone in the boldness of rhetoric and recommendations by some of the legislators, who are members of the United States Commission on Cooperation and Security in Europe.
Mr. Ivans, a former journalist, said, "We would like to see a high-level United States delegation visit the Baltic states as soon as possible."
But Senator John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania, added demands of his own, calling on the Administration to shut off Export-Import Bank credits to Moscow immediately. Senator Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona, said that with regard to strategic-arms negotiations and a summit meeting between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union that is scheduled for next month, "we must send a clear message and cease some of these activities with Mr. Gorbachev."
A bill submitted last week by several Republican Senators would suspend all United States economic assistance to the Soviet Union and adopt a "sense of the Congress" language saying "the President of the United States should not attend the summit."
The summit, described again by the White House as "up in the air," is scheduled for Feb. 11 to 13 in Moscow and provide the setting for the signing of a treaty to reduce strategic arms. Several Administration officials say the White House is weighing the idea of proposing a one-day meeting between the two leaders in Geneva instead.
Aside from public condemnation and protests to the Soviet leadership delivered here and in Moscow, the only concrete step the Bush Administration has taken so far in response to the Baltic repression has been to agree to join in seeking "an explanation" by the Soviet Union of its actions under the 1975 Helsinki Agreement.

(Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

The Economy
Greenspan urged Congress not to raise taxes to pay for war. The Administration has said it does not plan to ask for an increase, but some lawmakers and economists disagree. [Page A1.]

Markets
Oil prices jumped after the first flames leaped from Kuwaiti oil fields, and later rose more when an Iraqi missile exploded in Israel. Crude gained $2.88, to $24.18 a barrel. [D1.]
Stocks fell sharply in heavy trading after the missile attack on Tel Aviv. The Dow fell 25.99, to 2,603.22. [D8.]
Prices of Treasury securities fell and long-term interest rates rose after news of the Tel Aviv blast. [D15.]

Engineers have created a vision in plastics that they say can shave 10 minutes off a cyclist's time in a 100-mile race. [D7.]

HEADLINE: MNC Financial Spins Off Credit Card Unit

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
Unable to fetch an attractive price for its credit card business in a private transaction, the parent of Maryland National Bank spun off 85 percent of the subsidiary yesterday in an initial public offering valued at $861.6 million.
While the company did not realize as much in the deal as management had once hoped, it was above the threshold that the troubled parent company had determined it needed to repay coming debt obligations and satisfy banking regulators. The outcome of the offering was at least partly a function of the market rally kindled last week by early American successes in the Persian Gulf war, analysts and investors said yesterday.
 
$22.50 a Share
Under the deal, which was underwritten by Goldman, Sachs & Company, investors paid $22.50 a share for 38.3 million shares, representing an 85 percent stake in the MBNA Corporation, as the credit-card operation, based in Newark, Del., is now known. Of those shares, 27.7 million were sold by MNC Financial, the Baltimore-based parent company, and 10.6 million new shares were issued by MBNA. 
 At the same time as the initial public offering, MNC Financial also sold its remaining 15 percent interest in the credit card operation in two private transactions.
Alfred Lerner, chairman of MBNA, acquired about 10 percent, and the Progressive Corporation, a Cleveland insurance company he also heads, acquired a 4.9 percent stake, at the offering price less the underwriters' discount. Both he and Progressive would need additional regulatory approvals to raise their respective stakes beyond those amounts, investment bankers said yesterday.
Altogether, the series of transactions raised nearly $773 million for the ailing parent company, and $239 million more of common equity for the credit-card operation.
A roughly billion-dollar deal would have been ambitious even in a peacetime economy, but is especially impressive now. Indeed, the deal ranks as the third-largest public offering completed since the 1987 market crash, excluding closed-end funds, according to the Securities Data Company, a Newark research firm.
 
Efforts to Find Buyer
 As it turned out, the parent company had little choice. Goldman's attempts to find a buyer had faltered, and MNC desperately needed the cash to avert default.
Those efforts failed, analysts said, for several reasons. Many banks that would have made logical suitors had their own problems, and remaining bidders were well aware of the firm's financial straits and made disappointing offers. Another blow apparently came when Visa and Mastercard publicly implied that they would make it difficult for any potential buyer that was not already part of their network to acquire the business. That was an attempt by the credit card organizations to make it up to the banks for having given A.T.& T. approval last year to market its Universal card, said Elisabeth Albert Hayes, a bank analyst with Johnston, Lemon & Company in Washington.
To insure that at least the public offering would get done,the company's underwriters had shaved the final price down from a possible high of $25 to $22.50, a mere 7.8 times last year's earnings. The company also set the dividend yield at a fat 7.1 percent a year, roughly half its current earnings. And the company also promised in a revised version of its prospectus to terminate or review certain business relationships it has with some of its former affiliates that investors might have viewed skeptically.
 
Rushed to Market
 But in the end the market rally kindled by the early days of fighting in the Persian Gulf may have had more to do with MNC's ability to get the deal done than any other inducement.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Says Tax for Police Hides Surplus

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins admitted yesterday that his tax plan to pay for thousands more police officers would actually raise hundreds of millions more in taxes than the police hiring would require.
The surplus, more than $500 million over three years, was not mentioned by Mr. Dinkins when he presented the plan last month. 
 The hidden surplus first surfaced when state legislative aides, negotiating with the city over a city income-tax surcharge, noticed that it would raise more money than the plan apparently needed. It was first disclosed in an article in The New York Times yesterday analyzing the difficulties the criminal justice plan had run into in Albany.
"It should have been made clear, that is for sure," Mr. Dinkins said yesterday at a hastily called news conference.
 
Takes Blame for 'the Arithmetic'
 When his tax plan was first proposed, Mr. Dinkins repeatedly stated that the public was willing to support higher taxes as long as it was assured that the tax revenues would be used only for anti-crime efforts.
The disclosure of a surplus built into the plan seems likely to increase public cynicism about future tax increases, some city officials said, at a time when the city is proposing layoffs, service cuts and other tax increases to close a $2.5 billion budget gap over the next 18 months.
Mr. Dinkins said that while he did not "do the arithmetic" himself, he took responsibility for the failure of his administration to publicize the extra tax revenue, and seemed to apologize to the City Hall press corps for putting out incomplete information.
"There came a time when it was made clear to me that this funding mechanism would provide money in excess of the number of police officers we proposed to hire," he told reporters. "We certainly didn't intend to mislead anyone and we certainly didn't intend to incorporate you in our efforts."
 
Council President Is 'Distressed'
 Mr. Dinkins insisted yesterday that the surplus revenues would be used to pay for police officers already on the city payroll. But since city taxes already cover the cost of those officers, the new taxes would free money for the city's overall budget needs, fiscal aides said.
"I am distressed by this apparent deception," said City Council President Andrew J. Stein, referring to the surplus. "Many New Yorkers will feel betrayed when they learn that they have been misled. In these troubled economic times, government needs the cooperation and trust of the citizens. This will make it difficult to keep that trust."
Although Mr. Stein said he was unaware of it, City Council leaders said they had gone along with the plan to seek surplus taxes. Mr. Stein was not involved in the negotiations.
Herbert E. Berman, chairman of the City Council's Finance Committee, said the Council was aware of the surplus from the first, and viewed it as a cushion to protect the city's criminal justice system during a recession.
"If anything, it is going to help us provide services as we come out a recession," he said. "If that is an evil, it is an evil."
Mr. Dinkins's tax plan, announced on Dec. 5, was the result of a compromise with the City Council to pay for the hiring of 3,500 additional police officers over six years.
The plan, eventually costing $450 million a year, was to be paid for by increasing property taxes, creating a new city lottery and extending a city income-tax surcharge, enacted last year to close a city budget gap.
A fact sheet distributed at the time showed that the tax increases -- including a total of $670 million over four years from a surcharge on the personal income tax -- would raise exactly the sums the city needed to pay for the police plan each year.
 
Beyond Tactics of Bargaining
 But the administration did not disclose that, in fact, the income tax surcharge would raise $1.2 billion, about $530 million more than the amount publicly disclosed in three of the four years, according to city calculations.
In its perennial effort to get support from the Governor and the State Legislature for its tax programs, city officials often ask for more taxes than the city needs. It is part of the bargaining.
But some legislators said the current city effort went far beyond the usual bounds, especially since the taxes were supposed to be dedicated for a specific purpose.
"There is always extra money built in," said State Senator Serphin R. Maltese, Republican of Queens. "If it is built in for negotiations, that is one thing. If it is built in as extra money for the city, that is hogwash."
 
Tax Surplus a Critical Issue
 The anti-crime program has been held up for weeks, as legislators wrangled with the administration over the police deployment plans and sought assurances that the tax revenue would be spent on police officers.
Senate and Assembly negotiators wanted to penalize the city if it failed to hire the officers it promised to hire, by witholding a percentage of the revenue from the tax.
The tax surplus became a critical issue, because city officials wanted to exempt it from the calculation of any penalty. Mr. Dinkins said yesterday that his administration had conceded this point and agreed to the penalty.
At the same time, in an effort to spur the Leglsature to act, the City Council yesterday voted 28 to 2 to approve an increase in property taxes to provide up to $150 million a year for the plan.
The increase would raise the tax bill of the owner of a home with a market value of $250,000 a year by $17.02 during the next six months and about double that the following year.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: THE OVERVIEW;
IRAQ SETS OIL REFINERIES AFIRE AS ALLIES STEP UP AIR ATTACKS; MISSILE PIERCES TEL AVIV SHIELD

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 22

 BODY:
As the skies over Iraq cleared and allowed an intensification of the American-led air war, allied military officials said today that Iraq had set fire to two Kuwaiti oil refineries and to an oilfield near Kuwait's border with Saudi Arabia.
By setting the oil installations ablaze, they said, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq carried out his threat to destroy oil sites in the Persian Gulf if Iraq's occupation of Kuwait was challenged. 
 Tens of thousands of United States-led allied troops took positions along the Saudi border with Kuwait today, and in the Persian Gulf, where American forces attacked and apparently sank two Iraqi ships, one of them described as an Iraqi mine-laying vessel.
 
Bombing Republican Guard
 The American command said that so far more than 10,000 allied combat and support missions had been flown in what has been described as the most concentrated air attack over such a period of time. American military officials said much of today's bombing had been directed against positions of the Republican Guard, which forms Saddam Hussein's most important line of defense, and Basra, Iraq's second-largest city. B-52 bombers were reported to have dropped so much tonnage as to set off vibrations across the border in Iran.
No American warplanes were lost today, the United States command reported.
As they monitored today's oil fires in Kuwait, Western and Arab officials said they believed Iraq had sabotaged the oil installations in hopes of disrupting aerial surveillance of Iraqi forces in Kuwait, or in preparation for a possible Iraqi withdrawal from areas of Kuwait near the oilfields, or simply as a signal of Iraq's willingness to lay waste to Kuwait if American-led forces advance on Iraqi troops.
The fires, which poured thick, jet-black smoke into the skies over the Kuwaiti desert, were detected by American satellites this morning, Defense Department officials said.
 
Damage to Field Unknown
 The extent of the damage to the oil sites could not be determined this evening, although oil industry analysts were quick to point out that it would be difficult to inflict long-term damage on Kuwaiti oilfields even if the wellheads were set ablaze. Oil prices rose today in response to news reports about the fires.
Western military officials said smoke from the fires could affect military operations against Iraq by limiting aerial surveillance, by planes or by satellites, of Iraqi military positions in Kuwait.
"Obviously if there's heavy smoke, that's going to affect operations somewhat," said Lieut. Col. Greg Pepin, a Pentagon spokesman here. Despite the smoke from the fires, American air and satellites will still be able to monitor Iraqi troop movements through aerial surveillance, including radar systems, that can penetrate smoke and dust.
 
Threat of Sabotage
 Last September, the Iraqi Government threatened to sabotage oilfields in Kuwait and elsewhere in the Middle East if Iraq's economy was seriously damaged by international economic sanctions imposed after the invasion of Kuwait.
"Oil installations will be incapacitated" if the sanctions "strangle the people of Iraq," the Government said in a statement at the time.
The exiled Government of Kuwait has reported that the Iraqi military mined Kuwaiti oil installations shortly after the invasion, as a threat to any potential invader.
As the war against Iraq entered its second week, the Defense Department said today that the air assault on Iraqi forces in Kuwait and southern Iraq had been intensified after two days of cloudy weather in the region hindered bombing missions.
 
More Than 10,000 Missions
 The Pentagon said today that allied air forces from the United States, Britain, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait and other countries had flown 2,000 more missions today as part of the overall total of 10,000.
Because of bad weather earlier in the week that prevented pilots from seeing their targets, the number of sorties had reportedly dropped to 1,100 on Monday.
The importance of the opening of the skies was twofold. It allowed pilots a clearer look at their targets and at the antiaircraft defenses. In recent days, many missions were aborted because of the visual difficulty not only in confirming the targets but also in evading attacking missiles.
It also allowed American intelligence officers to receive clearer photos from reconnaissance planes and satellites of the targets that were hit and to allow them to evaluate the severity of the damage. From these reports, allied officials can decide whether it is necessary to repeat air strikes or shift to different targets.
 
On Strategic Waterway
 American military officials said a primary target of today's attacks was Basra, which is only about 20 miles north of the border with Kuwait and which rests on the strategic Shatt-al-Arab waterway.
The official news agency in neighboring Iran reported today that the explosions heard from Basra "were so powerful that buildings in the Iranian port of Khorramshahr, 25 miles southeast of Basra, were severely jolted."
Iraq responded this evening to the bombing attacks with another volley of Scud missiles aimed at American military installations in eastern Saudi Arabia and at Israel.
Military officials who had been briefed today on the Kuwaiti oil fires said wellheads and storage tanks had been blown up or set afire at the al-Wafra oilfield in the Kuwaiti half of the so-called Neutral Zone, an oil-rich, diamond-shaped region that is shared between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia.
Al-Wafra is a small, low-pressure field that had been responsible for only about 7 percent of Kuwaiti oil production before the Iraqi invasion on Aug. 2.
Oil industry officials said there were potentially more serious fires today at storage sites the two refineries that were set afire, at Mina Abdullah and Shuaiba, south of Kuwait city. They are two of Kuwait's largest.
Kuwait has the world's third-largest known oil reserves and produced more than 1.5 million barrels of oil a day before the invasion.
 
Impact of Fires
 Oil industry analysts agree that while mines could cause extensive damage to Kuwaiti oil installations, the explosions would not destroy the bulk of the oil beneath the ground in Kuwait. The fires, however, could delay Kuwait's efforts to restore oil production after the war.
Smoke from the burning tanks and wells could have a measurable environmental impact in the gulf region, Department of Energy officials said, although they cited a Sandia National Laboratories study that found that "major climatic change on a global scale are unlikely as a result of smoke discharge" in the gulf.
As air attacks against Iraqi targets were stepped up, tens of thousands of American ground troops in Saudi Arabia were moving north, toward the Saudi border with Kuwait, in preparation for what is expected to be a heavy ground war with Iraq.
 
Gunfire at Border
 There were new reports today of gunfire across the tense border.
A small group of American reporters organized by the Defense Department and traveling with front-line Marine troops said in an account made available today that Marine batteries of 155-millimeter howitzers were used to fire on Iraqi artillery units inside Kuwait, just north of Khafji, a now-deserted Saudi city.
One sign of the final preparations for the American-led ground offensive was noted today at a remote Saudi desert camp close to the border, where members of the Army's First Armored Division were finally provided with new, desert-colored uniforms.
Until today, elements of the armored division brought to Saudi Arabia from their bases in Germany had been wearing the forest green camouflage uniforms that, while well suited to European terrain, made the soldiers stand out like a beacon in the dun-brown Arabian desert.
"I expect they'll probably fight very hard," said Lieut. Col. Bill Reese, commander of the First Division's Cavalry Squadron, describing the enemy he expects to face soon. "I expect we'll have to destroy the enemy, its tank platoons, all his armored units, one by one by one."
At a briefing this afternoon in the Pentagon, Lieut. Gen. Thomas Kelly told reporters that the Iraqi President Saddam Hussein "is doing little or nothing" to respond to the threat from American-led forces "except launching the Scuds, which are really more of a terror weapon than anything else."

GRAPHIC: Chart/Map: "The Air War Continues"
 
1. A widespread air assault continued, as the weather cleared somewhat and allied planes hit Basra. The number of sorties against Iraq passed 10,000, but a British Tornado was downed. The air force of Qatar joined in the attack on Iraq.
 
2. An Iraqi Scud missile hit an apartment building in Tel Aviv, killing 3 people and hurting more than 90. It was the first confirmed miss for the Patriot, of which two were fired at the incoming Scud.
 
3. United States satellites spotted burning oil tanks, refineries and wells in Kuwait and in the former Neutral Zone between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. The fires were apparently set by the Iraqis, possibly to create a smoke screen to limit the visibility of attack planes. The fires can also confuse infrared targeting systems.
 
4. In the northern Gulf, four Navy A-6 attack planes sank an Iraqi mine-laying ship on Monday. Later, Navy aircraft attacked three other Iraqi boats, sinking one. (pg. A6)

HEADLINE: Opera Is on the March in Boston, But Financing Is Lagging

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL

 BODY:
Looked at one way, these are heady times for opera in Boston. Over the weekend, the ambitious, rapidly expanding Boston Lyric Opera presented two well-received performances of Richard Strauss's "Ariadne auf Naxos" at the recently renovated Emerson Majestic Theater.
 Tonight, the new Boston Opera Theater opens at the Colonial Theater with the first Boston performance of the Peter Sellars production of Mozart's "Nozze di Figaro." 
 Sarah Caldwell's Opera Company of Boston plans to present three operas later this season at the Opera House. Miss Caldwell is currently winning approving attention for her Making Music Together contemporary-music series in the Soviet Union.
 But, why, many Boston observers wonder, does a city without one truly established opera company have three similarly sized ensembles competing for the same financing sources -- sources that are dwindling in the current recession, which has hit Massachusetts severely?
 As Bruce Rossley, the city's Commissioner for the Arts and Humanities, said about a similar situation, the Boston opera scene is like "a feeding frenzy at an empty trough."
 
A Non-Producing Group
 There is even a fourth group: the well-heeled Bostonians who call themselves the Boston Opera Association stage no opera performances, their primary purpose up to 1986 having been the importation of the Metropolitan Opera on its annual tours. But they have declined to support any of the squabbling local companies.
 Boston's near-comic operatic hyperactivity stems from the mid-1980's, when several separate events conspired. In 1985, Miss Caldwell fell ill, and while she has fully recovered, her incapacity highlighted her financial difficulties and encouraged competitors.
The next year, the Met dropped its spring tours, creating voids in several American cities, including Boston.
 By 1987, the Lyric Opera had retired an accumulated $500,000 debt that dated back four years to an overambitious Wagner "Ring" cycle presented in Boston and at the Beacon Theater in New York, and felt ready to step up to a level beyond earnest community opera.
 
Another Group Heard From
 Then Mr. Sellars and his musical associate Craig Smith, encouraged by dissident board members from Miss Caldwell's company and support from local music critics, agreed to participate in the formation of a new company, the Boston Opera Theater.
 Miss Caldwell has already announced a season of Tchaikovsky's "Eugen Onegin" with Russian sets and singers; the double bill of Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana" (with Shirley Verrett) and Leoncavallo's "Pagliacci," and, replacing a Leonard Bernstein "Mass" that was to have been a Russo-American co-production, a Puccini "Tosca."
 Speaking over the weekend from Moscow, Miss Caldwell alluded to a budget of $2 million. She had placed her hopes for long-range survival in a theater-development plan organized three years ago by Mr. Rossley that would have entailed the city's purchase of the Opera House with state-bond money. This would have retired Miss Caldwell's debt (said to be between $5 million and $7 million) and permitted the theater's renovation. But dire economic straits scuttled the bond issue.
 
One Crisis Weathered
 The Lyric Opera, having weathered its "Ring"-induced crisis, now has a new general director in Justin Moss and a new artistic adviser in Richard Gaddes, who made the Opera Theater of St. Louis into a model of regional-opera excellence.
 The Lyric seems committed to sensible -- meaning conservative -- productions of mostly mainstream repertory with an occasional safe novelty featuring promising American singers. Its board members are suspicious not only of Miss Caldwell, but also of Mr. Sellars, who has many conservative enemies and a somewhat similar reputation for flighty career commitments.
 Instead, Mr. Moss hopes to build up the number of performances for each production beyond the present two, and to eventually expand the number of annual productions beyond the current three. He and his board have been heartened by the public and critical response to their Donizetti "Daughter of the Regiment" and "Ariadne" this season, and are looking forward to Marc Blitzstein's "Regina" in March. The current annual budget is about $600,000.
 The Boston Opera Theater was formed by Robert Canon, who had been asked by Mr. Rossley and others to sort out Miss Caldwell's finances at the Opera Company of Boston. Mr. Sellars, though he emerged from the Boston scene, is now so busy that he will agree only to serve as artistic adviser and to direct his familiar Mozart trilogy over three years.
 
'Figaro' Five Times
 Mr. Canon, who despite lively box-office interest and bold announcements has been slow to generate an actual working company, said that his budget for this first year, for the "Figaro" and start-up costs, was about $1 million. There will be five performances of the "Figaro" through Feb. 2.
 For the future, he talks of a new version of the Boston composer John Harbison's "Winter's Tale," a collaboration with the Handel and Haydn Society of Boston, a restaging of a Mark Lamos Puccini "Boheme" and possible joint importations with the Brooklyn Academy of Music. All

of this, Mr. Canon added, would entail an annual budget of nearly $3 million.
 The Boston Opera Association, in the meantime, is biding its time, contenting itself with supporting Boston Symphony star-singer concerts and semi-staged operas at Symphony Hall and Tanglewood. It is also discussing support for a revitalized opera program at Tanglewood.
 "The Boston Opera Association people had their life, being wined and dined in New York, and now they're searching for a new life," Miss Caldwell said.
 Everyone seems to feel some coalescing of forces is inevitable. But no one seems eager to coalesce.
 
Independence and Hostility
 The still-charismatic Miss Caldwell is likely to remain outside any alliance. "Sarah has poisoned the well," said Mr. Moss, citing Miss Caldwell's cancellations, schedule changes and last-minute bailouts. "As usual, she's now in total chaos."
Lawrence Perera, the association chairman, called her operation a "hair-raising ride that I and my board have no intention of galloping with."
Mr. Rossley, the arts commissioner, took a more sanguine view. "She has a history of being a phoenix," he said. "When people say there's no way there's going to be a season, it happens."
 In the meantime, both Mr. Moss and Mr. Canon said that when the Boston Opera Theater "Figaro" performances ended, they and their boards would discuss cooperation. "I don't know if it will be a merger or a cooperative venture or a split season," Mr. Canon said. "This is Boston -- it takes longer to get moving."
 Miss Caldwell, blaming the recession for most of her troubles, suggested that the present artistic climate is less chaotic than invigorating. The combined budgets of the three active Boston companies this season are less than $4 million, compared with $37 million for the Boston Symphony and $106 million for the Metropolitan.
"There are a number of little worlds in Boston, and if you are within one company, that becomes your little world," Miss Caldwell said. "But maybe it's healthier, instead of one centralized company, to have different people absolutely determined to do what they do. You have to keep trying. All of these companies, including ours, will last as long as a certain number of people will them to last."

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
Postwar Mideast Dreams

BYLINE: By Leslie H. Gelb

 BODY:
Contrary to frequent charges, Bush Administration officials are thinking about the postwar peace process. The direction of their brainstorming will displease knee-jerk advocates of an international Mideast conference and give Yasir Arafat a well-deserved diplomatic body blow.
 The ideas, and they are only ideas at this point, are grandiose and sound tinny to a political ear. But they spring from the shocks of war and the power of dreams -- the stuff that breakthroughs are made of.
 
 One track, encased in regionwide plans for economic cooperation and arms control, would try to clear the way for negotiations between two of the region's most bitter enemies, Israel and Syria. This regional effort, and not a Mideast conference, would be the diplomatic starting point.
 The second and parallel track would be laid by a generous Israeli offer to West Bank and Gaza Strip Palestinians for direct talks. The aim would be to make it tempting and possible for Palestinian locals to split from P.L.O. headquarters in Tunis.
These tracks could be set whatever Saddam Hussein's fate, although his early retirement to the post of color commentator for CNN would clearly benefit any peace process. The most immediate obstacle to the two tracks is not Saddam Hussein, but his now popular demand for an international conference.
 Such a conclave would produce only endless haggling over its own powers and guarantee Israel's isolation and intransigence. But Administration officials know that the U.S. cannot simply discard the idea. Britain, France and several Arab countries are paying dues in war and will expect it as their pound of peace. The challenge for Washington will be to convince them that the conference might serve a useful purpose if convened later rather than sooner.
 The right partners to start negotiations are Israel and Syria, under the rubric of a Mideast-wide conference on military and economic cooperation. They hold the key to future stability in the region. The pivotal question is Syrian President Assad's willingness to play. His historical instinct would be to reach for undisputed leadership of the radical Arab world, whatever Saddam Hussein's position after the war.
 But Mr. Assad is neither a romantic nor a masochist. He is a consummate strategist whose dispatch of Syrian troops to defend Saudi Arabia shows an appreciation of new strategic realities. He no longer has his Soviet military protector and is without funds. To rebuild his shattered economy, he can turn only to Saudi Arabia. The Saudis can use this dependence to nudge him toward talks with Israel. And it is to Israel that he must turn to fulfill his dream of restoring the Golan Heights to Syrian sovereignty.
Prime Minister Shamir shares the Syrian dictator's unromantic personality. Yet he and his fellow hard-liners make no secret of their willingness to probe Damascus on peace. They also know that if Mr. Assad would deal with them, the fearful Saudis and Jordanians would be close behind.
 But none of these Arab states would dare talk directly to Israel unless Mr. Shamir opened the second track for negotiations with the Palestinians. With all Palestinians in a state of shock and disarray, the moment could be ripe for an imaginative Israeli initiative.
 Mr. Arafat chose to back Iraq, and whatever Saddam Hussein's future, the P.L.O. leader and his organization will be losers. They will get no more money from the Saudis, and neither Israel nor Washington will let him back into the negotiating picture.
 The Arafat blunder creates the possibility of Israel's doing what it has always desired -- ignoring Mr. Arafat and negotiating directly with the Palestinians in the occupied territories.
 But no new group of Palestinian leaders will risk stepping forward unless Israel makes them an offer they cannot refuse. At a minimum, this means the right to organize their own elections and government, and not foreclosing their dream of a Palestinian state.
 Israeli officials have been hinting at similar thoughts. For they have a dream of their own -- absorbing a whole new generation of Israelis from the Soviet Union, a dream even many Israeli hardheads now sense will die unless Palestinians are reconciled.
 Historically, the power of Middle Eastern dreams has derived from their single-mindedness and exclusivity. The separate dreams of Arabs and Israelis lend themselves well to war, not compromise. But by ruminating on how to use the gulf crisis to retrack these dreams, Administration officials are on to something bold and attractive.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Buffalo, Finally Favored

BYLINE: By John Pettibone MacKenzie

 BODY:
Buffalo, erstwhile Queen City of the Great Lakes, a town often said to have a glorious past but a dismal present, is certifiably on the way back. Its football team, the Bills, is finally going to the Super Bowl. Suddenly the citizens of New York's second-largest city sense a long-deferred recognition, especially from the opposite end of the state where the Giants dwell.
The Giants, no less entitled to glory for their bitterly fought victory over San Francisco, will meet the Bills Sunday on Tampa's neutral ground. Students of the game favor the Bills by a few points. Whether they're right or not, it has been a long time since Buffalo was regarded with such favor in New York's first city. 
 Buffalo was attracting notice even before the Bills crushed the Los Angeles Raiders and earned their trip to Tampa. "The Last Best Time," by Verlyn Klinkenborg, a poetic account of the city and a family-owned bar, has revived interest in the city while winning favorable reviews. And Buffalo chicken wings, a celebrated bar food, have recently scored new culinary triumphs as the basis for "a trendy main course salad."
There's more to Buffalo, of course, but some other notices have not been so favorable. A city on the way to nowhere, some have said. Indisputably cold and bleak in winter, as the visiting Raiders were reminded. A region quick to suffer economic setback, sometimes slow to recover.
One favorite son, the late Michael Bennett, had a character in "A Chorus Line" speak of Buffalo as a place where suicide would be "redundant."
Not fair. Buffalo is above all livable, a place of diversity, congeniality and stubbornly high spirits. Getting around is easy, and its cool summers atone for some of winter's windy chills. Its legendary trees, blighted by disease, are fighting back. Canadian investors are stirring the economy. The State University of New York at Buffalo and other learning centers spark an active intellectual life. One can only pray that the city can keep and nourish its distinguished Philharmonic Orchestra.
If I grew up, it was in Buffalo. The Klinkenborg book captures many of the sounds and sights of that "city of panel-truck souls." I worked during my college summers not far from George & Eddie's, the East Side bar that is the star of the book. Relatives of mine have recently brought Buffalo baseball to the brink of major league status, ingeniously planting a gorgeous ball field in the heart of downtown.
I confess to a bias in favor of their National League franchise bid. Buffalo's minor league baseball, which outdraws some major league teams, has become a stylish civic event, even for baseball haters, with the help of side attractions like Pettibone's Grill, named for an ancestor.
At Sunday's American Conference championship game, when war anxiety was rising, Buffalonians on television showed their colors -- the flag's and the Bills' are the same -- and chanted from the stands that 1991 will be "the year of the red, white and blue." May the energy of those fans wave those banners proudly, in peace.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chief Operating Officer For Montgomery Ward

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
In a promotion that Montgomery Ward & Company called a step toward corporate growth, the Chicago-based retailer has announced the appointment of Daniel H. Levy as vice chairman and chief operating officer. He will be the first company executive in more than a decade to hold both titles.
Mr. Levy, who is 49, was previously Ward's president for the apparel and home furnishings group. He joined the company in 1987, a year before Bernard F. Brennan, its chairman, began a management buyout of the company from the Mobil Corporation. Since then, through a shrinking of the company, termination of its catalogue business and the adoption of a specialty-store approach, Montgomery Ward has generated steady increases in profits and expects to report record earnings soon for the 1990 fiscal year. 
 In a telephone interview yesterday, Mr. Brennan said he was not aware of industry reports that Mr. Levy had been offered the presidency of Hess's Department Stores Inc. and that Montgomery Ward promoted him to keep him. Hess's, based in Allentown, Pa., is a 70-store group owned by the Crown American Corporation, a leading mall developer.
"I don't know about such rumors," Mr. Brennan said, "but since our turnaround lots of recruiters have come after our senior people. But I have advanced Dan Levy steadily with the goal of eventually appointing to these new posts."
The job at Hess's is still open.
"We have to start planning our company for new growth, both internally and externally," Mr. Brennan added. "Most C.O.O.'s are operations people, but I felt that we needed a marketing and merchandising executive for the future like Dan Levy."
A New Yorker who started his retail career in 1964 as an assistant buyer at Bloomingdale's, Mr. Levy was associated with the Kaufmann's department stores in Pittsburgh from 1972 through 1979 as executive vice president, president and vice chairman. In 1981, he was merchandising senior vice president for Batus Inc., the American arm of B.A.T. Industries. He shifted to the Gimbels Pittsburgh group in 1982, where he was chairman and chief executive until he joined Ward's.
Mr. Levy holds a bachelor of science degree in economics from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School. He and his wife, Gayle, have two sons and live in Chicago.

HEADLINE: The Soviet Union Has Ceased to Exist

BYLINE: By Roman Szporluk; Roman Szporluk, professor of history at the University of Michigan, is the author of "Communism and Nationalism."

DATELINE: ANN ARBOR, MICH.

 BODY:
Although Mikhail Gorbachev insisted yesterday that "neither the internal nor the external policy has changed" in the Soviet Union, the truth is that everything has changed.
The Soviet interventions in Lithuania and Latvia have demolished any lingering hopes that Mikhail Gorbachev could transform the Soviet Union into a free association of republics. In essence, the Soviet Union has ceased to exist. The great question now, which will be played out over the next months and years, is what will emerge in its stead. 
 Before the Jan. 13 invasion of Lithuania, there was still hope that the republics could attain independence peacefully and go on to freely establish economic ties that would benefit them all. This still may occur, but not under the leadership of Mr. Gorbachev, who has clearly chosen to save the empire by falling back on the army, secret police and central bureaucracy.
While the crackdowns in Lithuania and Latvia mark the end of the reformist Gorbachev era, they do not portend, as some are saying, a return to the old ways. Given the political change that has already occurred and the country's sickly economy -- which might collapse entirely following a countrywide crackdown -- repression is not a solution.
The current trouble can be traced to early last year, when the Communist Party abdicated its constitutional claim to rule that had been based on its alleged insight into the laws of history. This left no justification, for holding the peoples of the Soviet Union together by force under a central Government in Moscow.
That Government lacked any alternative, democratic legitimacy. The Soviet Union might have been preserved by a popular, democratic election of a representative assembly that would in turn agree on a constitution binding all. But none of this was done. The central authorities in Moscow never acquired a democratic or constitutional foundation. The only democratic elections took place in some republics, regions and cities, most successfully in the Baltic states.
It is revealing and tragic that Mr. Gorbachev and his reactionary allies in Moscow have chosen to apply force precisely against nations that have behaved in a civilized, law-abiding way, free of terrible inter-ethnic violence. It is revealing because the Baltic states are defenseless, a fact that doubtless was not lost on a military that will think twice before invading one of the larger republics, such as Georgia and Azerbaijan, where the citizenry is more heavily armed.
It is tragic because Mr. Gorbachev has failed to understand that the Baltic states would have made excellent allies of Russia -- would have been another Finland -- had they been allowed to become independent. And we know that Finland has helped the Soviet Union economically without in any way threatening its security.
Although Vilnius in 1991 resembles Prague in 1968 and Budapest in 1956, there is something completely new in the present situation. The brutal action in Lithuania was condemned not only by national democratic movements in the republics but also by some of the establishment. Most importantly, the leader of the Russian republic, Boris Yeltsin, has condemned the action. Moreover, mass demonstrations in Moscow and other major cities show that his stand has popular support among Russians.
Mr. Yeltsin's move is consistent with a policy he has quietly and steadfastly pursued since his election last spring. Drawing on his relatively democratic credentials, he has defined himself as a spokesman for Russia, not a claimant to leadership in the Soviet Union.
In his travels to non-Russian republics, Mr. Yeltsin has been building the foundation for a new relationship between Russia and the republics. Not only has he recognized the Baltic states but, during a little-noticed trip to Kiev in November, he signed a treaty recognizing the Ukraine as a sovereign state and Russia's equal -- a move without precedent in Russian-Ukrainian relations.
Mr. Yeltsin and his advisers understand that the political independence of the republics does not preclude their economic cooperation with Russia. Unlike Mr. Gorbachev, they realize that ethnic affairs in the former Soviet Union have been transformed into international relations, and that political liberalization and economic reforms must proceed from this fact.
Events in the Baltics have destroyed any hope that economic reform will be promoted by the center. Mr. Gorbachev's new allies oppose the market and private property, and he has removed the reformers from the leadership. Any further reform must come from the republics.
What is likely to happen next? As the Soviet economy declines, we can expect a more severe and brutal version of the Polish crisis of 1981, which followed Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski's declaration of martial law. Throughout the 1980's, General Jaruzelski tried to institute economic reforms without political liberalization. Eventually, he gave up.
Mr. Gorbachev's problems run much deeper, since he also has to deal with republics demanding independence. In the Soviet version of this crisis, reactionaries in the center will battle reformers in the republics. As that struggle unfolds, a key role will go to Mr. Yeltsin, because he alone among the major Soviet figures active today has the credibility and vision to offer a way out of the chaos that seems likely to become Mr. Gorbachev's chief legacy.
The latest turn of events presents a dilemma for policymakers in the U.S. and the West. They understandably wish to keep dealing with Mr. Gorbachev, whose foreign policy has, to say the least, served Western interests. Yet, they have to recognize that to support Mr. Gorbachev and condone the repression in the Baltic states is to harm the forces of political and economic reform in all the republics.
In this respect, yesterday's decision by the European Parliament to block a $1 billion aid package was only half right. Actions aimed at penalizing the center should be accompanied by gestures of support for the democratic aspirations of the people.

HEADLINE: Eating Well

BYLINE: By Densie Webb; Densie Webb, a freelance writer and editor, is a registered dietitian.

 BODY:
IN recent years there has been a spate of research on how diet affects health and a dearth of practical information on what to do in the kitchen if one aspires to good health yet lusts for good food.
Now a biophysicist from Boston University School of Medicine has blended his research with the down-to-earth task of cooking dinner and produced a little kitchen chemistry that allows cooks to lower the fat and cholesterol content significantly of any grade of ground beef, lamb, veal or pork. 
 Dr. Donald Small, chairman of the department of biophysics at Boston University School of Medicine, developed a technique for lowering the fat content of ground meat. A paper outlining the procedure, which was published in The New England Journal of Medicine two weeks ago, received international coverage.
At first glance, the preparation seemed cumbersome and time-consuming, leaving some people questioning whether the fat saved was worth the extra effort.
If the most recent national dietary survey is any indication, a significant amount of fat could be saved by using Dr. Small's procedure for defatting ground beef. The survey, conducted by the United States Department of Health and Human Services from 1976 through 1980, found that ground beef was the single largest contributor of fat to the American diet.
Dr. Small said the idea for the procedure just hit him one day while he was cooking, and he spent the next seven years perfecting it.
He now uses the procedure for all of the ground meat he eats. As strange as it sounds, the first step in Dr. Small's procedure calls for cooking ground meat slowly in a large amount of oil, about one and a half cups for every two pounds of ground meat. When heated, the oil causes the animal fat to leach out of the meat and to dissolve in the oil in which it is being cooked.
The cooked meat is then strained and rinsed with boiling water to remove any leftover oil. The liquid from straining and rinsing is kept and refrigerated to separate the broth from the oil.
Once the fat is removed, the fat-free broth is added to the meat and it is ready to use in dishes like chili, tacos, enchiladas, spaghetti sauce, stuffed peppers, stuffed grape leaves, lasagna, burritos, soups and moussaka.
Because the meat does not hold together, making dishes like hamburgers or meat loaf is not feasible. But Dr. Small has begun experimenting with binders like egg whites and oatmeal to develop a technique to make those kinds of dishes with low-fat ground meat.
In his laboratory analysis, Dr. Small found that his method of extracting fat reduced the fat content of cooked meat by an average of 68 percent and the cholesterol content by 39 percent. That would produce ground beef with only 21 percent of its calories from fat, instead of 65 percent, making its fat content comparable to skinless chicken breast.
If the same meat is cooked as a meat patty and the fat drained off, the fat savings would be only 6 to 17 percent and the cholesterol loss 9 to 18 percent.
Using Dr. Small's method, some of the vegetable oil used during the procedure also replaces the saturated fat in the meat.
"You end up with a meat that has the fatty acid composition of a healthy vegetable oil," Dr. Small said in an interview.
Any vegetable oil will do the job. Dr. Small has used safflower, canola, soybean, olive and generic vegetable oil with equal success.
He estimated that if a person consuming a "typical American diet" with 35 to 40 percent of calories from fat substituted one-third of the meat in the diet with reduced-fat meat, he would cut daily cholesterol intake by about 35 percent and saturated fat intake by about 20 percent.
This, Dr. Small said, could result in a drop of six or seven points in blood cholesterol.
For every 1 percent drop in blood cholesterol, there is about a 2 percent drop in the risk of heart disease, according to the National Institutes of Health. A person with a cholesterol level of 250, who experienced a decrease of seven points would theoretically enjoy a 6 percent decrease in the risk of heart disease.
As to the practicality of the procedure, Gail Levey, a registered dietitian who is a spokeswoman for the American Dietetic Association said: "It is an elaborate procedure, but if somebody uses a lot of chopped meat, I think it's probably worth it. But for somebody like me who only eats meat maybe once a month, I don't know how practical it would be."
Ms. Levey, who tried the procedure at home, said the only way to make it practical is to have all the ingredients and supplies assembled beforehand and to prepare three or four pounds at a time.
Dr. Small insists that if the meat is to be cooked and drained anyway, the additional steps required to extract more of the fat and cholesterol take only an extra 5 to 10 minutes.
When I tested the procedure, it took only 15 minutes using a gravy skimmer to separate the oil, rather than separating it by refrigeration as Dr. Small recommends, a step that can take up to an hour. If the meat is prepared in bulk and frozen in half-pound to one-pound portions, a minimal amount of additional time is required for each meal in which the meat is used.
A shortcut to reducing the fat is to rinse cooked ground meat with boiling water. Dr. Small's analyses showed that fat could be cut by more than 50 percent just by rinsing, but he said that the meat is "relatively dry and tasteless" because the flavorful broth is not used.
The procedure to extract fat works with any grade of ground meat.
The more fat the meat contains at the start, the more fat is lost during the extraction. Though a meat with a igher fat content is less expensive, the more fat the meat contains at the start, Dr. Small said, the less yield there is of reduced-fat meat, canceling out any initial savings.
As for the cost of the oil, olive oil would be the least economical. Because any vegetable oil works, the best bet is to use whatever is on sale. Dr. Small said the oil can be saved and used three or four times with results that are almost as good as the first time.
It's an individual decision as to whether the process is worth the time and effort. If ground beef, lamb, pork and veal are staples in your kitchen, then the amount of fat saved could be significant.
But as Ms. Levey said: "For people who have already tossed out meat and are making meatless lasagnas, for them I would say they should stick with what they're doing. You're still better off eating a spinach lasagna than a lasagna with meat."
 
The Key: Oil
 
Low-Fat, Low-Cholesterol Ground Meat (Adapted from The New England Journal of Medicine)
 
Total time: 15 minutes
 
 2 pounds raw meat, ground (beef, veal, pork or lamb)
 1 1/2 cups vegetable oil
 2 cups boiling water.
1. Add the meat to the vegetable oil and heat to 176 to 194 Fahrenheit, while stirring. Use a candy thermometer to check the temperature. If it becomes too hot, the meat will fry and the fat will not be removed.
2. Stir for 5 minutes, allowing the meat and the oil to mix thoroughly. The meat will begin to brown.
3. Heat the meat and oil mixture to boiling, 212 Fahrenheit, for 5 more minutes while stirring, to finish browning the meat and boil off excess water.
4. Drain the hot mixture in either a large strainer or a colander, collecting the oil and remaining water into a measuring cup or bowl.
5. Pour the boiling water over the meat in the strainer or colander, collecting the water in the same cup or bowl in which the oil was collected.
6. Separate the fat from the broth by cooling the container in the refrigerator until the fat hardens on top and can be discarded or to save time, use a turkey baster to draw out only the broth that settles on the bottom or use a gravy skimmer.
7. The fat-free broth can be added immediately back to the cooked meat or it can be boiled to reduce the volume.
Yield: Approximately 5 cups.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 5, 1991, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
The Eating Well column in The Living Section on Jan. 23, about a technique for lowering the fat content of meat, miscalculated the percentage of calories from fat in ground beef from which fat had been removed. The technique produces ground beef with 37 percent of its calories from fat, comparable to a skinless chicken leg.

HEADLINE: Agency's View Of Recession

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Congressional budget officials today joined the growing number of economic experts predicting that the recession will be a brief one.
Robert Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, told the Senate Budget Committee that his agency "expects the recession to end by midyear and to be followed by a period of solid economic growth and significantly reduced inflation."
Mr. Reischauer said he expected the economy to grow by a weak 1.3 percent this year, measured from the fourth quarter of 1990 to the fourth quarter of 1991.
But in 1992, the economy will grow by 3.4 percent, he said. And he said that as the country pulls out of the recession, inflation -- now about 6 percent -- will drop to about 4 percent this year and 3.5 percent in 1992.
Despite his upbeat assessment of the economy's long- term performance, Mr. Reischauer told the senators that the economy will shrink for two consecutive quarters, the last quarter of 1990 and this year's first quarter.
That prediction, in which he was joined by White House budget officials, formally initiates a process under which Congress will decide whether to abandon last year's budget deal. But it seems highly unlikely that Congress will do so. The vote seems likely in the next few days.

HEADLINE: Delta Loss Sets Record

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Delta Air Lines Inc. said today that it had lost $207.8 million in the fourth quarter of 1990. It was the worst quarterly performance in company history.
The loss was attributed to the surge in fuel prices since the Persian Gulf crisis began, to the recession and to the discount fares that Delta said it was forced to offer to compete with the fading Eastern Airlines.
In the fourth quarter of 1989, Delta had net income of $64.2 million, or $1.13 a share.
Eastern, which went out of business on Friday night, was Delta's main competitor at Hartsfield International Airport in Atlanta. As Eastern tried to stay alive during a bankruptcy court reorganization, it began offering drastic discounts, which Delta often matched.
Delta's revenue for the 1990 fourth quarter was up 3.9 percent, to $2.13 billion, compared with $2.05 billion in 1989.
For the year, Delta lost $154 million, compared with earnings of $473.2 million, or $9.23 a share, in 1989. Revenue totaled $8.7 billion, up 1.2 percent from $8.6 billion in 1989.
Trading on Delta stock at the New York Stock Exchange was halted for about 90 minutes this afternoon in anticipation of the loss announcement. Delta's shares closed today at $66.625, down 12.5 cents.
Analysts said the last three months of 1990 had been difficult for all the nation's airlines. Last week the parent company of American Airlines reported a fourth-quarter loss of $215.1 million.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Wang Posts Loss Again

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LOWELL, Mass., Jan. 23

 BODY:
The computer maker Wang Laboratories Inc., which has been slashing costs, said today that it lost money in the last quarter as its revenue slumped.
For the quarter that ended on Dec. 31, Wang lost $24.7 million, compared with a loss of $10.5 million in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Wang's loss a year ago was reduced sharply by a one-time gain of $93 million from the sale of its 30 percent stake in a manufacturing plant in Taiwan.
Revenue for the latest period, which is Wang's second quarter, totaled $551.5 million, down 14.7 percent from $646.7 million a year earlier.
Despite the loss, Wang said its cash flow from operations remained positive. The company reported an operating loss -- earnings before interest expenses and income taxes -- of $7.7 million for the last quarter. It had an operating loss of $8.3 million a year earlier. But Richard W. Miller, Wang's chairman and chief executive, said the company's turnaround plans would be hurt by the weakening economies worldwide, the Persian Gulf war and sluggishness in the market for midrange computers.
Wang's close B shares slipped 12.5 cents today, to $2.625, on the American Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Sandiford Wins Second Term As Barbados Prime Minister

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Prime Minister Erskine Sandiford, running on a platform of "economic justice," easily won a second consecutive five-year term in parliamentary elections, according to final results today.
Mr. Sandiford's Democratic Labor Party captured 18 of the 28 seats in the House of Assembly, or Parliament, in Tuesday's balloting, the Electoral and Boundaries Commission announced.
The Barbados Labor Party, led by Henry Forde, won the remaining 10 seats, a gain of seven. The breakaway National Democratic Party, formed in 1989 by former Finance Minister Richie Haynes, lost all four of its seats.
Mr. Sandiford is one of the chief proponents of economic cooperation among the developing nations of the Caribbean. He has criticized the United States for what he regards as restrictive trade barriers, like low sugar import quotas.
