HEADLINE: Fast Start for G.M. Redesign Strategy

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 23

 BODY:
The new Buick Park Avenue sedan holds the distinction of being one of the few car models that has been selling briskly in a time of weak demand, and without the costly stimulus of rebates or other discounts.
The Park Avenue's strong sales in the last four months have encouraged the General Motors Corporation in its efforts to recapture customers by offering newly redesigned models, while avoiding the negative financial impact of low-interest financing and subsidized leasing plans, as well as rebates. 
 Buyers seem to like the new car's combination of price and looks, automotive industry analysts say. The Park Avenue costs between $27,000 and $30,000, depending on how well equipped the model is. With softer, rounder styling than past big G.M. cars, it is attracting some people who might otherwise have looked to European luxury cars.
Reviewers from several automotive enthusiast magazines, who routinely savage G.M. vehicles as drab and lethargic, rated the Park Avenue high on design, general allure and pleasing driving characteristics.
In recent years G.M. has introduced many models that started strong, only to fade after the initial excitement. Still, the company, which had been spending billions on new factories and tools while its market share dwindled, has lately redirected its financial resources to new vehicles like the Park Avenue. Executives at the nation's biggest auto maker are hoping that the warm reception for the Park Avenue will justify their efforts.
In this model year and next, G.M. is introducing 15 car and 7 truck models that have been substantially redesigned, more than any other car maker by far. These redesigns and work on new models beyond 1992 consumed the bulk of G.M.'s $7 billion capital outlay in 1990. G.M. says this spending pace will continue for several years.
Recent independent surveys show that G.M. has corrected many of the manufacturing problems and much of the shoddy workmanship in all model lines that drove customers away. In mid-1989, for example, G.M.'s Buick division surprised the industry by earning high marks from the influential J.D. Power & Associates, an automotive research company, in two important quality surveys.
But since its competitors are hardly standing still, G.M. must do more than simply eliminate defects to win back customers, automotive experts say. The auto maker has to make its interior and exterior styling more imaginative; improve the performance of engines and transmissions, and offer more advanced features like anti-lock brakes, which keep wheels from locking up during braking on slippery pavement, at reasonable prices.
The Park Avenue certainly seems to be a step in that direction. Its standard equipment includes anti-lock brakes and an air bag. The more luxurious versions like the higher-priced Ultra have an infrared security system with a remote control that opens the doors and trunk, and a climate control that allows a front-seat passenger to have a different temperature setting than the driver.
Car and Driver magazine, which frequently presents import models as the benchmark that Detroit routinely fails to meet, called the Park Avenue Ultra model "one significant step for Buick, one giant leap for G.M."
Buick executives have been jubilant at Park Avenue's reception by reviewers and the relatively strong early sales. In the first three months of the model year, Buick sold 21,979 Park Avenue models, an increase of 46.2 perecent over the corresponding period a year earlier. But Park Avenue sales, like those of all cars and trucks, have fallen sharply in January because of wariness over the crisis in the Middle East. Although Buick executives say dealers have been trading some import models for new Park Avenues, it is still too early to know whether the division is significantly adding business or just drawing from other G.M. brands.
To regain ground in the United States market, G.M. is trying to attract younger buyers who are driving imported brands, like Honda and Toyota, while hanging on to its traditional but dwindling pool of customers who would not dream of owning anything but a domestic car. G.M.'s Saturn and Chevrolet Geo cars attempt to lure younger import buyers.
The Park Avenue is primarily meant for the typical Buick customers who are looking for a comfortable sedan that can seat six. The company says the car is also attracting drivers in their 40's and early 50's who may be moving up to a luxury model and are considering imports.
"From a demographic viewpoint, Buick hit a home run," said Christopher Cedergren, who is in charge of evaluating vehicles for J.D. Power. Describing younger buyers who are considering the Park Avenue, Mr. Cedergren said: "This is a fringe generation. If the Park Avenue weren't there, this customer might buy Japanese."
The Park Avenue's performance and style do not match those of such Japanese and European luxury cars as the Lexus and BMW, he said. The Buick's ride is somewhat soft, especially compared with European road cars, although stiffer suspension and tighter handling options are availble.
 
Breaking the Mold
 But Park Avenue's price is at least $10,000 less than most of the model's foreign competition. That probably would not have been enough to assure Park Avenue's early success. But the car is also a distinct improvement over G.M.'s previous generation of domestic luxury cars: the Cadillac DeVille, Oldsmobile 98 and Buick Electra, introduced in 1984. Those three are about equal in size and weight and suffered from criticism that their boxy designs looked alike and were dated.
To make sure the Park Avenue's exterior styling was different, Buick designers rounded and softened their initial drawings and clay models. In fact, they borrowed styling themes from recent Jaguar models. Several reviewers noted a resemblance.
"There's a voluptuous quality," said William L. Porter, Buick's styling chief. "Not Euro-somebody or Oriental stir-fry, but rather an American motor car in the grand tradition of Buick." As for the Jaguar comparisons, Mr. Porter insists Buick is simply reclaiming designs that Jaguar filched in the 1940's.
G.M. engineers lengthened and widened the car, which increased the interior volume and trunk space. While the extra space added to the weight, the fuel-efficiency rating remained the same at 18 miles a gallon in city driving and 27 on the highway.
Buick engineers also increased Park Avenue's power with electronic and mechanical improvements to its six-cylinder engine. But the conventional V-6 could repel dedicated import-car owners, who for the most part prefer the engines with more than the usual two valves per cylinder used in luxury import brands.
Such multi-valve engines generally have just four cylinders, but are lighter and more powerful than American V-6's. They endow the car with a higher top speed and greater acceleration once it reaches moderate speed. G.M. engineers counter that the bigger V-6 engines give faster acceleration from a dead stop, a quality that their customers prefer.
Only if the Park Avenue can continue to sell without heavy rebates will it fulfill the auto maker's strategic goal of profitably increasing market share.
Buick executives know that strong early reaction to a new model does not guarantee strong sales for the three or four-year period until the next new model. When the new model was introduced in the fall of 1990 "availability was tight, a lot of people were ordering the car," said Stephen J. Snyder, general sales manager of Wilkins Buick in Glen Burnie, Md. "Now that they are more widely available, the Park Avenue is just another car in the lineup."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The new Buick Park Avenue sedan has been selling strongly without help from rebates or discounts. Car shoppers inspected the 1991 Park Avenue recently at Tamaroff Buick, a dealership in Southfield, Mich. (Peter Yates for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Is Driven Lower On Signs of a Rate Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was driven significantly lower yesterday by signs that United States interest rates may be headed down as German interest rates hold steady.
The dollar fell after testimony by Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve chairman, before the Senate Banking Committee that the Fed was considering a further rduction in interest rates, among other options, to help the United States economy start growing again. 
 Analysts said the market immediately interpreted his statements to mean the Fed might move to ease interest rates further, which would have the effect of eroding the dollar's value.
"The market would not be surprised if we saw a further cut as early as this week," said Bob Morrissey, senior trader for the Bank of Boston.
Some traders said they were caught off guard by Mr. Greenspan's comments because the remarks came one day after the Fed chairman seemed to indicate he would hold the line on interest rates and explore other methods of easing credit.
The dollar was down in particular against the German mark after statements from Germany's central bank that the nation's economy could not sustain lower interest rates and needed to keep its mark strong against other foreign currencies.
The dollar settled in New York at 1.4820 German marks, down from late Tuesday's 1.4970 marks.
The apparently unfavorable interest-rate climate overshadowed reports of another missile attack on Israel, which during less uncertain times might have prompted traders to flock to the dollar as a safe holding.
In New York, the dollar fell against the British pound. Sterling fetched $1.9595, more than late Tuesday's $1.9450. In London, the British pound rose to $1.9545, from $1.9490 late Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Florio Rejects Plan to Raise the PATH Fare

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey yesterday rejected a Port Authority of New York and New Jersey plan to raise the fare on PATH trains and withheld a decision on an increase in bridge and tunnel tolls that the authority is seeking.
"It makes no sense to make our mass transit system unaffordable for those who need it most," Mr. Florio said in a statement issued a day before officials of the authority had hoped board members would approve a budget that included the increases. The board meeting has been postponed. A spokeswoman for Mr. Florio, Nancy Kearney, said he was "still in the process of evaluating" the bridge and tunnel toll increase. 
 Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, whowith Mr. Florio has the power to veto the Port Authority's budget, also has not made a decision on the agency's plan, said his press secretary, Anne W. Crowley.
"We are still discussing the whole budget with both the Port Authority and the New Jersey Governor's office," she said.
The authority, which operates most of the region's seaports, its three major airports and many bridges, tunnels and transportation terminals, has argued that without the toll and fare increases it would be forced to cut $325 million in capital spending and about $25 million in operating expenses in 1991.
The reductions would come on top of about $300 million in similar cuts made last year, when the agency withdrew a proposal to raise tolls and the Path fare after encountering opposition from Trenton.
"I think it's fair to say that we're still having discussions," said Stanley Brezenoff, the Port Authority's executive director.
In his statement, Mr. Florio indicated he was not satisfied with the speed with which the authority was proceeding with projects in his state. He cited the need for a mass-transit link to Newark International Airport. "More needs to be done with respect to transportation projects that will contribute to the state's economic growth," he said in the statement. "These projects have been in the discussion stage for too long."
The Path fare increase would raise only $8 million of the $131 million that the authority anticipates it would gain from the higher fares and tolls. But agency officials had argued that it was necessary to raise the transit fare along with bridge and tunnel tolls because of a possible legal challenge from motorists over the extent to which the agency can use revenues from bridges and tunnels to subsidize the Path system and its bus terminals.
The authority wants to raise tolls to $4, from $3, for the George Washington, Bayonne and Goethals Bridges, the Outerbridge Crossing and the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels. Fares on the Path system would rise to $1.25, from $1.
The agency -- which raises money from tolls and fares, from bonds and from fees and rentals from airlines for airport gates and terminals -- has outlined plans to spend $5.4 billion from 1991 to 1995 on a capital program that includes rehabilitating its Hudson River crossings and modernizing the airports.
Even if it gets the toll and fare increases it is now seeking, officials have indicated, the authority would be likely to seek additional increases in 1994.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Silver Prices in a Plunge To Lowest Level in 15 Years

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Silver futures prices plunged yesterday to new 15-year lows as hopes for a quick resolution to the Middle East war continued to recede, leaving traders to ponder the oversupply that has weighed on the market for months.
Silver futures settled 9 cents to 10.6 cents lower on New York's Commodity Exchange, with the contract for spot delivery at $3.908 a troy ounce, the lowest spot silver price since February 1976. The more actively traded March contract finished at $3.937. 
 Gold futures ended $1 to $1.40 lower on the Commodity Exchange, with the January contract off $1, to $378.40 a troy ounce. The active February contract fell $1.20 an ounce, to 378.90.
Platinum settled $5.70 to $5.80 lower, with the spot January contract at $394.80 an ounce.
 
Off With the Economy
 Silver's value has generally fallen as the economy slowed, reflecting both its relative abundance and its use in the photographic, jewelry and electronics industries.
It dropped to $3.93 an ounce in mid-December, but by mid-January silver had ridden on gold's coattails to nearly $4.20 as investors, unnerved by the threat of war in the Persian Gulf, sought the perceived safety of precious metals, analysts said.
But recent developments indicate the gulf war may last longer than many expected, and investors are focusing on the possibility that the American economy will suffer in a prolonged war, according to Frederick Demler, metals economist with Paine Webber Inc. in New York.
"The euphoria of last week has turned to a realization this week that Saddam Hussein is in for the long haul," Mr. Demler said. "Consumer confidence is not as high as it was last week."
John Jonat, precious metals analyst with Deak International Inc., said the silver market "gave up the ghost" of following gold higher and has again come under pressure from oversupply.
Analysts said further selling was prompted by silver's drop below $4, a psychological barrier they said now looks more difficult to surmount than a month ago.
Livestock and meat futures, meanwhile, rose on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange ahead of a monthly Agriculture Department report that showed a greater supply of frozen pork bellies than was expected.
The department said there were 47.2 million pounds of pork bellies in cold storage as of Dec. 31, compared with expectations of about 46.7 million pounds.
Analysts said belly futures probably would open 0.50 cent to 0.75 cent lower today in reaction to the report.
Live cattle futures settled 0.02 cent to 0.67 cent higher, with February at 77.12 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to 0.58 cent higher, with January at 89.45 cents a pound; live hogs were 0.18 cent to 0.60 cent higher, with February at 51.35 cents a pound, and frozen pork bellies were 0.05 cent to 0.30 cent higher, with February at 67.40 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: Kohl Says Gulf War May Bring Tax Rise

BYLINE: By FERDINAND PROTZMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl today raised the possibility of lifting German taxes, citing Bonn's increased contribution to the allied effort in the Persian Gulf war as the reason. But economists said part of any additional tax revenues would be used to finance the ever-higher costs of German unification.
The international implication of Mr. Kohl's statement is that higher taxes, if enacted, would reduce the nation's borrowing needs and ease the pressure to maintain high interest rates. High German rates have been criticized by Bonn's European neighbors because it makes it more difficult for them to lower their own rates to stimulate economic growth. 
 Mr. Kohl did not give a specific figure for the increase in the German contribution to the United Nations' effort to drive Iraqi forces out of Kuwait, saying it would be "of a large dimension which we will not be able to finance by normal budgetary means."
"I cannot exclude that we will have to raise revenues for some time," Mr. Kohl said. Asked if that meant a tax increase, he said, "I cannot exclude that either." He did not say which taxes might be raised.
 
'Fig Leaf' Seen
 Finance Minister Theo Waigel said on Monday in New York that Germany would pay more toward the cost of the war. Government sources in Bonn said the new aid could total as much as $6.7 billion. Germany has already promised $2.2 billion for the war effort and financial assistance to front-line nations like Egypt, Turkey and Jordan.
Economists said financing Bonn's contribution to the war also presented Mr. Kohl with an easy way around the promise he made during his re-election campaign in December not to raise taxes.
"I would call his statement a fig leaf," said Warren Oliver, an economist with UBS Phillips & Drew in London. "Everyone has been expecting tax increases because the costs of unity are proving greater than anticipated. The gulf war provided an unassailable excuse."
The German budget deficit is expected to total well over $100 billion this year, up from $73.3 billion last year. Some experts say it could top $120 billion because of a surge in borrowing by the five new states in eastern Germany. Economists have estimated the cost of reviving eastern Germany at $1 trillion to $2 trillion over the next 10 years.
The Bundesbank has kept interest rates high in an attempt to counter the potential inflationary effects of the soaring Government budget deficit and demands for large pay increases by labor unions. The Bundesbank's president, Karl Otto Pohl, indicated on Tuesday that the bank intended to maintain its restrictive course.
"The Deutsche mark is a stable currency and there is no reason to doubt that it will remain so in the future," he said.
That stance and Germany's high interest rates have irked France and other European countries whose monetary policies are tied to Germany's through the European Monetary System. The system limits the exchange rate movements of most European Community currencies to a specific range.
Economic growth in France and elsewhere in Europe is slowing, however, and there is a growing fear of negative effects from the gulf war. French officials say Germany's tight monetary policy is keeping them from lowering interest rates in an effort to stimulate economic growth.
"It is vain to think you can compensate for budgetary policy which is too expansionary with monetary policy which is too restrictive," the French Finance Minister, Pierre Beregovoy, said in late December of the German position.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Striving to Keep Libraries Open In Budget Pinch

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
A 13-year-old Brooklyn boy is the unsung hero of the Saratoga branch library, but his may have been a hollow victory.
From across the street, he called the police to report that vandals were stripping copper flashing and gutters again from the Spanish tile roof of the 83-year-old library building, endowed by Andrew Carnegie, on Hopkinson Avenue in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville section. The vandalism had begun a year earlier, but library officials said they lacked the $42,000 or so needed for repairs; moreover, the job was apparently too small then to qualify for an emergency contract from New York City's construction budget. 
 Finally, the damage became so severe -- and the rehabilitation project so large -- that the leaky library was shuttered last fall. The suspected vandals were caught a few weeks later.
After lobbying by Howard Golden, the Brooklyn Borough President, and an expedited response from the city's Department of General Services, a new roof is expected to be completed next week. Repairing interior water damage is likely to take months more -- maybe until the end of the year. The total bill is likely to be about $300,000.
But even when the branch reopens, the young boy who so impressed grand jurors with his testimony against the vandals that he received a standing ovation will be shortchanged. As a result of budget cuts, library service throughout the city is being curtailed. The Saratoga branch, with 7,116 card-carrying borrowers, would be open only three days a week: Tuesday and Thursday afternoons, from 1 to 5 P.M., and Wednesdays, from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.
Its problems are, in some respects, emblematic of a system that historically has been both a vehicle for advancement and an early line of defense against juvenile delinquency -- a term that seems quaint, given the degree of violent crime committed by teen-agers today. This week, a City Council panel headed by Councilman Sal F. Albanese of Brooklyn documented an alarming increase in juvenile arrests.
 Among the recommendations made by the panel were expanded after-school programs and greater focus on literacy. Mr. Albanese also hailed libraries as "a safe haven."
Children have been Mayor David N. Dinkins's mantra. His administration has gone to some lengths to preserve the youth services component of his public safety proposal and to all but guarantee that no library will be closed completely. Nonetheless, the impact of the libraries' share of economies will be profound, even if not all of the threatened or planned austerity measures are imposed or maintained.
This month, officials announced these reductions:
In Brooklyn, the central libary at Grand Army Plaza will be closed on Mondays; 52 of the 58 branches will be open only parts of three or four days a week. Nearly all of the branches will be closed on weekends. Layoffs are to take effect next week.
In Queens, only the central library will remain open on Sundays; 35 of the 62 branches have lost an additional day of service since the fiscal year started last July.
The New York Public Library will reduce hours at its central research library three days a week -- leaving some people little alternative but to camp on the Fifth Avenue steps and read what they can between the lions. Nineteen of the 82 branches in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island, which receive most of their financial support from the city, will be open only three days a week because, officials said, the library's total allotment from the city has been reduced by $5.9 million from the $68.5 million approved last summer; about 40 employees are expected to be laid off, effective next week.
A Mayor must choose sometimes among hiring more police officers, dismissing teachers and improving library services. Only imagination and energy define other choices, though.
Libraries in many public schools never recovered from the city's fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's. Why not find some means of melding the school and public libraries to capitalize on scarce resources? Why not encourage corporations -- particularly those that depend on literacy -- and individuals to adopt branch libraries in much the same way that they subsidize individual schools? These strategies are under discussion, but, perhaps, without the urgency to which youngsters, in particular, are entitled.
For want of a roof, a library was lost. For want of its books, more children may be lost in a tough neighborhood where the teen-ager whose diligence spared the Saratoga branch from further damage declined to be honored publicly because his grandmother feared reprisals.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Strategy;
Iraq: Hidden Cards?

BYLINE: By R.W. APPLE JR., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Is Saddam Hussein playing possum? If so, what does that portend for the course of the war in the Persian Gulf? A week after allied bombers opened the campaign to oust Iraq from Kuwait, those are the most pressing questions facing American strategists.
 Iraqi air bases, control posts, troop units and supply lines have been heavily damaged, according to witnesses and allied assessments. Enemy radar operations are said to have dropped off. The allies say their losses have been tiny. 
 Officials say Mr. Hussein has launched no militarily meaningful air, ground or naval attacks on allied forces in Saudi Arabia. "He has not thrown a single military punch at us," Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said at a Pentagon briefing today.
Yet allied officials acknowledge that most of Iraq's army and air force remain intact, despite an air assault of unprecedented intensity. There is no indication yet that the Iraqis have lost either the capacity or the will to defend conquered Kuwait and their homeland.
As a result, a widespread expectation has developed here and in Riyadh that the war is going to last longer than many had anticipated. Three months or longer is now a commonly voiced estimate. Few officers predict a ground attack before another two weeks have passed, at least. That may be disinformation, designed to mask the allies' real intentions, but it seems more likely that it reflects the need for further softening-up raids.
 
Iraqis 'Hunkering Down'
 "They are hunkering down, probably questioning whether we can keep this up," General Powell said. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney conceded that major surprises might still lie ahead and added, "No one should assume that Saddam Hussein does not have significant remaining military capacity."
"For one reason or another," a British staff officer commented, "Saddam has decided to play it long. He says in his speeches that he hasn't yet begun to fight, and from my vantage point, that seems to be true enough. The only question is, why?"
Vladimir N. Sakharov, a former Soviet military attache in Iraq who defected to the United States, said this week that the Iraqis had assimilated much of basic Russian military doctrine. One of its principal tenets, he said, is to conserve one's resources if attacked by a superior enemy, with the intention of launching a surprise counterattack with massed forces.
Baghdad has committed no more than a fraction of its 600-odd combat aircraft to battle, and although a few American officers see this as evidence that Iraqi pilots lack the stomach for a fight or that most of their bases are unusable, many find it a disturbing development.
 
Damage to Communications
 In addition, American intelligence suggests that although the communications network by which Mr. Hussein controls the defense of Iraq and Kuwait has been damaged, there are enough backup systems to keep him in touch.
Nor is there much conviction here that the bombing has sapped the fighting qualities of the Iraqis or destroyed their capacity to adapt, repair, invent, replace and survive, as populations under air assault have often done. Like economic sanctions, bombing has made life in Baghdad and Basra and on the front much harder, but there are no signs yet of any large-scale defections.
A United States Marine officer on the Kuwaiti brder, relecting a typical view here, said he believed he was faced with elaborate systems of trenches and underground headquarters that would prove largely impervious to air attack. Skeptical about what he termed "Pentagon euphoria," he predicted that a bloody land offensive would be needed to break the 30 or more Iraqi divisions based in or near Kuwait.
The American command said today that to date its pilots had shot down 19 enemy planes and destroyed 22 more planes on the ground. Even if the figures are conservative, that would leave more than 500 combat aircraft in President Hussein's inventory.
 
Refuges for Planes
 According to pilots' accounts, some planes have been flown to northern Iraq, where there are at least three big airfields. Others may be hidden in tunnel-like bunkers with walls four feet thick and heavy blast doors, built in recent years by British contractors. Some hangars are believed to be buried in huge sand dunes, making the job of hitting them harder.
"If he has saved all those planes," an American operations officer said, "he must plan to use the for some big bang or other. Maybe a chemical attack on Israel, hoping that if he sends enough planes one or two could penetrate their air defenses. Maybe a run against our ships with Exocet missiles. Maybe an attempt to hit our ground forces as we move up."
Exocet missiles, made in France, proved deadly against British ships during the war in the Falkland Islands, sinking the frigate Sheffield. It was an Iraqi Exocet that severely damaged the American frigate Stark in the Persian Gulf in May 1987. Civilian analysts have spoken as well about the possibility that Mr. Hussein might be planning to use an even more horrific weapon, never before employed in combat, known as the fuel air bomb, which spreads a circle of fire.
 
Closer to Parity
 Others believe that the Iraqi leader will commit his planes and other weapons that he has held back, such as chemical and perhaps biological agents, only when the ground battle has been joined. Although on a man-for-man basis Iraqi troops are not considered a match for American, British and other allied troops, the size of the Iraqi ground forces means that they come far closer to equal strength with their opponents than Iraqi air or naval forces.
Their chances of hanging on for a time would be improved if even a fraction of Baghdad's planes could be used to support their resistance.
Iraq's intention would not be winning the war at a stroke, which allied officers and most analysts consider well beyond Mr. Hussein's reach, but striking a psychological blow, perhaps weakening the allied coalition by pulling Israel into the war and stringing out the conflict in the hope that public opinion in the United States would tire of protracted fighting.
Mr. Cheney sought to dismiss that possibility today with the comment, "He will quit long before we do."
Clearly, Vietnam is the Iraqi leader's model, at least in part. But his terrain is much more favorable to the allies than Ho Chi Minh's, and he has other disadvantages, such as the difficulty of resupply and the lack of a highly motivated civilian population and a mass political party.
Still, even in eventual defeat, experts on the Middle East think Mr. Hussein might be able to make himself a warrior-hero to many Arabs, as did Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt. The longer he can hold out, the more he can argue that he stood up to the United States and other big Western nations and the more he can foment continued unrest in an already unstable region.

HEADLINE: Audi Spending Heavily to Rebuild Image

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TROY, Mich., Jan. 23

 BODY:
Few automotive brands have been besmirched in recent years as much as Audi.
To brighten its tarnished image, the German auto maker introduced today its new "Take Control" advertising campaign, which will be broadcast this week on radio and in two 60-second spots during the Super Bowl on ABC. Newspaper and magazine ads will follow in a yearlong effort estimated to cost $40 million to $50 million. 
 Still, like many advertisers concerned about placing their message alongside reports of the Persian Gulf war, Audi has issued instructions to pull any commercials during breaks for war news. The company said it also might cancel ads later in the year "if the economy becomes disastrous," said Ben Hilverda, Audi's director of marketing.
"We're a victim of timing," he said. "It's one area I can't control."
 
Good Reason for Urgency
 Audi, a division of Volkswagen A.G., has good reason for attacking its image problems with urgency. Sales of Audis have plummeted since a report in 1986 on the CBS program "60 Minutes" said Audis could accelerate out of control and cause accidents -- charges that never were substantiated. From a peak of 74,000 cars sold in 1985, Audi sales dropped to a mere 21,000 last year.
The charges against Audi were made by drivers involved in accidents, but tests in automotive laboratories could never reproduce the reported "unintended acceleration."
But Audi has also suffered from a less-than-stellar reputation for mechanical reliability and a soaring price because of the appreciation of the German mark.
While Audi floundered, the competition flourished, with Japanese auto makers introducing luxury brands and Mercedes and BMW aggressively going after the same market niche.
 
'Our Image Was Confused'
 "When we asked, people told us our image was confused," Mr. Hilverda said. "They recognized our cars as beautifully designed with good handling, but they also talked about mechanical problems."
The "Take Control" slogan, portrayed visually by Audi's symbol of four interlocking rings, is meant to convey the company's philosophy of "enabling the driver to have complete confidence and control" in all weather conditions and on all road surfaces.
The interlocking-rings, recognized by 81 percent of the company's target market, replaced Audi's old symbol, an oval.
In the luxury-car market, Audi is one of the few car lines to offer four-wheel-drive, which it calls "Quattro." Thus, the advertisements talk a great deal about poor weather, slippery roads and how comforted the driver will feel when power is transferred automatically "to the wheels that can use it best."
 
$800,000 a Commercial
 The campaign was created by Audi's ad agency, DDB Needham Worldwide, in Troy, Mich., where the auto maker's American operations are based, and in Chicago.
As for mechanical reliability, Audi believes recent quality surveys by J. D. Power & Associates and Maritz, the automotive consulting firms, confirm that those concerns have been solved.
At $800,000 for each 30-second commercial, the decision to buy time on the Super Bowl obviously was significant. But Audi believes it will be worthwhile because it expects about 72 percent of the prospective import luxury-car buyers to be watching the football game. One commercial will be shown during the pre-game show and the other during the first commercial break of the third quarter.

HEADLINE: Super Bowl Is All New York! (With Some Qualifications)

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY

 BODY:
A battle between a state's two largest cities sounds like such a promising civic rivalry, a throwback to the famous Subway Series between New York's baseball teams. But something seems to be missing from the Super Bowl this Sunday.
Football fans are not calling it the Thruway Thriller. No headline writer has suggested the Empire Spate. The New York Post half-heartedly offered "The Supe's in a New York State of Mind," and reporters pestered Gov. Mario M. Cuomo with awkward questions about his loyalties, but otherwise the press and the fans have paid little attention to the all-New York angle. 
 One possible explanation is that the New York Giants' move to a stadium in New Jersey complicated everything, since it means that the only authentic New Yorkers in the Super Bowl are the ones from Buffalo. To some fans, that means there are no authentic New Yorkers in the Super Bowl.
 
Shuffle Off to Where?
 But the issue may go beyond even New Jersey. Another explanation for the civic indifference, suggested by the results of an unscientific survey of 25 adults in Manhattan, is that the average Giants fan has no idea where Buffalo is. The typical fan in the survey could not even place Buffalo in the correct half of the state.
Still another explanation, backed by the work of scholars, is that New York City and Buffalo have never really belonged in the same state anyway. These geographers have argued that it would make more cultural and economic sense to put Buffalo in another state, along with parts of northern Pennsylvania and perhaps Cleveland.
The current boundaries created problems for politicians this week. Yesterday, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, a lifelong Giants fan, explained his Super Bowl preference by saying: "I've always been a stand-up guy, and nobody can ever accuse me of not letting you know where I stand -- until now. I'm rooting for the best team."
Mr. Cuomo, ever the agonizer when it comes to decisions, at first tried neutrality when asked about the Super Bowl. "Who are you rooting for?" he said to reporters. "I need instruction."
 
Cuomo Declares His Intention
 The Governor cited the Giants' odd status -- still named after New York but playing in East Rutherford, N.J. -- and mused: "They thought enough about their roots never to give up their name. On the other hand, the guy who stayed home, there's a special feeling there, too. But they're both born-in-New York teams."
On Tuesday he finally took a stand. Mr. Cuomo, a Queens native, announced that, having rooted the New York Giants and the New York Jets on to past Super Bowl victories, he would be rooting for the Buffalo Bills when they take the field in Tampa on Sunday at 6:15 P.M. (New York time). This left his press secretary, Anne Crowley, with some intricate -- not to say sophistic -- explaining to do.
"He's not going against the Giants; he's going for Buffalo," Ms. Crowley said yesterday. "He's supportive of the Giants."
She said the decision was based on "a criterion of need," since the Bills were the only New York team without a Super Bowl title, and on the fact that Mr. Cuomo had helped lure the quarterback, Jim Kelly, to Buffalo by promising to support the Bills.
 
'Our Giants,' Florio Says
 Mr. Cuomo did demonstrate some loyalty to the Giants by turning down a bet offered on Tuesday by the Governor of New Jersey, Jim Florio, who was watching Mr. Cuomo's plight with some amusement.
"I understand the Governor's confusion," Mr. Florio said yesterday, "because there used to be three football teams in New York. But the Jets and the Giants play in New Jersey now, so there's only one left. We wanted to bet on our Giants against his Bills. But since he doesn't want to, we're going to send him a nice sweatshirt to help him root for his team."
The sweatshirt, which Mr. Florio held up at a public appearance in Jersey City yesterday, has a Buffalo Bills logo on the front and a New Jersey Giants logo on the back.
One merit to Mr. Florio's view of the game is that a New York-New Jersey rivalry would at least be interesting. The residents of both states know each other well enough to have a healthy mutual disregard. But Buffalo remains a mystery to most Giants fans -- or at least to 25 reasonably sober adults interviewed in Manhattan bars this week.
 
Shrugs All Around
 When asked to point to Buffalo on a blank map of New York State, only three of the 25 men and women came within 50 miles. The average margin of error was 150 miles. The most common answer put Buffalo in the eastern half of the state, somewhere above Albany; the next most common answer was east of Rochester, on the wrong lake.
"The real answer is: Does anybody here care where Buffalo is?" said Tom Leder, an assistant commodities trader from Garden City, L.I., who was one of the three to get Buffalo's location. "When people think New York, they don't think Buffalo. It really would be more appropriate to have Buffalo in the Canadian Football League."
"Buffalo, there's just nothing there," said David Lois, a sanitation worker from the Bronx who placed Buffalo near Albany. "When you think about Buffalo, all you can think about is cold. It's surprising to me they even have fans. I just can't think of it being in New York."
 
Worry About That Offense
 Dave Sims, a talk-show host on the sports radio station WFAN-AM, said callers this week had been been concerned only with the football teams, not their cities or states.
"If there's a city rivalry, it's news to me," he said. "The Giants fans are worried about stopping the Bills' offense, but there's no animosity against Buffalo. You can't compare this to the Subway Series. If the Giants were playing Philly or Boston, there'd be some natural rivalry, but Buffalo is -- what, four or five hundred miles west?"
Actually, it's only 372, according to Rand-McNally's highway calculations, but that still means it's farther from New York City than Pittsburgh, Norfolk and Portland, Maine. This distance is one reason geographers have suggested that it would be more logical to put Buffalo in another state.
One proposal was put forth in the early 1970's by G. Etzel Pearcy, a geographer at California State University who drew a map of a 38-state America. One state, Hudson, would include downstate New York, northern New Jersey and parts of Connecticut and Massachusetts. Buffalo would be in the adjoining state of Mohawk, which would start around Albany and include most of upstate New York as well a strip of northern Pennsylvania.
 
Not to Be Outdone
 Another geographer, Stanley Brunn, has drawn a 16-state America that places Buffalo at the eastern end of a state he calls Industry, which includes western Pennsylvania, all of Ohio and much of Michigan. New York City and northern New Jersey belong to a separate state he calls Empire.
"Buffalo is much more similar to Pittsburgh and Erie and Cleveland than it is to New York City," said Dr. Brunn, a professor at the University of Kentucky at Lexington, "and New York has much more in common with Philadelphia or Boston. When it comes to the way people think of themselves, a regional identity is much more important than a state boundary drawn a long time ago."
At least one geographer, though, thinks it might be premature to expel Buffalo from New York State. The geographer, Saul B. Cohen, a professor at Hunter College and president emeritus of Queens College, agrees that Buffalo and New York have grown apart over the years, but he argues that a new bond is forming.
"As the preeminent foreign trade center, New York City needs Buffalo more than ever now," Dr. Cohen said. "Trade with Canada is becoming more and more important, and Buffalo is becoming the most important gateway to Canada, so New York City needs to keep its ties with Buffalo. I'd keep it in the state."
Dr. Cohen acknowledged that many New York City residents might be suspicious of his enthusiasm for Buffalo, especially in light of another opinion he offered. "For what it's worth," he said, "I'm picking the Bills by six."

HEADLINE: Fed's Advocate of Lower Rates to Resign

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Martha R. Seger, the Federal Reserve Board's most outspoken advocate of lower interest rates, announced today that she would resign within the next two months.
Ms. Seger, who is 58 years old, has been on the board since 1984, longer than any other member. Her resignation will give President Bush his third chance to fill a seat on the seven-member board, but it is unlikely to change the balance between those who want lower interest rates and those who favor higher rates to fight inflation. 
 The Federal Reserve Board determines the nation's monetary policy and thus has more influence over the economy than any other Government agency. It also is one of the principal regulators of the banking system. Ms. Seger has seven years remaining in her 14-year term, but Fed governors rarely serve the full 14 years.
 
Consistently a Dissenter
 In a letter she sent to President Bush today, Ms. Seger said she was resigning to "pursue other interests and tend to personal and family responsibilities."
In the last few years, she has consistently voted in the minority, often as the only dissenter, against what she saw as a Federal Reserve policy of keeping interest rates too high.
At a news conference this evening, she said the failure of the Fed to lower rates in the first half of this year might have contributed to the current recession. Certainly, she said, the Persian Gulf crisis contributed to the economic downturn, but she added, "The economy was slowing dramatically before Saddam Hussein even looked cross-eyed at Kuwait."
In Congressional testimony Tuesday, Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, said he thought the chances were better than even that a recession would not have occurred had it not been for the higher oil prices and loss of consumer confidence that resulted from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2.
 
Previous Nominations
 Last year, President Bush named David W. Mullins Jr., then an Assistant Treasury Secretary, to a board vacancy. This month, he promoted Mr. Mullins to be vice chairman and nominated Lawrence B. Lindsey, an economist on the White House staff, to fill a vacancy. Mr. Lindsey is awaiting confirmation. The other four board members were selected by President Ronald Reagan.
The Bush Administration has been pressing the Fed to reduce interest rates, and it is generally believed the President will fill vacancies with people who support that approach. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady is known to favor candidates who have what he calls "real world experience" in business or even politics, but Mr. Greenspan has indicated he would like to have a board consisting of economists.
Ms. Seger, who is a professional economist, said she hoped to earn more money by teaching, lecturing and serving as a director of some corporations. She said she might also do some consulting work. Fed board members are paid $115,300 a year.
A native of Michigan, Ms. Seger said her views about the need for lower interest rates might have stemmed from her many conversations with executives in the Midwest whose businesses were suffering. "I picked up a different message from them than I picked up within the Beltway," she said.
In addition to her views on monetary policy, Ms. Seger was known as a supporter of looser regulation of banks and freedom for banks to enter other lines of business.

HEADLINE: Oil Prices Move Higher; Crude for March at $22.04

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The price of oil edged up yesterday as traders continued to fret about the possibility of Israeli retaliation for a fatal Iraqi missile attack on Tuesday.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude for March delivery rose 16 cents a barrel yesterday, to $22.04. The spot price of oil in cash transactions had already risen in after-market trading on Tuesday following reports describing the extent of the damage from an Iraqi Scud missile that landed in Tel Aviv. 
 Robert F. Murphy, an energy futures broker at Lehman Brothers, said yesterday's modest gain also reflected traders' and investors' concerns about a weekly report released late Tuesday by the American Petroleum Institute, a Washington trade group. The report stated that the nation's supplies of oil, gasoline and particularly heating oil and diesel fuel had dropped during the last week.
 
Large Worldwide Supplies
 Energy Secretary James D. Watkins said yesterday that oil prices were likely to remain between $20 and $25 a barrel because worldwide supplies were large, Reuters reported.
Large speculative buyers of oil, including some oil companies and brokerages, are much less active in the market this week after sustaining heavy losses when the price of oil plunged $12.75 a barrel last Thursday and Friday, traders and analysts said.
"They're not in this market; they're on the sidelines licking their wounds," said Peter C. Beutel, an oil price analyst at Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. in Hoboken, N.J.
The Merc's contract for February delivery of oil expired Tuesday at $24.18 a barrel, up $2.88. During times of crisis, oil for immediate delivery tends to sell at a premium. The March contract rose $1.56 on Tuesday.
Wholesale gasoline for February delivery rose 0.45 cent yesterday, to 63.1 cents a gallon. Wholesale heating oil for February delivery climbed 1.69 cents a gallon, to 70.15 cents. These February contracts for refined products do not expire until Jan. 31.
 
Few Cash Transactions
 There were few cash transactions for individual ship cargoes after the Merc closed, and prices were little changed, said Cees W. Van Den Hout, an energy broker at Star Supply Inc. in Hoboken.
Several traders expressed surprise on Tuesday and yesterday that heating oil prices have risen very little lately despite cold weather in the Northeast, which tends to push up demand.
Mr. Murphy said that many speculative investors in heating oil had bought large quantities at the much higher prices prevailing before the United States and its allies began bombing Iraq. These speculators are now selling their stocks, and taking losses, each time the price begins to rise significantly, he said.
Few corporations are now willing to risk holding large positions in the oil market, said Alan R. Kaufman, the president of Mount Lucas Associates, an energy risk insurer in Princeton, N.J., that trades actively on the Merc. It is unusually difficult right now to predict the future price of oil, he said, adding, "I and most people I talk to are struck by how little we know."
Mr. Kaufman said premiums for insuring against sharp moves in oil or refined product prices had increased by 50 percent to 75 percent since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2.

HEADLINE: War Cuts Companies' Trips Abroad

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
Most globe-trotting executives will be staying home for a while. With war raging in the Persian Gulf, many large corporations have banned travel to the Middle East and greatly curtailed other international travel, officials of several dozen top companies said.
At many companies, permission for international trips deemed essential for business must come from senior-level executives. Domestic travel has apparently not been affected. 
 Many companies "have either limited travel, banned travel to Europe or banned travel outright," said John Riepe of the National Business Travel Association, an association of corporate travel managers based in Arlington, Va.
 
Bans at G.M. and 3M
 "Prior to the outbreak of conflict, we had implemented a ban on international travel," said Thomas Pyden, a spokesman for the General Motors Corporation in Detroit. "That has remained in effect."
The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, in St. Paul, eliminated European travel in early January, and broadened the ban after war broke out on Jan. 17. "All international travel has effectively been curtailed," said Mark Fenner of 3M.
Companies said they had restricted travel because they were concerned about the safety of employees. President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has encouraged his followers to commit acts of terrorism against the interests of the United States and its allies.
Some large companies, however, have simply urged employees to be careful. "We have advised employees to use extreme caution and common sense, but we don't have any travel bans," said Jack Batty, a spokesman for the General Electric Company in Fairfield, Conn.
A survey conducted last week by the Carlson Travel Group, one of the nation's largest travel agencies, found international travel bans at 25 percent of the companies surveyed. "Travel today is much more the exception than the rule," said Dexter Koehl, a spokesman for the Minneapolis-based agency. He said the other companies had restricted international travel, allowing trips only with approval from the highest corporate level.
Carlson Travel surveyed travel managers at 20 corporations. It also interviewed the managers of 20 of its own travel agencies.
The curtailing of travel goes beyond safety concerns, Mr. Koehl said. Senior executives "are very concerned about liability" if an employee is injured or killed traveling on business, he said.
At the Chrysler Corporation, for example, which has scaled back international travel sharply, responsibility for approving trips abroad has been kicked upstairs to the company's senior management, said Thomas Houston, a company spokesman.
 
Reduced Demand for Flights
 The shutdown of corporate travel has dealt another blow to the troubled airline industry. Trans World Airlines, for example, plans to cancel up to half of its overseas flights because of the drop in traffic.
At United Air Lines, "we have seen a softening in demand for international seats," said Sara Dornacker, a spokeswoman in Chicago. "We attribute this to a temporary suspension of travel by business travelers to international destinations." United has not cut flights because of the reduced demand, she said.
Traffic to Europe is also down for American Airlines. In a typical January, American's flights to Europe are nearly 60 percent full. Since the war broke out, the trans-Atlantic flights are only about 40 percent full, said Lise Olson, a spokeswoman for American.
"We have received reports from companies that have canceled business meetings in Europe," she said.
 
Scrutinizing Travel Costs
 While employee safety is the paramount concern, the travel bans come at an opportune time for corporations already scrutinizing travel costs in light of the weakening economy.
Several companies surveyed by Carlson Travel spend more than $100 million a year on travel.
Mr. Riepe of the National Business Travel Association said American companies spent more than $30 billion a year on travel.
The price of jet fuel doubled after Iraq invaded Kuwait in August, and airlines raised the price of tickets three times. As a result, even before the war and the threat of terrorism, the sharp increase in travel costs in a soft economy had caused a number of companies to curtail travel.
"This just makes the decision to stay put a little easier," said Mr. Houston of Chyrsler.
 
Alternatives to Travel
 For safety reasons, the International Business Machines Corporation is trying to avoid all travel to sensitive areas and is suggesting that employees use teleconferences or video conferences to avoid trips, said Rita Black, a spokeswoman. She said I.B.M. had been seeking alternatives to travel for some time to control costs.
The companies with travel bans said the bans were in place for an indefinite amount of time.
A number of companies, including the Xerox Corporation in Stamford, Conn., Tenneco Inc. in Houston, and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, do not have bans. A.T.& T. has only put out a memorandum about the dangers of air travel.
Barry Lane, a spokesman for the Unocal Corporation in Los Angeles, said, "We haven't restricted travel, but the company has strongly recommended against it at this time, particularly foreign travel." He said he knew of one executive, due to be transferred to London, who put off the move because of security concerns.
A few companies continue to send workers to the Middle East. The Lockheed Corporation has employees in Saudi Arabia supporting the operation of its transport aircraft and other Lockheed products.

HEADLINE: New York Total For Job Losses Tops Early 80's

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 23

 BODY:
The recession in New York State, when measured by the number of jobs lost, is already worse than the economic downturn of the early 1980's but is not nearly as severe as the recession of the mid-1970's, according to a report released today by the State Department of Labor.
The state lost 46,000 jobs between 1989 and 1990, surpassing the 33,000 jobs lost in the recession of 1981-82, the report said. By comparison, the state lost 247,000 jobs between 1974 and 1975, losing an additional 40,000 jobs in the following year. 
 State labor analysts called the current downturn a "new age recession" because it has preyed on white-collar jobs that were once considered recession proof.
 
'A Very Different Animal'
 "We weathered the '81-'82 recession quite well in New York State because it was a commodity recession," said Vincent F. DeSantis, a market analyst for the Labor Department. "This recession is a very different animal."
The report also showed that the state began to lose jobs last January, six months earlier than had previously been believed by state labor analysts.
The state's job loss has yet to be accompanied by a significant rise in its unemployment rate, which at 5.2 percent at an annual rate was less in 1990 than the national rate of 5.5 percent. But state officials said today that New York's economic downturn might be far from its nadir.
"I'm not sure that we've seen the bottom yet, and that's one of the scary parts," said Thomas F. Hartnett, the State Labor Commissioner. "I don't see it ending by midsummer, as some prominent economists project."
The report, which includes end-of-the-year revisions to the state's annual work force analysis, compares the number of jobs in a given month in 1990 with those in the same month in 1989.
The losses began in January, when the state lost 7,600 jobs and accelerated through December, when the state lost 121,600 jobs. The annual average job loss was 46,000, which represented an erosion of six-tenths of 1 percent of the state's nonagricultural job base.
The largest declines were in construction, which lost 22,300 jobs, or 7.1 percent of its base; manufacturing, which lost 58,000 jobs, or 5.1 percent; wholesale and retail trade, which lost 37,900 jobs, or 2.2 percent, and finance, insurance and real estate, which lost 13,200 jobs, or 1.7 percent.

HEADLINE: Foreign Airlines Can Raise Stake In U.S. Carriers

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
With the nation's airlines losing billions of dollars, the Administration moved today to attract foreign investment to the industry. Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner announced that foreign airlines would be allowed to invest more heavily in domestic carriers.
He said the changes would help preserve competition among airlines by strengthening them financially when they face higher fuel costs, stagnant revenues and in some cases bankruptcy. 
 As an immediate result of the change, the Dutch airline KLM will be allowed to retain 49 percent ownership of Northwest Airlines.
 
Shutdowns and Bankruptcies
 Mr. Skinner's move comes less than a week after the industry suffered its latest casualty. On Friday, Eastern Airlines, already operating in bankruptcy, stopped flying. Pan Am and Continental are operating under bankruptcy protection from creditors.
Despite Mr. Skinner's goals, some independent analysts questioned whether the move would have much effect, especially on weaker companies, because the rules limit foreigners to owning 25 percent of an airline's voting stock. Previously, foreign carriers were limited to owning 25 percent of the equity.
"I question what foreign owner would put up to 49 percent of equity into a domestic airline without exercising control," said Bradley R. Larschan, the general counsel at the Association for International Investment, which favors lowering investment barriers like those governing the airlines.
"I don't think that given the actual level of control that would be permitted it would have the effect of saving any of the endangered airlines," he said.
A senior Transportation Department official agreed that the new policy was "not a magic bullet," but he called it "a step in the right direction" and said it would help the industry in the long run.
In his speech, Mr. Skinner proposed two other ways the airlines might stem losses: cutting wages and raising fares. He has no legal authority over either wages or fares.
Mr. Skinner noted that pilots make five times the average American wage and that the average airline employee, when ticket agents and baggage handlers as well as pilots and mechanics are counted, makes twice the average national wage. "One might question whether something is seriously out of balance," he said.
As for fares, he said, "Unrealistically low prices are a bad bargain in the long run."
The losses of domestic airlines last year are expected to total $2 billion, with most of that coming after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 produced a surge in the price of jet fuel.
The previous limits on foreign ownership had been in place because of both strategic and protectionist concerns about other governments' controlling domestic carriers. .
But today's announcement signals the Administration's intention to broaden the international ties throughout the airline industry. "U.S. carriers must stay ahead of the pack in the move toward globalization," Mr. Skinner said.
Mr. Skinner, who has spent most of the last few weeks in a review of policies involving foreign investment in the airlines, told an audience at the National Press Club that he had in effect changed the yardstick by which the department would measure the merits of foreign investments. The changes announced today require no new legislation.
 
Outlook for Competition
 Mr. Skinner said today, as he has many times before, that "the loss of one or more airlines will not necessarily mean less competition." His policies, he said, are aimed at strengthening the stronger airlines and encourging competition, both by granting foreign airlines better access to American markets and by expanding the nation's airports so that more competitors can operate in large cities.
Domestic airlines that borrow from foreign banks or companies would not be considered to have fallen under foreign control, as long as the loans did not give special rights to the foreign lenders, Mr. Skinner said.
At least for the time being, he will not seek changes in the law prohibiting foreign citizens from dominating the management of domestic airlines.
"We will allow foreign membership on airline boards to reflect their voting-stock ownership, as long as it satisfies the statutory ceiling, and as long as representatives of foreign airlines do not take part in decisions affecting competition," Mr. Skinner said.
The immediate practical effect of the ruling is to allow KLM to hold onto the bulk of its investment in Northwest Airlines. More than a year ago KLM was ordered to sell much of its 57 percent stake, which was purchased as part of a complex package when the company was taken over in a leveraged buyout led by Alfred Checchi, the current chairman.
 
Speculation Dampened
 At the time, the booming airline business was viewed as an attractive investment, and the decision to limit foreign participation in Northwest was an important factor in dampening speculation in airline stocks. Shortly after the decision, an agreement to take United Airlines private, with financing from foreign banks and from British Airways, fell apart.
British Airways remains a prominent example of a thriving international carrier seeking partnerships with other airlines worldwide, and Mr. Skinner said the policy announced today acknowledges this trend and effectively encourages it.

HEADLINE: U.S. Budget Deficit Grows

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON. Jan. 23

 BODY:
The Federal deficit grew by $7.4 billion in December, swelling to $87 billion for the first three months of the 1991 fiscal year, the Treasury Department said today.
Many analysts had expected a far bigger deficit in December because of expenditures for the Persian Gulf operation and the savings and loan bailout and because of the sluggish economy. But last month's gap was only half as large as the $14.8 billion deficit in December 1989.
The Government did spend $2.7 billion on the savings and loan bailout in December, more than double the amount spent in December 1989. But military spending fell 9.3 percent, to $25.2 billion. Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets said the Persian Gulf buildup was nearly completed by December.
Individual income tax receipts were up 24 percent, to $46.5 billion, and corporate tax receipts increased 19 percent, to $22.5 billion.
The deficit for the first quarter of the 1991 fiscal year was 23 percent larger than a year earlier. Total receipts were up 10.9 percent, to $253.8 billion, while outlays rose 13.8 percent, to $340.7 billion.
The Bush Administration has acknowledged that the 1991 deficit will set a record. The budget director, Richard Darman, has projected the imbalance at $250 billion to $300 billion.

HEADLINE: Hartford Panel Urges Overhaul Of Government

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 23

 BODY:
An independent commission established two years ago to study what does and does not work in state government said in its final report today that Connecticut's fiscal crisis offers an "unmatched opportunity" to overhaul the scope and vision of government.
The report, by the Commission to Study the Management of State Government, recommended paring back many state services, consolidating others, capping aid to towns and cities and reducing fringe benefits for state workers. 
 The analysis, based on 18 consultants' studies, would affect every state agency, every public employee and probably most contacts between residents and their government.
 
'The Pressure Will Be On'
 For legislators struggling to address the state's shortfall of more than $600 million in tax revenues brought on by the regional recession, the report also provided support for an idea that many people here believe is inevitable anyway: state government must scale back. And with such a document now in hand -- loaded with detailed arguments -- the pressure to make those cuts has also increased, lawmakers say.
"The pressure will be on now, particularly, to make some implementation," said House Speaker Richard J. Balducci, a Newington Democrat.
Connecticut faces a projected revenue shortfall of more than $600 million over the next five months in a budget of just over $7 billion, and of an estimated $1.5 billion more in the fiscal year that begins on July 1.
 
Far Beyond Finances
 Today's recommendations, even if enacted entirely into law as written, would save perhaps $578 million next year, according to the commission, and about $300 million to $400 million according to estimates by state budget officials.
But many of the most sweeping proposals go far beyond their financial impact.
The study concludes for example, that one of the fundamental categories of state spending, aid to local communities and nonprofit groups, should be rethought entirely because of shifting demographics, changes in Federal financial aid and the long-term prospects for the state's economy. The local grants, which total nearly $2 billion this year -- more than a quarter of the budget -- should be capped and frozen until the new "environment" can be assessed, the report says.
The state's budget director, William J. Cibes Jr., who was a member of the commission and voted on its proposals, has already said that towns should expect no increase in funds next year.
The commission, which was informally known as the Thomas Commission, for its chairman, DeRoy C. Thomas, a top Hartford executive with the ITT Corporation, also suggested cutting back on the traditionally generous terms with which the state has treated its own employees.
Specifically, the report recommended reducing the state's contribution to the employee medical plan and the retirees' medical plan from 100 percent to 80 percent, for a savings of about $20 million, reconsidering the 35-hour work week, and reducing workers-compensation benefits.
 
Drew Angry Rejoinders
 Last year, the Republican Party candidate for governor, John G. Rowland, recommended precisely those things during the governor's race and drew angry rejoinders from many Democrats. But today it was the clear that many Democrats had become convinced.
"We're going to take every nickel and dollar," said State Representative William R. Dyson, the co-chairman of the General Assembly's Appropriations Committee and a Democrat of New Haven. "There's a public perception out there that we're being presented with a tremendous opportunity to save money for the state and we have to do it," Mr. Dyson said of the commission's recommendations.
Some of its early recommendations have already been taken to heart. Former Gov. William A. O'Neill established an interagency task force last year that was charged with looking at every state agency's relationship with the Federal Government and finding all the loopholes to squeeze out Federal dollars in grants or other aid.
Other recommendations are clearly moving through the system. On Tuesday, for example, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. announced that as many as 180 state employees at the Department of Mental Retardation's Mansfield Training School could be laid off to save money. Today, the report said the school should be closed.
 
A Bonus System
 Some of the changes seem to further what has been a trend in Connecticut for years anyway. The study recommended that many of the duties now performed by county sheriffs, such as providing security in court buildings, be scaled back, eliminated, or folded into state agencies like the Department of Correction. County sheriffs are a last vestige of county government, which was abolished in the 1960's.
Other proposals would take the state into new territory. The study suggests implementing a bonus system that would directly link a manager's performance to his pay -- an idea completely alien to civil service tradition.
But the commission also stopped short on many recommendations. One consultant suggested, for instance, that the state reduce the number of local offices of the Department of Motor Vehicles, from 18 to 8. In its final document, however, the commission said that while such ideas should perhaps be considered in the long-run, the consolidation would cause too much inconvenience to be worthwhile for the moment, and was perhaps impractical given the realities of the legislative process.
"There will have to be an attitudinal change," the commission's report said. "Legislators cannot rise in opposition every time someone suggests closing a school or a court house or shutting down a motor-vehicle office in their district."

GRAPHIC: Chart: 'Counting Every Dollar in Connecticut'
 
The final report of the Commission to Study the Management of State Government recommends hundreds of ways for Connecticut to save money or raise new revenue in the next fiscal year. The following are examples.

Close satellite vocational-technical schools in Enfield and Essex. Savings: $1,190,000.
 
Double tuition, to $400 a semester from $200, for adult students in all full-time vocational-technical trade programs. Revenue: $234,000.

Reduce environmental review staff. Savings: $76,400

COUNTY SHERIFFS
 
Eliminate courthouse security from civil courtrooms except in high-risk cases. Savings: $992,000.
 
Eliminate local suppport staff in each county sheriff's office. Savings: $512,920.
 
Eliminate high sheriff's state-owned personal cars. Savings: $101,282.
 
DEPARTMENT OF MENTAL RETARDATION
 
Phase out the Mansfield Training School. Savings: $2,500,000.
 
BUREAU OF PURCHASES
 
Reduce the number of vehicles in the state fleet by 625. Savings: $1,889,000).
 
Increase the use of state courier services for inter-agency mailings. Savings: $225,000.
 
Contract out the mop and cleaning service. Savings: $250,000.

HEADLINE: More Signs Of a Slump Nationwide

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Business activity was falling in most parts of the country in the weeks leading up to the outbreak of war in the Persian Gulf, with little sign that the contraction was being blunted by lower interest rates, a Federal Reserve survey showed today.
The Fed's "beige book" report on current economic conditions called the situation in the gulf "a key determinant of both current and future economic activity," which the Fed said "appears to be declining in most districts." 
 The survey, taken to help the Fed prepare for its Feb. 5-6 meeting to plot monetary strategy for the rest of the winter, suggested that further cuts in interest rates lie ahead.
 
'Additional Easing' Is Seen
 "The report strongly supports the case that the Federal Open Market Committee will approve additional easing steps," said Robert T. McGee, chief economist for the Tokai Bank Ltd.
He said his view was strengthened by statements to this effect by the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, in appearances before Congress on Tuesday and again this morning. Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee today that the Fed would act in a "shorter rather than a longer" period to spur greater lending and borrowing.
Both the stock and bond markets reacted positively to the Fed chairman's comments. Traders said the prospect of lower rates helped push up the Dow Jones industrial average, which ended the day ahead 15.84 points. And prices of Treasury notes and bonds also rose and yields fell. But the dollar, whose value is eroded by lower rates, dropped against most leading currencies.
 
A Resignation Announced
 The most consistent champion of easier credit on the Fed, meanwhile, announced today that she was resigning. Martha R. Seger, who has been on the seven-member board since 1984, said she would be leaving within the next two months. Although departing board members normally remove themselves from policy actions that will extend beyond their terms, Ms. Seger said she saw no reason why she would not vote at the policy meeting in two weeks. [Page D16.]
The beige book report today stated that so far "interest rate declines have done little to stimulate residential housing" and, by implication, other interest-sensitive parts of the economy.
The survey, which consists of anecdotal evidence collected by the Fed's 12 district banks, was compiled this time by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis. The information was collected before Jan. 14.
"Despite continued export growth," the Fed found, "manufacturing orders, employment and shipments have weakened" and construction is still slowing in most places. It also cited "widespread weakness" in both consumer and business loan demand, and even farm incomes, which had been holding firm, "have weakened somewhat."
Inflation, however, "does not appear to be accelerating," the survey declared.
Nearly all the Fed's districts reported weak or falling activity in manufacturing, it said, but export growth remained stronger than domestic growth in Boston, Atlanta, Chicago, Minneapolis, Kansas City, Dallas and San Francisco. Cleveland, Chicago and St. Louis reported a drop in automobile output that had spread to the auto makers' suppliers and other related sectors.
The Cleveland Fed reported signs of consumer distress, including increases in auto repossessions and foreclosures.
The New York district's economy was reported to have remained "soft to mixed," with office vacancy rates rising in both midtown and downtown Manhattan in recent weeks. Upstate merchants were said to be hopeful of finding new customers from Canada, which in mid-December imposed a 7 percent sales tax.
Mr. Greenspan said again today that while there was some evidence that the "intensity of the credit crunch may be topping out, it is sufficiently severe to create considerable concerns at the Federal Reserve."
