HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Fire Fight;
U.S. and Iraqi Soldiers Skirmish Near Border

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 23

 BODY:
In the first significant ground skirmish reported in the Persian Gulf war, Iraqi troops crossed the border into the Saudi desert on Tuesday night and exchanged fire with American troops, wounding two of them before six of the Iraqis were taken prisoner, United States military officials said today.
The clash near the Iraqi-Saudi border was disclosed in a Pentagon statement released here on a day when Iraq launched more missiles on eastern Saudi Arabia and Israel and as Iraqi forces continued sporadic artillery fire against American-led troops massing near Kuwait. There were no immediate reports of casualties from the missile attacks tonight. 
 American officials said relatively clear weather in the northern Persian Gulf today allowed extensive bombing of targets in Iraq and Kuwait.
The air forces of the anti-Iraq coalition, led by bombers and attack jets from the United States, Britain and Saudi Arabia, have flown more than 12,000 sorties since Jan. 16, the officials said today; they said 6,000 of those were combat missions.
 
Small Arms Fire Returned
 The pilot of an American Marine Harrier jet was killed today when the vertical-takeoff plane crashed during an exercise. There were no reports of allied planes lost today in combat.
According to the Defense Department's account of Tuesday night's fighting, soldiers from the Army's Third Armored Cavalry, working from an observation point near the Saudi border with Iraq, confronted an Iraqi patrol and returned small arms fire.
The department did not provide details on the two soldiers' wounds, except to say that they had received medical treatment and have returned to duty. The Iraqi prisoners of war were moved to a Saudi detention center, the statement said.
American officials denied an Iraqi assertion that American troops were captured in the skirmish, the exact location of which was not disclosed. The Iraqi assertion was reported by the official Iranian press agency.
As coalition forces make final preparations for what is expected to be a large-scale ground war against Iraq, the border region between Saudi Arabia and Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait has grown tense.
 
'The Knockout Punch'
 A small group of American reporters, organized by the Defense Department under restrictions for covering the war, provided details today of an American artillery attack on mobile Iraqi batteries in southern Kuwait on Tuesday night.
According to one report, American forces fired 155-millimeter howitzer salvos against Iraqi border forces that had been responsible for what American military officials called harassment rocket attacks against American soldiers dug in close to the border.
The First and Second Marine Divisions are stationed across miles of Saudi desert near the Kuwaiti border. Should a ground war against Iraq begin, it will be the first time the two divisions have fought side by side since World War II.
"We are looking to deliver the knockout punch," said Capt. Bryan McCoy, a 28-year-old infantry commander from Norman, Okla.
Iraq responded to the American-led, week-old bombing assault with yet another volley of Scud missiles tonight on eastern Saudi Arabia and Israel.
Initial reports indicated that at least three missiles had been launched at 11 P.M., one each against Riyadh, the Saudi capital; Dhahran, the Saudi oil industry center, and another area in central Saudi Arabia.
There were no reports of injuries in Saudi Arabia, and military officials said they believed that the Scuds aimed at Riyadh and Dhahran had been intercepted by American-made Patriot anti-missile missiles.
 
Iraq Halts Gasoline Distribution
AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 23 (Special to The New York Times) -- Iraq reported today that distribution of gasoline had been halted throughout the country to marshal supplies, suggesting that the allied air assault and economic sanctions are forcing the authorities to divert essential supplies to the military.
Earlier this week, residents of Baghdad reported long lines at the few gasoline stations still open.
In a commentary, Baghdad Radio also said that the Iraqi missile that hit a Tel Aviv suburb on Tuesday night showed "the superior creativity of the Iraqi mind." The remarks were broadcast hours before another Iraqi missile attack was thwarted tonight over northern Israel by Patriot missiles. Three people died and nearly 100 were wounded in the attack Tuesday night.
The Iraqi radio also reported the capture of a British pilot that it identified as Robert Stewart, and said that more than 20 allied pilots previously captured had been moved to "vital targets" to serve as shields against allied attacks.
Baghdad Radio also asserted that at least 60 more Iraqi civilians had been killed in allied attacks, 13 of them when a downed plane plowed into four houses. That brings the total number of civilian deaths reported by Iraq to about 100.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
3M Earnings Rise 1%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MAPLEWOOD, Minn., Jan. 23

 BODY:
The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, its business affected by the weakened economy, said its earnings rose 1 percent in the fourth quarter and 5.6 percent for all of last year. For the three months that ended on Dec. 31, 3M's net income totaled $295 million, or $1.34 a share, up from $292 million, or $1.31 a share, in the 1989 period. Sales totaled $3.28 billion, up 11 percent from $2.95 billion in the 1989 quarter. For the year, 3M's net income was $1.31 billion, or $5.91 a share, compared with $1.24 billion, or $5.60 a share, in 1989. Revenues totaled $13.02 billion, an increase of 8.6 percent from $11.99 billion in 1989.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Japan;
Japan Pledges $9 Billion to War Amid Opposition

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 24

 BODY:
The Japanese Government said today it would contribute $9 billion to the allied force fighting Iraq and supply military aircraft for evacuating refugees from the war zone. But both proposals are encountering stiff opposition among the Japanese people.
The money would be in addition to the $4 billion in aid already promised by Japan, although less than half of that pledge has actually been disbursed. Half of the earlier sum was earmarked for the war effort and half for economic assistance to Jordan, Egypt and Turkey. 
 To pay for its contribution, the Government must obatin legislative approval. The opposition has focused on reports this week that Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu will soon propose a special tax and possibly a bond issue to raise the cash as quickly as possible.
Officials expressed confidence that they would win Parliament's approval of the tax and the airlift measures. But the Government has had problems mustering a consensus even within its own leadership and that of the governing Liberal Democratic Party.
 
Kaifu Canceled Announcement
 On Wednesday evening, Mr. Kaifu suffered embarrassment when he was forced to cancel a news conference at which he was planning to unveil the aid proposal and outline his views on Japan's role in the war.
Officials said the cancellation was the result of squabbling among Government officials and senior members of the ruling party and of criticism from opposition parties controlling the upper house of Parliament.
There has been disagreement about how many strings are to be attached to the new money. Up to now, Japan's aid to the gulf military effort has been restricted to nonlethal support. Even the cash has come with a requirement that it not be spent on arms or ammunition.
The United States has asked that these restrictions be removed, but the announcement today left them in effect for the time being.
 
Opposition to War
 The announcement also comes amid growing dissatisfaction with the American-led offensive against Iraq. Some officials in the Government are worried that news accounts and television commentary has focused over the last week on the American decision to wage war rather than on the Iraq's initial invasion of Kuwait.
Opposition in Japan has focused on the price tag of the aid proposal, estimated earlier as ranging from $5 billion to $10 billion. The possibility of a tax is increasingly denounced by business and consumer groups.
The Japanese press has described the proposed aid as equivalent to Japan's annual welfare payments, and the tax as equivalent to $75 for every man, woman and child in Japan. Many seem shocked at the amount of money Japan is being asked to pay.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Egypt;
In Egypt, Public Sentiment Is Shifting in Baghdad's Favor

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Jan. 23

 BODY:
A segment of public opinion in Egypt, the largest Arab country and a key Arab ally of the United States, is clearly shifting in favor of Iraq in the Persian Gulf war.
The shift is evident enough to force the Government of President Hosni Mubarak to step back from its propaganda campaign against Iraq and to recast its stance as one dictated by the United Nations rather than Egyptian national interest. 
 Apparently taken aback by this rapidly growing shift in public opinion in favor of Iraq, the Government extended the midyear vacation for high schools and universities, out of fear that public demonstrations in favor of Iraq might break out if students returned now and that other Egyptians might join in.
Fundamentalist Islamic forces and leftist secular opposition parties have called for a pro-Iraqi rally this week.
The shift has been equally clear in the growing criticism by the Egyptian public of what they perceive as the callous behavior of many Kuwaiti exiles, sitting out the war in luxury hotels in Egypt and "struggling in the discos," as some Egyptians have described it. And it is finding an echo in the apologetic comments by the Cairo Government about its military participation in the war, with 45,000 soldiers making up the second largest army contingent among the allied forces in Saudi Arabia.
Of equal significance is the visible and increasingly solitary role of Mr. Mubarak, who has made himself the central Egyptian and Arab figure in the overt anti-Iraqi campaign, in the same way President Anwar el-Sadat, shortly before his slaying by Muslim fundamentalists in 1981, became a lone figure defending his signing of a peace treaty with Israel.
By contrast, other leaders of the Arab pro-Western alliance, including King Fahd of Saudi Arabia and the Emir of Kuwait, have kept a low profile and limited their verbal assaults on the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, to occasional comments.
"Mubarak is committing a tactical mistake by making himself the center of all comments and positions about Iraq to the exclusion of other senior officials in Egypt," said Tahseen Bashir, a former senior Egyptian diplomat who was a close aide to Mr. Sadat.
This apparent change in Egyptian attitudes is in direct contrast to what seemed to be total support for Mr. Mubarak in August, immediately after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. He took a very hard line against Iraq and Mr. Hussein as most Egyptians were aghast at the sight of Egyptian refugees streaming out of Iraq and Kuwait, penniless and jobless.
But over the last few months, the feeling that the Arab gulf nations have not done much to ease Egypt's growing economic burdens, in addition to the killing of 21 Palestinians by Israelis at Al Aksa Mosque in Jerusalem, has diluted enthusiasm for Mr. Mubarak's anti-Iraqi stand.
In addition, over the last few days, many Egyptians have been shocked by the force and breadth of the allied aerial bombing of Baghdad and other places in Iraq, where nearly a million Egyptians continue to live and work, seeing in it a measure of carelessness for the value of Arab lives that exceeds what is necessary to force Iraq out of Kuwait. This has been aggravated by incidents that betray a growth of anti-Arab sentiment in Western Europe and the United States, which have been reported here.
In the six days since the war started, Egyptian professional groups of engineers, doctors, pharmacists and students as well as leading figures in the opposition and other Egyptians have been arguing that Egypt's troops stationed in the gulf region should not take part in any assault on Kuwait with allied troops led by the United States.
Instead, these voices call for the Egyptian military forces in Saudi Arabia to limit their mission to defending Islamic holy places in Mecca and Medina, close to the Red Sea and away from the borders of Kuwait on the Persian Gulf coast where allied attacks are expected.
In addition, there is increasing skepticism among a widening segment of the Egyptian public about the ability of the American-led troops to wipe out Iraqi defenses and score clear "surgical" strikes against Iraqi troops and a growing suspicion that Iraq is far from being down and out.
 
Islamic Militants a Problem
 By far the most worrisome opposition for the Government has come from the militant ranks of Islamic fundamentalists.
A leading opposition weekly newspaper representing Islamic groups, Al Shaab, said in a fiery front-page editorial this week, "The blood being spilled in Iraq is our blood, and the bodies being torn on the land of Iraq, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are our bodies." The editorial went on to ask the Egyptian Goverment whether "all this destruction being sowed across Iraq in the name of liberating Kuwait or out of love for the ruling Al Sabah family of Kuwait" could be justified by any other purpose.
Al Shaab said the lives of the million Egyptians still in Iraq were also endangered by the United States-led bombing campaign.
The growing opposition against the war and against Egypt's part in it is affected by three factors that in some ways bring even those who support the eradication of the Iraqi Government together with those who oppose any action against Iraq.
 
Insufficient Reward Seen
 The most important factor is the view that Mr. Mubarak was feeble in negotiating the terms of his support for Saudi Arabia and the United States. This argument maintains that the country got little for its involvement save for vague promises of financial support and the elimination of about $14 billion in debts owed to the United States for arms purchases and to Arab oil-producing countries -- debts that the country was not expected to pay anyway.
"Egypt's support for the multinational campaign is like a match," said Mohammad Farid, an Egyptian businessman. "It is valuable before you strike it, but it looses all its value once it has been lit." He opposes Iraq's invasion of Kuwait but argues that without Egypt's commitment of troops it would have been impossible for the United States to put an Arab face on the international coalition.
"I think we should have sat down with the Saudis and insisted on a written commitment that after the war Egyptians will get an absolute priority in the reconstruction of Kuwait and Saudi Arabia in terms of expatriate labor as well as substantial financial assistance in real numbers," Mr. Farid added. "We have lost almost a million jobs in Kuwait and Iraq because of this invasion and the return of Egyptian expatriates without their money or possessions as unemployed persons here. The Syrians got cold cash from these regimes because they bargained hard. Mubarak has been too soft."
The second factor is the strong alliance of the United States with Israel that has resurfaced in the aftermath of Iraq's Scud missile attacks against Israel. That revived alliance has aroused the almost automatic reflex widely shared by many Egyptians of not wanting to appear to side with these two Westernized nations against an Arab country.
The Muslim Brotherhood party, a very strong political force, is banned from taking part in Egyptian politics as a religious institution but is allowed to play what turns out to be a big role as an instigator of pan-Islamic feelings against the West.
Finally, one of the principal sources of eroding support for Mr. Mubarak is the prospect that the gulf war will be long and bloody, a prospect that contradicts his repeated assertions that Iraq will crumble in the face of the superior technological and military might of the American-led forces in a matter of days.
Mr. Mubarak, undoubtedly feeling this mounting criticism, has scheduled an address to the nation in the form of a speech Thursday to a combined session of Parliament and the Shura, or consultative council.
But it is already clear that the longer the war lasts, the stronger the opposition to it here will become.
"I do not think it will reach the point of freezing Egypt's armed forces' participation in the war effort, but the longer this goes on, the more it will arouse feeling of sympathy for the Iraqi people," Salamah Ahmad Salamah, the managing editor of Egypt's main daily newspaper, the Government-owned Al Ahram, said in an interview here today.

HEADLINE: Fourth-Quarter Profit Dropped 10% at Southwestern Bell

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The Southwestern Bell Corporation announced yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings had fallen 10 percent because of one-time charges.
Southwestern Bell, the main provider of local telephone service in Missouri, Arkansas, Kansas, Oklahoma and Texas, reported fourth-quarter profits of $267.5 million, or 89 cents a share, on revenues of $2.45 billion. This compared with earnings of $297.2 million, or 99 cents a share, on sales of $2.32 billion a year earlier.
The company's results roughly matched analysts' expectations, although the company suffered a sharp drop in the number of new telephone lines it installed, said Joel D. Gross, a telephone industry analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, a New York brokerage.
 
Concern Over Regional Economy
 "The concern is where the regional economy goes from here," he added.
Excluding $45 million in special charges, Southwestern Bell's profits rose 5.1 percent in the fourth quarter, to $312.5 million. The biggest of these special charges was for a voluntary severance and retirement plan accepted by 1,100 managers.
Southwestern Bell said that it acquired a record 92,000 new cellular phone customers in the fourth quarter. But its total number of conventional phone lines increased by only 15,000, down from 110,000 lines a year earlier, and from 140,000 in the third quarter of 1990.
The fall in new phone lines reflected a reluctance by residential customers to install a second phone line and a reduced effort by the company to promote such lines, said Susan B. Fox, Southwestern's managing director of investor relations.
The business market for telephone services remains strong in the region, she added.
For all of 1990, Southwestern Bell earned $1.10 billion, or $3.67 a share, on sales of $9.11 billion. In 1989, the company had profits of $1.09 billion, or $3.64 a share, on sales of $8.73 billion.
 
Shares Drop $2.375
 Shares in Southwestern Bell dropped $2.375 in a rising market yesterday to close at $50.25. The stock had already fallen $2.625 on Tuesday. The shares of the other regional Bell companies, with the exception of the Nynex Corporation, all fell by at least $1 yesterday for the second day.
The Pacific Telesis Group and the Bell Atlantic Corporation announced weak fourth-quarter results on Tuesday. The recession was blamed for the poor performances. Pactel fell $3.125 on Tuesday and another $1.50 yesterday, to $39.75. Bell Atlantic dropped $4 on Tuesday and another $2 yesterday, to $48.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Germany;
Kohl Is Sending $165 Million In Humanitarian Aid to Israel

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl announced today that his Government would send $165 million to Israel as "immediate humanitarian aid" after Iraqi missile attacks, and that more money would be sent to support the anti-Iraq alliance in the Persian Gulf.
"The news of renewed rocket attacks by Iraq against the territory of Israel fills us Germans with deep outrage," Mr. Kohl said at a news conference. "It is a clear blow against Israel's integrity and right to exist, for which we Germans have a special responsibility." 
 Mr. Kohl said he would send Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher to Israel to demonstrate German support.
A Foreign Ministry spokesman in Jerusalem welcomed the gesture as "very, very positive."
 
No Decision Yet on Amount
 Mr. Kohl said no decision had been made on how much extra money the German Government would give to the alliance, but he has warned that tax increases may be necessary.
Germany has been under international criticism for not taking part more fully in the anti-Iraq coalition. Germany has pledged $2.2 billion to the anti-Iraq coalition, and it has contributed some planes to Turkey, a fellow member of NATO, for defensive purposes. But its postwar Constitution prohibits it from conducting offensive operations abroad.
Chancellor Kohl's advisers say that he would like to do more for the allied effort, but that the political climate here is unfavorable.
Public opinion surveys taken in recent days suggest that most Germans support the allied decision to attack Iraq. Nonetheless, the anti-war movement here is very active and appears to have tapped a well of public concern.
At a news conference today, leaders of the German anti-war movement rejected charges that their movement was anti-American or that it advocated the appeasement of tyrants.
 
'Arguing for Peaceful Way'
 "The reason for these charges is that our peace movement seems at this moment to be the largest in the world," said one of the protest organizers, Andreas Buro. "We are arguing for a peaceful way, and not the military way chosen by the United States and its European and Arab allies. The social, economic and ecological costs of this policy are so great that it must be changed."
In an interview on Tuesday, Volker Ruhe, one of Chancellor Kohl's advisers, said the German anti-war movement was strong because Germans have "a different psychology regarding the use of force."
"In countries like the United States and France and Britain, there is a psychology that if other means fail, it is the right of the state to use force," Mr. Ruhe said. "That is not the case in Germany."
"Here there has been a selective understanding of the United Nations resolutions," he said. "There was great attention to the various peace initiatives. The other side, that if everything failed the United Nations was legalizing the use of force, has not been talked about here."

HEADLINE: War Hurt Theaters And Helped Films, But Effect Was Brief

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
War in the Persian Gulf glued people to their television sets and reduced attendance at some entertainment events last week, people in the cultural and entertainment industry in New York report. But they add that some escapist entertainment benefited from the war and that attendance and video rentals are returning to normal.
"Box office was off by about 7.5 percent last week, but yesterday sales were as good as before the war started," said Paul Libin, producing director of Jujamcyn Theaters, one of Broadway's major theater owners. He was interviewed yesterday. 
 "I think people responded pretty much the way the news media did," he continued. "At first, the only news was war news, but then gradually other things reappeared. People were the same. After four days of watching TV or listening to the radio, they began to say, 'I've got to start getting my life back on track.' "
Mr. Libin added that January is normally "a very tough season for ticket sales." He said he was nevertheless hopeful because "traditionally, in bad times people go to the theater to get away from it all."
Phil Smith, executive vice president of the Shubert Organization, the largest Broadway theater owner, said his company's experience was much the same as Jujamcyn's.
"The daily take was considerably off last Wednesday and Thursday," he said, "but on the weekend it began to build as if people needed some diversion."
 
Closings Were Expected
 A spokesman for the Nederlander Organization, Broadway's second largest theater owner, said attendance at its theaters declined sharply, but he attributed that to the traditional January slump.
Sunday's closing of "Black and Blue," "Shogun" and "Peter Pan," said Arthur Rubin, vice president and general manager of the company, was expected even before the fighting started.
Mr. Rubin acknowledged that the Nederlander Organization's box office receipts were definitely affected by a new war-related phenomenon -- the sudden departure for Israel by stars who are Israeli citizens or who want to express solidarity with Israel during the war.
Topol, who stars in the revival of "Fiddler on the Roof," left Saturday night and is expected back in time for Sunday's matinee. The comedian Jackie Mason canceled four performances of "Jackie Mason: Brand New" to visit Israel. He is expected back for tomorrow's performance.
"It's hard to differentiate whether box office is being affected by the season, the economy or the war," Mr. Rubin said. "We may get some indication of what's going on next Monday when the box office opens for Neil Simon's play 'Lost in Yonkers.' "
 
Half-Price Tickets Off
 Stuart Little, a spokesman for the Theater Development Fund, said that sales at the TKTS booth in Times Square were "considerably down," but he attributed that to the recent closing of shows like "Peter Pan" as well as to preoccupation with the war.
But cancellations are few. "People cancel when there's a snowstorm," Mr. Rubin said, "but not when there's a war."
Several producers said they have noticed a few empty seats in sold-out houses, and they suspect that some foreign tourists cut short their stays to return home before the expiration of the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline for Iraq to leave Kuwait.
Joseph E. Spinnato, president of the Hotel Association of New York, agreed with this assessment. "Foreign visitors to New York went home sooner than originally planned," he said.
Joseph McKaughan, vice president for public affairs at Lincoln Center, said that ticket sales for tonight's performances were "good to strong." The shows are "Don Giovanni" at the Metropolitan Opera, "Six Degrees of Separation" at the Beaumont, "Monster in a Box" at the Newhouse and performances by the New York City Ballet and the New York Philharmonic.
He added: "That's largely because subscription tickets for these performances were sold about a year ago. However, the City Ballet held a nonsubscription performance last Sunday and that sold quite well."
 
Movies Do Well
 Movie attendance apparently benefited from the war. "Last week was a big box office week," said John Krier, president of the Exhibitor Relations Company of Los Angeles, which tracks movie attendance.
"The box office take was about $63 million, which is approximately the same as the previous week and slightly better than the same period last year," he said.
The comedy "Home Alone," about a boy who defeats a couple of burglars when left at home alone by his vacationing parents, led the top 10 box-office earners for the 10th consecutive week by taking in an estimated $9.4 million.
More disappointing was "Flight of the Intruder," featuring Vietnam-era air combat, which was in fifth place, grossing $4.9 million for the week. "It didn't capture the public interest as might have been expected," Mr. Krier said.
"If the heavy coverage of the war continues," he added, "people will tend to look for escapism more and more."
A spokesman for Loew's Theaters in New York said business seemed not to have changed at all from this time last year.
Video rentals, however, went into "a steep decline and then rebounded," said Amy Innerfield, general manager of Videoflash, a home video tracking service of Alexander & Associates in New York.
Before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August, she said, about 41 percent of the families owning a VCR rented at least one cassette a week. After the invasion, only 36 percent of VCR households did so. Later, the figure slipped to 35 percent, but then after the fighting started last week it bobbed up to 42 percent.
"You could see a real impact," Ms. Innerfield said, "and the reason seemed to be that last fall people were watching the news and didn't have time for rental cassettes. Then, after the first few days of real war, people wanted some escape from the war coverage so they went out and rented a movie."

HEADLINE: Fighting Fire With Rubles

 BODY:
President Mikhail Gorbachev can't be serious. He may think he can solve his political problem in the Baltics even to the extent of some 19 deaths in Latvia and Lithuania. Now he purports to get tough with the Soviet Union's economic problems by withdrawing 50- and 100-ruble notes from circulation. That is supposed to control an explosive growth of the money supply and stifle a booming black market.
In fact, the plan is little more than a half-hearted detour from the monumental reform needed to move the Soviet economy out of the wreckage of Communism. It will punish ordinary citizens, incite justifiable outrage at the Kremlin and risk inflaming the Soviet public against the real reforms needed. 
 Mr. Gorbachev knows what effective monetary reform requires. It means, first, that he would have to close the Government's budget deficit, immense even by U.S. standards. Perhaps he would replace rubles with a limited supply of a new currency. He would certainly decontrol prices.
But he has rejected these fundamental steps; they would transfer economic, and therefore political, power from Moscow bureaucrats to ordinary citizens. The Soviet economy is self-destructing; Mr. Gorbachev is dithering.
Illegal markets are thriving in the Soviet Union. The Government has been running huge deficits, pumping billions of rubles into the economy. That makes each ruble worth less. Worse, there is precious little for Soviet workers to spend their rubles on. And, because prices are controlled, the workers cannot use all their extra rubles to bid for whatever goods are available.
 The combination of excess rubles and controlled prices is an open invitation for black marketeers to buy low and sell high. Mr. Gorbachev says he will defeat them by wiping out the 50- and 100-ruble notes.
The claim is dubious. Most black marketeers are smart enough to deal in small notes or hard currency. But the policy will hurt ordinary workers, many of whom lack American-style bank accounts and are forced to save much of their earnings in cash. At the black-market rate of 20 rubles to the dollar, a 50-ruble note is well within reach of many citizens, especially the elderly, who have had plenty of years to save.
If Mr. Gorbachev ever gets serious about economic reform, this "ruble overhang" will become a serious obstacle. When price controls are lifted, Soviets with the extra cash will rush into stores waving fistfuls of rubles. Inflation will skyrocket, punishing people without extra cash.
Mr. Gorbachev knows the solution. First, he must plug his Government's budget hemorrhage and stop printing new rubles. But there's no sign that he's willing to get tough in this real way. Two former economic advisors, Nikolai Petrakov and Stanislav Shatalin, disparage the latest 1991 budget as a fraud, sure to generate a huge deficit and another round of money creation.
Mr. Petrakov and Mr. Shatalin lobbied hard for tough fiscal policy and sweeping monetary and price reforms; they left the Government because Mr. Gorbachev wouldn't listen. He has degraded central control but remains unwilling to substitute market control. So now there is no control. The economy is imploding, and Mr. Gorbachev fiddles.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: What If the Oil Just Burned Away?

BYLINE: By Andrew Revkin; Andrew Revkin, who teaches journalism at Columbia University, is the author of "The Burning Season: The Murder of Chico Mendes and the Fight for the Amazon Rain Forest."

 BODY:
I had a little daydream as I watched the latest television reports from the war in the Persian Gulf. As plumes of black smoke rose from the blasted refineries in Kuwait and Iraq, and Saddam Hussein promised to blow up still more, I found myself briefly imagining what would happen if all the oil beneath the desert sands of that troubled region were set ablaze by this war.
Just imagine the startled looks on the faces of all the generals and politicians and economic pundits as they looked around after the last flickering flames had died down and the last clouds of smoke dissipated. 
 Suddenly, they would see the swamps of Iraq and the deserts of the Arabian Peninsula in a different light. All around would be an inhospitable landscape unsuited for the production of anything except dates and camel dung. Everyone would just pack up and go home.
Even Saddam Hussein.
After all, why did he invade Kuwait to begin with? He was fighting with the Emir over the vast pool of oil that straddles their common border, 10,000 feet underground.
Once all the oil burned, things would get interesting on the home front as well. With the world deprived most of its known reserves, oil prices would jump, let's say, fivefold. Suddenly, President Bush wouldn't have to worry about crafting an energy policy because the country would have one instantly, born of necessity. Who would need Government incentives to conserve oil with crude going for $125 a barrel and gasoline hitting $7 a gallon at the pump?
The millions of commuters who take their cars to the office every morning might finally have to opt for mass transit. Maybe then they'd be willing to put some of the money they spend on parking and gas into improving those woeful trains and subways.
Car manufacturers might even be forced to start putting those unsightly gas mileage figures back in their sleek magazine ads again. And the Japanese -- who have recently put all their efforts into outdoing the Americans at building high-performance, eight-cylinder, gas-guzzling luxury sedans -- might have to lead Detroit back to small cars again.
Maybe the worldwide population explosion of automobiles would be slowed. It had better slow down. There are 500 million cars on earth. In 35 years, that number is expected to quadruple. Two billion cars. More oil wars.
Maybe American businesses would finally learn to use fossil fuels efficiently. After all, the Europeans and Japanese already get twice as much industrial production out of a gallon of oil as we do.
Maybe Americans would finally replace some of their leaky windows. More energy escapes through the poorly insulated windows of American homes each year than flows through the Alaska pipeline.
Maybe more people would screw in those new compact fluorescent bulbs that throw the same amount of light as standard incandescent bulbs but consume a fourth as much energy and last 10 times as long.
Maybe solar power would no longer be scoffed at as a pipe dream. With the price of plastics -- which are made from oil -- skyrocketing, maybe Americans would finally put an end to the throw-away age.
It was a nice dream while it lasted. But the days wore on, the casualties mounted and the ground war began. There were plenty of fires in the Middle East, yes. And the smoke posed a grave environmental threat. But most of the oil still lay safe, beneath the sand.
There it will stay, patiently waiting for the day when peace returns. After the last of the fallen soldiers and civilians are buried, the Saudis and Kuwaitis -- and the Iraqis -- will return to the battered oilfields, uncap the wells and let it flow.
And we in America, Japan, Europe and the third world will write them a check, breathe a sigh of relief, and slake our relentless thirst.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Banks Try to Make Students Debt Junkies

 BODY:
To the Editor:
American banks are deluging college students with plastic, encouraging credit-card debt for many who, on top of tuition loans, will graduate with debt burdens. 
 "Dear John," began a letter to my son from a bank in Virginia, "Because you are a full-time college student or recent graduate, . . . [the] Bank has reserved a Visa or Mastercard for you with a credit line up to $1,500 . . . available immediately!" And: "Obtaining your Visa or Mastercard couldn't be easier: No parental signature necessary -- No need to be currently employed (if you are a full-time student) -- No previously established credit required."
What happened to the 3 C's of credit: capacity to repay, collateral and character? That 10 banks would offer $1,500 each, or $15,000, to an unemployed college student raises questions about bank management and morals. Even in the most highly leveraged corporate transactions of the 1980's, loans were not made to companies with no cash flow, no assets, no business plan and a negative net worth. Banks mostly complied with the adage "Know your customer."
"Flexible monthly payments," the letter continued. "Your minimum monthly payments are only 3 percent of your balance. Unpaid balances will be charged at an annual percentage rate of 19.8 percent." In the small print was the $18 annual fee, the 2 percent flat fee on cash advances, the 5 percent fee on late payments.
Saddling college students with credit-card debt is a growing business. That does not make it right. As parents, we must now teach our children that they must also just say no to debt.
 
JOHN M. WILKIE
Darien, Conn., Jan. 14, 1991

HEADLINE: Don't Scrap U.S.-Soviet Arms Accord Summit

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I have no quarrel with the analysis and account of recent events in Lithuania by Jeri Laber and Catherine Cosman, respectively executive director and Washington representative of Helsinki Watch, in "A 'Gorbachev Doctrine' Takes Shape" (Op-Ed, Jan. 16). But they are unconvincing in arguing that Washington should cancel next month's scheduled summit between President Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev. 
 This meeting relates to an arms accord between the United States and the Soviet Union. The article's authors urge that the United States should not support a Soviet Government that is party to repression and killings. But arms control is vital and mutually beneficial.
Punishment of President Gorbachev reinforces the designs of the Soviet military-industrial complex. The United States thereby sacrifices political leverage. Independence, separatism and sovereignty in Lithuania are not realizable through this suggestion. World tensions are not reduced by it. One cannot ascertain whether or not a successor to Mr. Gorbachev would treat the Baltic republics differently. Linkage is a risky doctrine; diplomacy is continuous.
The two authors also propose that the United States withhold economic aid from the Gorbachev Government This may make us feel better; however, it gives no reasonable assurance of increasing Moscow's receptivity to independence for the Baltic republics.
However one condemns Soviet behavior in this instance, President Gorbachev is scarcely likely to modify his Baltic policies or those toward other nationalities because the United States tries to exact political extortion. And in attempting to punish Mr. Gorbachev by cancelling a summit, in disregard of the United States interest in bringing down the levels of armament, this nation unwisely punishes itself, to its own political-military detriment.
 
ELLIOTT A. COHEN
New York, Jan. 16, 1991

HEADLINE: A Rock Climber's Reach For the Top on Wall St.

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
Before going to Wall Street, Steve Wunsch became a legend in the world of free rock climbing -- scaling sheer rock faces using gear only to break a fall. He became so known for his death-defying climbs with names like Supercrack that he is immortalized in such places as Moose, Wyo., at the base of the Grand Tetons, where his portrait hangs at the local outfitting store.
Today, he is testing limits of a different sort. The former Kidder, Peabody trader is taking on the New York Stock Exchange with a controversial -- threatening, to some -- computer designed to replace specialists who trade shares on the exchange floor. If successful, he will run the nation's first electronic auction exchange, setting prices off the Big Board. And, according to schedule, it should be up and running next month. 
 There are, of course, other electronic trading systems that have cropped up to steal business from the Big Board. But these are simply computerized bulletin boards that match brokers' buy and sell orders, typically using Big Board prices.
Mr. Wunsch's proposed exchange is different in that it threatens to undermine the basic role of the New York Stock Exchange as the price setter for corporate shares -- a role that has helped keep the Big Board the central marketplace for nearly 200 years.
Mr. Wunsch's exchange is, in fact, a computer programmed to create an auction. It will come up with a price at which buyers and sellers will trade their stocks -- and then execute those orders. This is what specialists do on the floor throughout the day.
Under his system, investors will submit their buy and sell orders. Then, three times a week, the computer will sort through the orders, come up with a price, and execute trades. At times of extraordinary demand, as when bombs first fell on Baghdad, Mr. Wunsch says he could hold more frequent sessions.
Not surprisingly, most of the nation's exchanges have protested to the Securities and Exchange Commission. The New York Stock Exchange contends the Wunsch system will "cherry pick" less risky trades, while the Philadelphia Stock Exchange says it threatens "fair competition." The Pacific Stock Exchange calls for "close oversight" and the National Association of Securities Dealers, which trades over-the-counter stocks, terms it a "novelty."
For his part, the 43-year-old Mr. Wunsch dismisses such talk. "Their not-surprising attempts to stop us are coming from their self-interest," Mr. Wunsch said in an interview. "Although there is the appearance of competition among the exchanges, in fact, it's like all different rooms in the same club. We're not worried."
Mr. Wunsch landed his job at Kidder when his rock-climbing skills attracted the attention of a fellow climber, Max C. Chapman, former Kidder president and now chairman of the Nomura Securities Company's American operations. He's been working on the system, first at Kidder, but success is hardly assured. Before trading begins, Mr. Wunsch must pass stiff regulatory hurdles. After that, he must garner enough business -- "liquidity" as it's called by traders -- to make his exchange worthwhile. So far, some 125 institutional investors, like pension funds and insurance companies, have signed on. And more are waiting to see if it succeeds before trading.
Today, there are basically two ways to trade stocks: through the continuous auction market on an exchange floor or over electronic screens, where dealers trade stocks directly among themselves based on Big Board prices. Like the competition between A.T.& T. and such rivals as MCI and U S Sprint, the Big Board has seen its market share erode steadily because of these off-exchange activities. Currently, the Big Board trades 83 percent of its listed shares, compared with 88 percent in 1980 -- a decline that affects the profitability of the exchange since it collects a fee for every share traded.
 
Costs Are Lower
 Large institutional investors have turned to a number of electronic trading systems because of lower transaction costs. A trade on the exchange floor might cost 3 to 7 cents a share, compared with about a half-cent to 2 cents off the floor.
Every day, institutional investors telephone each other, send facsimiles and get in touch with broker-dealers announcing what they want to buy and sell. This "Rolodex and fax" market, as it is called, is tapped first by big buyers, who then turn to the Big Board if they do not easily find a counterparty or if they have a particularly difficult trade.
Timothy F. McCarthy, an executive vice president at Fidelity Investments in Boston, recently surveyed institutional trades and found that up to a third were off an exchange. "Daily, we are inundated with faxes and phone calls," Mr. McCarthy said. "When investors look for liquidity, they look at exchanges, and they also look beyond the exchanges."
Still, Mr. McCarthy said, institutional traders do not want the exchanges to disappear. "A lot of people are talking out of both sides of their mouths," he said. "They say they want to meet directly. But they still want the exchange because that's where the central price discovery mechanism is and where they go when the markets get bad."
So far, Mr. Wunsch's machine has garnered interest, both for its unique approach as well as Mr. Wunsch's relentless promotion. He promises to keep trades at under 2 cents a share, and lined up the Bankers Trust Company as a clearinghouse.
"Wunsch's system is an economist's dream machine," said Hans Stoll, head of financial markets research at Vanderbilt University. "It brings buyers and sellers together at one point and the computer quickly reflects prices. I kind of like it."
 
Not for Quick Traders
 But will institutional investors? With auctions held only three times a week, the system is not designed for those needing quick trades. In addition, investors put in the price at which they want to trade, and, if the computer's price is quite different, orders could be left unfilled.
"Those people who have to trade at 10 A.M. are not a candidate for this auction," Mr. Wunsch said. "It's more for non-time critical trades. How many of those are there? That's the $64 question."
Mr. Wunsch believes that by taking non-time critical trades out of the market, volatility will be reduced. "With these orders out, the market won't be subject to wild swings," he said. "Ironically, we may be the salvation of the markets."
Institutions are cautious, but curious. DeWitt Bowman, chief investment officer of the California Public Employess Retirement System, which trades $4 billion a year, said a "growing 30 percent" of his trades were off an exchange. He has no electronic system of choice, and only cares that there is sufficient "liquidity" -- enough people trading.
 
Courting Brokerages
 Mr. Wunsch must also win over large brokerage houses. Head traders at two major firms, who asked not to be identified, said they preferred to support the Big Board. 'Automatic trading systems that create fractionation are a terrible danger to the entire financial system," said one trader. These firms, it should be noted, are members of the New York Stock Exchange.
Another obstacle are such entrenched operations as Instinet and Posit, two electronic systems, as well as the Cincinnati Stock Exchange, a floundering electronic system that trades at very low volume.
Robert H. Reid, executive vice president of Instinet, said Mr. Wunsch's exchange might have trouble getting orders. Like Instinet, which trades about 95,000 shares a day, compared with the Big Board's 200 million, he said Wunsch's system may suffer from a reluctance of older brokers and traders to use computers. "How much business will we lose to him, if any? I don't know," Mr. Reid said.
 
Exemptions Sought
 Mr. Wunsch's attention is focused on the S.E.C., which will soon decide whether to exempt his system from costly regulations governing exchanges -- the first such request from an electronic system. All other electronic systems are registered as broker-dealers because they do not fit the definition of an exchange. Mr. Wunsch argues that his exchange's volume will be so limited and his customers sufficiently sophisticated to warrant an exemption. Without it, institutions could not trade with him, nor could he list over-the-counter stocks, restrictions that would cut deeply into his business.
Brandon Becker, associate director of the S.E.C.'s division of market regulation, gives no hint about the agency's thinking. "The question of what constitutes an exchange is becoming an exciting one," Mr. Becker said. "Where does a trading system end and an exchange begin?"
Mr. Wunsch remains confident. He's doggedly pursuing test runs and preaches to potential clients. "I'm hopeful," he said. "I believe in our approach and that what we're doing is the correct philosophy."

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Thursday about a new stock trading system developed by Steve Wunsch, a former Kidder, Peabody trader, misstated the average daily volume on Instinet, an electronic stock trading system. Instinet says its average in the last six months has been about eight million shares -- most reported as trades through Nasdaq -- not 95,000.

HEADLINE: At Last, Pax Americana

BYLINE: By Joshua Muravchik; Joshua Muravchik, resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, is author of the forthcoming "Exporting Democracy."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
It will be weeks before the guns in the gulf fall silent, but we can see already the political contours of the world following an American victory. Important changes are in the offing on three levels of politics: domestic, Arab and global.
Domestically, the most profound consequences may be felt in the Democratic Party, dominated ideologically since the Vietnam War by its dovish wing. If the large majority of American voters continues to view the gulf war as the most just, necessary and successful our country has fought since World War II, the Democrats will pay a heavy price for having opposed it. 
 However, those who bucked the leadership and supported the President -- Stephen Solarz, Les Aspin, Dave McCurdy, Dante Fascell in the House; Joseph Lieberman and Albert Gore in the Senate -- will emerge vastly strengthened. They will win plaudits both for being right and for having risen above partisanship. If they stick together even loosely they will constitute a formidable new force in the party. From their ranks may come the next Democratic Presidential candidate, albeit not before Mr. Bush has had his second term.
In the Arab world, the drubbing of Saddam Hussein will be an epiphany that will demolish the appeal of the radical path. The bane of Arab politics has been a millenarianism that has stood in the way of a reckoning with reality -- the reality of Israel, the reality of the West. Whether in the form of pan-Arabism, religious fanaticism or secular radical ideologies, this millenarianism has led many Arabs to believe that, with unity or the right leader or theory, the humiliations of colonialism and underdevelopment could be redeemed and the world could be had on Arab terms rather than through compromise.
Not since the heyday of the former Egyptian President, Gamal Abdel Nasser, has one man concentrated in his own person all the wishful hopes of Arab radicalism as has Saddam Hussein. The very outrageousness of his aggression against Kuwait, his irrational defiance of America and his missile attacks on Israel have only reinforced his hold on the radical imagination.
If -- as seems all but certain -- the war ends in Saddam Hussein's utter humiliation, the sobering effect should be enormous. With Mr. Hussein's Baath Party in tatters, Soviet influence a thing of the past, Islamic extremism losing its luster in Iran and the myth of unity shattered as never before, the Arab world may be ready finally for realism and moderation.
Last but not least, the gulf war marks the dawning of the Pax Americana. True, that term was used immediately after World War II. But it was a misnomer then because the Soviet empire -- a real competitor with American power -- was born at the same moment. The result was not a "pax" of any kind, but a cold war and a bipolar world.
During the past two years, however, Soviet power has imploded and a bipolar world has become unipolar. A global rush toward democracy and free markets has spelled a huge victory for America on the ideological plain. Now, in the gulf war, our ideological supremacy is being matched by a demonstration of America's refurbished military capability.
Since Vietnam, doubts had abounded, both at home and abroad, about America's willingness to use force and its ability to do so effectively. It may well have been such doubts that led Saddam Hussein to ignore President Bush's pleas and threats. It is not likely another ruler will soon hasten to make the same miscalculation.
America's rediscovered prowess will not be used for conquest but to deter others from conquest: to secure the "new world order" that has been a goal of American policy since President Woodrow Wilson. In addition, it will strengthen the attraction of America's political and economic system.
This Pax Americana will rest not on domination but on persuasion and example as well as power. It will consist not of empire but of having won over a large and growing part of the world not only to the joys of jeans and rock and Big Macs but also to our concept of how nations ought to be governed and to behave.

HEADLINE: Peru Develops Plan to Work With U.S. to Combat Drugs

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Peru has drawn up plans for a multi-faceted joint venture with the United States to fight coca leaf cultivation, a detailed outline received here indicated today.
To help Peru cut its coca harvest, the world's largest, the plan calls for the United States to provide military aid, development aid and debt relief. A new Peruvian "super ministry" would coordinate a multi-pronged effort to promote crop substitution and to attack traffickers and their guerrilla backers, a planner said in a telephone interview from Lima today. 
 On Friday, Hernando de Soto, a Peruvian economist, is to present the plan in Washington to United States officials. Mr. de Soto is working against a deadline: if President Bush does not certify by March 1 that Peru is cooperating in the drug war, Peru will lose $100 million in military and economic aid.
 
Fujimori's Drug Plan
 The blueprint that American officials will start studying this weekend represents the first comprehensive drug strategy presented by the Peruvian President, Alberto K. Fujimori, since he took office last July.
In a break with previous Peruvian policy, the plan calls for the United States to help "feed, equip, train, outfit and adequately remunerate the police and armed forces who will be fighting drug trafficking and those who support" the traffickers.
Under this provision, the United States, for the first time, would provide military equipment and counterinsurgency training to help Peruvian security forces fight the Shining Path. A Maoist guerrilla group, the Shining Path protects growers and traffickers in Peru's main coca leaf production area, the Upper Huallaga Valley.
On the national level, Peru's spreading war with the Shining Path accounted for the majority of 3,384 Peruvians killed in political violence last year. The group, which last week declared President Saddam Hussein of Iraq "a world hero," is believed to have carried out a dynamite attack Wednesday on an English-language school in Peru, the North American Cultural Institute.
 
Military Aid Rejected
 Last September, Mr. Fujimori rejected $36 million in United States military aid on the grounds that coca leaf cultivation should be fought on many levels. With a four-month delay, the new proposal reflects that approach -- aid for farmers and repression for traffickers.
To encourage Peru's estimated 200,000 coca farmers to switch to other crops, the Government would improve roads in the Huallaga, would provide land titles, low interest credit and agricultural extension services and would slash government bureaucracy that strangles food production. Peru's agriculture is in such disarray that the United States currently provides $85 million in food aid. American food reached 13 percent of the population of 22 million.
To spur food exports, Peru would cut domestic bureaucracy and would sign a free trade pact with the United States, the 10-page anti-drug plan said. President Bush has called for free trade between the Americas, and the United States is currently negotiating free-trade pacts with Mexico and Chile.
 
Role of Military
 To atack drug traffickers, an elite military force would intercept airplanes, blow up laboratories and seize traffickers' assets. Other units would protect judges and special prisons, would investigate corruption and would minimize environmental damage caused by coca cultivation in rainforest areas.
Coordinating the campaign would be the "superministry," formally called the Autonomous Authority for Alternative Development. This agency's director would answer directly to President Fujimori and would have the power to coordinate anti-drug efforts carried out by 11 ministries.
In addition to direct financing from the United States, the Peruvians are asking for relief -- or outright forgiveness -- of Peru's $1.2 billion official debt to the United States.
In Lima today, one diplomat expressed skepticism that Peruvians could be easily weaned away from what has become the nation's most profitable export -- semi-refined cocaine.
"The proposal may make a lot of sense, but there is going to be a lot of bloodletting," the diplomat said in a telephone interview. "Hernando de Soto seems to think that the United States would be enchanted to see a good plan. The United States would love to see a good plan -- put in place and working."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Figuring a War Into the Budget

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE problem of managing the American economy now is complicated by the war in the Persian Gulf, coming on top of a recession that is cutting tax revenues, increasing unemployment and swelling the Federal debt and the budget deficit.
In his Congressional testimony this week, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, urged Congress not to raise taxes to finance the war, arguing that since nobody knew what the war would cost, it was better to borrow the money, at least for now. Such borrowing would increase the Federal debt but would not add to the deficit for the fiscal year 1991, as defined by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law. 
 In the agreement reached in December between the Administration and Congress to cut nearly $500 billion from deficits over the next five years, the costs of the military operations in the gulf were excluded from the deficit. The hostilities are what Congress calls an "off-budget war."
The Administration has joined Mr. Greenspan in opposing a tax increase, even as officials watch the budget deficit climb, with the extra costs of the savings and loan bailout taking their toll -- Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady has just asked for an extra $30 billion for the bailout. Indeed, in its budget proposal for the fiscal year 1992, due in two weeks, the Administration is expected to seek a cut in the capital gains tax. Such a cut seems unlikely, given the opposition of Congressional Democrats, who see it as a tax break for the rich.
Without other specific plans for fighting either recession or inflation through fiscal policy, the Administration is really relying on the budget as an automatic stabilizer of the economy against either inflation or recession. Michael J. Boskin, President Bush's chief economic adviser, said the new budget legislation adjusts the deficit targets forshort-run changes in economic conditions: A forecast of higher growth lowers the deficit target and a forecast of lower growth raises it. He calls this "good economic policy," adding, "There is widespread consensus among economists that Government budget deficits should rise if the economy weakens and should fall if it strengthens." Tax revenues automatically rise or fall in booms or slumps, and Government payments, like unemployment insurance, do the reverse, reinforcing the countercyclical effect of the budget.
By shifting attention from the "cyclical" components of deficits or surpluses, Mr. Boskin said in an interview, the deficit targets focus attention on reducing the "structural" deficit. In the longer run, this should reduce interest rates and stimulate investment, productivity and economic growth.
One concern, however, is whether the war's cost might overwhelm the automatic stabilizers. Mr. Greenspan this week estimated the cost of the air war at "several hundred million dollars a day" but "probably under half a billion a day." Military planners put the cost of an air-ground war at $1 billion a day, but this is a very rough number.
Much depends on the intensity of the war and whether one uses total costs, including sums already in the military budget, or incremental costs-- the extra costs of using reserve troops, fuel, ammunition and so forth -- and whether lost equipment is replaced.
The Congressional Budget Office, in a study prepared shortly before the war began, said, "If a war started early in calendar year 1991, added costs could range from $17 billion to $35 billion in budget authority in fiscal year 1991, with large additional costs in later years for the replacement of lost equipment." If all losses of major weapons and munitions were replaced, the report added, the cost could range from $28 billion to $86 billion.
Those costs are to be reduced by aid from the allies, but how much they will contribute is unclear. Up to the start of this year, direct allied contributions to the United States' gulf operations came to $4.6 billion in cash and $1.3 billion in kind.
Kuwait's government-in-exile gave $2.5 billion in cash and $6 million in kind. Saudi Arabia contributed $760 million in cash and $854 million in kind. Prof. M. A. Adelman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology estimates that the Saudis have been earning $45 billion to $50 billion at an annual rate because of higher prices and increased sales of their oil since the gulf crisis began.
Japan contributed $428 million in cash and $206 million in kind up to this month. The Japanese Government, which had pledged support of $4 billion, half to the war effort and half for economic aid to Jordan, Egypt and Turkey, said this week that it would raise its contribution to $9 billion, but that pledge is facing stiff opposition at home. Germany has done even less. So far German contributions total $272 million in cash and $66 million in kind.
The United Arab Emirates have put up $661 million, mostly in cash. Korea has given $61 million, $50 million of it in cash.
The budget office puts other allied contributions to the United States at $3 million in kind. These figures do not include the amounts that countries like Britain, France, Italy and Turkey spend on their own operations in the gulf.
As the budget office dryly notes: "Allied contributions will have to rise substantially if they are to offset a large fraction of U.S. costs in 1991."

HEADLINE: New York's Urban Problems Inspire Gifts to the Neediest

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ

 BODY:
For some contribututors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, concern about New York City's sick and poor was only a secondary reason for giving. They were moved by their devotion to New York -- and the pain they feel at its current plight.
In interviews and letters to the fund, these contributors often mentioned fond memories of New York as a center of culture and commerce. But they also described it as a city that has declined in recent years, becoming a national symbol of urban ills, a place where people sleep in cardboard boxes and the number of homeless people grows every day. And they said that their gifts to the Neediest Cases were intended to help the city rise from its current economic troubles. 
 "New York remains our capital for human talent," wrote J. Nicholas Ziegler, a professor at the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge. "The homelessness and desperation of the city's less fortunate persons are diminishing the moral, not to mention the economic, vitality of the whole country."
 
A 'Unique Collection'
 Dr. Ziegler said the decline of New York should be considered a national issue. He sent $75 to the fund, calling it a small step toward encouraging the "unique collection of firms and organizations to remain in the city." Many businesses will move away if the city's problems continue to grow, he said, and such a flight would affect the entire country's economic vitality.
Another donor, Margaret F. Boorstein, of East Norwich, L.I., sent a $45 contribution "to help to improve life in New York -- not only directly for the 'needy,' but for all." She added, "A city needs a vibrant and healthy society in order to survive and thrive."
There was also a gift of $36 from Michael M. Arrow, of New Rochelle, N.Y. "I was born in New York City, living in a modest and not unpleasant area of the Bronx that is now synonymous with severe urban ills and despair," he wrote. "That the need is there is without doubt; the fund is a ray of light and hope in satisfying it."
The 79th annual appeal for the Neediest Cases opened in November and runs through February. The proceeds are distributed among seven charities to aid the sick and the poor in the New York area. The New York Times pays for the campaign's overhead.
More than 11,600 people and organizations have contributed to the current drive, and many of them have written that they see donating to the fund as something they owe a city that has given them so much.
 
'The Most of Everything'
 "New York, of course, has the most of everything, and much of it the best," wrote Jeanne Alexander, of San Francisco. "Twenty-five years of living there taught me that."
Ms. Alexander said the city also has "the most and the neediest of neighbors." A $100 gift was enclosed to show that "moving away doesn't mean forgetting."

HEADLINE: So Far From Mideast: Mongolia's Oil Intrigues Bush

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
It has a vast desert and a large oil potential, President Bush was told, and this piqued his interest in Mongolia, a country about three times the size of Texas and thousands of miles from the Middle East.
The topic of oil came up when the President, a former Texas oilman, conferred with Punsalmaagiyn Ochirbat, President of Mongolia, the Asian leader said today. 
 Asked about reports that American oil companies are interested in developing production in basins in the Gobi desert, Mr. Ochirbat said that at his White House meeting with Mr. Bush on Wednesday "we told him about it and maybe expanded his knowledge."
President Bush was extremely cordial to Mr. Ochirbat, the first Mongolian head of state to visit Washington, and after announcing that the United States would extend trade benefits to his Government said he was looking forward to increased American commerce with Mongolia.
 
Oil Production to Begin
 In a meeting with reporters, President Ochirbat said that within two years Mongol Gazryn Tos, the Mongolian petroleum company, would begin extracting oil from deposits discovered decades ago by Soviet geologists at Zuunbayan, 280 miles southeast of the capital, Ulan Bator, and that "shortly we will begin exploration for new deposits."
Mr. Ochirbat said the Mongolian Parliament had recently approved laws permitting foreign investment and joint ventures.
Mongol Gazryn Tos was set up a year ago, replacing a Government ministry, as part of program removing Communist political and economic structures that had existed since the 1920's.
Last month, Exploration Associates International of Houston, a consulting concern, published a report on previous petroleum exploration in Mongolia that showed good prospects in Gobi desert sedimentary basins.
Mike Buck, vice president of the company, said the report was based on 150 exploratory studies conducted by Soviet, Hungarian, Romanian, East German and Polish geologists and geophysicists between 1939 and 1989 and covering about 60 percent of Mongolia.
Mr. Buck said he became interested in exploring Mongolian oil deposits two years ago when he learned while in China that some of the oil-rich sedimentary basins of North China extended across the frontier into southern Mongolia. The North China basins are estimated to contain about 10 billion barrels, he said.
 
200 Wells Are Drilled
 "The more we dug into the geological reports, the more we found," Mr. Buck said of oil prospects in Mongolia, "We are very enthusiastic." About 200 exploratory wells have been drilled in Mongolia.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Buck said the report covered Mongolia's 13 major sedimentary basins, most of which lie to the south of Ulan Bator.
The report, at $45,000 a copy, has become something of a best seller in the oil industry, and the company has become the technical adviser of Mongol Gazryn Tos in a new joint venture.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
I.B.M. Gets Lift From Mainframes

BYLINE: By John Markoff

 BODY:
STRONG sales of I.B.M.'s newest mainframe computers gave the computer maker a solid fourth-quarter report, and analysts say the trend will continue in 1991.
The International Business Machines Corporation's results surprised Wall Street, which pushed the company's stock up 8 percent since Jan. 17. The robust showing also appears to have surprised I.B.M. itself. Company executives told analysts in a conference telephone call on Jan. 17 that demand was exceeding supply of the new System 390 mainframes. The company also said that it had seen unusual strength in the sales of its largest disk drives used to store data for its mainframes. 
 Growth in mainframe sales appears to contradict advocates of a computer industry trend called "downsizing." In the past, some industry analysts have said mainframe growth would slow as important corporate data processing applications were moved to networks of smaller work stations and personal computers.
But I.B.M.'s strong results appear to present a more complicated picture. "Downsizing is real," said Peter L. Burris, a researcher at the International Data Corporation, a market research firm in Framingham, Mass. "It's not wise to say we're seeing an upsizing trend, but clearly the mainframe has remained a moving target."
In fact, many industry researchers and Wall Street analysts say that the most significant factor in predicting mainframe sales growth rates appears to be the product cycle, which moves far more slowly in the mainframe business than in markets for smaller systems. New families ofmainframe computers are introduced as infrequently as every 7 to 10 years, while in the personal computer business product lines tend to emerge every 2 to 3 years.
Over long periods of time, mainframe growth has been surprisingly constant. Rick Martin, an analyst at Prudential-Bache, said mainframe growth had varied little, staying between 5 to 10 percent a year since he began surveying the market more than 15 years ago.
Mr. Martin said that he had surveyed 50 of the largest data processing customers in early December and that he believed I.B.M. would have a particularly strong second half this year when its more powerful water-cooled ES/ 9000 processors become available in the third quarter. Currently I.B.M. is selling a transitional system, with much of the new System 390 equipment, that can be easily adapted to the next generation central processor.
The second half of the year could be particularly strong because of I.B.M.'s strategy for encouraging the company's largest customers to upgrade to the new top-of-the-line water-cooled ES/9000, said Robert Djurdjevic, president of Annex Research, a Phoenix-based consulting firm. He believes that I.B.M. is hoping to pave the way for a smooth transition by offering attractive trade-in options for its current machines. He said the company will guarantee the 1990 price of its previous top-of-the-line machine, giving a customer effectively free use of the machine for 12 months.Such incentives plus new models from I.B.M.'s competitors guarantee a resurgence of the mainframe market in the second half of the year, analysts believe.
"Both I.B.M. and Amdahl estimates show weak first-half comparisons with acceleration in the second half with the mainframe cycle," said Steven Cohen, an analyst at the Soundview Financial Group, referring to the Amdahl Corporation, the No. 2 mainframe maker after I.B.M.
To keep its dominance of the market, I.B.M. is making it more difficult for competitors to sell their equipment to I.B.M. customers. Much of the compatible business has come from selling added performance at lower cost to I.B.M. customers, Mr. Burris said. I.B.M.'s new System 390 family will make it more difficult for compatible makers to integrate their machines into I.B.M. data processing centers using the new systems. Such a strategy will increase what is referred to as I.B.M.'s "account control." This is an indicator of the computer maker's ability to keep its customers from mixing machines from different vendors.
Perhaps the most striking aspect of I.B.M.'s strong quarter is the new evidence the report provides that the computer industry may escape the worst effects of the recession. said Mark D. Stahlman, a computer industry analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons. "For computer companies, the recession has proved to be a hoax," he said. A 20-year analysis shows no relation between the rate of G.N.P. growth and computer company performance, he added. Factors as diverse as product cycles and strong marketing campaigns have offset broader economic factors.
A recession can even be a plus for computer makers, he argued. "The more people thrown out of work, the more people will start a business out of their homes. You can't start a business without a computer."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up After Early Slide; Silver Plunges a Second Day

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday after recovering from a morning slide on concern that the Federal Reserve will lower interest rates to cushion the recession.
Silver, meanwhile, plummeted for the second day and gold also fell. 
 Gold was under pressure from the steep slide in silver prices. Silver for March delivery fell 15.2 cents, to $3.785 an ounce, its lowest level since 1976. Gold for January delivery on the Commodity Exchange fell $5.40, to $373 a troy ounce. The active February contract also fell $5.40, to $373.50 an ounce.
In the currency market, the dollar's recovery, which was partly technical, followed comments by Israel's Ambassador to the United States, who said Tel Aviv would be ready to join in regional arms control efforts and possible peace talks with the Palestinians once the Persian Gulf war ended.
Traders said the dollar initially dropped on the news. But when it did not fall as far as traders had feared, it rebounded.
"I think the initial reaction was selling," said George Eckhardt of Paine Webber Group. "It should be somewhat bearish for the dollar if you accept the idea that war is bullish."
Traders said the dollar also received a late lift from comments by a Federal Reserve Board governor, Edward Kelley, who told Reuters that a lower dollar was cause for concern.
The dollar is seen as a safe holding, and tends to rise in times of crisis.
But after the initial selloff, traders grew encouraged by the dollar's resilience, said Chuck Spence of First Interstate Bank in Los Angeles.
The dollar closed at 1.4870 German marks, up from Wednesday's close of 1.4825 marks. Against the Japanese yen, the dollar closed at 132.35 yen, up from Wednesday's closing price of 131.72 yen.
Trading remained edgy, as dealers focus on both the fragile state of the economy and war in the Middle East.
With the nation mired in wartime recession, the prospect of lower interest rates to spur growth is looming large, and would be bad news for the dollar, whose value erodes when interest rates fall. But the tougher war proves, the more investors seek safety, a possible plus for the dollar.
Tom Moore of American Express Bank said that those bearish on the dollar have been talking about a fall to 1.4300 marks and 1.2200 Swiss francs. The all-time low for the dollar against the mark is 1.4630, set late last year.
Mr. Moore said the bearishness was reinforced when United States and German authorities this week talked of the possibility of lower American interest rates and steady German rates.
The British pound closed at $1.9565, down from Wednesday's $1.9595. The dollar rose to 1.2575 Swiss francs, from 1.2510 francs Wednesday, and to $1.1595 against the Canadian currency from Wednesday's $1.1580 (Canadian).
Against the French franc, the dollar closed at 5.0545 francs, up from Wednesday's 5.0410 francs.
