HEADLINE: Northwest Air in No Hurry to Spend

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
While strong airlines like American and United have been jumping to buy the precious international routes that weaker carriers have been forced to sell, Northwest has so far remained on the sidelines, picking up only small pieces.
Northwest, the nation's fourth-largest carrier, certainly appears to be in a position to buy. Moreover, its cash position was strengthened considerably by the decision announced Wednesday by Samuel K. Skinner, the Transportation Secretary, to allow foreign companies to own bigger portions of domestic carriers. As a result, the Dutch airline KLM will be able to keep its 49 percent ownership of Northwest, and Northwest will not have to use $250 million to redeem common shares held by KLM. 
 Even so, John Dasburg, Northwest's president and chief executive,gave no indication in an interview yesterday that he was poised to go after major European routes.
 
Threat to Dominance
 Granted, the buying pace set by the leaders, American and United, is not being matched by strong carriers like Delta and USAir, either. But the stakes are higher for Northwest because it stands to lose ground where it has been dominant in the past -- international routes.
For years from its base in Minneapolis and major hubs at Detroit and Memphis, Northwest was the largest American carrier to the Pacific. Now its leadership is being challenged by United Airlines, which acquired the Pacific routes of Pan American World Airways in 1986 and after stumbling badly at first has become a formidable competitor.
International routes are awarded to airlines only after long lobbying and negotiations between the United States Government and the other country involved. Airlines with any resources at all are usually eager to bypass those delays and buy routes wholesale when bleak times force weaker carriers to give them up.
 
A Faster Consolidation
 Mr. Dasburg said the economic effects of the Persian Gulf war have greatly speeded up a consolidation that most of the industry had believed would take a decade to complete.
"It has been telescoped into a 12-month period of time by Saddam Hussein," he said. "The industry is under tremendous pressure both from fuel prices and a rapid fall in traffic."
But so far, the pressures have not caused Northwest's managers to jump into the fray to become a major player in Europe.
"We're a niche player in the North Atlantic and Europe," Mr. Dasburg said. "We're reviewing our strategy at this time."
While Northwest has been reviewing, others have been pouncing. United bought Pan Am's London routes for $400 million, and American bought the London routes of Trans World Airlines for $500 million.
 
Move in Hawaii
 Last December, Northwest bought a 25 percent interest in Hawaiian Airlines for $20 million. That gave Northwest the ability to fly to Australia and to Nagoya and Fukuoka, in Japan, strengthening its already huge Pacific system.
This week the airline announced that it had bought landing slots, gates and other assets at Washington National Airport from Eastern Airlines for $23.2 million.
While Northwest, which Alfred A. Checchi and a group of investors bought in 1989, has used much of its cash to pay off a large part of its debt from the acquisition, Mr. Dasburg said the airline still had the money to make strategic acquisitions. He refused to disclose any details about the airline's cash.
Northwest's moves so far, however, will not be enough to keep it in the running with the major carriers.
"Northwest must make a strategic move either in the North Atlantic or further strengthen its domestic system," said Julius Maldutis, an airline analyst with Salomon Brothers.
To do so, he said, Northwest might be forced to make a major purchase like buying the rest of Pan Am, which even without its London routes still offers extensive service to Europe. Pan Am has filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code and is awaiting final approval of the sale of its London routes to provide it with enough money to get through its financial crisis.
 
'Quietly Aggressive'
 Edward Starkman, the airline analyst for Paine Webber, said Northwest in its own modest way was making moves that it could build on later.
"They have been quietly aggressive in their own way," he said. He said that Northwest was building on its strong Pacific routes and that the National Airport acquisition would add another important domestic hub.
As for Europe, he said the association with KLM could give Northwest the advantages of new routes to Europe without having to buy and fly the routes. He said Northwest could offer its frequent-flier customers flights to Europe on KLM, with coordinated connecting flights on Northwest.
"If done well, it's as good as flying the system itself," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alfred A. Checchi acquired Northwest, the nation's fourth-largest air carrier, in 1989. (Bart Bartholomew)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Continue Upward

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose again yesterday and yields fell, as traders responded to a second day of seemingly positive developments in the Persian Gulf war by buying notes and bonds.
In addition to the generally favorable news from the gulf, credit market participants said the nearly pervasive sense that the Federal Reserve Board would move soon to push down short-term interest rates also helped to buttress prices. 
 "Everybody understands that the Fed chairman has given the market assurance that the Fed will be helpful in the near term," one government bond trader said. "That assurance is the groundwork for further gains."
In Congressional testimony earlier this week, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, suggested that the central bank was looking at a number of options, including a reduction in short-term interest rates, to stimulate the economy and address the credit squeeze at the nation's commercial banks.
Although the fixed-income market dotes on bad economic news, largely because such reports tend to push down inflation, the Government announcement yesterday of a rise of 67,000 in initial unemployment claims for the week ended Jan. 12, to 463,000, did not create much of a stir.
"For the next few weeks, the bond market is likely to be more responsive to reports of defections from the Iraqi Army than it is to weekly unemployment claims numbers," said David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services Inc.
Similarly, market participants gave only a token response after the Federal Reserve reported late yesterday that two of the three measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended Jan. 14. The narrowest measure, M-1, fell by $4.2 billion.
 
Concern Over Money Growth
 In recent weeks, Mr. Greenspan and other Fed officials have expressed concern about weak money growth.
Analysts said the money figures were pretty much in line with expectations.
Market participants said that an auction of $9 billion worth of new five-year Treasury notes went well.
The securities were sold at an average yield of 7.62 percent, the lowest yield on a five-year note in nearly four years. At the last five-year note sale on Nov. 28, the average yield was 7.95 percent.
Trading activity, which dealers said was fairly brisk early in the session, wound down as the day progressed. In part, traders said they were unwilling to establish additional positions in advance of a report expected from the Commerce Department this morning on how the economy fared in the fourth quarter.
 
Estimates on the G.N.P.
 Virtually all economists inside the Government and out are predicting that the Commerce Department's preliminary estimate will show that the gross national product contracted sharply in the fourth quarter. Estimates of the rate of decline range from as low as 2 percent to as high as 4 percent.
In making their projections, most analysts have added that the fourth-quarter decline in output will most likely represent the steepest slide of the recession.
"We are in the neighborhood of down 3.0 percent," for the fourth quarter, said Dana Johnson, chief money market economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. "And while it is a reasonable forecast that the drop was the steepest in the fourth quarter, that isn't very comforting."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered in late trading at a price of 106 18/32, up 14/ 32, to yield 8.15 percent, compared with 8.19 percent late Wednesday.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 103 1/2, up 1/4 point, to yield 7.97 percent. And the 7 percent two-year notes auctioned on Wednesday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.03 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates fell slightly.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 6.11 percent, down one basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bills were offered at a 6.15 percent rate, down three basis points.
In other developments, positive developments in the Persian Gulf spurred a number of corporations to price new debt issues in the investment-grade corporate bond market.
Among the issuers was BP America, the American subsidiary of the British Petroleum Corporation.
The company offered $350 million of 8 3/4 percent 12-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The securities were priced at $99.75, to yield 8.784 percent, 80 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities, which mature Feb. 1, 2003, are rated AA-3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said prices of outstanding Chrysler Corporation and Chrysler Financial Corporation securities were little changed despite the fact that a major ratings agency, Fitch Investors Service Inc., lowered its ratings on $12.5 billion worth of debt to BB-plus, a sub-investment grade level, from BBB.
"The downgrade is already in the market," one trader said.
Traders said that prices of most corporate bonds rose by about 1/8 point in generally sluggish trading.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of most widely quoted issues rose by about 1/4 point, traders said.

HEADLINE: Stocks Climb Broadly as Dow Jumps 24.01

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
With no unsettling news from the Middle East by closing time, stock prices advanced broadly yesterday in the heaviest trading in a week.
Analysts attributed it to Wednesday's Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that the economy needs a lift -- a clue that he would make sure it happens. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 24.01, or nearly 1 percent, to 2,643.07. Birinyi Associates said repeated waves of computerized program buying raised the blue-chip index close to 21 points.
Activity soared to 223.2 million shares, up from 169.4 million the day before and the highest since last Friday.
The broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 1.4 percent, or the equivalent of 37 points on the Dow, while the Nasdaq composite index climbed nearly 2 percent, the equivalent of 56 Dow points.
 
Gains Outpace Declines
 Advances outnumbered declines 3 to 1, with 1,231 stocks, or 61 percent of the Big Board total, ahead for the day while 398 fell. Seventy-two stocks reached new highs and 17 fell to new lows.
Analysts were impressed by the rise in secondary stocks, the mainstay of the Nasdaq index. The lesser stocks were a big factor in leading the market out of its lows last October and are expected to do it again.
From airlines, banks, chemical companies and paper to technology, drugs, insurance and retailing, the advance in the Dow extended across most leading industry groups.
Airlines were especially strong, rising in the wake of weak crude oil prices and the news that foreigners would be allowed to invest more heavily in American air carriers.
The rise pushed the Dow transportation index ahead 40.02 points, or 4 percent, with UAL up 5 1/4, to 128 3/4; Airborne Freight 2 1/8, to 20 1/2; AMR 1 1/2, to 52 5/8; Delta Air Lines 1 3/4, to 68 3/8, and Southwest Airlines 1 5/8, to 22 5/8. Conrail rose 4 3/8, to 44 1/2, after reporting better-than-expected profits.
 
March Crude Oil Contract
 The March crude oil contract, meanwhile, fell 33 cents, to $21.71 a barrel, close to its low for the day.
"Many people were puzzled why the transportation index went up so much," said Hugh Johnson, chief strategist for the brokerage firm First Albany Corporation. "I think the main reason was that the Saudi oilfields appear to be safe," but he also cited the relaxation of limits on foreign investment in airlines.
He attributed the rise in the Dow to "a carry-over of Greenspan's testimony on Wednesday implying that the Fed was prepared to lower short-term interest rates, particularly if bank lending and money growth remains sluggish."
Shocked by the rise in the market -- after Wednesday's gain -- short-sellers who had hoped to make a killing if the market fell, were forced to buy to cover stock they had borrowed, driving the market ahead.
The Dow picked up steam from the opening bell. By 10 A.M. it was ahead nearly 25 points. Bt 11:15 it was up 31. Prices fell a little but by 12:30 were ahead 33 points.
Traders have become accustomed to shocks from the Middle East late in the day, which may explain why the Dow drifted a little toward the close.
Despite the strong rise in the Dow industrials, individual price gains were mainly thin. A.T.& T. rose 5/8, to 29; Kodak 1/8, to 40 1/8, and Coca-Cola 3/4, to 48 7/8. But International Paper tacked on 2 1/4, to 57 7/8; Boeing 1 5/8, to 48 3/4; I.B.M. 1 3/4, to 121, and Sears 1, to 26 7/8.
Blockbuster Entertainment, which has been strong since the fall, headed the Big Board active list, sliding 2 1/4, to 25 5/8, on 4.8 million shares even though fourth-quarter earnings met analyst estimates.
Data General, a technology company, rose 4, to 8 1/4, after going into the black in the December quarter. Bankers Trust fell 4 1/8, to 41, after George Salem, banking analyst for Prudential-Bache, cut his earnings estimate for this year after a lower-than-expected 1990.
News Corporation, headed by Rupert Murdoch, rose 7/8, to 7 7/8. He said he was prepared to dilute his family's 45 percent control by issuing more full voting stock, Dow Jones reported.
 
Tokyo Stocks Advance
TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 25 (REUTERS) -- Japanese stocks rose today for the second straight gain. The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 304.24 points, or 1.3 percent, to close at 25,573.25. The Nikkei rose 218.91 points on Thursday.

HEADLINE: A.T.& T.'s Earnings Are Flat

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
A.T.& T. announced yesterday that its earnings were nearly flat in the fourth quarter. The loss of tax credits, higher interest expenses and reduced gains from cash investments and asset sales offset a strong increase in operating profits.
Two of the seven regional Bell companies created by the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in 1984 also reported fourth-quarter results yesterday. U S West posted a tiny gain in profits, while Nynex reported that profits from operations fell slightly. Nynex also announced a one-time after-tax loss of $211 million, mostly to cover losses and reorganization costs in subsidiaries selling equipment and software to businesses. 
 Nynex fared worse than U S West because of management problems, regulatory disputes and a weakening economy in the Northeast, said Marion M. Boucher, a telephone industry bond analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc.
Following are details of the companies' results:
 
A.T.& T.
A.T.& T. said it earned $698 million, or 64 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, off about 1 percent from $705 million, or 65 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales for the quarter jumped about 7 percent, to $9.96 billion from $9.31 billion.
The nation's largest long-distance carrier also reported modest increases in sales and profits for all of 1990.
Morris Tanenbaum, the chief financial officer and a vice chairman of A.T.& T., said that while the company's executives had hoped for better earnings in 1990, he was satisfied with the results because of weaknesses in the economy last year. "Considering the environment we have had, particularly in the last three quarters of last year, I think our people have done a really solid job," he said.
John S. Bain, a telephone industry analyst at Raymond James & Associates, a brokerage in St. Petersburg, Fla., said the company had exceeded his earnings estimate of 62 cents a share because of continued growth in long-distance telephone traffic and rising sales of telephone company switching equipment. "Everything looks good across the board," he said.
James M. McCabe, a telephone industry analyst at Nomura Securities, said A.T.& T.'s telecommunications equipment business had done much better than he had expected, while the long-distance business had done worse.
A.T.& T. reported an 8 percent increase in long-distance traffic in the quarter but only a 1.8 percent increase in long-distance revenues. More and more large business customers are buying packages of telecommunications services at heavily discounted rates, instead of paying for each service separately at higher rates.
The company said it had stopped losing market share in the business market, and Mr. Tanenbaum said this change contributed to the company's growth in long-distance traffic.
This growth did not drop at the end of the quarter even though the economy was slowing, said C. Perry Colwell, A.T.& T.'s senior vice president for financial management. "We were pleased with the strength we saw in December," he said, "and we closed out the year on a strong note."
A.T.& T. predicted that it might not feel the full effects of a recession until this year but added that it expected the economy and its own financial results to rebound later this year.
Some analysts have suggested that A.T.& T.'s rising marketing expenses could reduce its profit margins on long-distance service and that a drop in long-distance traffic this year could plunge the industry into a costly price war.
A.T.& T.'s companywide sales and administrative expenses rose in the fourth quarter. But the increase was partly offset by a $50 million drop in network operation expenses, the result of labor cutbacks and heavy investment in computerized equipment that requires little maintenance.
Mr. Tanenbaum said that A.T.& T. would not start a price war and that "it is not our intention to join or to fuel a price war."
Several regional Bell companies have reported anemic growth in telephone lines during the fourth quarter, a situation that has traditionally led to reduced purchases of new switching equipment. While A.T.& T.'s sales of telephone network equipment to these companies were weak in the fourth quarter, sales to other domestic phone companies and to foreign companies more than made up the difference.
The company reported that its overall sales of telephone network products and services grew 12.4 percent in the fourth quarter.
On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, A.T.& T.'s share price gained 37.5 cents, to $30.875.
 
Nynex
The main provider of local telephone service in New York and New England announced a series of changes in its unregulated businesses and took a $211 million charge to cover the anticipated cost.
Nynex said it would seek a corporate partner for Nynex Business Centers, which sells office computers. Nynex said it also planned to sell or transfer to another division its 460-employee unit that maintains office telecommunications equipment. And the company took several one-time losses relating to its purchase and sale of various small software companies and the creation of a holding company for some overseas operations.
The New York Department of Law and the New York State Public Service Commission are investigating whether some of these unregulated business-equipment subsidiaries overcharged the company's regulated local telephone companies. Peter T. Goodale, a spokesman for Nynex, said yesterday's moves were part of a continuing effort to reorganize the company and were not related to the investigations.
David S. Cook, owner and chairman of the Computerland franchise in Hartford, said that Nynex Business Centers had been selling computers for as little as 1 percent above wholesale cost. Most companies charge a 12 to 15 percent markup to cover costs like labor, rent and advertising, he added.
Mr. Goodale said the Nynex unit became profitable in the fourth quarter of last year and was growing.
Nynex earned $60.7 million, or 30 cents a share, on sales of $3.44 billion in the fourth quarter. A year earlier it had a loss of $43.7 million, or 22 cents a share, on sales of $3.37 billion.
Excluding one-time charges in both quarters, earnings fell 3.4 percent, to $271.7 million from $281.3 million.
For 1990, Nynex's profits rose 17.6 percent, to $949.4 million, or $4.78 a share, from $807.6 million, or $4.10 a share, in 1989. Sales rose about 3 percent, to $13.59 billion from $13.20 billion.
Nynex's share price rose 75 cents, to $68.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
U S West
The dominant provider of local telephone service in 14 Western states reported fourth-quarter earnings of $348 million, or 89 cents a share, up about 1 percent from $344.4 million, or 92 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 3.9 percent, to $2.64 billion from $2.54 billion.
In all of 1990, U S West Inc. earned $1.20 billion, or $3.11 a share, up 8.1 percent from $1.11 billion, or $3.01 a share, in 1989. Sales rose 2.8 percent, to $9.96 billion from $9.69 billion.
U S West's share price climbed 50 cents yesterday, to $36.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: British Court Decision Could Hurt U.S. Banks

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
In a decision that exposes United States commercial and investment banks to tens of millions and possibly hundreds of millions of dollars in potential losses, the House of Lords today upheld a lower-court ruling that local governments in Britain had no authority to enter into complex financial transactions known as interest-rate swaps.
The unanimous ruling by the five law lords of the House, which serves as Britain's highest court of appeals, means that international financial institutions -- including American companies like Citicorp, Chemical, Security Pacific, J.P. Morgan and Salomon Brothers -- face losses that could total as much as 600 million ($1.18 billion). But one banker at an American institution who spoke on the condition of anonymity estimated that exposure of United States banks was probably no more than 10 to 15 percent of the total, or no more than $176 million. 
 Many American and British banks had previously added to their reserves to cover the potential losses following rulings by lower courts, which date back to November 1989.
Interest rate swaps are basically transactions in which two parties agree to exchange interest payments on their debts. The financial institutions are liable in this case because the way they arranged the swaps was to enter into the individual agreements themselves; offsetting one swap against the other so their own position was neutral. Before the current case, many financial institutions, lawyers, accountants and local governments had interpreted existing law to mean that the local governments could enter into swaps as part of their legal power to borrow.
 
'Provide a Just Outcome'
 In response to today's decision, financial institutions called on the British Government to pass a law that would make most if not all of the deals legal. The decision "now frees the British Government to take action and to provide a just outcome," said Mark C. Brickell, chairman of the International Swap Dealers Association, whose members include 130 financial institutions in 15 countries.
Mr. Brickell, who is also a vice president at J.P. Morgan & Company, noted in a phone interview from New York that the Conservative Government had previously said it would take no action while the matter was before the courts.
If the Government does not act, financial institutions said they might sue those who had either entered into the swap deals or who had rendered opinions that they were legal. These include local governments, their individual councilors, lawyers and accounting firms
Several bankers said today that 130 local governments in Britain had engaged in interest-rate swaps with 78 banks. The Press Association, the British news agency, put the number of local governments at more than 70.
 
Hundreds of Lawsuits Are Likely
 "There are likely to be hundreds of lawsuits," said Daniel Cunningham, a lawyer for the International Swap Dealers Association. Indeed, several American banks and many British banks had filed lawsuits against local governments that were on hold, pending the outcome of the test case. Today, some bankers said they would proceed with those suits unless the British Government enacted a law to legalize swaps.
Mr. Cunningham, a partner at the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, said in a phone interview from New York that under British legal doctrine known as restitution, banks might be able to insist that parties in the deals remiburse whatever they had paid to each other, and in essence go back to where they stood before entering into the deals.
In a phone interview from New York, Joyce Oberdorf, a spokeswoman for Chemical, said the bank's lawyers were studying the decision. But she added: "In our opinion, many legal avenues still exist and can be pursued. This decision" by the House of Lords "is unlikely to be the end of the matter." She said Chemical added $26 million to its reserves to cover its exposure in late 1989.
Spokesmen for Citicorp and J.P. Morgan said their banks had modest exposures. And Citicorp, which has a lawsuit pending against a local government, has already set aside reserves.
Executives of Amerian and British banks said if the British Government did not settle the dispute, it would undermine confidence in British financial markets and threaten London's position as a major financial center.
 
Reluctance to Lend
 Some bankers also warned that unless a new law were passed to legalize most swaps, including past deals, financial institutions would be reluctant to lend to local governments.
Sir Jack Layden, chairman of the Association of Metropolitan Authorities, said the Government "must act to head off the torrent of litigation that could flow from this decision. If it does not act, then taxpayers, local government and the reputation of" London "as an international banking center could all suffer."
The case arose over the use of swaps by the local government of Hammersmith and Fulham, a London borough. While most local governments that engaged in swaps did so as part of their prudent management of debt, Hammersmith and Fulham reportedly tried to use them to make a profit and increase its spending resources. This occurred at a time when the Conservative Government then headed by Margaret Thatcher was trying to limit local government spending.
Mrs. Thatcher believed that many local governments, especially those controlled by the opposition Labor Party, were irresponsible big spenders.
The dozens of institutions that had made swaps with the borough included Midland and Barclays, the British banks; Security Pacific; Chemical; Citicorp, and Japan's Mitsubishi Finance International.

HEADLINE: Bush Said to Lean Toward Summit Delay

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Administration officials said today that it was increasingly likely that the next Soviet-American summit meeting would be postponed, as President Bush came under increasing pressure from Congress to put off the Moscow meeting because of the violence in the Baltic republics.
After a meeting in the White House today between Mr. Bush and Republican Congressional leaders, some lawmakers who attended the session said Mr. Bush was warned of a rising sentiment in Congress for him to take some action toward Moscow, and that postponing the summit meeting, scheduled for Feb. 11 to 13, seemed like a good way to do that. 
 "There was sentiment that he should not go," Representative Vin Weber, Republican of Minnesota, said of the hourlong meeting, which also touched on the situation in the Persian Gulf and domestic issues.
A senior Administration official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Mr. Bush's initial disapproval of Soviet policy toward Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia had hardened into a sense of "outrage" during the recent violence in the Baltic regions, which are seeking independence from Moscow.
 
Baltics and Other Reasons
 After some initial reluctance to put off the summit talks, primarily because of his desire not to undercut President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's position, Mr. Bush is now leaning more strongly toward a delay, officials said.
According to another senior official, Mr. Bush told the Republican lawmakers this morning that if the summit meeting was delayed, he wanted to find a way to do so "in a way that doesn't weaken Gorbachev's position vis-a-vis those who might be more authoritarian than he is or who seek to strengthen the crackdown in the Baltics."
For that reason, officials said that if Mr. Bush made the final decision not to go to Moscow in February as planned, the White House would avoid citing the Baltics as the only reason. Instead, both sides are likely to present a delay as a "mutual decision" that was also based on the war in the gulf and on delays in arms-control talks.
The final decision is expected to be made after a meeting this weekend between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh of the Soviet Union, officials said.
 
Soviet Official's Customary Call
 The White House said no meeting had been scheduled between Mr. Bessmertnykh and Mr. Bush, but officials said it was customary for the Soviet Foreign Minister to be received in the Oval Office when he is in Washington.
The possibility that the summit meeting would be postponed was first reported by Administration officials more than two weeks ago, as war in the Persian Gulf loomed, Soviet internal tensions worsened and negotiators from both countries remained snagged in their efforts to wrap up a treaty on reducing long-range nuclear weapons. That treaty is to be signed at the Moscow summit meeting.
The United States and the Soviet Union also are at odds over American assertions that Moscow is evading counting and verification rules in the treaty on reducing conventional weapons that was signed in November in Paris. Until those problems are solved, Administration officials said, Congress has warned Mr. Bush that he should not send that treaty to the Senate for its advice and consent.
The White House has said there is no formal linkage between the two treaties. But officials have made it clear in private that the Administration is not eager to conclude the treaty on long-range missiles while the fate of the accord on conventional arms is unsettled.
 
Gorbachev's Backing in Gulf
 A senior official indicated today that there had been a significant change in the Administration's thinking about the summit talks, shifting the burden of proof, in effect, from those who argued that the summit meeting should be put off to those who are arguing that Mr. Bush should proceed with the plan to go to Moscow.
The official said he did not want to paint too pessimistic a view of Soviet-American relations, particularly because of the Administration's desire to promote democratic change in that country and because of Mr. Gorbachev's continued support for American policy in the gulf.
But he said, "The summit is being reconsidered because of the war, because of the arms-control problem and because of the situation in the Baltics."
He continued: "If we can clear all those things out of the way, maybe there is still a chance. But it clearly is up in the air."
 
Senate Vote on Baltics
 During this morning's meeting in the White House, Mr. Weber said: "There was no pounding of the table and saying, 'You better not go to Moscow.' But there's a sense that we ought to make our position clear to Moscow as firmly as we can and the summit is one of the few pieces of leverage that we have."
Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House Republican leader, also said that some of those at the meeting suggested that Mr. Bush consider a delay in the summit.
By a vote of 99 to 0, the Senate today passed a nonbinding resolution condemning Soviet action in the Baltics. It urged the President to suspend all technical exchanges with the Soviet Union, review all American economic assistance to Moscow and consider withdrawing Washington's support for Soviet membership in the world's financial institutions, the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: THE COSTS;
2 Unsavory Choices on the Budget: Increase Borrowing or Raise Taxes

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
No one knows how much the war will cost. That is because no one knows how long it will last, how many lost planes and expended weapons will have to be replaced and how much money the allies will contribute to offset the price to the American taxpayer.
 But the cost, running at several hundred million dollars a day since the shooting began, is sure to be substantial, and that started a debate this week over how the war should be paid for. 
 Policy makers have their fingers crossed that a healthy share of the tab will be picked up by the Japanese, the Germans and the Saudis, but most officials agree that the United States will end up bearing the brunt of the financial cost as well as the human cost of the allied effort.
 
Two Options
 Since few in the Administration or Congress are willing to cut domestic spending by enough to pay the war bills, there are only two ways to meet them: by raising taxes or by borrowing the money.
Those who favor a "pay as you go" approach take their text from the contrast between the American experiences in Korea and Vietnam.
In 1950, at the outset of the Korean War, taxes were raised; the country came out of the war with inflation under control, and the economy boomed after the war.
By contrast, President Lyndon B. Johnson waited for more than a year to propose a tax increase after his Council of Economic Advisers in late 1965 recommended one to pay for the Vietnam buildup. Then, Congress did not approve the war surtax for another 18 months. The inflation that resulted from the increased budget deficit damaged the economy for years afterward.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office and Congress's chief economist, say that circumstances now are different in two respects from those that existed at the outset of the Vietnam War.
 
Recession Is a Factor
 First, the economy was growing rapidly in the mid-1960's; now it is in recession. As a consequence, inflation is a less serious threat now than it was then. And a tax increase now, Mr. Greenspan and Mr. Reischauer said at separate Congressional hearings this week, could worsen the recession. Mr. Greenspan urged Congress not to raise taxes to pay for the war, even though that would increase the budget deficit.
The second difference is that when the fighting began in Vietnam, the military's supply of planes, tanks, ships and weapons was deemed inadequate, and a rapid expansion of Pentagon spending ensued. Now, because of the military buildup in the 1980's and the end of the cold war, the war in the Persian Gulf can be fought largely with stockpiled weapons and equipment.
Each of the Navy's Tomahawk cruise missiles, for example, costs $1 million to produce. But if new missiles are not produced to replace the ones that are shot in the war, there is no budget cost and thus no cost to the economy.
Economists acknowledge that borrowing the money to finance the war would substantially raise the budget deficit, which already will be above $300 billion this year. The war costs could easily wipe out the nearly $40 billion in deficit reduction for the fiscal year 1991 that President Bush and Congress so laboriously negotiated in the fall. That would lead to somewhat higher interest rates, less saving and investment and some long-term harm to the economy, they say.
 
Uncertainty Is Cited
 But most economists in and out of the Government agree that to raise taxes now when the country is in a recession and when no one has the foggiest idea how much money will be needed would be foolhardy.
"This is a one-time emergency expenditure," a Bush Administration economist said in an interview. "It's like an investment, like a city issuing a bond to pay for a sewer system, and it makes more sense to deficit finance than to tax finance."
Charles L. Schultze, who was budget director in the Johnson Administration and who is now a senior fellow in economics at the Brookings Institution, said he agreed that taxes should not be raised while the economy is in recession and that taxes might not need to go up at all if the war turns out to be a short one. But he said, "If as we learn more, the costs seem to be at the higher end of what seems probable, once we're in recovery we probably ought to put on a temporary tax to recover the loss."
But some politicians are uneasy with the idea of going further into debt to pay for the war. "We face a choice of whether we are going to face up to this thing and do it on a 'pay as you go' basis or let it slide by and let our grandchildren pay for it," said Senator Paul Simon, an Illinois Democrat.
The lawmakers have been frustrated by the Bush Administration's reluctance to address the matter fully and publicly. Charles H. Bowsher, the Comptroller General and the Government's top auditor, told Congress that the Pentagon's accounting systems were so weak that it was impossible to measure the costs with any precision. Indeed, the budget President Bush will send to Congress early next month will have what budget writers call a "place-holder," a number picked out of the blue with a notation that the actual amount cannot be estimated.
 
Sharing the Burden
 What the politicians want, of course, is for more of the burden to be borne by the allies, particularly Japan and Germany, which have strong economies, rely on Middle Eastern oil and do not have any troops in the gulf region.
Japan promised $4 billion last year but has only paid about $600 million so far. After days of behind-the-scenes wrangling, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu announced today that Japan would give another $9 billion this year. But the contribution must be approved by Parliament, and Mr. Kaifu faces strong opposition on the issue.
Germany pledged about $3 billion last year, but actually contributed about a tenth of that. Chancellor Helmut Kohl, despite strong antiwar sentiment among Germans, has promised an additional, unspecific amount this year. Mr. Kohl said he would probably have to raise the money with a tax increase. Analysts said the Chancellor was simply using the war as an excuse for higher taxes that were necessary in Germany for other reasons, principally to pay the high costs of the unification of West and East Germany. In any case, getting the allies to contribute a larger share may be easier said than done.
"What do we have to do to force the Germans and the Japanese and others to pay more?" Senator Timothy E. Wirth, a Colorado Democrat, asked a panel of economists at a hearing this week. "How do we do it? What kind of leverage do we have?"
The economists had no ready answer.

HEADLINE: Microsystems' Results Soar

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Buoyed by strong demand for its newest work stations, Sun Microsystems Inc. today reported record revenues and earnings for its second quarter. The company said internal cost controls helped increase its profitability.
For the quarter ended Dec. 28, Sun had earnings of $39.1 million, or 39 cents a share, nearly 94 percent above the $20.2 million, or 23 cents a share, it reported in the comparable period a year earlier. Revenues rose nearly 27 percent, to $753.5 million, from $595.4 million in the second quarter of the 1990 fiscal year.
About half of Sun's revenues were derived from outside the United States. The strength of foreign currencies relative to the dollar benefited revenues and earnings.
"Our momentum in the marketplace has helped us overcome the economic and product uncertainty of the last several quarters," Scott McNealy, Sun's chairman, president and chief executive, said in a statement.
He said that while overall economic conditions could suppress demand, Sun is confident about the remaining quarters of 1991.
The company's shares rose 62.5 cents today, to $27.875, in over-the-counter trading before the results were announced. Sun's trading volume of almost 2.1 million shares was the seventh highest of the day.

HEADLINE: Disney Profits Drop 2% for Quarter

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BURBANK, Calif., Jan. 24

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company's profits dropped 2 percent in the final three months of 1990, the first quarterly decrease in six years, as the recession and Persian Gulf worries hurt theme park attendance, Disney said.
Disney said today that domestic tourism was so soft that revenues from its booming film entertainment division exceeded those from theme parks and resorts for the first time.
In the quarter ending Dec. 31, the first quarter in Disney's fiscal year, the company earned $170.4million, compared with $174.4 million in the corresponding period a year earlier.
Revenues, pumped up by the film entertainment and consumer products divisions, rose 16 percent, from $1.29 billion to $1.49 billion. Earnings on a per-share basis rose from $1.26 to $1.28 as Disney bought back stock. Disney's stock closed today at $99.50, down $1.625 in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Film entertainment revenues surged 28 percent, to $646 million, and operating profits rose 19 percent, to $92 million, Disney said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Revises New York Census: City Is Growing, Not Shrinking

BYLINE: By EDWARD B. FISKE

 BODY:
The United States Census Bureau revised its 1990 count of New York City's population yesterday, adding 289,385 people to its August count and providing the city with a net gain since 1980.
The new figure, 7,322,564, was about 300,000 people short of the population estimate by city officials, but it represented an important statistical gain that left New York as one of the few older urban areas to experience such growth. The previous figure, released in August, left the city with a population of 7,033,179, a slight decline from 1980. 
 The increase failed to silence a fierce debate between the Census Bureau and city officials over the correct count. Mayor David N. Dinkins continued to insist that the numbers were incorrect.
 
'Report Falls Short'
 "After much prodding, we are pleased that the bureau no longer is headed in the wrong direction, is no longer statistically shrinking a city which actually is growing," the Mayor said. "But even today's bureau report falls short -- far short -- of the number of people who live in New York City."
The Census Bureau reported that all three states in the metropolitan area gained in population during the 1980's, though at a far slower pace than the national average of 10 percent.
The biggest gainer proportionally was Connecticut, whose population grew to 3,287,116, up by 5.8 percent from 3,107,564. The number of New Jersey residents increased to 7,730,188, up 5 percent from 7,365,011. The population of New York State rose to 17,990,455, up 2.5 percent from 17,558,165 in 1980.
The figures released yesterday were part of the second of three rounds of reports from the 1990 census. They would normally be considered final, but this year's results are subject to a Federal court ruling on a lawsuit filed by New York, Chicago and other urban areas seeking to force the bureau to adjust its figures.
In adding to the August figures for New York City, the Census Bureau again acknowledged that its earlier figure was incomplete. Since August the census officials have recanvassed neighborhoods where initial counts looked suspiciously low and have obtained from state correction officials lists of parolees and probationers who might have been missed during the initial counting.
The population of New York City increased by 3.5 percent over the last decade, in part because Manhattan enjoyed its first big jump in residents since before World War I, the Census Bureau reported yesterday.
 
Reversal of Loss
 The new population figure of 7,322,564 is up from 7,071,639 in 1980 and reverses the loss of more than 800,000 people during the previous decade. All five boroughs showed population increases of at least 3 percent, with Staten Island, the least densely populated, having the largest gain, 7.7 percent.
The figures released yesterday were 4 percent higher than those in preliminary data released in August, when the final phases of the 1990 count were still under way. At the time the bureau put the city's population at 7,033,179, but indicated that more people would be added before the count was complete.
New York City's turnaround in the 1980's contrasted sharply with the continuing decline in the state's other large cities. Albany was essentially stable, but Buffalo, Rochester, Syracuse and Yonkers all showed falloffs in population.
 
Big Drop in Newark
 Among New Jersey cities, Newark's population plummeted by 16.4 percent -- from 329,248 in 1980 to 275,221 in 1990 -- but Elizabeth, Jersey City, Paterson and Camden all registered modest gains.
Connecticut's largest city, Bridgeport, showed a drop of 0.6 percent -- from 142,546 in 1980 to 141,686 in 1990 -- but that state's other large cities -- Hartford, New Haven, Stamford and Waterbury -- showed gains.
Demographers attributed New York City's increase primarily to more births and new immigrants. Emmanuel Tobier, an economics professor at the Urban Research Center at New York University, noted that with the exception of "little blips" in the 1930's and 1940's, Manhattan had been declining steadily since a population peak in 1910 of 2,332,000. The borough's increase was fueled in part by a surge of jobs in fields like the financial services industry, experts said.
Mr. Tobier, who believes that the figures released yesterday underestimate the city's population by 200,000 to 300,000 people called the city's population growth "remarkable" because "it makes New York one of the few older big cities in the frostbelt or the rustbelt to show an increase."
 
Urban Decline Slows
 Other figures released yesterday by the Census Bureau showed that the rate of urban population decline in the country slowed during the last decade but did not stop.
Philadelphia, which lost 261,000 people in the 1970's, lost 103,000 more in the past decade, bringing its population to 1,586,000. In the 1980's, Pittsburgh lost 55,000 people, or 13 percent of its population, which now stands at 370,000. It had declined by 19 percent from 1970 to 1980.
This pattern was also evident in Ohio, where four of the five most populous cities -- Cleveland, Cincinnati, Akron and Toledo -- continued to show population declines. The state capital of Columbus, however, grew by 12 percent to 633,000 -- a gain that pushed it ahead of Cleveland as the state's most populous city. Cleveland's population, which declined by 12 percent, is now 505,000.
 
Detroit Tops a Million
 Detroit, which lost 175,000 people, or 14.6 percent of its population in the 1980's, barely nudged above one million with a population of 1,028,000. The city had fallen below one million in the August preliminary counts, creating fears that it would lose special taxing powers and other revenue benefits that Michigan law grants to cities whose population exceeds one million.
The Census Bureau also released data on the racial composition of New Jersey, showing that the percentage of the non-Hispanic white population of the state in 1990 was 79.3 percent, down from 83.2 percent in 1980. The largest increase was registered by Hispanic people, whose total rose from 491,883 in 1980 to 739,861, or 9.6 percent of New Jersey's population.
Such racial data is used in the redrawing of Congressional districts to prevent legislatures from diluting the impact of minority votes when creating districts.

HEADLINE: Sales of Cars and Light Trucks Down by 20.2%

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Sales of cars and light trucks made in the United States fell 20.2 percent in mid-January, as demand for vehicles remained sluggish.
Industry analysts cautioned that the market for vehicles could become volatile, as consumers are buffeted by sometimes contradictory economic signals and war-related developments. 
 The 10 auto makers with United States plants sold 123,994 cars between Jan. 11 and Jan. 20, a decline of 10.8 percent from the corresponding period last year, when sales were moderately strong. Sales of United States-made light trucks plunged 33.5 percent, as consumers shunned less fuel-efficient vehicles.
There were eight selling days in the period this year, and nine last year.
Cars sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.6 million, compared with 7.1 million in the period last year. The sales pace for the last 30 days was 6.9 million; for the last 60 days, it was 6.3 million.
Analysts said the mid-January results pointed to a deepening recession, suggesting that vehicle sales would stay soft.
 
Production Cuts Seen
 They added that buyer wariness caused by the war and economic uncertainty could could result in further production cuts during the first quarter at plants operated by the Big Three domestic auto makers. The car companies have already scheduled widespread temporary shutdowns because dealer orders have slipped.
Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry newsletter, said United States truck output for January was running 14 percent below schedule, while car assemblies were 7 percent behind planned output.
The General Motors Corporation said it will cut one of two work shifts at two car assembly plants later this year in Fairfax, Kan. and Van Nuys, Calif. At the G.M. plant in Fairfax, which makes the Pontiac Grand Prix model, 975 workers will be indefinitely idled. The G.M. plant in Van Nuys makes the Chevy Camaro and Pontiac Firebird, and 850 workers there will be indefinitely idled.
The Big Three domestic auto makers reported a 22 percent drop in overall sales of cars and light trucks. The Japanese companies with United States plants posted a collective sales gain of 1.1 percent in mid-January.
In cars alone, however, the so-called Japanese transplants suffered a 7 percent decline in sales of United States-produced cars, compared with a drop of 11.3 percent in sales of cars made by the Big Three.
The sales results include an estimate for the Chrysler Corporation, which since January has stopped reporting sales of its vehicles every 10 days. The estimates, provided by Ward's Automotive Reports, indicated Chrysler's sales of domestically produced cars fell 19.8 percent, to 14,400. Sales of Chrysler's mini-vans, Jeeps and pickup trucks plummeted 54.7 percent, to an estimated 12,930 vehicles in mid-January.
Last year, sales of Chrysler mini-vans were helped by large incentives.
G.M. sold 59,913 United States-made cars in mid-January, a decline of 3.3 percent. G.M.'s light-truck sales fell 25.3 percent, to 27,269 units.
The Ford Motor Company's domestic car sales were down 19.5 percent, to 33,173 units. The company's light-truck sales were off 30 percent, to 22,255.
The Toyota Motor Corporation posted a decline of 37.9 percent in sales of cars made at its plant in Georgetown, Ky., and the joint venture plant it operates with General Motors in Fremont, Calif. Toyota also reported that sales of imported cars in mid-January fell 23.4 percent, to 7,351 cars. Toyota's sales of imported light trucks were down 22.4 percent, to 4,561 units.
The Honda Motor Company's sales of United States-made cars were flat, at 6,490 units.
The Nissan Motor Company said it sold 2,178 domestically produced cars, up 44 percent from last year.
